('9', 0, 1, 2, 39) 1. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING
('9', 0, 2, 3, 65) [JOHANNESBURG, July 23, 1908]
('9', 0, 3, 4, 95) On the 23rd ultimo, all Indian business throughout the Transvaal ceased for the day, as a mark of respect towards the Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, Imam Abdul Kadir Bawazeer, and the other Indian leaders who had been sentenced to imprisonment with hard labour for hawking without licences, as a protest against the Transvaal Governments breach of faith.
('9', 0, 3, 5, 460) Indian hawkers and pedlars ceased their rounds, much to the discomfort of those European housewives who depend so entirely upon the services of these men.
('9', 0, 4, 6, 615) A large and enthusiastic meeting of over 1,500 persons 1 assembled in the precincts of the Hamidia Mosque, Fordsburg, and listened intently to the addresses delivered by Mr. Gandhi and other speakers.
('9', 0, 4, 7, 816) A few delegates from Reef towns attended though none were specially invited.
('9', 0, 4, 8, 893) Mr. Essop Ismail Mia presided.
('9', 0, 4, 9, 924) The following is the full text of Mr. Gandhis speech: I shall read to you telegrams that have been received from several parts of South Africa in reply to the request of the British Indian Association and the Hamidia Islamic Society that all our brothers throughout South Africa should close all Indian business stores as well as hawkingout of regard for the Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, who is also the Assistant Priest of this very Mosque under whose shadow we are standing this afternoon.
('9', 0, 4, 10, 1428) The response received has been most generous, and it shows how well the different portions of the Indian community in South Africa have been knit together.
('9', 0, 4, 11, 1584) I think we may congratulate and thank the Government upon having, perhaps unconsciously, assisted us in doing this wonderful thing.
('9', 0, 4, 12, 1716) I think that a new spirit has been infused into Indians throughout South Africa, and if that spirit continues, I think that we shall have to thank the Government for it.
('9', 0, 4, 13, 1886) Last January, when we embarked upon the passive resistance struggle in earnest, the ground had been prepared for close upon 16 months, but it was only in the month of January last that General Smuts and his co Ministers were able to test the reality of the feeling that underlay the whole Indian agitation against the Asiatic Act, which, rightly or wrongly, Indians considered constituted an attack on their self respect, their honour and their religion, but perhaps the finishing touch was not put upon the whole thing when the prisoners were suddenly discharged owing to
('9', 0, 5, 14, 2459) 1 The Transvaal Leader report mentions that some Chinese, too, were present in the gathering, the strength of which its correspondent estimated at 500.
('9', 1, 0, 1, 2611) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 1, 1, 2, 2651) the compromise.
('9', 1, 1, 3, 2667) That finishing touch, in my opinion, is being placed upon the whole thing on this occasion.
('9', 1, 1, 4, 2759) Evidently, General Smuts has been in formed by some enemies from out of our own camp that the agitation last year and during the month of January was mostly manufactured and that I was principally instrumental in keeping the fire up.
('9', 1, 1, 5, 2993) I think that General Smuts has now, by this time, come to understand that the agitation was not manufactured, that the movement was absolutely sincere and spontaneous, and, if I had any part in connection with the movement, the part that I played was that of a humble interpreter bet ween the Government and my own countrymen.
('9', 1, 1, 6, 3320) I was undoubtedly the first man to inform the community of what the Asiatic Act meant.
('9', 1, 1, 7, 3407) I was the first one undoubtedly to point out that it bristled with objections, religious, and on the score of the communitys Honour, but, having done that, I claim to have done everything that it was my duty to do.
('9', 1, 1, 8, 3622) It was the Indians themselves who recognized the importance of the obje ctions that I ventured to place before them, and they decided solemnly and sincerely not to accept the Act.
('9', 1, 1, 9, 3802) And here we are today in order to emphasize our objections, and we find also that one of the best men in South Africa among our own countrymen, the respected Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, has chosen to go to gaol rather than enjoy the liberty that he had received owing to his having received the volu ntary registration certificate.
('9', 1, 1, 10, 4147) He chose to suffer with his humbler coun trymen, the hawkers, and he felt that he himself would place himself in the same category and suffer imprisonment for the sake of the honour of India, for the sake of the hawkers themselves, whom the Government wanted to have in their grip; and we have assembled this afternoon to do honour to that beloved fellow countryman of ours, as also the others who have gone with him to share the miseries of a gaol life.
('9', 1, 1, 11, 4602) It is true that the imprisonment is to last only four daysbut is it only?
('9', 1, 1, 12, 4676) Indians, who have not been used to a gaol life, who have never been able to accommodate themselves to the hardships of life, to them even a days imprisonment is a great thing, and does not sentiment count for some thing in matters of this sort?
('9', 1, 1, 13, 4921) We and the European Colonists have known all along that Indians would rather pay large sums of money in fines than go to prison.
('9', 1, 1, 14, 5050) That feeling has been shared universally by the Indians in South Africa, and, yet, today we find the respected Cha irman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, we find other prominent Ind ians, willingly going to gaol, not because there is artificial agitation, but because they think sincerely that Indias honour is at stake, they feel that their self respect is going to be lost, if they do not stand up and give a proper fight, and that fight not a fight with any weapons but the cleanest.
('9', 1, 1, 15, 5536) The cleanest weapon that we have
('9', 2, 0, 1, 5569) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 3
('9', 2, 1, 2, 5608) discovered in self defence is the weapon of passive resistance, is the acceptance of a gaol life or whatever the Government may choose to impose upon us for a breach of its laws which we cannot, as human beings, accept.
('9', 2, 1, 3, 5828) The tele grams that the British Indian Association and the Hamidia Islamic Society have received are from Pretoria, Durban, Fortuna, Warmbaths, Volksrust, Ermelo, Potchefstroom, Zeerust, Klerksdorp, Standerton, Middelburg, Salisbury, Christiana, Rustenburg, Kimberley, Nylstroom, Roodepoort, Lichtenburg, Lydenburg, Vereeniging, Pietersburg, Ven tersdorp, Heidelberg, Cape Town and Springs.
('9', 2, 1, 4, 6219) I dare say there are more telegrams still lying at the office.
('9', 2, 1, 5, 6282) I shall venture to read a few of these telegrams.
('9', 2, 1, 6, 6332) The purport of all is sympathy and support to the cause of the British Indians, and decision to close all business throug hout these places.
('9', 2, 2, 7, 6473) [Mr. Gandhi then read the telegrams.] These telegrams show that the Indians are absolutely unanimous in the Transvaal, and the incarceration of the Chairman shows also that there is absolutely no difference of opinion between Mahomedans and Hindus, that all the different races of India who are in South Africa have met in a common cause and well have they met, seeing that the difficulties that surround one portion of the community surr ound all the other portions of that community.
('9', 2, 2, 8, 6959) Gentlemen, our own position is absolutely clear.
('9', 2, 2, 9, 7008) Our friends have advised us and told us that we should wait, that we should not take strong measures, and that we should not take any step that might be irrevocable.
('9', 2, 2, 10, 7174) I do not quite understand the meaning of this advice.
('9', 2, 2, 11, 7228) I do know this, that the ques tion of the burning of the registration certificates should not be defi nitely decided Until we know exactly the legislation that the Govern ment intend to pass.
('9', 2, 2, 12, 7420) That we have done.
('9', 2, 2, 13, 7439) Beyond that it is impossible for the Indian community to go.
('9', 2, 2, 14, 7500) The Government have put a barrier between those who have taken out voluntary registration certificates and those who are now coming into the country, and who are entitled to come in.
('9', 2, 2, 15, 7683) The Government ask them to submit to the law.
('9', 2, 2, 16, 7729) It is im possible for these men to do any such thing at all, especially when their rights have been safeguarded under the compromise.
('9', 2, 2, 17, 7863) What are these men to do?
('9', 2, 2, 18, 7889) Are they not to trade until they have received their registration certificates?
('9', 2, 2, 19, 7969) Are they to live upon the charity of their fellow countrymen?
('9', 2, 2, 20, 8031) I think that it is utterly impossible.
('9', 2, 2, 21, 8070) Then these men must honestly earn their livelihood, and the only advice that it was possible for the British Indian Association to give these men was to trade in spite of the refusal to issue licences on the part of the Lic ensing Officer.
('9', 2, 2, 22, 8310) 1 The hawkers and store keepers whose licences ended
('9', 2, 3, 23, 8363) 1 Vide Johannesburg Letter, Before 2 7 1908.
('9', 3, 0, 1, 8408) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 3, 1, 2, 8448) on the 30th day of June are also in a similar plight.
('9', 3, 1, 3, 8502) They are now called upon by the Government to submit to the Asiatic Act so far as licences are concerned, before licences can be issued to them.
('9', 3, 1, 4, 8647) Are they then to sit still?
('9', 3, 1, 5, 8675) Are they not to trade until it pleases the Govern ment to bring forward their legislation?
('9', 3, 1, 6, 8766) It is not we who are waiting, or who can afford to wait.
('9', 3, 1, 7, 8823) It is utterly impossible for us to take up any such position.
('9', 3, 1, 8, 8885) We are taking no irrevocable step, but we are taking every step that we must take in self defence.
('9', 3, 1, 9, 8984) If we are to live in this country as honest citizens, if we are to earn our livelihood honestly, then it is absolutely necessary that we carry on our usual occupations, and for these occupations are required licences, and, if the Govern ment will not issue these licences, it is necessary for us to trade without them.
('9', 3, 1, 10, 9303) Some hawkers have already taken out licences.
('9', 3, 1, 11, 9349) I understand that 300 have had licences issued to them without submission to the Asiatic Act.
('9', 3, 1, 12, 9443) Four hundred have taken out licences by giving thumb impressions.
('9', 3, 1, 13, 9509) They did not know what they were doing.
('9', 3, 1, 14, 9549) They did not know that they were submitting to the Asiatic Act by giving thumb impressions.
('9', 3, 1, 15, 9641) The balance have now come to know what the Govern ment intend to do.
('9', 3, 1, 16, 9710) Are they, again I ask, to sit still and not carry on their occupation?
('9', 3, 1, 17, 9781) It is utterly impossible.
('9', 3, 1, 18, 9807) It might be asked why should prominent Indians go and take up hawking and force matters.
('9', 3, 1, 19, 9896) The answer is obvious and very simpleit is not possible for these men to sit still and remain in their homes, when they see poor hawkers, who perhaps do not understand the position just as well as the leaders do, suffering.
('9', 3, 1, 20, 10120) I think that the leaders would have failed in their duty if they had not come forward and taken up hawking for themselves, in order that they might be able to direct their poorer countrymen, in order that they might be able to explain the real position to their poorer countrymen.
('9', 3, 1, 21, 10401) I understand that, this afternoon, Superintendent Vernon and a detective went amongst some of the Tamil members of the Indian community.
('9', 3, 1, 22, 10538) He asked these men to produce their registration certifi cates, and I understand also that there was hard swearing indulged in by one or other of the officials.
('9', 3, 1, 23, 10699) I understand that it was Superinten dent Vernon who used an expression unbecoming for me even to repeat.
('9', 3, 1, 24, 10804) I will not repeat that expression.
('9', 3, 1, 25, 10839) I do say this that, if my coun trymen have the courage of their convictions, not a single Indian will show his voluntary registration certificate.
('9', 3, 1, 26, 10986) The British Indian Associa tion has called in all these registration certificates, in order that the poorer, the humbler, members of the community might be protected, and if they have to go to gaol for non production of registration certificates, I do hope that they will go to gaol, and thus teach a lesson in civility to the police.
('9', 3, 1, 27, 11321) I shall never forget the scene that was enacted
('9', 4, 0, 1, 11369) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 5
('9', 4, 1, 2, 11408) before the Court House when Mr. Sorabji was sentenced to be impri soned with hard labour for one month.
('9', 4, 1, 3, 11512) I cannot easily forget the hus tling that took place, the assaults that took place in front of the Court House, under the nose of the Magistrate as it were.
('9', 4, 1, 4, 11669) 1 I cannot easily forget how the constables, without the slightest provocation, without any warning being given to the British Indians, assaulted them, how they roughly handled them, and how they roughly shoved them from the verandah of the Court House.
('9', 4, 1, 5, 11923) That shows what a bitter struggle is before us.
('9', 4, 1, 6, 11971) That shows also how cheaply we are held in the estimation of the police, if not in the estimation of the citizens of the Transvaal and of South Africa.
('9', 4, 1, 7, 12123) It is necessary then for British Indians to show in quiet, in dignity, in perfect calmness, in a perfectly law abiding spirit, to show that they are not here to suffer such indignities, that they are not here to have their liberties trampled underfoot, and that if all these things are done in the name of His Majesty the King Emperor, we are here also humbly to protest, and we are here also as British citizens to suffer for it, and to show the whole world what things are possible and done even in the British Empire, even under the British flag.
('9', 4, 1, 8, 12673) We have been nurtured in British traditions.
('9', 4, 1, 9, 12718) We have been told that [in the British Empire] even a lamb is free.
('9', 4, 1, 10, 12786) The lamb can go with the lion, is a literal translation of a verse I was taught when I was a youth, when I was of school going age.
('9', 4, 1, 11, 12918) That verse has not yet been effaced from my memory.
('9', 4, 1, 12, 12970) I do say here such a thing is not possible, that British Indians, because they are docile, because they are humble, because they do not want to tread upon anybody elses corns, are being spat upon, are being ill treated, and now we have got the Asiatic Ordinance to fight, which is intended to take away the very last vestige of self respect from us.
('9', 4, 1, 13, 13320) It is because we feel these things that we have met here to honour our countrymen who have gone to gaol, that those who are here may also have that courage, may also have sufficient self respect in them to go to gaol, to suffer the same hardships, and if you do that, as surely as I am standing here today, a day will come when we shall regain our liberty, when we shall regain the full rights attached to British citizenship, when we will be respected even in theTransvaal as men, as human beings, and will not be treated as dogs.
('9', 4, 2, 14, 13852) Indian Opinion, 1 8 1908

('9', 5, 1, 2, 14133) 2. LETTER TO INDIAN OPINION 1
('9', 5, 2, 3, 14163) JOHANNESBURG, July 24, 1908 THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('9', 5, 3, 4, 14217) SIR, I wish to draw public attention to the case of R. Lalloo v.
('9', 5, 3, 5, 14282) Rex, reported in the Press.
('9', 5, 3, 6, 14310) 2 The case, which, fortunately, has been now considered by the Supreme Court, shows most clearly that the Immigrants Restriction Act does not prohibit the entry of those Asiatics who can comply with the education test.
('9', 5, 3, 7, 14529) The summons issued against Lalloo charged him with contravening Section 25 of the Immigrants Restriction Act, in that he, being unable to write in European characters, having insufficient means to support himself, and being the minor child of a prohibited immigrant, was himself a prohibited immigrant.
('9', 5, 3, 8, 14832) Had he, then, been able to satisfy the education test, assuming that he had sufficient means to support himself, he would not have been prevented from entering the country.
('9', 5, 3, 9, 15005) Sir William Solomon, in giving judgment, said:
('9', 5, 4, 10, 15052) His (Sergeant Mansfields) evidence was that the prisoner could not write any document in a European language, and there was no denial of it.
('9', 5, 4, 11, 15193) Ser geant Mansfield could only have obtained the information either by asking the accused to write or the accused telling him that he could not write, in which case, it would have been a farce to call upon him to write a document in Eng lish characters.
('9', 5, 4, 12, 15447) It will, therefore, be seen that, according to the learned Judge, the Immigrants Restriction Act does not debar Asiatics possessing educational qualifications from entering the country.
('9', 5, 4, 13, 15633) In the light of this judgment, the British Indian contention is absolutely upheld and strengthened by the incarceration of Mr. Sorabji, who lawfully entered under the Immigrants Restriction Act, but became a criminal because he would not submit to the Asiatic Act.
('9', 5, 4, 14, 15898) There is, therefore, nothing new in the claim brought forward by the British Indian community in insisting on the retention of the right of entry on the part of educated Asiatics under the Immigrants Res

('9', 5, 5, 16, 16166) 2 Vide Johannesburg Letter, 1 8 1908.
('9', 6, 0, 1, 16204) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 7
('9', 6, 1, 2, 16243) triction Act.
('9', 6, 1, 3, 16257) It is General Smuts who demands from British Indians their consent to an abrogation of that right, which Indians are in hon our bound to resist.
('9', 6, 1, 4, 16402) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 1 8 1908
('9', 6, 2, 5, 16452) 3. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 1
('9', 6, 3, 6, 16487) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 24, 1908 [THE DIRECTOR OF PRISONS PRETORIA
('9', 6, 4, 7, 16551) SIR,] Eight British Indian prisoners, who were imprisoned for haw king without licences, were discharged today, and they have reported to my Association that, at the Johannesburg Gaol, for the morning meal, they were offered mealie pap, which they did not take at all, never having been accustomed to it.
('9', 6, 4, 8, 16856) Consequently, they had to be satisfied with only rice at noon, and beans, if beans were available, for supper.
('9', 6, 4, 9, 16967) These men were hard labour prisoners.
('9', 6, 4, 10, 17005) My Association begs to draw your attention to the fact that Bri tish Indians, as a body, are not used to mealie pap at all, and it is most difficult for them all of a sudden to take to that diet.
('9', 6, 4, 11, 17201) In view of many more Indians suffering imprisonment in connection with the Asiatic struggle, I think it is but right for my Association to ask you to change the diet scale for British Indians.
('9', 6, 4, 12, 17394) My Association does not ask for any favours, but simply for a substitute which will be in keeping with the habits of British Indians.
('9', 6, 4, 13, 17528) As the matter is rather urgent, my Association will be obliged if you will be good enough to give it immediate attention.
('9', 6, 4, 14, 17650) [ESSOP MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION] Indian Opinion, 1 8 1908
('9', 6, 5, 15, 17724) Also Colonial Office Records: 291/132
('9', 6, 6, 16, 17762) 1 This was presumably drafted by Gandhiji.
('9', 7, 0, 1, 17805) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 7, 1, 2, 17845) 4. SORABJI SHAPURJI OF ADAJAN
('9', 7, 2, 3, 17875) Mr. Sorabji Shapurji AdaJania has been sentenced to a months hard labour.
('9', 7, 2, 4, 17949) 1 We take this to be the conferment of an honour on him.
('9', 7, 2, 5, 18006) A time is coming when, to ascertain the number of titles a man holds, we shall have to inquire of him how often he has been to gaol.
('9', 7, 2, 6, 18139) Sorabjis case is different from those of the others and such as brings him greater credit.
('9', 7, 2, 7, 18230) Other Indians went to gaol in defence of their own rights as well as those of others.
('9', 7, 2, 8, 18316) They were all, however, residents of the Transvaal.
('9', 7, 2, 9, 18368) Sorabji is not domiciled in the Colony.
('9', 7, 2, 10, 18408) He did not have to defend any rights of his own.
('9', 7, 2, 11, 18457) Sorabji has gone to gaol exclusively for his countrys sake, and in defence of educated Indians [rights].
('9', 7, 2, 12, 18562) Other Indians were not awarded hard labour, but Sorabji has been.
('9', 7, 2, 13, 18628) He and his family deserve to be complimented on all this.
('9', 7, 2, 14, 18686) But the best compliment Indians can pay Sorabji will be to remain very firm, to achieve the objective which he has sought to serve by going to gaol, and to follow him there.
('9', 7, 2, 15, 18860) That would be the right way of congratu lating him.
('9', 7, 2, 16, 18912) We will not commiserate with him or his family.
('9', 7, 2, 17, 18960) Imprisonment is our destiny.
('9', 7, 2, 18, 18989) It contains the seeds of our freedom, so that there is no call to console those who are gaoled.
('9', 7, 2, 19, 19085) The hardships of gaol must be looked upon as comforts.
('9', 7, 2, 20, 19140) Only when we are inspired with such courage and such ideals shall we be able to fulfil our tasks.
('9', 7, 2, 21, 19238) We print a photograph of Sorabji in this issue.
('9', 7, 2, 22, 19286) Everyone will admire his courage.
('9', 7, 2, 23, 19320) Few indeed are the heroes who join the fray from no Other motive than the [pleasure of] battle.
('9', 7, 2, 24, 19416) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 25 7 1908

('9', 8, 2, 8, 20429) 6. LETTER TO J. J. DOKE
('9', 8, 3, 9, 20453) [JOHANNESBURG]
('9', 8, 4, 10, 20468) DEAR MR. DOKE, The questions 2 you have asked me are very pertinent and very seasonable.
('9', 8, 4, 11, 20557) If only the public can be induced to take sufficient inte rest in the Asiatic question to understand what it is that we want, half the difficulty will be over.
('9', 8, 4, 12, 20717) Speaking from a British Indian standpoint, British Indians have long since accepted the position that Asiatic immigration should be severely restricted; but, if the Colonists demand that even the most highly educated Indians shall not enter the Colony, they require not only the severe restriction of immigration, but total prohibition.
('9', 8, 4, 13, 21054) What British Indians have offered is, in effect, equivalent to total prohibi tion, and yet it is not quite that.
('9', 8, 4, 14, 21167) Underlying the total prohibition is the desire, I understand, that trade competition on the part of British Ind ians should be confined only to those who are domiciled in the Colo ny.
('9', 8, 4, 15, 21351) If that be so, the desire is entirely met by confining the entry of educated Asiatics only to those possessing education of a very high order; in other words, in practice it may be limited to professional men.
('9', 8, 4, 16, 21561) I need hardly point out that a free and healthy Asiatic commu 
('9', 8, 5, 17, 21624) 1 Wylie, K.C.; lawyer and legislator; was part author of the Dealers Licenses Act; took notable part in suppressing the Zulu rebellion in Natal; as leading counsel in Gogas case (Indians in Potchefstroom, 28 1 1905), he argued that even an Indian is entitled to justice and fair play.
('9', 8, 5, 18, 21909) 2 In his letter Rev.
('9', 8, 5, 19, 21930) Joseph Doke had asked three questions: (I) .
('9', 8, 5, 20, 21975) [most Colonists] are afraid that, should the Immigration Restriction Law be applied to Asiatics, .
('9', 8, 5, 21, 22074) a number of educated men might still be admitted .
('9', 8, 5, 22, 22125) is there any way in which you can meet this objection[?] (2) Is it true that your chief objection is .
('9', 8, 5, 23, 22228) that by claiming your consent to the closed door before repealing the Asiatic Law Amendment Act [General Smuts] [I] is asking you to be a party to the absolute exclusion of your educated brethren [?] (3) .
('9', 8, 5, 24, 22434) would it not be easy for Government to introduce legislation .
('9', 8, 5, 25, 22497) to close the door absolutely?
('9', 8, 5, 26, 22527) If so, what action would be taken by the Asiatics?
('9', 9, 0, 1, 22578) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 9, 1, 2, 22619) nity in the Transvaal would be impossible without, say, a few lawyers, a few doctors, a few teachers, and, it may be, a few preachers amongst them who are their own kith and kin.
('9', 9, 1, 3, 22798) These should not come to the country on sufferance, but as a matter of right.
('9', 9, 1, 4, 22876) These can never enter into competition with the Europeans; but, assuming that they would be men of the right stamp, they can promote the progressive growth of the Indian community in the Transvaal, and can only be of very great assistance to it, and, indeed, to the Colonists.
('9', 9, 1, 5, 23153) The only reasonable way in which this can be done is by leaving the immigration law as it is, without making the principle of the Asiatic Act applicable to such cases, for the simple reason that no identification can be necessary for men of education.
('9', 9, 1, 6, 23405) To ask us to consent to an alteration of the law so as to bring about absolute exclusion of educated Indians is not only an additional objection, but, in my opinion, an insuperable one.
('9', 9, 1, 7, 23591) Of course, the Parliament of the Colony can at any time bring forward prohibitory legislation independent of our consent.
('9', 9, 1, 8, 23713) I should person ally strain every nerve to oppose absolute prohibition, and should ask my countrymen to offer passive resistance to such law.
('9', 9, 1, 9, 23855) Whether I would be able to carry them with me or not in such a case, it is diffi cult for me to judge at present, and passive resistance in connection with any such legislation can only mean that Indians would far rather leave the country than live in it deprived of the natural assistance of educated men such as I have described above.
('9', 9, 1, 10, 24193) Passive resistance, in my opinion, means self imposed suffering of an acute type, intended to prove the justice of the cause, and thus to bring conviction home to the minds of the Colonists.
('9', 9, 1, 11, 24384) I hope that I have made the position clear.
('9', 9, 3, 12, 24428) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 25 7 1908

('9', 11, 2, 8, 27541) 9. LETTER TO A. CARTWRIGHT
('9', 11, 3, 9, 27568) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 27, 1908
('9', 11, 4, 10, 27598) DEAR MR. CARTWRIGHT, Mr. Hosken very kindly showed me the Asiatic Voluntary Registration Bill that General Smuts intends to bring in.
('9', 11, 4, 11, 27732) I need hardly say that it will never be accepted by the Indian community, if I know its temper well.
('9', 11, 4, 12, 27833) It indirectly puts voluntary registrants in the same category as those who have accepted the Act.
('9', 11, 4, 13, 27931) I draw your attention to the fact that it takes no note of pre war refugees, whether holding []3 Dutch registration certificates or not.
('9', 11, 4, 14, 28068) It rejects even the claims of those who hold Peace Preservation Ordinance permits and have thus a right to demand entry, and makes them liable to take out registration under the Asiatic Act.
('9', 11, 4, 15, 28259) The Bill is, to my mind, a wanton insult to the intelligence of the Asiatics, whom it evidently assumes to be a lot of children who can be pleased by a little bit of gilding on the pill.
('9', 11, 4, 16, 28446) I know that the Progressive Party has appointed a committee to consider this Bill, and then to confer with General Smuts.
('9', 11, 4, 17, 28568) This party, therefore, evidently holds the trump cards.
('9', 11, 4, 18, 28624) Will it play them in keeping with the title it has arrogated to itself, or will it throw British Indians overboard?
('9', 11, 4, 19, 28740) Although Sir Percy Fitzpatrick, Mr. Chaplin, and Mr. Lindsay, as you are aware, at the meeting at which you were present, admitted the justice of the contention that those who re entered after the late compromise and had the right to do so should be treated the same as those who were in the Transvaal on that date, and that the rights of pre war residents should be recognized.
('9', 11, 4, 20, 29119) Now the Bill before me overrides all these things.
('9', 11, 4, 21, 29170) It is a very subtle Bill, but it is also, I hope you will allow me to use the term, a fraudulent Bill.
('9', 11, 4, 22, 29273) It will enable General, smuts to say that he does not take away the rights which he contends 1 are reserved by the Asiatic Act.
('9', 11, 4, 23, 29401) Here lies the fraud
('9', 11, 5, 24, 29421) 1 The source has have contende.
('9', 12, 0, 1, 29453) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 13
('9', 12, 1, 2, 29493) because he knows too well that Asiatics do not wish to receive any benefits under that Act.
('9', 12, 1, 3, 29585) I am sending you a copy of a communication 1 which I am addressing to the chief members of the Progressive Party.
('9', 12, 1, 4, 29699) I am, Yours truly, ALBERT CARTWRIGHT, ESQ.

('9', 12, 7, 14, 30301) 11. TRIAL OF RAMASWAMY AND OTHERS
('9', 12, 8, 15, 30335) [JOHANNESBURG, July 27, 1908]
('9', 12, 9, 16, 30365) In D court yesterday [July 27], Mr. P. C. Dalmahoy disposed of another batch of cases in which Indians were charged with hawking without licences.
('9', 12, 9, 17, 30512) Mr. Cramer prosecuted, Mr. Gandhi appearing for the defence.
('9', 12, 10, 18, 30573) The first case to be taken was that of an Indian named Ramaswamy.
('9', 12, 11, 19, 30639) After formal evidence had been given for the prosecution, Mr. Gandhi called Mr. L. H. Jefferson, Chief Licence Inspector to the Johannesburg Municipality.
('9', 12, 11, 20, 30794) MR. GANDHI: You have received a list of exemptions?
('9', 12, 12, 21, 30846) [JEFFERSON:] Fourteen.
('9', 12, 13, 22, 30869) MR. GANDHI: Will you produce that list?
('9', 12, 14, 23, 30909) The Magistrate and the Public Prosecutor both interposed and objected to its production.
('9', 12, 15, 24, 30998) MR. CRAMER: I have no objection to Mr. Gandhi asking if the accuseds name

('9', 13, 1, 2, 31259) is on the list.
('9', 13, 2, 3, 31275) MR. JEFFERSON: It is not on the list.
('9', 13, 3, 4, 31313) MR. GANDHI: Does this mean that I cannot see the document?
('9', 13, 4, 5, 31372) THE MAGISSTRATE (to Mr. Jefferson): Are you permitted to show the document?
('9', 13, 5, 6, 31448) [JEFFERSON:] No, Sir.

('9', 13, 7, 9, 31560) THE MAGISSTRATE: (interrupting) I m not going to allow it, Mr. Gandhi; that is final.

('9', 13, 13, 16, 32147) Mr. Gandhi further asked whether the witness had been prevented by the authorities from giving the list.
('9', 13, 14, 17, 32252) THE WITNESS: I have been told not to publish the list.
('9', 13, 14, 18, 32307) These are my general instructions.
('9', 13, 15, 19, 32342) Addressing the Court, Mr. Gandhi said that he held it was a most curious position that here they had a list which applied to the whole community, and which could not be produced.
('9', 13, 15, 20, 32521) He thought it very remarkable that they were not allowed to see it.
('9', 13, 15, 21, 32589) He had to subpoena Mr. Jefferson at the expense of his clients in every case, to ascertain if their names appeared on the document.
('9', 13, 15, 22, 32721) He thought it within the jurisdiction of the Court to say whether Mr. Jefferson should produce the document.
('9', 13, 16, 23, 32830) THE MAGISSTRATE: (to the accused) You have had plenty of warning to get a licence, and you will not do it.
('9', 13, 16, 24, 32937) You are fined 1 or seven days imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 13, 17, 25, 32998) OTHER CASES
('9', 13, 18, 26, 33010) Another Indian hawker was then charged with a similar offence, and Mr. Gandhi put Mr. Jefferson in the box and made another unsuccessful endeavour to have the list put in.
('9', 13, 18, 27, 33182) He asked that the Magistrate would note his request that the list should be produced.
('9', 13, 19, 28, 33268) The accused was fined 1 or seven days imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 13, 20, 29, 33337) A third hawker was then placed in the dock, and Mr. Gandhi again called Mr. Jefferson.

('9', 14, 3, 4, 33725) Mr. Gandhi said that, even if Mr. Jefferson was called by the Crown, it would still be very unfair to his clients, as the names of Asiatics were very frequently mixed up.

('9', 14, 6, 9, 34201) 12. TRIAL OF HARILAL GANDHI AND OTHERS
('9', 14, 7, 10, 34240) [JOHANNESBURG, July 28, 1908]
('9', 14, 8, 11, 34270) Six more Indian hawkers 1 appeared in D Court before Mr. P. C. Dalmahoy yesterday [July 28], charged with hawking without licences.
('9', 14, 8, 12, 34402) These included Thambi Naidoo, who went to prison in January last with Mr. Gandhi, and who was sentenced to four days imprisonment on Tuesday of last week for hawking without a licence, and Harilal Gandhi, eldest son of Mr. M. K. Gandhi, who was arrested some days ago at Volksrust [for failing to register] and warned to appear at Pretoria to apply for a registration certificate.
('9', 14, 8, 13, 34783) 2 Young Gandhi came to Johannesburg, and immediately commenced hawking fruit, when he was arrested.
('9', 14, 9, 14, 34883) Mr. Cramer prosecuted, Mr. Gandhi appearing for the defence.
('9', 14, 10, 15, 34944) The first to be charged was an Indian named Hera Mariji.
('9', 14, 11, 16, 35001) Formal evidence as to accuseds having been hawking within the municipality without a licence was given, and the accused, who pleaded guilty, was fined 1, with the alternative of seven days imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 14, 11, 17, 35221) The next to be placed in the dock were Harilal Mohandas Gandhi (son of Mr. M. K. Gandhi), Thambi Naidoo and Govindasamy Kistnasamy, who were all described as Indian hawkers.
('9', 14, 11, 18, 35395) They pleaded guilty.
('9', 14, 12, 19, 35416) A sergeant of police gave evidence that he had arrested the accused, who were hawking fruit in Bellevue East without licence.
('9', 14, 13, 20, 35542) 1 Naidoo, Harilal Gandhi, Hera Mariji, (Mawji in Indian Opinion) Kistnasamy, Pillay and Naiker.
('9', 14, 13, 21, 35638) Indian Opinion also mentions one Charlie Singli who was similarly charged and sentenced.
('9', 14, 13, 22, 35727) 2 The Transvaal Leader, 28 7 1908, mentions that Gandhiji had written to the Registrar of Asiatics that his son did not intend to apply for a registration certificate at Pretoria.
('9', 14, 13, 23, 35907) This letter, however, is not available.

('9', 15, 1, 2, 35988) Mr. Gandhi said he did not propose to call witnesses, but wished to make a few remarks.
('9', 15, 1, 3, 36076) He hadbeen weak enough on the previous day to protest against the increase of penalty 1, but in this instance he had a long conference with the prisoners at the gaol, and he had been requested to ask for the severest penalty.
('9', 15, 1, 4, 36302) The accused had acted as they had done with deliberation.
('9', 15, 1, 5, 36360) Naidoo had been in gaol last week, having been sentenced to four days imprisonment for hawking without a licence.
('9', 15, 2, 6, 36474) THE MAGISTRATE: There is a previous conviction against Naidoo.
('9', 15, 3, 7, 36537) MR. GANDHI: Two previous convictions under this Act; one for hawking without a licence.
('9', 15, 4, 8, 36625) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said that the two others had also asked him to ask for a severe sentence.
('9', 15, 4, 9, 36722) If a light sentence was imposed, as soon as they came out, they int ended to repeat the action.
('9', 15, 4, 10, 36818) It would be a saving of time to give them a long sentence, and it would be better for the sake of their health if they had a sustained term.
('9', 15, 5, 11, 36959) Naidoo was fined 2, with the alternative of 14 days imprisonment with hard labour, and Gandhi and Kistnasamy were fined l [each], or seven days imprison ment, with hard labour.
('9', 15, 6, 12, 37136) Two other British Indians, named Sinnappa Rangasamy Pillay and Soopa Veerasamy Naiker, were then charged.

('9', 16, 4, 12, 38748) 14. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('9', 16, 5, 13, 38772) RECEPTION FOR PRISONERS
('9', 16, 6, 14, 38796) Imam Abdool Kadir and other satyagrahis who had been sentenced to four days imprisonment have now been released; some were released on Friday and the others on Saturday 2. No one went to receive those released on Friday since people were under the impression that they were not being let off that day.
('9', 16, 6, 15, 39098) When people went to receive those who were being released on Saturday, they discovered that the satyagrahis had been released at 7 oclock though according to rules they should have been released only at nine.
('9', 16, 6, 16, 39307) This was done in order to forestall their reception by a procession.
('9', 16, 6, 17, 39376) But Mr. Coovadia 3, having set out early for the gaol, met and greeted the prisoners, and escorted them back towards the gaol.
('9', 16, 6, 18, 39503) Meanwhile, the other Indians arrived.
('9', 16, 6, 19, 39541) Those present included Mr. Essop Mia, Moulvi Mukhtiar Saheb, and Messrs Osman Ahmed Effendi, Kallenbach, Polak and Doke.
('9', 16, 6, 20, 39662) Imam Saheb and others were garlanded, and then they all proceeded to Mr. Essop Mias house where they were served tea and biscuits.
('9', 16, 6, 21, 39793) Many complimentary speeches were made.
('9', 16, 6, 22, 39832) In reply, Imam Saheb and the others said that four days imprisonment had meant no hardship whatsoever for them.
('9', 16, 6, 23, 39944) They were ready for a second, longer term of imprisonment.
('9', 16, 7, 24, 40003) BETTER RECEPTION ON SUNDAY

('9', 19, 2, 4, 44976) CONDITIONS IN PRISON
('9', 19, 3, 5, 44997) The conditions in gaol described by Imam Saheb and others deserve to be noted.
('9', 19, 3, 6, 45076) Every prisoner is given a pair of sandals and woollen socks.
('9', 19, 3, 7, 45137) Two woollen shirts and two of coarse cloth are also issued.
('9', 19, 3, 8, 45197) At night, one is given three blankets to cover oneself with, and a hard wooden bed with hessian spread on it, so that one does not feel cold.
('9', 19, 3, 9, 45339) Thrice a week, rice is served at lunch, and in the evening beans, potatoes and mealie pap.
('9', 19, 3, 10, 45430) Since Indians do not like mealie pap for breakfast every day, a petition 1 has been submitted to the Director of Prisons, and it is hoped that proper arrangements for food will be made in a few days.
('9', 19, 3, 11, 45630) One does not get shoes and socks immediately on arrival in prison, and the prisoners had to suffer the cold for a few hours, with the result that the Imam Saheb and others felt benumbed in the feet.
('9', 19, 3, 12, 45829) They were otherwise very comfortable.
('9', 19, 3, 13, 45867) The rice was coo ked by the prisoners themselves, and Mr. Naidoo attended to this.
('9', 19, 3, 14, 45950) The tasks assigned to the prisoners were not excessive.
('9', 19, 3, 15, 46006) The prisoner is req uired to carry loads of gravel from one place to another.
('9', 19, 3, 16, 46084) This being so, 2 people [outside] remain full of courage and are not worried by [the prospect of] imprisonment.
('9', 19, 3, 17, 46196) My own view is that it will be useful to accustom oneself to mealie pap.
('9', 19, 3, 18, 46269) It is not at all becoming of us to ask favours from one whom we consider an enemy.
('9', 19, 3, 19, 46352) However, as long as Indians are incapable of putting up with these privations, we will continue to voice our demands [to the prison authorities on their behalf].
('9', 19, 4, 20, 46514) SORABJIS CONDITION
('9', 19, 5, 21, 46533) Fellow prisoners reported that, during the first few days, Mr. Sorabji was feeling rather depressed.
('9', 19, 5, 22, 46634) After the others had joined him, however, he cheered up.
('9', 19, 5, 23, 46691) He is now in high spirits.
('9', 19, 5, 24, 46718) Mr. Sorabji has been assigned the task of sewing buttons on to shirts.
('9', 19, 5, 25, 46789) The Governor and the Chief Warder of the prison are very kind to the prisoners.

('9', 21, 0, 1, 49275) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 21, 1, 2, 49316) KRUGERSDORP INDIANS Newspapers here report that the Krugersdorp hawkers held a meeting in the Location, and passed a resolution to the effect that they would abide by whatever the Government decided.
('9', 21, 1, 3, 49516) It is a matter for regret that the community has such enemies.
('9', 21, 1, 4, 49579) From a letter Mr. Cursetji Desai has written to me, it appears that the number of Indians who profess this view is not very large; there are only three or four [of them].
('9', 21, 1, 5, 49750) I further hope that there are not many Indians elsewhere who show the same lack of understanding.
('9', 21, 2, 6, 49848) WHAT WILL HAPPEN NOW?
('9', 21, 2, 7, 49870) This question is difficult to answer.
('9', 21, 2, 8, 49908) Of one thing, however, we can be sure: the answer will depend on us.
('9', 21, 2, 9, 49977) If we are not strong, the struggle may be a prolonged one.
('9', 21, 2, 10, 50036) For the fact that it has been so long drawn out, we have ourselves to thank, for, in Johannesburg, a large number of Indians have taken out licences and the Government has already received their licence fees.
('9', 21, 2, 11, 50245) The fees have not, however, been paid by about a hundred persons; the Government may well forgo the money and do nothing about these persons for six months in the hope that the Indians will have cooled off by that time.
('9', 21, 2, 12, 50465) I, on the other hand, think that we shall have grown stronger.
('9', 21, 2, 13, 50528) If no one is arrested for [being without] licences, there will be no cause left for anxiety.
('9', 21, 2, 14, 50621) But be alone can take this view who is ever ready to resist tyranny and to defy the law.
('9', 21, 2, 15, 50710) If the Government behaves as suggested above, it may also be under the impression that refugees will not enter at all and that Permit holders outside [the Colony] now will submit to the obnoxious law after entering.
('9', 21, 2, 16, 50926) KEY The key, therefore, lies with us.
('9', 21, 2, 17, 50964) Hawkers and store keepers should do without licences.
('9', 21, 2, 18, 51018) If someone comes to inspect licences, they should refuse to Produce them.
('9', 21, 2, 19, 51092) If the Government introduces a Bill of which we do not approve, we should immediately proceed to burn up the certificates and licences, and those (1) who hold the Dutch passes in their own names, or (2) who can produce strong evidence to prove that they have been residents of the Transvaal from pre war times, [or] (3) who have received a good education in English should enter the Transvaal all at a time.
('9', 21, 2, 20, 51500) If 50 or 100 men enter in this manner, the Government will be obliged to send them to gaol.
('9', 21, 2, 21, 51592) We know, however, that it is difficult to send so many persons to gaol.
('9', 21, 2, 22, 51664) We will embark on this plan only after the Governments intentions are known for cer tain.
('9', 21, 2, 23, 51754) Meanwhile, educated Indians and others must wait patiently.
('9', 21, 2, 24, 51814) From this very instant, no Indian should give his thumb imp 
('9', 22, 0, 1, 51875) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 23
('9', 22, 1, 2, 51915) ression when entering the Transvaal.
('9', 22, 1, 3, 51952) All Indians should bluntly refuse to give them.
('9', 22, 1, 4, 52000) We should have the requisite courage; we may then take it that the law is as good as repealed.
('9', 22, 1, 5, 52095) Among those whose names I mentioned above, Mr. Ali Mian and Mr. Kanji Morar were licence holders, yet they refused to produce their licences and chose to go to gaol.
('9', 22, 1, 6, 52261) That is real courage.

('9', 24, 2, 6, 56753) 15. TRIAL OF DAYA LALA
('9', 24, 3, 7, 56776) [JOHANNESBURG, Monday Wednesday, July 27 29, 1908]
('9', 24, 4, 8, 56827) The much discussed Act 2 of 1907 also figured in B Court yesterday, this time, however, in a different class of criminal charge, and one having an intimate connection with the offending finger print clauses, when Daya Lala, an Indian, appeared before Mr. Jordan, charged with having entered the Colony by means of a forged certificate of registration.
('9', 24, 5, 9, 57179) Mr. Schuurman prosecuted, Mr. Gandhi appearing for the accused.
('9', 24, 6, 10, 57243) Superintendent J. G. Vernon gave evidence that he was authorized to inspect permits under Act 2 of 1907. He arrested the accused outside Mr. Gandhis office on July 2. Witness asked him to produce his registration certificate under Act 2 of 1907 and he replied that Mr. Gandhi had it.
('9', 24, 6, 11, 57527) Witness went into the office and saw Mr. McIntyre, an employee of Mr. Gandhi.
('9', 24, 6, 12, 57605) He told Mr. McIntyre what the accused had said, and asked to see the certificate.
('9', 24, 6, 13, 57687) Mr. McIntyre opened the safe, took out a certificate and showed it to witness.
('9', 24, 6, 14, 57766) Witness refused to take it, and said, Give it to the man to whom it belongs.
('9', 24, 6, 15, 57843) McIntyre handed the certificate to the accused, who handed it to witness.
('9', 24, 6, 16, 57917) He then saw the document was a forgery, and arrested the accused.
('9', 24, 6, 17, 57983) Witness took the accused in a cab to the latters house at 168, Market Street, and the house was searched, and a number of letters written in Hindustani were seized.
('9', 24, 6, 18, 58148) While being taken to the Charge Office, the accused said, I bought the paper (referring to the certificate) from Jaymal for 14. I paid 7 in Durban and 7 after I arrived here.
('9', 24, 6, 19, 58323) I gave the paper to Gandhi yesterday. The accused was then charged at Marshall Square.
('9', 24, 6, 20, 58410) The witness here put in a number of Government proclamations and notices dealing with Act 2 of 1907. Continuing, the witness stated that he visited Mr. Gandhis office continually between June 29 and July 2, and nothing was told him or other members of the police of a forged certificate.
('9', 24, 7, 21, 58698) MR. GANDHI: You will admit that it is a clear forgery?
('9', 25, 0, 1, 58753) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 25, 1, 2, 58794) [VERNON:] Yes; it is a fair forgery.
('9', 25, 1, 3, 58831) It would pass anyone who did not know
('9', 25, 2, 4, 58869) Mr. Chamneys signature.
('9', 25, 2, 5, 58893) Mr. Chamney, Registrar of Asiatics, said that he did not know the accused.
('9', 25, 2, 6, 58968) The signature on the registration certificate was not his, but was a forgery.
('9', 25, 2, 7, 59046) There was a slight difference in the printing, in the number, and in the size of the document as compared with the registration certificates issued by the Gov ernment.
('9', 25, 2, 8, 59214) Witness received no notification from Mr. Gandhi that the accused was in possession of a forged certificate.
('9', 25, 2, 9, 59323) Witness reported the existence of the forged certificate to the police.
('9', 25, 2, 10, 59395) All registration certificates were signed by him only.
('9', 25, 2, 11, 59450) No one in Natal had authority to issue permits.
('9', 25, 3, 12, 59498) MR. GANDHI: Is the forged document a fair imitation of the official document?
('9', 25, 3, 13, 59576) [CHAMNEY:] The document is certainly a fair imitation; my signature is not.
('9', 25, 4, 14, 59652) Superintendent Vernon, recalled, stated that on searching the accused at the Charge Office he found a certificate of domicile under the Immigration Restriction Act No.
('9', 25, 4, 15, 59820) 13 of 1903, also a number of poll tax receipts.
('9', 25, 4, 16, 59868) On the domicile certificate were two thumb impressions, and the certificate was in the name of Daya Lala.
('9', 25, 4, 17, 59974) On searching the accuseds house Police Constable Henry was present, and saw witness recover the documents.
('9', 25, 5, 18, 60081) Mr. Schuurman asked for the purposes of the case that the finger impressions of the accused should be taken.
('9', 25, 5, 19, 60190) He would have to call expert evidence on the matter.
('9', 25, 6, 20, 60243) Mr. Gandhi said he would raise no objection, and the case was remanded.

('9', 25, 8, 23, 60466) On the afternoon of accuseds arrest, Superintendent Vernon had called at Mr. Gandhis office and had asked for the accuseds registration certificate.
('9', 25, 8, 24, 60615) He opened the office safe and found the certificate inside.
('9', 25, 8, 25, 60675) He handed it to the accused who, he believed, handed it to Superintendent Vernon.
('9', 25, 8, 26, 60757) Cross examined, [he said] he was in charge of the safe.
('9', 25, 8, 27, 60813) He had one key and Mr. Polak had another.
('9', 25, 8, 28, 60855) Mr. Polak was an attorney and a clerk in Mr. Gandhis employ.
('9', 25, 8, 29, 60916) Mr. Gandhi was then called by the Crown to give evidence.
('9', 25, 8, 30, 60974) About 5 oclock in the afternoon of the day before the arrest, accused had come to his office and said that some men were after him on account of his permit.
('9', 25, 8, 31, 61131) He (Mr. Gandhi) asked him to bring his permit and, upon inspecting it, said at once that it was a forgery.

('9', 26, 4, 12, 62684) 16. IMAM ABDOOL KADIR BAWAZEER We print a photograph of Imam Saheb in a supplement to this issue.
('9', 26, 4, 13, 62782) Indian traders throughout South Africa have earned credit for themselves by closing their shops in Imam Sahebs honour.
('9', 26, 4, 14, 62901) 2 That honour was not given to Mr. Bawazeer [as a person], but to the Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society, and Assistant Priest of the Hamidia Mosque.
('9', 26, 4, 15, 63056) Everyone knows of the valuable work done by the Hamidia Society and Mr. Bawazeers role in it.
('9', 26, 4, 16, 63150) He assumed the office of Chairman about the time that the satyagraha campaign started in right earnest.
('9', 26, 4, 17, 63254) Those familiar with [the history of] the movement know the difficulties he has had to encounter in continuing in that office.
('9', 26, 4, 18, 63380) From every point of view, therefore, Mr. Bawazeer deserved the honour accorded him.
('9', 26, 4, 19, 63464) He wants to go to gaol again.
('9', 26, 4, 20, 63494) We hope that his wish will be fulfilled.
('9', 26, 4, 21, 63535) We do not believe that it is wrong to court imprisonment but are in fact convinced that it is the best course.
('9', 26, 4, 22, 63646) Mr. Bawazeer comes from a great family of Arabia.
('9', 26, 4, 23, 63696) His father left Arabia many years ago to settle in India.
('9', 26, 4, 24, 63754) He is the chief Imam of the Jumma Masjid of Bombay and his 3 mother is a resident of Konkan.

('9', 27, 0, 1, 64289) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 27, 1, 2, 64330) 17. SENTENCE ON THE GREAT TILAK
('9', 27, 2, 3, 64362) The sentence passed on Mr. Tilak, the great patriot, is terrible.
('9', 27, 2, 4, 64428) 1 The few days imprisonment which the Transvaal Indians suffer is as nothing compared to transportation for six years.
('9', 27, 2, 5, 64547) The sentence is not so much surprising as terrible.
('9', 27, 2, 6, 64599) At the same time it is nothing to be unhappy about.
('9', 27, 2, 7, 64651) It is not surprising that a Government we seek to defy should inflict oppressive measures on us.
('9', 27, 2, 8, 64748) Mr. Tilak is so great a man and scholar that it would be impertinent, in this country, to write of his work.
('9', 27, 2, 9, 64857) He deserves to be adored for his work in the service of the motherland.
('9', 27, 2, 10, 64929) His simplicity is extraordinary; but the light of his scholarship has reached even Europe.
('9', 27, 2, 11, 65020) Yet we should not blindly follow the policies of those whom we regard as great.
('9', 27, 2, 12, 65100) It would be casting a reflection on Mr. Tilaks greatness to argue that his writings had no bitterness in them or to offer some such defence.
('9', 27, 2, 13, 65241) Pungent, bitter and penetrating writing was his objective.
('9', 27, 2, 14, 65300) He aimed at inciting Indians against British rule.
('9', 27, 2, 15, 65351) To attempt to minimize this would be to detract from Mr. Tilaks greatness.
('9', 27, 2, 16, 65426) The rulers are justified, from their point of view, in taking action against such a man.
('9', 27, 2, 17, 65515) We would do the same in their place.
('9', 27, 2, 18, 65552) If we look at the matter thus, we realize that we need not feel bitter towards them.
('9', 27, 2, 19, 65637) Mr. Tilak, however, deserves our congratulations.
('9', 27, 2, 20, 65687) He has, by his suffering, attained undying fame and laid the foundations of Indias freedom.
('9', 27, 2, 21, 65779) If the people, instead of being overawed at the sentence passed on Mr. Tilak or being intimidated by it, rejoice at it and keep up their courage, the sentence will in the sequel prove to have been a blessing.
('9', 27, 2, 22, 65988) What we need to consider is whether Indians should accept the views of Mr. Tilak and his party.
('9', 27, 2, 23, 66084) We submit, after great deliberation, that Mr. Tilaks views should be rejected.
('9', 27, 3, 24, 66163) 1 Shortly after the Muzaffarpur incident (vide Turmoil in India, 9 5 1908), Tilak wrote two articles in his journal, Kesari, praising the enthusiasm of the Bengal revolutionaries without, however, endorsing their violent methods.
('9', 27, 3, 25, 66393) Self rule, he said, was the only lasting solution to the problem.
('9', 27, 3, 26, 66459) He also warned the Government against suppressing public opinion through the Newspapers Act.
('9', 27, 3, 27, 66552) On June 24, he was arrested on a charge of sedition on two separate warrants, one for each of his two articles.
('9', 27, 3, 28, 66664) Tilak was found guilty by the jury by a seven to two vote and was sentenced to six years deportation.
('9', 27, 3, 29, 66766) The majority of the jury were Anglo Indians, the two dissentients being Indians.
('9', 28, 0, 1, 66847) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 29
('9', 28, 1, 2, 66887) Indias welfare does not consist in merely uprooting British rule.
('9', 28, 1, 3, 66953) It will be harmful, even useless, to use force or violence for uprooting that rule.
('9', 28, 1, 4, 67037) Freedom gained through violence would not endure.
('9', 28, 1, 5, 67087) And the sufferings to which the people of Europe submit would also become our lot then.
('9', 28, 1, 6, 67175) As for the masses, they would merely pass from one form of slavery to another.
('9', 28, 1, 7, 67254) No one will gain this way and almost everyone will losethat is what the result will be.
('9', 28, 1, 8, 67342) We believe that the easiest way to make British rule beneficent is to adopt the way of satyagraha.
('9', 28, 1, 9, 67441) If British rule becomes tyrannical, it will come to an end as soon as the British Government attempts to resist satyagraha.
('9', 28, 1, 10, 67565) If the same workers who went on strike in protest against the sentence on Mr. Tilak were to become satyagrahis, they would be able to get the Government to agree to any reasonable demands.
('9', 28, 1, 11, 67754) What is our duty in this context?
('9', 28, 1, 12, 67788) Though Mr. Tilak and other great Indians like him differ from us, we should continue to hold them in the highest esteem.
('9', 28, 1, 13, 67909) We must emulate them in their capacity to suffer.
('9', 28, 1, 14, 67959) Since they are great patriots, we must consider no honour too great for them, and act in the same spirit of patriotism.
('9', 28, 1, 15, 68079) Their object is the same as ours, namely, to serve the motherland and to work for its prosperity.
('9', 28, 1, 16, 68177) Compared to what they have been doing to secure that end, the course we have chosen is not in the least difficult.
('9', 28, 1, 17, 68292) But we are convinced that the outcome of our exertions will be a thousand times better.
('9', 28, 1, 18, 68380) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 1 8 1908
('9', 28, 2, 19, 68421) 18. TROUBLE AMONG CAPE INDIANS 1
('9', 28, 3, 20, 68454) There are two public bodies in the Cape.
('9', 28, 3, 21, 68495) They seem to be working at cross purposes.
('9', 28, 3, 22, 68538) From time to time we read reports of their disputes even in the English papers.

('9', 28, 3, 25, 68814) The dispute between the two bodies proba bly relates to insignificant issues.
('9', 28, 3, 26, 68892) It will improve matters a great deal if all Indians aspire to be known as servants of the community rather than as leaders.
('9', 28, 3, 27, 69016) A servant does not insist on privileges.
('9', 28, 3, 28, 69057) He is only mindful of his own duty.
('9', 28, 3, 29, 69093) Similarly, it is possible for us to remain

('9', 29, 2, 7, 69588) 19. PARLIAMENT FOR TURKEY
('9', 29, 3, 8, 69614) Reports have appeared in newspapers that the Young Party 1 in Turkey has brought about reforms in the Government.
('9', 29, 3, 9, 69728) The people are pleased, a cablegram reports, because the Sultan has adopted a consti tution for the governance of the country, and the occasion is being celebrated everywhere.
('9', 29, 3, 10, 69904) The news agency also reports that Turkey will soon have a Parliament similar to the British Parliament.
('9', 29, 4, 11, 70008) If the report is true, it is indeed an epoch making development.
('9', 29, 4, 12, 70073) Turkey has among its common people and nobility men of such [remarkable] stature that, when she comes to have a Parliament, they can put her on par with the great European states, and indeed make her a world power.
('9', 29, 4, 13, 70288) The country is so situated that it can achieve a commanding position.
('9', 29, 5, 14, 70358) Thus, the world over, we hear the cry of swarajya.
('9', 29, 5, 15, 70409) However, those who demand it hardly understand what real swarajya means.
('9', 29, 5, 16, 70482) The Transvaal struggle involves Turkeys honour as much as Indias.
('9', 29, 5, 17, 70548) It is obviously the duty of Muslims to carry on that fight till the end.
('9', 29, 5, 18, 70621) It is the duty of Hindus to join it, as they are brothers of the Muslims.
('9', 29, 5, 19, 70695) For they are [both] sons of the same Mother India.
('9', 29, 5, 20, 70746) Also, although vote less, they have both to win swarajya in the Transvaal and they have an opportunity of doing that without much effort.
('9', 29, 5, 21, 70884) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 1 8 1908

('9', 30, 6, 10, 71572) 21. TRIAL OF MULJIBHAI G. PATEL I
('9', 30, 7, 11, 71606) [Tuesday, August 4, 1908]
('9', 30, 8, 12, 71632) On Monday afternoon Mr. Muljibhai G. Patel, a member of the Committee of the British Indian Association, was arrested for being in the Transvaal without a registration certificate.
('9', 30, 8, 13, 71813) He was admitted to 10 bail, but he refused to be bailed out, and was detained in the cells overnight....
('9', 30, 9, 14, 71918) He was brought before Mr. H. H. Jordan in B Court on Tuesday afternoon charged under section 8, sub section 3, of Act 2 of 1907. He pleaded guilty.
('9', 30, 9, 15, 72066) Mr. Gandhi defended and Mr. Cramer prosecuted.
('9', 30, 10, 16, 72113) Superintendent Vernon of the Transvaal Police stated that he was an Inspector appointed under the Registration Act to demand from Asiatics their registration certificates.
('9', 30, 10, 17, 72285) The accused had stated to him that he had no certificates, that his Association had told him not to register, that he had refused to register under the Act, and would continue to do so.
('9', 30, 10, 18, 72471) He produced a Peace Preservation Ordinance permit and a registration certificate, taken out on Lord Milners advice 2.
('9', 30, 11, 19, 72589) Cross examined [he said] he had received instructions on Thursday to effect this arrest.
('9', 30, 11, 20, 72678) There were a good many like accused in the Transvaal who had entered and were not registered under the Actat least 200. He would get instructions with regard to these directly, he hoped.
('9', 30, 12, 21, 72865) For the defence, the accused stated that he was a general agent, and had been in the Transvaal for about nine years.
('9', 30, 12, 22, 72982) He took out his permit and registration certificate in 1903. Last year he paid a visit to India and returned to the Transvaal on 25th May last.
('9', 30, 12, 23, 73126) He had not applied for a registration certificate under the Registration Act, nor had he any wish so to apply.
('9', 30, 12, 24, 73237) His reason was that, according to last Januarys com

('9', 31, 1, 2, 73448) promise, the law was to be repealed.

('9', 31, 5, 12, 74116) 22. TRIAL OF TWELVE HAWKERS
('9', 31, 6, 13, 74144) [JOHANNESBURG, August 4, 1908]
('9', 31, 7, 14, 74175) In D Court, in the afternoon, before Mr. H. H. Hopkins, 12 British Indian hawkers were charged with having traded as hawkers without licences, or, alternatively, with not having their names painted on their trading receptacles.
('9', 31, 8, 15, 74403) Mr. Shaw prosecuted, Mr. Gandhi appearing for the accused.
('9', 31, 9, 16, 74462) In almost every case the accused stated that they had applied for licences, which were refused because they would not give thumb impressions.
('9', 31, 10, 17, 74604) In the first case Mr. Gandhi asked Mr. Barrett, the Licence Inspector, whether he had hitherto taken any notice of the fact that hawkers did not have their names on their trading receptacles.
('9', 31, 11, 18, 74796) The witness replied that he had not.
('9', 31, 11, 19, 74833) He stated that the accused told him that Mr. Gandhi had his licence.
('9', 31, 12, 20, 74902) MR. SHAW: He did not say whether he had let, hired, or lent his licence to Mr. Gandhi?
('9', 31, 13, 21, 74989) [BARRETT:] No.
('9', 31, 14, 22, 75004) All of the accused were fined 1 [each], with the alternative of seven days imprisonment with hard labour, with one exception.
('9', 31, 14, 23, 75130) In this case Mr. Gandhi said that there were two previous convictions.
('9', 31, 15, 24, 75201) Mr. Shaw said that the accused was one of those sentenced last month for hawking without a licence, and was sentenced to pay a fine of 1, or four days imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 31, 16, 25, 75383) Mr. Gandhi said that the accused had been also sentenced in January last, and sentence was remitted because of the compromise.
('9', 31, 17, 26, 75510) The accused was fined 2, with the alternative of 14 days imprisonment.
('9', 31, 17, 27, 75581) The Transvaal Leader, 4 8 1908

('9', 32, 2, 3, 75676) NAIDOOS SACRIFICE Monday [August 5, 1908] I am pained to have to report that Mr. Thambi Naidoos wife has had a miscarriage.
('9', 32, 2, 4, 75800) The child was buried today.
('9', 32, 2, 5, 75828) Mr. Naidoo does not know this.
('9', 32, 2, 6, 75859) But the communitys obligation to him is mounting.
('9', 32, 2, 7, 75909) He left his wifes side at a difficult time and deliberately went to gaol for the sake of the community, and this is what has happened meanwhile.
('9', 32, 2, 8, 76054) Mr. Naidoo is still in gaol.
('9', 32, 2, 9, 76083) It is probable that this happened because of Mr. Naidoos having gone to gaol.
('9', 32, 2, 10, 76161) I saw Mrs. Naidoo on the same day on which he went to gaol.
('9', 32, 2, 11, 76221) She was, as described by Mr. Doke, in a pathetic state.
('9', 32, 2, 12, 76277) There is hardly another woman so spirited who would face with courage a second term of imprisonment for her husband.
('9', 32, 2, 13, 76394) In any case that cannot be expected of a woman in Mrs. Naidoos condition.
('9', 32, 2, 14, 76468) There is no doubt that the guilt for this death must attach to the Transvaal Government.
('9', 32, 2, 15, 76557) It is because of its injustices that Indians have to suffer in this fashion.

('9', 39, 1, 10, 92030) They will then be asked to get of [the train].

('9', 39, 1, 12, 92158) They should present themselves for trial.
('9', 39, 1, 13, 92200) They will either be fined or imprisoned.
('9', 39, 1, 14, 92241) They should not pay the fine, and cheerfully accept the imprisonment.
('9', 39, 1, 15, 92311) This is what has to be explained to Indians who are entitled to enter.
('9', 39, 1, 16, 92382) Indians who are ready for this should send in their names to the British Indian Association, who should be informed when any Indian with a legitimate right leaves [for the Transvaal] by train.
('9', 39, 1, 17, 92575) Educated Indians who are patriotic should watch these trains for any Indian [immigrants] travelling by them, and properly acquaint them with the position as above.

('9', 39, 1, 21, 92981) In no other part of the world have Indians done anything comparable to what has happened in the Transvaal so far.
('9', 39, 1, 22, 93095) Even in India a similar battle has not been fought.
('9', 39, 1, 23, 93147) The Transvaal campaign is a clear and pure one and furthers the interests of both the rulers and the ruled.
('9', 39, 1, 24, 93255) That is the point of the campaign.
('9', 39, 1, 25, 93290) All Indians, high or low, should understand what their freedom really consists in.
('9', 39, 1, 26, 93373) Indians who feel the urge to be free and learn to have no fear of privations in gaol or of any suffering will achieve swarajya this day.

('9', 41, 4, 14, 96407) SIR, I have received inquiries from many quarters as to why I sent Harilal, my son, to gaol.
('9', 41, 4, 15, 96500) 2 I give some reasons below: 1. I have advised every Indian to take up hawking.
('9', 41, 4, 16, 96580) I am afraid I cannot join myself since I am enrolled as an attorney.
('9', 41, 4, 17, 96649) I therefore thought it right to advise my son to make his rounds as a hawker.
('9', 41, 4, 18, 96727) I hesitate to ask others to do things which I cannot do myself.
('9', 41, 4, 19, 96791) I think whatever my son does at my instance can be taken to have been done by me.
('9', 41, 4, 20, 96873) 2. It will be a part of Harilals education to go to gaol for the sake of the country.
('9', 41, 4, 21, 96959) 3. I have always been telling people that satyagraha is easy for those who can understand it well.
('9', 41, 4, 22, 97058) When I go to defend those who have been arrested, I do not, strictly speaking, defend them but only send them to gaol.
('9', 41, 4, 23, 97177) If we have acquired real courage, there should be no need for me to present myself in Court.
('9', 41, 4, 24, 97270) I thought it only proper that I should make this experiment in the first instance with my son.
('9', 41, 4, 25, 97365) Accordingly, no arrangements were made for him at Volksrust, and he was left to fall back on his own strength.
('9', 41, 4, 26, 97476) Since there were others with him in Johannesburg, I attended the Court, but asked for the maxi

('9', 43, 2, 3, 99631) [JOHANNESBURG,] August 8, 1908 [THE EDITOR THE TRANSVAAL LEADER]
('9', 43, 3, 4, 99696) SIR, May I, through your columns, place before those of your readers who are interested in justice being done to all the inhabitants of the Transvaal a phase of the Asiatic question?
('9', 43, 4, 5, 99879) I read in your impression of todays date a brief report of the two cases of Indians who were alleged to have been connected with forged certificates.
('9', 43, 4, 6, 100029) One of the men secured his discharge by becoming Kings evidence.
('9', 43, 4, 7, 100094) The man against whom he became Kings evidence has also been discharged.
('9', 43, 4, 8, 100166) The public know how far one party, according to his own confession, was involved in the forgery traffic.
('9', 43, 4, 9, 100271) The evidence against the other was undoubtedly, according to the newspaper reports, too weak to sustain a conviction.
('9', 43, 4, 10, 100389) Thus those who are connected with the forgery are largely free.
('9', 43, 4, 11, 100453) The Asiatic Law Amendment Act does not, and did not, touch them.
('9', 43, 4, 12, 100518) They were not charged under it either, and I frankly admit that no Asiatic Act could deal with such cases.
('9', 43, 4, 13, 100625) Wherever there is restriction on personal liberty, there will be found people ready enough to resort to a variety of practices to shirk such restriction.
('9', 43, 4, 14, 100779) It is worthy of note that Indians were not the only parties connected with the traffic.
('9', 43, 4, 15, 100867) Europeans are

('9', 43, 5, 17, 100988) 2 The Transvaal Leader commented editorially on this letter as follows: .
('9', 43, 5, 18, 101062) .he asserts that Asiatics sent to gaol under the present Tom fool administration of the Asiatic Act are being half starved, owing to their not being given the kind of food they are accustomed to, and to their inability to consume that which is supplied to them.
('9', 43, 5, 19, 101324) These men are political prisoners; it is unjust if they are put to hard labour or made to wear prison clothing; it is infamously unjust if they are treated dietetically as Mr. Gandhi says they are.

('9', 43, 5, 21, 101603) We seem to be an exception.

('9', 44, 1, 2, 102247) also alleged to have been engaged in it.
('9', 44, 1, 3, 102288) Now, let your readers turn to the other side of the picture.
('9', 44, 1, 4, 102349) Indians who have entered the Colony openly, who have proved their pre war residence, who have always conformed to its laws, and who have recently, by universal acknowledgement, helped the Government completely to identify such persons, are being harassed on all sides, and subjected, to use Lord Milners historic expression, to pinpricks.
('9', 44, 1, 5, 102688) Inoffensive Indiansin many instances Indians belon ging to the highest strata of the Indian communityare being impris oned, not because they have committed any heinous offence, but because their conscience does not approve of what they consider to be irritating and insulting legislation.
('9', 44, 1, 6, 102977) Standerton is at present practically denuded of its chief Indian store keepers, who are now serving a term of 14 days imprisonment, with hard labour.
('9', 44, 1, 7, 103127) As if this were not in itself sufficient harassment, no relief has yet been granted regarding the food of these Indian prisoners.
('9', 44, 1, 8, 103257) European prisoners get that food to which they are generally accustomed; Cape Boys receive European food; Natives get a diet to which they are accustomed; Indian prisoners get practically Native diet, and, therefore, are half starved.
('9', 44, 1, 9, 103492) They get mealie pap for breakfast every day and mealie pap for supper three times per week.
('9', 44, 1, 10, 103584) Mealie pap, I know, to those who are accustomed to it, or who can by a long course of training habituate themselves to it, is good.
('9', 44, 1, 11, 103716) Unfortunately, my countrymen do not take mealie pap.
('9', 44, 1, 12, 103769) The result is that in the Transvaal gaols they have to suffer partial starvation.
('9', 44, 1, 13, 103851) The authorities have been approached for relief, 1 but up to the time of writing there has been no response.
('9', 44, 1, 14, 103960) My countrymen draw the conclusion, probably unjustifiably, that relief has been withheld in order to exasperate the Indians into submission.
('9', 44, 1, 15, 104101) If so, let the authorities take care that they do not exasperate them into bitterest opposition to the Government and their measures.
('9', 44, 1, 16, 104235) Asiatics, having fulfilled their part of the contract, are now endeavouring to keep General Smuts to his part of that contract, which, according to The Transvaal Leader, he publicly declared to be as follows: He had told them (the Asiatics) that the law would not be repealed so long as there was an Asiatic in the country who had not registered; 2 and, again, Until every Indian in the country had registered the law would not be repealed.
('9', 44, 1, 17, 104676) It is admitted that all
('9', 44, 2, 18, 104700) 1 Vide Letter to Director of Prisons, 24 7 1908
('9', 44, 3, 19, 104748) 2 Smuts said this in his Richmond speech; vide Appendix VIII.

('9', 45, 6, 10, 105872) Mr. Gandhi, on behalf of the accused, said that the latter had no desire to leave the Colony, but nevertheless he was desirous that the Court should make an order for the accused to leave the Colony within 24 hours.
('9', 45, 6, 11, 106088) He made the request because two other Indians whose time under the Act would expire on Wednesday would be ready to go to gaol.
