('9', 45, 8, 15, 106419) 32. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING
('9', 45, 9, 16, 106446) [JOHANNESBURG, August 10, 1908]
('9', 45, 10, 17, 106478) Immediately after the case in which Harilal Gandhi was charged with being in the Colony without a registration certificate yesterday [August 10, 1908,] a mass meeting of Indians was held in an open space near the Court buildings.
('9', 45, 10, 18, 106708) Mr. M. K. Gandhi addressed the meeting in English, and said that he had just received a telegram
('9', 45, 11, 19, 106805) 1 Harilal Gandhi was earlier tried on July 28, 1908; vide Trial of Harilal Gan dhi and Others, 28 7 1908.
('9', 46, 0, 1, 106911) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 47
('9', 46, 1, 2, 106951) from Vereeniging to the effect that several Indian store keepers who were arrested for hawking or trading without licences had been given by the Magistrate no option of imprisonment, but had been fined 2. 7s.
('9', 46, 1, 3, 107160) 6d each, and had to pay the fines within 24 hours, or elect to have their goods sold by the Court.
('9', 46, 1, 4, 107259) This introduced a new phase into the struggle, but he had no doubt that British Indians would not be baffled by this.
('9', 46, 1, 5, 107377) He did not know whether the Magistrate had received instructions from the Law Department to put into force the provisions of the law for certain exceptional cases, or whether the Magistrate had done this on his own initiative, but it showed to them that they were going to receive no quarter from General Smuts, nor did it behove them to ask for quarter.
('9', 46, 1, 6, 107732) They were carrying on a fight in order that General Smuts might be compelled to carry out his promise to repeal the Act a promise which was published in an account of a meeting held at Richmond, when he said that when all had registered he would repeal the Act.
('9', 46, 1, 7, 107994) 1 There was one incident in connection with the matter which he (Mr. Gandhi) wished to recall.
('9', 46, 1, 8, 108089) When he was lying in Mr. Dokes house, the Registrar of Asiatics came to him and said that it appeared that the Chinese and some Indians would not come forward, as they were suspicious of the intentions of the Government, and wanted something in black and white to confirm the promises made.
('9', 46, 1, 9, 108380) A notice was drafted there and then, which was to be published in all the Indian languages and in the Chinese language, stating that, if the Asiatic communities carried out their compact, the Act would be repealed during the next session.
('9', 46, 2, 10, 108619) FORTUNATELY
('9', 46, 3, 11, 108631) Unfortunatelyno, he would say fortunately, because they were now in a position to know with whom they were dealingfortunately, the next day Mr. Chamney brought the news that all the Asiatics were coming in, and that the Chinese had withdrawn their objections, and asked whether he (Mr. Gandhi) thought it necessary that the notice should be published.
('9', 46, 3, 12, 108983) They had then no reason to doubt the honesty of Mr. Smuts or Mr. Chamney, and he replied that there was no reason for the publication of the notice.
('9', 46, 3, 13, 109132) He would only say that when Mr. Smuts made the statement at Richmond he must have had in his thoughts some such difficulty cropping up with the Asiatics as that which Mr. Chamney spoke to him of, and it was for this reason that he made the declaration.
('9', 46, 3, 14, 109385) Today they found that General Smuts had offered to repeal the Act on certain conditions, which could not be acceptedconditions which were not imposed on them when they agreed to take out voluntary registration certificates.
('9', 46, 4, 15, 109609) PURE ADMINISTRATION AND THE EMPIRES PEACE
('9', 46, 5, 16, 109651) The Asiatics were helping the Government against themselves, and helping Mr. Smuts to keep to his word, and maintaining the purity of administration within the colony and peace within the Empire.
('9', 46, 5, 17, 109847) If they found that the statesmen who were
('9', 46, 6, 18, 109889) 1 Vide Appendix VIII.
('9', 46, 7, 19, 109911) 2 For the conditions, vide Johannesburg Letter, 23 6 1908
('9', 47, 0, 1, 109969) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 47, 1, 2, 110010) controlling the Government in South Africa had no notion of ordinary honesty and that, when it suited them, they withdrew from their promises, and tried to break these promises, the British Indians should compel them to keep their promises, and by so doing they would be rendering a signal service not only to the Colony but to the Empire.
('9', 47, 1, 3, 110350) It did not therefore baffle them when they stood face to face with suffering imprisonment, with being half starved, and going barefooted in the prisons, and it did not baffle them when they stood face to face with having their goods confiscated.
('9', 47, 1, 4, 110596) He could only characterize this as organized robberylegalized robbery.
('9', 47, 1, 5, 110667) They were now brought under a section of a law which was only designed for exceptional purposes.
('9', 47, 2, 6, 110764) DECLINE TO PAY
('9', 47, 3, 7, 110779) He hoped that his countrymen had sufficient self sacrifice to decline to pay their fines, and have their goods sold under their noses.
('9', 47, 3, 8, 110914) He had no doubt that the Colonists themselves, when they saw that the British Indians would suffer this, they would ask General Smuts to stay his hand and keep his promises, and to repeal the Act on the conditions he had agreed upon.
('9', 47, 3, 9, 111148) They had to suffer in order that they might give complete identification to the compact made by General Smuts with them.
('9', 47, 3, 10, 111269) The Chairman of the British Indian Association had his nose broken because he stood up for the Government in keeping his compact with them, 1 and the reward of the Government for this was a broken promisea breach of faith.
('9', 47, 3, 11, 111492) He had no hesitation in repeating anywhere that this was the solemn promise made by General Smuts.
('9', 47, 3, 12, 111591) They found that not only was the Act not repealed, but all kinds of vexatious regulations were being passed through Parliament affecting those who came from British India.
('9', 47, 4, 13, 111763) PARTNERS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('9', 47, 5, 14, 111788) He said that this country was as much the British Indians as the white mans.
('9', 47, 5, 15, 111865) They were partners and the white men were predominant partners, but they were only partners.
('9', 47, 5, 16, 111958) The Indians only wanted justice and fair play, and if they could not get that they should show that they were prepared to suffer.
('9', 47, 5, 17, 112088) His opinion was that no man who called himself a subject of King Edward should allow his rights to be taken away from him, but should suffer if necessary in order to prevent this.
('9', 47, 5, 18, 112268) In this country, because they had committed the crime of having a coloured skin, they were as nothing, their feelings should be set aside, their sentiments disregarded, and their consciences set at naught.
('9', 47, 5, 19, 112474) Let them show that they had sufficient of the spirit of self sacrifice to suffer the confiscation of their property in order to compel the Government to keep its part of a compact which the Asiatics had honourably fulfilled.
('9', 47, 5, 20, 112699) Mr. Naidoo had only come out of gaol that day.
('9', 47, 5, 21, 112746) He (Mr. Gandhi) had declared before that Mr. Smuts was respon sible for the death of the Chinaman who had committed suicide.
('9', 47, 5, 22, 112871) 2 Mr. Smuts was responsible for this, and he was now responsible for the murder of young Mr. Naidoo.
('9', 47, 6, 23, 112972) 1 Vide Johannesburg Letter,16 5 1908 and Essop Mia,23 5 1908
('9', 47, 7, 24, 113033) 2 Vide Johannesburg Letter, 16 11 1907 & Speech at Chinese Associa tion, 27 11 1907.
('9', 48, 0, 1, 113118) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 49
('9', 48, 1, 2, 113158) Mrs. Naidoo was in pain when Mr. Naidoo went to gaol, and Mrs. Naidoo had given birth to a still born child.
('9', 48, 1, 3, 113267) Who was responsible for this if not Mr. Smuts?
('9', 48, 1, 4, 113314) He (Mr. Gandhi) was certain that all these pains would have to be accounted for, if not now, then hereafter.
('9', 48, 1, 5, 113423) Mr. Smuts was a Christian, and believed, as they all believed, in a hereafter, and he would have to answer for these things just as they would have to answer for their actions.
('9', 48, 2, 6, 113600) Mr. Gandhi concluded with a further appeal to British Indians to suffer whatever might be necessary for what they considered was right and just, and then proceeded to speak in Gujarati.

('9', 48, 4, 8, 113818) 33. TRIAL OF THREE HAWKERS
('9', 48, 5, 9, 113845) [JOHANNESBURG, August 11, 1908]
('9', 48, 6, 10, 113877) Three Indian hawkers were charged before Mr. H. H. Hopkins in D Court yesterday morning [August 11] with trading as hawkers without licences, or, alternatively, with failing to produce their licences when called upon.
('9', 48, 6, 11, 114095) Mr. Shaw prosecuted, Mr. Gandhi appearing for the defence.
('9', 48, 7, 12, 114154) While giving evidence in one case, Mr. French, Municipal Licence Inspector, said that one of the accused had told him that his licence was in the possession of Mr. Gandhi.
('9', 48, 7, 13, 114326) Witness went to Mr. Gandhis office, and was there told that they did not have the licence.
('9', 48, 8, 14, 114417) Mr. Gandhi went into the witness box, and said that with reference to what the accused was alleged to have said, witness held several licences, probably two or three hundred, which had been deposited with him, and also held probably a thousand registration certificates, which had also been deposited with him by British Indians, who had made up their minds not to make use of these certificates or licences.
('9', 48, 8, 15, 114826) He had not searched his records to see whether he had this particular licence or not, as the Inspector had not asked him to do so.
('9', 48, 9, 16, 114957) Two of the accused said that they had not taken out licences, as they were required to give their thumb impressions before licences were issued.
('9', 48, 10, 17, 115102) Replying to the Magistrate, Mr. Shaw said that the extreme penalty for the offence was a fine of 20, or three months imprisonment.
('9', 48, 10, 18, 115233) All of the accused were found guilty, and sentenced to pay a fine of 1, or go to prison for seven days with hard labour.
('9', 48, 11, 19, 115354) They all elected to go to gaol.

('9', 55, 4, 8, 128483) SIR, You will, I hope, allow me to correct you with regard to the question of educated Indians, touched upon in your leader of yesterday on the Asiatic struggle.
('9', 55, 4, 9, 128645) 2 British Indians do not ask for the opening of the door to educated Indians.
('9', 55, 4, 10, 128723) They ask that the door should be left open as it is at present under the Immigrants Restriction Act.
('9', 55, 4, 11, 128824) You assume that a demand is being made for admitting English speaking lads.
('9', 55, 4, 12, 128900) The truth is that Indians have declared that they would be satisfied with an education test, no matter how severe, so long as the door is kept open (not now to be opened) for those possessing the highest educational attainments.
('9', 55, 4, 13, 129129) You say that General Smuts will be justified in withdrawing from any promise he may have made, in view of the above alleged fresh demand.
('9', 55, 4, 14, 129267) From the facts stated by me, you can verify for yourself that

('9', 57, 2, 5, 133502) 38. INTERVIEW TO THE TRANSVAAL LEADER
('9', 57, 3, 6, 133540) [JOHANNESBURG, August 12, 1908]
('9', 57, 4, 7, 133572) A number of the leading Transvaal Indian 1 left for Charlestown yesterday [August 12] with the intention of crossing the border into the Transvaal without giving evidence of identity....All of these are domiciled in the Transvaal, and all but one possess voluntary registration certificates.
('9', 57, 4, 8, 133864) They will decline to produce their registration certificates, which must be demanded in accordance with the Asiatic Act....
('9', 57, 4, 9, 133988) On their refusal to supply particulars required by the Government, these men will be arrested.
('9', 57, 4, 10, 134083) In that event they will plead guilty to the charge of refusing to comply with the provisions of the Asiatic Act in order that they may be imprisoned....
('9', 57, 4, 11, 134236) A number of other Indians who are qualified to enter the Transvaal under the Immigrants Restriction Act, but not under the Asiatic Amendment Act, will also probably try to enter the Transvaal within the next few days....
('9', 57, 5, 12, 134457) Mr. Gandhi said that the Bill will not satisfy the Asiatic communities, because they hold that it breaks the terms of the promises made by General Smuts when the compromise was arrived at, and that it sets up two kinds of legislation for the same class of people.
('9', 57, 5, 13, 134721) The Bill does not protect Asiatics who they hold are entitled to enter the country, and have entered after the expiry of the three months appointed for voluntary registration, and also those Asiatics who were resident in the Transvaal on the date of the compromise, but did not take out voluntary registration certificates.
('9', 57, 5, 14, 135045) These Asiatics have, in accordance with the new Bill, to be registered under the Asia tic Act.
('9', 57, 5, 15, 135140) The result in some cases would be peculiar for the Asiatics.
('9', 57, 5, 16, 135201) There are cases in which sons have taken out voluntary registration certificates, and fathers who were not in the Colony during the three months have not done so, and would therefore be called upon to register under the old Act.
('9', 57, 5, 17, 135430) The Bill, they hold, only nominally exem pts Asiatics who have voluntarily registered from the provisions of the Act.
('9', 57, 5, 18, 135548) The Asiatics hold that there are two conditions to be fulfilled by the Govern ment under the compromise.
('9', 57, 5, 19, 135653) The one is that to all those who registered voluntarily the Act should not be applied.
('9', 57, 5, 20, 135740) The other is that the voluntary mode of registration should apply to those who entered the Transvaal under the terms of the compromise.
('9', 57, 5, 21, 135876) Both of
('9', 57, 6, 22, 135884) 1 For the names,vide Johannesburg Letter, 15 8 1906
('9', 58, 0, 1, 135936) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 59
('9', 58, 1, 2, 135976) these conditions, they say, are disregarded.
('9', 58, 1, 3, 136021) Again, no provision has been made for prewar Asiatic residents who have not yet returned to the Transvaal; such old resi dents, if they chose to accept the old Asiatic Act, could, under the discre tionary clause, take out certificates of registration.
('9', 58, 1, 4, 136273) As such Asiatics will not comply with the terms of the old Act, they will be debarred from entering.
('9', 58, 1, 5, 136374) The same remarks apply to educated Indians who could enter the Colony under the Immigrants Restri ction Act, but who would become unregistered by reason of their non compliance with the Asiatic Act.
('9', 58, 1, 6, 136573) This, remarked Mr. Gandhi, is an adroit move, but hardly an honour able one. The new Bill the Indians hold to provide separate legislation for one class of people, as it regulates the movements of those Indians who have taken out volun tary registration certificates and the old Asiatic Act, the move ments of the others.

('9', 58, 4, 10, 137079) JOHANNESBURG, August 13, 1908 2
('9', 58, 5, 11, 137111) THE PETITION OF ESSOP ISMAIL MIA, IN HIS CAPACITY AS CHAIRMAN, AND M. K. GANDHI, IN HIS CAPACITY AS HONORARY SECRETARY OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('9', 58, 6, 12, 137264) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT 1. The British Indian Association represents the British Indian residents of the Transvaal.
('9', 58, 6, 13, 137376) 2. The members of the Association have read with much concern the Bill published in the Government Gazette, entitled to validate the voluntary registration of certain Asiatics who failed to comply with the provisions of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, 1907.
('9', 58, 6, 14, 137633) 3. When British Indians undertook to take out voluntary registration, they never had any intention of submitting to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act of 1907. 4. Whilst, nominally, the Bill before this Honble House does not make British Indians submit to the said Act, in reality, there is no
('9', 58, 7, 15, 137922) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 22 8 1908, under the title, A Peti tion to Parliament.
('9', 58, 7, 16, 138017) 2 Although the petition was drafted on this date, it was not submitted until after August 14; vide the following item, Letter to General Smuts, 14 8 1908
('9', 59, 0, 1, 138171) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 59, 1, 2, 138212) distinction between the incidents of voluntary registration to be legalized under the said Bill and registration under the Asiatic Act.
('9', 59, 1, 3, 138348) 5. The terms of the compromise as embodied in the letters that passed between the Honble the Colonial Secretary and the Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association and the other co signa tories were: (a) all Asiatics resident in the Colony at the time of the compromise should take out voluntary registration certificates say within three months from the date of the compromise.
('9', 59, 1, 4, 138736) (b) Children under 16 years were to be exempt from any registration.
('9', 59, 1, 5, 138805) (c) Such mode of registration was to be applicable to those who were entitled to enter the Transvaal but who were not in the Transvaal at the time of the compromise.
('9', 59, 1, 6, 138971) (d) To those who submitted to voluntary registration, Act No.
('9', 59, 1, 7, 139033) 2 of 1907 was not to be applied.
('9', 59, 1, 8, 139066) (e) The voluntary registration was to be legalized in any other manner that the Government considered proper.
('9', 59, 2, 9, 139176) 6. These were supplemented by conversations that took place at interviews granted by the Honble the Colonial Secretary to the Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association.
('9', 59, 2, 10, 139356) 7. At these interviews, the question of mode of legalization was discussed, and the Honble the Colonial Secretary definitely promised that, if all the Asiatics in the Transvaal submitted to voluntary registration, the said Act would be repealed.
('9', 59, 2, 11, 139602) 8. The said promise was referred to by the Honble the Colonial Secretary in one of his speeches 2 delivered at Richmond soon after the compromise.
('9', 59, 2, 12, 139749) 9. The Petitioners respectfully invite the attention of this Honble House to the fact that all the Asiatics who had an opportunity of submitting to voluntary registration have done so, and that the others have been always ready to do so, but voluntary registration after the 9th of May has been refused.
('9', 59, 2, 13, 140053) 10. The Bill before this Honble House, therefore, is in conflict with the compromise in the following particulars: (a) It does not repeal the said Act No.
('9', 59, 2, 14, 140208) 2 of 1907. (b) Whilst it seemingly validates voluntary registration under a
('9', 59, 3, 15, 140284) 1 Vide Letter to Colonial Secretary, 28 1 1908
('9', 59, 4, 16, 140331) 2 Vide Appendix VIII.

('9', 60, 1, 2, 140393) separate measure, it does not definitely and unequivocally except voluntary registrants from the operation of the said Act.
('9', 60, 2, 3, 140517) (c) It does not exempt from registration the children under the age of 16 years of holders of voluntary registration certificates.
('9', 60, 3, 4, 140648) (d) It does not leave any opportunity for voluntary registra tion for Asiatics referred to in Sub Paragraph (c) of Paragraph 5 hereof.
('9', 60, 4, 5, 140783) 11. The Bill is, therefore, in the humble opinion of the Petitioning Association, in breach of the terms that were to be fulfilled by the Government.
('9', 60, 5, 6, 140933) 12. The community represented by the Petitioning Association has no desire to take advantage of the voluntary registration certificates that were taken out by it in good faith.
('9', 60, 6, 7, 141110) 13. The Petitioning Association respectfully invites the attention of this Honble House to the fact that, at much personal sacrifice and even at the risk of their lives, 1 leading members of the Indian community fulfilled their part of the compromise.
('9', 60, 7, 8, 141362) 14. The Petitioning Association feels that the Bill before this Honble House disregards the admittedly valuable help rendered to the Govern ment of the Colony by the Association in connection with the compro mise.
('9', 60, 8, 9, 141576) 15. Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that this Honble House will reject the Bill, or grant such other relief as to it may seem fit and proper.

('9', 61, 2, 3, 142131) [JOHANNESBURG,] August 14, 1908
('9', 61, 3, 4, 142163) DEAR SIR, I deem it to be my duty to approach you, at the eve of what pro mises, for Indians, to be an interminable struggle.
('9', 61, 3, 5, 142289) Nearly sixty Indians are now undergoing imprisonment with hard labour at the Johannesburg Gaol.
('9', 61, 3, 6, 142385) Over thirty have suffered imprisonment and been discharged since the renewal of the struggle.
('9', 61, 3, 7, 142479) Thirteen Indian merchants are at present undergoing imprisonment at Standerton.
('9', 61, 3, 8, 142559) On Sunday 2, we meet to burn registration certificates.
('9', 61, 3, 9, 142615) The return of these certificates up to the time of writing is about 3. .
('9', 61, 3, 10, 142688) .They are still pouring in, and, by Sunday, it is highly probable that we will have at least fifteen hundred.
('9', 61, 3, 11, 142798) I do not know that all those are true men [who] would fight to the last and suffer every form of hardship.
('9', 61, 3, 12, 142905) The giving of their certificates is an earnest.
('9', 61, 3, 13, 142953) The Chairman 4 the Natal Indian Congress Durban, the Chairman 5 of the British Indian League, Cape Town, the Vice President 6 of the Natal In dian Congress and the Joint Secretary 7 of the Natal Indian Congress, each representing a different faith or clan of India, accompanied by a few indentured Indian and a few who claim pre war residence are today at the border either to be arrested and impresoned, or to be passed unchal lenged.
('9', 61, 3, 14, 143389) In my opinion, these facts represent strong, [gen]uine and invincible opposition to the Asiatic Act, and I am right in assuming that you do not intend to deal unjustly by those who are entitled to reside in the Transvaal.
('9', 61, 3, 15, 143611) The 8 difference between you, as representing the Government, and the British Indians is very small indeed.
('9', 61, 3, 16, 143719) I appeal to you once more, therefore, to revert to the draft Immigrants

('9', 62, 5, 11, 145607) 41. SUMMARY OF LETTER TO SIR GEORGE FARRAR2 August 14, 1908
('9', 62, 6, 12, 145667) Mr. Gandhi to Sir George Farrar writes, on the eve of another opening of a very fierce struggle, because he considers it his duty to lay before the leader of the Opposition, the gravity of the position; to set out the points of his objection to the Validation Bill, and requests consideration of them.
('9', 62, 7, 13, 145969) India Office, Judicial and Public Records: 3722/08
('9', 62, 8, 14, 146020) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('9', 62, 9, 15, 146047) 2 This is from a precis of events in the Transvaal sent by Ritch along with his letter of October 6, 1908 to the Colonial Office.
('9', 63, 0, 1, 146177) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 63, 1, 2, 146218) 42. WHAT IF GOODS ARE AUCTIONED
('9', 63, 2, 3, 146250) Vereeniging Indians were not sentenced to imprisonment but were only asked to pay a fine.
('9', 63, 2, 4, 146340) The Magistrate ordered the recovery of the fine, if not paid, by the auctioning of their goods.
('9', 63, 2, 5, 146436) There is no provision in the Licences Act for this [procedure] but the Magistrate has this power under another law.
('9', 63, 2, 6, 146552) What pleases one is that Indians have not been alarmed by this order; on the contrary, they have been able to see that what has happened is better.
('9', 63, 2, 7, 146700) This suggests that real wealth consists in poverty, for the rich cannot hold out against the Government as well as the poor can.
('9', 63, 2, 8, 146829) The rich will be afraid.
('9', 63, 2, 9, 146854) We congratulate the Vereeniging Indians on their informing the Magistrate that they would rather have their goods auctioned than pay the fine.
('9', 63, 2, 10, 146997) We do not think the slightest harm will befall them if their goods are auctioned.
('9', 63, 2, 11, 147079) To be sure, the goods of some traders will be so auctioned.
('9', 63, 2, 12, 147139) But we certainly cannot argue that there will be no loss of money in case of imprisonment.
('9', 63, 2, 13, 147230) We should not therefore be afraid of similar loss through auctioning of goods.
('9', 63, 2, 14, 147309) The fact is that, as hundreds of men cannot be imprisoned, equally, the goods of hundreds of traders cannot be auctioned.
('9', 63, 2, 15, 147431) The Government does not have the requisite facilities.
('9', 63, 2, 16, 147486) It would lose its prestige if it did so and might even be ousted from power.
('9', 63, 2, 17, 147563) Moreover, there is nothing that the Government can get out of hawkers.
('9', 63, 2, 18, 147634) No Indian is bound to produce his goods for auction.
('9', 63, 2, 19, 147687) The Government may, if it wants, search for a persons goods.
('9', 63, 2, 20, 147748) It will grow tired of doing so and then hawkers will be absolutely free to go about their business without licences.
('9', 63, 2, 21, 147865) The Government will find itself in the position of the woman who went out in search of her son and lost her husband.
('9', 63, 2, 22, 147982) Coveting the goods, the Government will even miss the opportunity of sending people to gaol, with the result that Indians will grow more determined.
('9', 63, 2, 23, 148131) This being the case, no Indian need be alarmed.
('9', 63, 2, 24, 148179) When the Government seeks a settlement, Indians, if they have the courage, can demand compensation for those whose goods were auctioned.
('9', 63, 2, 25, 148316) This campaign in the Transvaal is of the greatest importance to Indians.
('9', 63, 2, 26, 148389) Natal should watch it carefully.
('9', 63, 2, 27, 148422) The Natal Act does not provide for imprisonment in the matter of licences.
('9', 63, 2, 28, 148497) Only goods can be auctioned.
('9', 63, 2, 29, 148526) From [the events in] the Transvaal, Natal Indians will see that the campaign has been made much easier by the auctioning of goods.
('9', 63, 2, 30, 148657) If hawkers really hold out against the Government, they can
('9', 64, 0, 1, 148717) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 65
('9', 64, 1, 2, 148757) compel it to yield.
('9', 64, 1, 3, 148777) That is why true poverty means true wealth.
('9', 64, 1, 4, 148821) What true poverty is, we shall consider on another occasion.
('9', 64, 1, 5, 148882) For the present, Indians must bear in mind the need to endure the hardships, whatever they be.
('9', 64, 1, 6, 148977) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 15 8 1908
('9', 64, 2, 7, 149019) 43. NEW BILL
('9', 64, 3, 8, 149032) The following Bill has been published in the Transvaal Government Gazette of August 11: 1
('9', 64, 4, 9, 149122) BILL TO VALIDATE VOLUNTARY REGISTRATION OF CERTAIN ASIATICS WHO FAILED TO COMPLY WITH PROVISIONS OF ASIATIC LAW AMENDMENT ACT, 1907
('9', 64, 5, 10, 149254) 1. Every person (a) who is an Asiatic as defined by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act [2 of] 1907; and (b) by whom an application for such voluntary registration as aforesaid was on the tenth day of February [1908], or on any day subsequent thereto up till the tenth day of May 1908, made to the Registrar of Asiatics or other duly authorized officials; and (c) to whom a certificate in the form set forth in the Schedule to this Act was issued by such Registrar shall be deemed to be the lawful holder of a certificate entitling him to enter and reside in the Colony.
('9', 64, 5, 11, 149819) 2. Every Asiatic as is described in section l who enters or is residing in this Colony shall, upon demand made upon him by any member of the police force or by any other official authorized thereto, shall producehis certificate [of registration] and shall also on like demand supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification as the Colonial Secretary may by notice in the Gazette prescribe.
('9', 64, 5, 12, 150226) Any Asiatic who fails to produce [such certificate] shall be liable to be dealt with under Act 2 of 1907the obnoxious Actin the manner provided by section 8 thereof.
('9', 64, 5, 13, 150392) Any Asiatic who fails to supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification as may be prescribed shall be liable to a fine not exceeding 10, or in default of payment, to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a
('9', 64, 6, 14, 150623) 1 The translation has been collated with the English text of the Act found in Indian Opinion, 5 9 1908.
('9', 65, 0, 1, 150727) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 65, 1, 2, 150768) period not exceeding 14 days.
('9', 65, 1, 3, 150798) 3. Any person who has lost his certificate shall apply to the Registrar for a new certificate and supply him such particulars and furnish such means of identification as may be prescribed.
('9', 65, 1, 4, 150987) Any person into whose hands shall have come any such certificate shall, unless he is the person to whom it was issued, forthwith deliver or transmit the same as soon as may be to the Registrar of Asiatics, failing which he shall be liable to a fine not exceeding 50 or in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding 14 days.
('9', 65, 1, 5, 151358) 4. No Asiatic shall obtain any trading licence under the Revenue Licences Ordinance of 1905, unless he is the [lawful] holder of a certificate [of registration] issued under the Asiatic [Law] Amendment Act of 1907 or under section 1 of this Act and supplies such particulars and furnishes such means of identification as the Colonial Secretary may prescribe.
('9', 65, 1, 6, 151717) Any [trading] licence issued .
('9', 65, 1, 7, 151748) 5. Any person who forges or attempts to forge any document in the form set forth in the Schedule to this Act, or aids another person in doing the same shall be liable to a fine not exceeding 500 or in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding two years, or both.
('9', 65, 1, 8, 152059) 6. This Act shall be known as the Asitic Voluntary Registration Validation Act 1, and shall not come into force till such time as it receives Royal assent and such assent is notified in the Gazette.
('9', 65, 1, 9, 152258) The registration certificate under this Act requires the following particulars: name, race, description, name of wife, place of residence, right thumb impression, Registrars signature, date and signature of the person to whom the certificate is issued; in the case of a child under sixteen or a ward, the name, age, address and relationship to the guardian.

('9', 66, 1, 2, 152935) 44. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING 1
('9', 66, 2, 3, 152964) [JOHANNESBURG, August 16, 1908]
('9', 66, 3, 4, 152996) Last Sunday [August 16] afternoon witnessed such a scene as, it is to be hoped, may never need to be re enacted in this country.
('9', 66, 3, 5, 153125) Some three thousand British Indians gathered together purposefully.
('9', 66, 3, 6, 153193) intent only upon consigning [the registration certificates] to the flames.
('9', 66, 3, 7, 153268) .The whole of the space looking westwards from the Fordsburg Mosque within the fence was packed with members of the Indian community.
('9', 66, 3, 8, 153402) It was a wonderful display of national unity, and one that the mother country might well be proud of....
('9', 66, 4, 9, 153507) On the platform were the Congress leaders.
('9', 66, 4, 10, 153550) various prominent Transvaal Indians .
('9', 66, 4, 11, 153588) Mr. Leung Quinn, Chairman of the Chinese Association, and Mr. Gandhi .
('9', 66, 4, 12, 153659) Mr. Essop Ismail Mia presided over this vast gathering.
('9', 66, 4, 13, 153715) beyond that, a sea of upturned and expectant faces, with determination and a bitter merriment stamped deep.
('9', 66, 4, 14, 153823) In the front row a dozen representative Chinese leaders grimly sat, awaiting the fateful moment.
('9', 66, 4, 15, 153920) Briefly, the Chairman, first in Gujarati, and then, through the medium of Mr. N.A. Cama, detailed in measured accents the reason for calling the meeting together .
('9', 66, 4, 16, 154084) Then Mr. Gandhi addressed the gathering, after which the voluntary registration certificates were thrown into a large cauldron, saturated with paraffin, and set ablaze by Mr. Essop Mia in the name of the community.
('9', 66, 4, 17, 154299) 2 Mr. S. Haloo who, it will be remembered, registered under the Act, now publicly burnt his badge of slavery, and poured oil upon the flames.
('9', 66, 5, 18, 154441) MR. GANDHIS SPEECH

('9', 66, 6, 20, 154550) I have been taken to task, in connection with the advice that I have been giving to my fellow countrymen for some length of time, by friends.
('9', 66, 6, 21, 154692) I have been ridiculed by those who do not profess to be friends, and, yet, after due consideration, and, shall I say,

('9', 67, 0, 1, 155660) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 67, 1, 2, 155701) prayer also, the advice that I ventured to give to my fellow country men 1 am going to repeat this afternoon, and that advice is that, as events have taken the turn that you know in connection with our struggle, we must burn our certificates.
('9', 67, 1, 3, 155944) [Applause.] I am told that I may be instrumental in imposing on my countrymen untold suffering because of the advice that I have given, if they follow that advice.
('9', 67, 1, 4, 156108) I know that well, but I do know this also, that, if the burning of the certificates will impose untold suffering on you, the keeping of these certificates and submission to the Asiatic Act or to the Validation Bill that is to be read a second time tomorrow will impose on my country men untold indignity, and I say with the greatest emphasis at my command that I would far rather that my countrymen suffered all they have to suffer than that they imposed on themselves indignity.
('9', 67, 1, 5, 156588) Further, my countrymen here in the Transvaal have taken a solemn oath not to submit to the Asiatic Act.
('9', 67, 1, 6, 156692) The solemn oath was taken not merely to be fulfilled to the letter but in spirit also, and if you were so ill advised by me, or by anybody else, that you may accept the Voluntary Asiatic Registration Validation Bill and flatter yourselves with the belief that you have escaped the Asiatic Act, I should call myself a traitor to my countrymen, a traitor to God, a traitor to my oath.
('9', 67, 1, 7, 157075) I shall do no such thing, no matter what suffering may be imposed on you by reason of burning your certificates, but, if you do burn your certificates, please bear in mind that you are not to take advantage of the certificates at any time whatsoever until a proper and just and honourable settlement has been arrived at.
('9', 67, 1, 8, 157396) It is open to you to take copies tomorrow of the certificates that may be burned to ashes today by paying 5 s, I dare say that the Government will give you copies of these certificates even free of charge because the Bill has not yet become law, but, if there is any Indian in this vast assemblage who wants to take out a copy of that certificate, and today wishes to burn the certificate either out of shame or false modesty or any other reason of a similar nature, then I say emphatically let him step forward and say he does not want his certificate to be burned, but if it is your solemn resolution that you will not go to the Government to ask for a copy of the certificate, then I say, you have well done.
('9', 67, 1, 9, 158108) Before this resolution was arrived at at the Committee meeting of the British Indian Association, you had already sent to gaol several Indians.
('9', 67, 1, 10, 158252) Mr. Sorabjee, all honour to him, came from Charlestown to fight your battle.
('9', 67, 1, 11, 158329) hear !) Several Indians, humble folks amongst us, went to Johannesburg Fort in order that they might serve their countrymen, in order that their suffering might appeal to the Government, in order that we might be able to live in this Colony with self respect and dignity.
('9', 67, 1, 12, 158601) Does it behove any of us to keep the voluntary registration
('9', 68, 0, 1, 158661) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 69
('9', 68, 1, 2, 158701) certificates, to sit tight on those certificates, and allow our poorer countrymen or those of our countrymen who happened to enter the country after the expiry of the three months to go to gaol or to expect them to accept the Asiatic Act?
('9', 68, 1, 3, 158940) I say emphatically, no.
('9', 68, 1, 4, 158964) I did not come out of the gaol before my time was up in order that I might leave the hardships that I was suffering therepersonally, I was not undergoing any hardships whatever.
('9', 68, 1, 5, 159142) It would be a far greater hardship to me to have to submit to indignity or to see a fellow countryman trampled underfoot or his bread, to which he is justly entitled, taken away from him.
('9', 68, 1, 6, 159330) I would pass the whole of my lifetime in gaol, and I say that in the House of God, in the House of Prayer, and I repeat it that I would far rather pass the whole of my lifetime in gaol and be perfectly happy than see my fellow countrymen subjected to indignity and I should come out of the gaol.
('9', 68, 1, 7, 159626) No, gentlemen, the servant who stands before you this afternoon is not made of that stuff, and it is because I ask you to suffer everything that may be necessary than break your oath, it is because I expect this of my country men, that they will be, above all, true to their God, that I ask you this afternoon to burn all these certificates.
('9', 68, 1, 8, 159968) (Cries of we are ready to burn them.) I have been told that the statement I have made lately with reference to the position of British Indians in this Colony has been misconstrued.
('9', 68, 1, 9, 160149) I have read some remarks that have been passed upon that statement, and it is this: that I claim that this country belongs to British Indians just as much as it belongs to the Europeansand I claim that claim, but what does that claim mean?
('9', 68, 1, 10, 160389) I do not, therefore, mean that it is open to us to have an unchecked influx of Asiatics into this country.
('9', 68, 1, 11, 160496) No, I claim to be a Colonist, I claim to have passed a fair measure of my life in this country, and if this country, the welfare of this country, demands that Asiatic immigration should not proceed unchecked, then I should be the first man to say, let that be so.
('9', 68, 1, 12, 160760) If the majority of the inhabitants of this country demand that Asiatic immigration should ceasemind, I lay stress upon the term immigrationif Asiatic immigration should be under well ordered control, then I say that I should also accept that position, but having accepted that position, I should claim that this country is just as much mine as any other Colonists, and it is in that sense that I put forward that claim on behalf of my countrymen and I say also that it behoves the Colonists to recognize that claim.
('9', 68, 1, 13, 161276) It cannot benefit the Colonists to have British Indians in the Transvaal who are not men but who may be treated as cattle even though it may be showcattle.
('9', 68, 1, 14, 161432) It will not do the Colonists any good, it will not do British Indians any good, and if that is the position that the Colonists or the British Indians take in this Colony, it will be far better that Indians are hunted out of this Colony and sent to
('9', 69, 0, 1, 161680) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 69, 1, 2, 161721) India to carry their tale of woe to India rather than that they should remain in this Colony in the most humiliating position.
('9', 69, 1, 3, 161848) It is in that sense that I claim that this country is just as much the British Indians as it is the Europeans.
('9', 69, 1, 4, 161959) What is this fight that we are engaged upon?
('9', 69, 1, 5, 162004) What is its significance?
('9', 69, 1, 6, 162030) To my mind, its significance did not commence with a demand for the repeal of the Asiatic Act, nor does it end with the repeal of the Asiatic Act.
('9', 69, 1, 7, 162177) I know full well that it is open to the Government of the Colony to give a repeal of this legislation today, to throw dust into our eyes and then embark upon other legislation, far harsher, far more humiliating, but the lesson that I wanted to learn myself, the lesson I would have my countrymen to learn from this struggle is this: that unenfran chised though we are, unrepresented though we are in the Transvaal, it is open to us to clothe ourselves with an undying franchise, and this consists in recognizing our humanity, in recognizing that we are part and parcel of the great universal whole, that there is the Maker of us all ruling over the destinies of mankind and that our trust should be in Him rather than in earthly kings, and if my countrymen recognize that position I say that no matter what legislation is passed over our heads, if that legislation is in conflict with our ideas of right and wrong, if it is in conflict with our conscience, if it is in conflict with our religion, then we can say we shall not submit to that legislation.
('9', 69, 1, 8, 163231) We use no physical force, but we accept the sanction that the legislature provides, we accept the penalties that the legislature provides.
('9', 69, 1, 9, 163370) I refuse to call this defiance, but I consider that it is a perfectly respectful attitude, for a man, for a human being who calls himself man.
('9', 69, 1, 10, 163513) And it is because it was necessary that British Indians should learn that lesson that the heads of the community gathered together and assembled together and said to themselves that this is the struggle, this is the method of struggle that they would place before their countrymen.
('9', 69, 1, 11, 163795) It can do no harm whatsoever to the Government of the Colony, it can do no harm to those who are engaged in this struggle; it simply tests them and, if they are true, then they can only win; if they are not true, then they simply get what they deserve.
('9', 69, 1, 12, 164048) One thing more and I shall soon ask you whether you propose that Mr. Essop Mia, your Chairman, should set fire to these registration certificates; and it is this: I have been hitherto refraining from making any personal attack whatsoever.
('9', 69, 1, 13, 164287) I did make a slight attack at the time of the trial of Ram Sundar, and that was in connection with the head of the Registration Department, Mr. Chamney.
('9', 69, 1, 14, 164440) 1 I feel bound in the inter ests of the Colonists, in the interests of the Indian community, and for the honour of the Colony,

('9', 70, 1, 13, 166510) He not only listened to the promise made by General Smuts as to the repeal of the Act, but he repeated that promise to me; he mentioned that promise to me, if once, twelve times, and each time he said that General Smuts was going to play the game, that he was going to repeal the Act.
('9', 70, 1, 14, 166795) There was once an occasion when I believe there was a fellow countryman of mine in my company and he said, But remember that General Smuts also said that so long as there is a single Asiatic in the Colony who has not made a voluntary registration application that Act will be enforced against him.
('9', 70, 1, 15, 167093) Today the position is that there is no Asiatic, so far as I know, none to talk of, who has not made his application for voluntary registration.
('9', 70, 1, 16, 167237) I now ask

('9', 73, 1, 2, 170983) 46. LETTER TO E. F.C. LANE 1
('9', 73, 2, 3, 171012) PRIVATE JOHANNESBURG, August 20, 1908
('9', 73, 3, 4, 171050) DEAR MR. LANE, Mr. Cartwright told me that I should write to you what I told
('9', 73, 4, 5, 171127) 1 This letter was published with the following introduction: Owing to the manner in which the Transvaal Colonial Secretary made public use of a private letter in such a way as to induce in the minds of members of the Assembly a belief that the Indian community had forwarded an ultimatum on the question of a settlement, Mr. Gandhi, in his speech last Sunday, explained the circumstances fully.
('9', 73, 4, 6, 171522) In view of General Smuts breach of etiquette, we publish below the full text of Mr. Gandhis letter, of which unauthorized extracts have already appeared. Writing of these events from Yeravda jail some 15 years later, Gandhiji perhaps mistook his letter of August 14, 1908 to General Smuts (Letter to General Smuts, 14 8 1908) for this letter, and the mass meeting of August 16 (Speech at Mass Meeting, 16 8 1908) for that held on August 23 (Speech at Mass Meeting, 23 8 1908).
('9', 73, 4, 7, 171999) The following excerpts from Chapters XXVI and XXVII of Satyagraha in South Africa compared with extracts from contemporary statements or reports (in square brackets below), may throw some light on the genesis of this confusion.

('9', 76, 5, 10, 179901) 47. SPEECH AT CLOSER UNION SOCIETY
('9', 76, 6, 11, 179936) [JOHANNESBURG, August 20, 1908]
('9', 76, 7, 12, 179968) The first meeting of the Transvaal Closer Union Society was held in the Congre gational Church Hall, Bree Street, last night [August 20], Mr. Edward Nathan presiding.
('9', 76, 7, 13, 180135) The subject of debate was The Asiatic Question in Relation to Closer Union, Mr. Alfred Barkers papers, which appeared in the Leader on Monday and Tuesday last, forming the basis of discussion.
('9', 76, 8, 14, 180328) After Mr. Barker had read his papers, Mr. M. K. Gandhi said he thought it was com mon ground between both Europeans and Asiatics in South Africa that Asiatic immigration should be controlled or restricted, and it was so controlled or restricted.
('9', 76, 8, 15, 180574) In the Gape Colony and in Natal there was a law with this object, and in the Transvaal, too, there was a closed door.
('9', 76, 8, 16, 180692) Rhodesia had already an Immigration Restriction Law, and her legislators were now endeavouring to place an Asiatic Registration law on the Statute book.
('9', 76, 8, 17, 180845) 1 Personally, he did not think they needed that law at all; they had achieved their object by passing the immigration law.
('9', 76, 8, 18, 180968) That narrowed the question down very materially, and one had now to consider the effect of the residence of Asiatics on Closer Union, and not the effect of the immigration of Asiatics.
('9', 76, 9, 19, 181153) THE IMMIGRATION LAW
('9', 76, 10, 20, 181173) The immigration law of the Cape and of Natal allowed the entry of Asiatics who could pass the same education test that was imposed on others who might enter the country.
('9', 76, 10, 21, 181343) The object of that legislation was principally to guard against the influx of Asiatics.
('9', 76, 10, 22, 181431) In 1896, the late Mr. Escombe first approached Mr. Chamberlain for
('9', 76, 11, 23, 181498) 1 Vide Rhodesia Indians, 30 5 1908; 4 7 1908.
('9', 77, 0, 1, 181544) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 77, 1, 2, 181585) permis sion to pass an Asiatic Exclusion Bill, and Mr. Chamberlain laid down the policy, for the guidance of all the Colonies, that the basis of distinction should not be colour, but education or some such qualification.
('9', 77, 1, 3, 181806) That policy had been hitherto followed.
('9', 77, 1, 4, 181846) At the Conference of Prime Ministers, Mr. Chamberlain placed that view before them for their acceptance.
('9', 77, 1, 5, 181951) Very few Asiatics had been able to enter Natal under the education test, not because India did not possess a large number of educated Indians, but because the educated Asiatics had ample scope for their abilities in India, China, and Japan; but there were some who undoubtedly must follow the traders, hawkers, and other classes of Asiatics.
('9', 77, 1, 6, 182293) If they could not come to South Africa, and if the door was effectually shut even against them, the solution of the question would be far more difficult than it would otherwise be.
('9', 77, 1, 7, 182474) If it were admitted that those Asiatics who had been domiciled in South Africa should remain in South Africa and should obtain fair treatment, it was natural that those who could lead them and who could act as interpreters between the races must also be allowed to come.
('9', 77, 1, 8, 182745) What was to be the position of those Asiatics who were allowed to remain in South Africa?
('9', 77, 1, 9, 182835) The people who had settled in South Africa had laid down certain conditions under which the nation that was now forming had to live.
('9', 77, 1, 10, 182968) Was it possible, then, to eradicate from ones mind the problem of Asiatic residence?
('9', 77, 1, 11, 183053) It was a very interesting and instructive study; but it passed his comprehension that in all the papers he had read from the pens of those who had made South Africa their home they had never taken into consideration what the feelings of the Asiatics or of the Natives themselves might be.
('9', 77, 1, 12, 183342) What would they have to say to any solution that was suggested for their acceptance?
('9', 77, 1, 13, 183427) Was it suggested that the Asiatics or the Coloured races must perforce accept any solution which was found for their treatment by the predominant racethe European race?
('9', 77, 1, 14, 183596) He ventured to suggest that if they ever adopted that policy it was doomed to failure.
('9', 77, 1, 15, 183683) It was possible, perhaps, for one, two, or three years to follow a policy of that nature; but he was certain they would find that both the Asiatics and the Natives would demand to be consulted with reference to their disposition.
('9', 77, 1, 16, 183913) It was impossible to conceive that those races would ever allow the predominant race to dispose of them just as they chose.
('9', 77, 2, 17, 184037) INDENTURED LABOUR
('9', 77, 3, 18, 184055) Mr. Barker had first of all discussed the question of indentured immigration.
('9', 77, 3, 19, 184133) The speaker observed: There we are absolutely on common ground.
('9', 77, 3, 20, 184197) I have said in season and out of season, whenever I have had the opportunity, that it is undoubtedly the introduction of indentured labour into Natal that has made the Asiatic question in South Africa possible at all.
('9', 77, 3, 21, 184415) It was the introduction of indentured labour that was followed by free emigration of Asiatics from India.
('9', 77, 3, 22, 184521) It was because Natal committed a very serious blunder in admitting indentured labour that posterity has to suffer, if it has to suffer.
('9', 77, 3, 23, 184657) But the solution does not lie in compulsory repatriation.
('9', 77, 3, 24, 184715) To my mind, it offends the feelings of
('9', 78, 0, 1, 184754) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 79
('9', 78, 1, 2, 184794) humanity to suggest that a body of people should be allowed to enter a particular Colony to which they should give the best years of their then be sent back to a place which has become comparatively strange to them.
('9', 78, 1, 3, 185010) The people who have been invited to go to Natal under indenture are drawn from the poorer classes.
('9', 78, 1, 4, 185109) They break off all connection with India when they emigrate to Natal.
('9', 78, 1, 5, 185179) They are told that they will have all comforts and convenience; they believe that they will be able to pass their time in comparative ease, that they will be able, after slaving away for the Colonies for five years, to work for themselves independently.
('9', 78, 1, 6, 185433) If those men were invited, or were even told in India that at the end of five years they should go back to India, it is possible that they, not knowing the conditions, might accept those conditions, but I do not call that an equitable contract.
('9', 78, 1, 7, 185678) If those men, knowing the conditions, came to Natal, I would even suggest that it would be inhuman to expect them to go back, or to repatriate them.
('9', 78, 2, 8, 185827) FOR THE PLANTERS BENEFIT
('9', 78, 3, 9, 185852) The better policy would be to stop indentured labour entirely; and three years should be the period fixed.
('9', 78, 3, 10, 185959) If I were an autocrat in Natal, I would fix not even three years, but stop it entirely.
('9', 78, 3, 11, 186047) This kind of labour has not done any good whatsoever to the Indians who have emigrated under those conditions to Natal, or to the Colonies themselves.
('9', 78, 3, 12, 186198) It has undoubt edly benefited a few planters but they have benefited at the expense of the Colonists, and in the Colonists I venture to include my own countrymen also.
('9', 78, 3, 13, 186366) If the Colony persists in that policy, I should admire General Smuts or anyone else using the steamroller 1 (Laughter.) and compelling Natal to stop indentured immigration.
('9', 78, 3, 14, 186539) That is a question of practical politics, a question of humanity, and a question upon which you will have a consen sus of opinion not only among Europeans, but you will have every assis tance possible from the Indians themselves.
('9', 78, 3, 15, 186769) The question of traders who are domiciled in South Africa and the question of industrial Indians who have risen to the training point become comparatively easy of solution.
('9', 78, 3, 16, 186942) The bugbear of an Asiatic influence will then have vanished.
('9', 78, 4, 17, 187003) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi alluded to Mr. Barkers proposal to confine Asiatic traders to Bazaars, and maintained that that would not solve the difficulty.
('9', 78, 4, 18, 187154) If the Asiatics would not consent to have their trading activity thus restricted, what remedy could Mr. Barker suggest?
('9', 78, 4, 19, 187274) He was certain that the people of South Africa had no desire to treat British Indians as if they were less than human beings.
('9', 78, 4, 20, 187400) They must take the Indians into their confidence.
('9', 78, 4, 21, 187450) As to the franchise, personally he did not wish to
('9', 78, 5, 22, 187501) 1 The allusion is presumably to the cartoons.
('9', 79, 0, 1, 187547) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 79, 1, 2, 187588) receive it until the barrier of prejudice was broken down.
('9', 79, 1, 3, 187647) The solution of the difficulty, to his mind, lay in the fact that the Indians should first of all be recognized as human beings, as fellow subjects.
('9', 79, 1, 4, 187796) Europeans should consider it their duty to raise those men and not level them down.
('9', 79, 1, 5, 187880) (Applause.) It was not fair to treat South Africa as a white South Africa.
('9', 79, 1, 6, 187955) There could be no question of segregation or restriction of their trading activities if they were to be treated as a Christian nation would treat them.
('9', 79, 1, 7, 188107) The only solution was the one he had suggested.

('9', 80, 0, 1, 189757) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 81
('9', 80, 1, 2, 189797) 49. INTERVIEW TO THE TRANSVAAL LEADER
('9', 80, 2, 3, 189835) [JOHANNESBURG, Before August 21, 1908] 1
('9', 80, 3, 4, 189876) There is a great deal of misunderstanding regarding the Indian position on the question of the admission of educated Indians.
('9', 80, 3, 5, 190002) We contend that the Immigrants Restriction Law, as it stands, does not debar educated Indians from entering the country, but nothing can be further from the Indian thought[sic] than that hundreds of Indian youth should be able to come into the country.
('9', 80, 3, 6, 190255) All that we want is that the colour of the skin should not act as a bar sinister, and that professional Indians, who are necessarily required for the organic growth of the community, should be allowed to enter.
('9', 80, 3, 7, 190466) This may not be even at the rate of one per year, because there will be no scope for many such men.
('9', 80, 3, 8, 190566) They certainly cannot compete in trade, and, after all is said and done, the Asiatic question is very largely a trade question.
('9', 80, 3, 9, 190694) What is, however, lost sight of is that it is not the Indians who have raised the education question, but it is General Smuts who wishes them to accept his reading of the law.
('9', 80, 3, 10, 190870) He does not care to consult Indians when he wishes to pass any offensive legislation concer ning them, but when it is a matter of fulfilling the Governments part of the compromise he, in effect, says, I shall fulfil the compromise if you accept this additional disability in the shape of a prohibition of the entry of educated Indians, no matter what their qualifications may be. It is quite open to him to fulfil the promise of repeal of the Act, and at the same time in disregard of our sentiments to bring in the educational disqualification, and we will fight that question on its own merits.
('9', 80, 3, 11, 191467) He has not consulted us with reference to the present Bill, which, to my mind, is a breach of the compromise on the part of the government, and yet he refuses to pass a Bill which he had actually drafted repealing the Act because we object to a clause in it which, among others, disqualifies educated Indians.

('9', 81, 1, 2, 192159) 50. INTERVIEW TO THE STAR 1
('9', 81, 2, 3, 192187) [JOHANNESBURG, August 21, 1908]
('9', 81, 3, 4, 192219) The Asiatic community of the Transvaal will not accept the new Bill concerning voluntary registration introduced by the Colonial Secretary yesterday.
('9', 81, 3, 5, 192369) Passive resistance must, therefore, continue.
('9', 81, 3, 6, 192415) This policy was laid down in a statement made by Mr. M. K. Gandhi, the spokesman of the community, in an interview with a representative of The Star today.
('9', 81, 3, 7, 192571) The new Bill, save for two things, would have been considered fairly satisfactory to my countrymen, but the non repeal of the Asiatic Act of 1907 and the absence of provision for highly educated Asiatics to reside in the Transvaal are vital to its acceptance by the Asiatics.
('9', 81, 3, 8, 192847) The question of the repeal is a very important one from the Indians standpoint.
('9', 81, 3, 9, 192927) They claim that repeal was promised and that a point of honour should have been granted.
('9', 81, 3, 10, 193016) As a question of practical politics, having studied the new Bill, I can see no reason for keeping on the Statute book the Asiatic Act as a perfect dead letter.
('9', 81, 3, 11, 193176) It will give rise to many a humorous situation.
('9', 81, 3, 12, 193224) If my reading of the Bill is correct, an Asiatic has the option of applying under the old Act or under the new Bill.
('9', 81, 3, 13, 193341) If he wishes to take advantageif advantage it beof the old Act and enter the Colony before making his application, no one can prevent him.
('9', 81, 3, 14, 193480) But under the new Bill he cannot apply for registration except from a place outside the Transvaal in South Africa.
('9', 81, 3, 15, 193595) This strikes me as being ludicrous, and it opens the door to fraudulent practices which all parties want to prevent.
('9', 81, 4, 16, 193712) A SUPREME QUESTION
('9', 81, 5, 17, 193731) The question of the introduction of highly educated Indians is also of supreme importance to us but, as far as I can see, of none to the Europeans.
('9', 81, 5, 18, 193879) It must not be forgotten that British Indians were absolutely free to enter the Colony before the war.
('9', 81, 5, 19, 193982) After the war the entry of educated Asiatics was not prohibited, but they were subject to the Peace Preservation Ordinance just as any European was.
('9', 81, 5, 20, 194131) The Asiatic Act of 1907 dealt only with domiciled Asiatics.
('9', 81, 5, 21, 194191) It did not regulate Asiatic immigration, as General Smuts himself admitted.
('9', 81, 5, 22, 194267) The Immigration Act does not, even now, prohibit the entry of Asiatics who can pass the education test.
('9', 81, 5, 23, 194371) Prohibition, therefore, has been
('9', 81, 6, 24, 194404) 1 This was republished in Indian Opinion under the title No Surrender and the sub titles The Asiatic Attitude: Submission, Not Ultimatum: Passive Resistance to Continue.
('9', 82, 0, 1, 194574) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 83
('9', 82, 1, 2, 194614) brought about by the presence of the Asiatic Act to which British Indians will not submit.
('9', 82, 1, 3, 194705) Surely then if we are restricting ourselves to the entry of highly educated Indians, it is we who give up something and not the legislature that will give us a new privilege.
('9', 82, 1, 4, 194880) It is, therefore, prepos terous to say that we are setting forth a new demand.
('9', 82, 1, 5, 194959) The other points, in what has been called the Asiatic Ultimatum 1, and what I would call the Asiatic submission, are really not matters of law but of adminis trative act.
('9', 82, 1, 6, 195130) The recall of Sorabjee, we have humbly maintained, is a matter on which the Government should have yielded.
('9', 82, 1, 7, 195238) The other points are too insignificant to be dealt with.
('9', 82, 1, 8, 195295) All I feel is that for these small matters an otherwise admirable Bill will be wrecked, so far as I can judge.
('9', 82, 1, 9, 195406) My countrymen will not accept the benefit of the provisions of the new Bill until the wrong I have referred to has been redressed and passive resistance will, therefore, unfortunately, have to go on.
('9', 82, 1, 10, 195606) I have been advised not to lead the passive resistance trouble, but I cannot possibly as one who prefers, or tries to prefer, his conscience to everything else accept the advice, no matter what the consequences may be.
('9', 82, 1, 11, 195825) Indian Opinion, 29 8 1908
('9', 82, 2, 12, 195851) 51. INTERVIEW TO THE TRANSVAAL LEADER
('9', 82, 3, 13, 195889) [JOHANNESBURG, August 21, 1908]
('9', 82, 4, 14, 195921) Interviewed yesterday [August 21] in regard to the new Bill, Mr. Gandhi said: The Bill, I must admit, is a vast improvement on the Validating Bill, which would undoubtedly have been a violation of almost all the terms of the compromise.
('9', 82, 4, 15, 196158) It embodies, from a cursory glance at the summary published in The Star, the points which were discussed at the interview with the meeting of Het Volk and Progressive leaders.
('9', 82, 4, 16, 196334) 1 am afraid, however, that it falls short of the terms proposed by the Asiatic Conference.
('9', 82, 4, 17, 196425) It is a most unfortunate thing that the Government have not seen their way to grant the very limited concessions asked for by the Conference namely, repeal of the Asiatic Amendment Act, and admission of highly educated Indians.
('9', 82, 4, 18, 196653) The two points are most important for British Indians, but in my opinion of little importance from the Colonists standpoint.
('9', 82, 4, 19, 196778) Personally, knowing the law and its effect, I could reconcile myself to the present Bill standing side by
('9', 82, 5, 20, 196884) 1 Vide Letter to General Smuts, 14 8 1908 Letter to E.F.C. Lane, 20 8 1908 and 1st footnote of Letter to E.F.C. Lane, 20 8 1908.
('9', 83, 0, 1, 197013) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 83, 1, 2, 197054) side with the Asiatic Act of 1907 as a mere dead letter, but my countrymen cannot understand the intricate distinction.
('9', 83, 1, 3, 197174) To them no law is a dead letter, and the fervour with which they spoke on the point at the Conference on Thursday last demonstrated to me the depth of feeling regarding the Bill.
('9', 83, 1, 4, 197353) When, therefore, we offer that the essential clauses of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act so far as they might be necessary for a proper check on the Asiatic population might be re enacted, I certainly cannot see any reason for not granting the repeal of the Act.
('9', 83, 1, 5, 197613) It is true that as there has been so much controversy over the Act the Colonists may demand its retention on the Statute book with just as much pressure as my countrymen demand its repeal, but the representatives of the European Colonists are enlightened enough to see without difficulty that, if the purposes of the Colony can be served equally well by repeal of the Act, they should have no objection to such repeal.
('9', 83, 1, 6, 198032) The question of recognizing the rights of highly educated Indians is also equally simple.
('9', 83, 1, 7, 198122) There is no demand for an unrestricted influx even of educated Indians.
('9', 83, 1, 8, 198194) British Indians think that fullest discretionary powers should be reserved to the Colonial Secretary as to the administration of the Act, but do say, and I think with perfect justice, that between Europeans and Asiatics of high attainments there should be no distinction.
('9', 83, 1, 9, 198466) It would be a thousand pities to wreck an otherwise good Bill and to keep up Asiatic discontent for the sake of these minor points.
('9', 83, 1, 10, 198598) The other matters are really matters of detail and not touching the Bill itself.
('9', 83, 1, 11, 198679) It would be, in my opinion, highly unjust to expect my countrymen to sacrifice Mr. Sorabji, who has suffered for his country, but the Government have made it a matter of principle that Mr. Sorabji, having entered in defiance of the law, should suffer the penalty.
('9', 83, 1, 12, 198943) He has suffered the penalty by being imprisoned for a month, butto follow it up with a deportationif Mr. Sorabji should be sent out of the country because he was under a removal order, so was I and many another Indian, but the Government have been pleased not to touch us.
('9', 83, 1, 13, 199216) I notice a statement to the effect that we are daily growing more and more impudent in our requests.
('9', 83, 1, 14, 199317) This is rather a nice way of emphasizing what is contrary to fact.
('9', 83, 1, 15, 199384) The request for repeal of the Act is as old as the Act itself, and if I personally was prepared to place before my countrymen the question of another Bill provided that the Act became a dead letter, surely that cannot be described as impudent; for my countrymens rejection of any such proposal was in that they have all through fought for repeal of the Act.
('9', 83, 1, 16, 199742) A general education test
('9', 84, 0, 1, 199767) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 85
('9', 84, 1, 2, 199807) has become necessary, because of the interpretation placed upon the Immigration Restriction Act by the Colonial Secretary, and he knows well that repeal of the Asiatic Act makes the entry of educated Indians perfectly possible under the Immigrants Restriction Act.
('9', 84, 1, 3, 200072) I therefore fail to see any impudence at all.
('9', 84, 1, 4, 200118) On the con trary, I make bold to say that the legislature have first of all stripped us naked, and then propose to dole out what they call concessions little by little, still refusing to return what to us is the main thing, and then exclaim, How magnanimous! If, therefore, the very moderate request of my country[men] is not embodied in the new Bill, I very much fear, though I am very sorry, that the passive resistance will be resumed.
('9', 84, 1, 5, 200557) General Smuts calls it a state of anarchy, lawlessness, and a declaration of war.
('9', 84, 1, 6, 200639) 1 We call it a state of suffering, and pray to our Maker, our reliance being entirely on Him.
('9', 84, 1, 7, 200733) It is indeed a declaration of war on the part of General Smuts against British Indians.

('9', 85, 2, 3, 202198) [JOHANNESBURG, August 23, 1908]
('9', 85, 3, 4, 202230) Last Sunday [August 23], unfortunately, as the Chairman of the Association sorrow fully remarked, found it necessary to hold another large Mass Meeting of protest.
('9', 85, 3, 5, 202394) The members, if anything, exceeded those of the crowd that massed within the Mosque grounds the week before.
('9', 85, 3, 6, 202503) General Smuts had brought forward his new Bill, but as it did not repeal the Asiatic Act, and as it made no provision for the freedom and rights of highly educated Asiatics, it was not possible to accept the new measure.
('9', 85, 3, 7, 202724) Hence Sundays Meeting.
('9', 85, 3, 8, 202747) A dramatic note was struck when the Pathan leaders admitted their previous errors 2 and declared their intentions of joining the fight until the end.
('9', 85, 3, 9, 202897) Amongst those present who gave encouragement to the people, were the Durban leaders, anxious only for the time when they should be summoned before the Court to pay the penalty of their patriotism ...
('9', 85, 3, 10, 203097) It is only necessary to add that the meeting broke up when some 525 more certificates had been consigned to the flames amidst loud cheers, Mr. S. Haloo and Mr. U.M. Shelat assuming the role of stokers....

('9', 86, 1, 3, 204902) It required the incarceration of over 200 Indians before we could gain the admission from General Smuts that his law was bad, that it was unworkable, and that it would be removed from the Statute book.
('9', 86, 1, 4, 205104) It again required the incarceration of nearly 100 Indians before we could gain what we have through the Validation Bill, and I have no hesitation in making this admission, that the Validation Bill, is a vast improvement on the old Asiatic Act, much of the irritating clauses have been removed, the great religious objection has been removed, our oath has been preserved, and, for this, all honour to the Government, all honour to the Progrcssive Party, and I am now in a position to tell my countrymen, that if they do not choose to fight for a principle but if they have wished to demonstrate to the world that they were fighting only that they might be able to keep their solemn obligation but not that they might be able to keep their own status in the country, I can freely advise them to accept the Validation Act, but if it is their desire, as I hope it ever was their desire, that we have undertaken this battle not merely for our personal benefits, but in order to fight for a principle or a bundle of principles, then I have no hesitation in asking my countrymen to undergo further suffering, but, whether they do so or not in a body, whether the majority of the Asiatics choose to accept the benefits that the Government have so liberally given, as they put it, it is open to them to do so; but so long as I remain in this country, it is my desire to oppose the measures of the Government until we get the redress to which we are entitled, until the promise that I still declare General Smuts made in connection with the repeal of the Act is fulfilled, and until the status of highly educated Asiatics is placed on a firm footing.
('9', 86, 1, 5, 206745) These are no new demands.
('9', 86, 1, 6, 206771) The Colonists or the Government, by giving us a little, inch by inch, make the Colonists believe that they are conceding what they need not have conceded, but I deny that position absolutely.
('9', 86, 1, 7, 206963) I take the position that the Chairman has taken, and it is only when these two things have been fulfilled that we shall have got what was our own or what should have been our own.
('9', 86, 1, 8, 207143) I draw your attention to this fact, that General Smuts himself has told us now and told the world that the natives of South Africa, the Zulus and Bantus, get treated the same as the Europeans, if they possess the same educational qualifications as the Europeans, but the poor Indian and the poor Chinaman cannot do that.

('9', 87, 1, 4, 207772) It is quite enough that we consent to the influx from British India being stopped entirely; but the stopping of that influx does not meanit never meantthat educated Indians were to be shut out of this country or that they could enter it only on a permit granted by the Governor in Council and which might be revoked at pleasure.

('9', 87, 1, 13, 209506) I do declare that our fight, my fight, has always been for a principle, and it shall be for a principle.

('9', 90, 3, 4, 214255) SIR, It is wonderful how every demand made by British Indians is being misunderstood.
('9', 90, 3, 5, 214341) When my countrymen recognize that the Bill 2 just passed by the local Parliament is better than the Asiatic Act, they do not admit that their position of serfs is removed.

('9', 90, 3, 14, 215609) It is not only hypocrisy 3 and humbug 4 but downright injustice.
('9', 90, 3, 15, 215674) I, however, see nothing wrong in an Immigration Act which provides against an indiscriminate entry of a class of people, the distinction being based not on their race or colour but on an educational qualification.

('9', 92, 4, 7, 218901) 57. TRIAL OF BHIKHABHAI D. MALIHA 1
('9', 92, 5, 8, 218937) [JOHANNESBURG, August 26, 1908]
('9', 92, 6, 9, 218969) n B Court, Johannesburg, on Wednesday, before Mr. H.H. Jordan, Mr. Bhikhabhai D. Maliha was charged under section 8, sub section 3 of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act No.
('9', 92, 6, 10, 219137) 2 of 1907 for failing to produce a registration certificate issued under the Act on demand.
('9', 92, 6, 11, 219229) Mr. Gandhi defended.
('9', 92, 6, 12, 219250) Superintendent Vernon, who gave evidence as to the arrest, stated that he had arrested the accused on instructions.
('9', 92, 6, 13, 219366) He knew that there were many Indians today in Johannesburg who had permits and old registration certificates, but he was not instructed to take action against them.
('9', 92, 6, 14, 219531) The accused, giving evidence on his own behalf, stated that he was an old resident of the Transvaal and that he had a Peace Preservation Ordinance Permit and a registration certificate under Law 3 of 1885, both of which documents were produced before the Court.
('9', 92, 7, 15, 219793) Addressing the Court, Mr. Gandhi remarked upon the strangeness of the proceedings.
('9', 92, 7, 16, 219876) Here was a man arrested and convicted under the Asiatic Act, whose rights were fully safeguarded under the Act 2 that had just been passed.
('9', 92, 7, 17, 220016) Either the Government intended to stick to their new measure or they did not.
('9', 92, 7, 18, 220094) In view of the delicate relations that existed at the present time he had specially asked that this case should be remanded until next Monday, but whilst the Prosecution was willing to meet him in this, instructions had been received by the latter from Pretoria to proceed.
('9', 92, 7, 19, 220368) It certainly reflected upon Pretoria methods of administration.

('9', 93, 3, 4, 220765) WHAT HAVE WE GAINED THROUGH NEW BILL?
('9', 93, 4, 5, 220803) Again, this time, I will have to discuss the latest news first.
('9', 93, 4, 6, 220867) The new Bill was passed by both the Houses within 24 hours.
('9', 93, 4, 7, 220927) This only shows that they still do not give our feelings due consideration.
('9', 93, 4, 8, 221003) The Bill contains almost everything [we wanted].
('9', 93, 4, 9, 221052) I have no time for a detailed explanation.
('9', 93, 4, 10, 221095) But the Bill obviates the objections regarding the Turkish Muslims.
('9', 93, 4, 11, 221163) Voluntary registrants will not come within the scope of the Act as also others who may [voluntarily] register themselves in future.
('9', 93, 4, 12, 221295) This will enable the community to keep its pledge inviolate.
('9', 93, 4, 13, 221356) But there are two things which the Bill does not contain.
('9', 93, 4, 14, 221414) The obnoxious law will be repealed in effect; but it will remain as a dead letter.
('9', 93, 4, 15, 221497) The Indian community has every right to oppose this [proposal].
('9', 93, 4, 16, 221561) Mr. Smuts made a promise [to repeal it].
('9', 93, 4, 17, 221602) But, what is more important, [the rights of] the educated have not been safeguarded.
('9', 93, 4, 18, 221687) I am afraid that there is going to be a long drawn out struggle over this issue.
('9', 93, 4, 19, 221768) It is the duty of the Indian community to put up a fight.
('9', 93, 5, 20, 221826) WHO SHOULD BE TREATED AS EDUCATED?
('9', 93, 6, 21, 221861) This question is often discussed.
('9', 93, 6, 22, 221895) What the Indian community wants is that all educated persons should have equal rights under the law.
('9', 93, 6, 23, 221996) But though rights may remain equal in theory, Indians may in practice be subjected to a more severe test than the whites.
('9', 93, 6, 24, 222118) This is what happens in Natal and the Cape.
('9', 93, 6, 25, 222162) The test for Indians [in these Colonies] is very severe.
('9', 93, 6, 26, 222219) We have said that we shall not object to an even severer test in the Transvaal.
('9', 93, 6, 27, 222299) In consequence, only barristers and others of equal [attainments] will be able to enter the Transvaal.
('9', 93, 6, 28, 222402) I do not see that we can do anything more.
('9', 93, 6, 29, 222445) What is important is that the educated should not be kept out altogether.
('9', 93, 6, 30, 222519) As for those with a lower standard of education who may want to come in for business or professional reasons, the section which allows them to come in with a temporary permit remains.
('9', 93, 6, 31, 222703) In fact, there is no real difficulty about these persons.
('9', 93, 8, 32, 222761) There is, however, a snag in this Bill.
('9', 93, 8, 33, 222801) Those who enter the Trans vaal henceforth must, if they do not have a permit, prove that they had resided in the Colony for at least three years before the [Boer] War.
('9', 94, 0, 1, 222969) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 95
('9', 94, 1, 2, 223009) This section will also apply to those who are already in the Transvaal.
('9', 94, 1, 3, 223081) I feel it may be possible to find a way out of this.
