('9', 96, 5, 6, 227287) 60. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS2
('9', 96, 6, 7, 227322) [JOHANNESBURG,] August 28, 1908 THE DIRECTOR OF PRISONS PRETORIA
('9', 96, 7, 8, 227387) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant with reference to the diet scale laid down for British Indian prisoners in the Transvaal Gaols.
('9', 96, 7, 9, 227568) My Association begs to point out that a change in the diet scale has been asked for not because the food supplied is medically improper but because it is not suited to the habits of British Indian prisoners.
('9', 96, 7, 10, 227776) My Association, therefore, ventures to submit that it is hardly a question for medical opinion, but it is one for investigating the habits of British Indians as to food.
('9', 96, 7, 11, 227946) My Association admits that mealie meal forms part of the diet scale for Indian prisoners in the Natal gaols, but my Association does not agree with the inference drawn therefrom that mealie meal is suitable for Indian prisoners.
('9', 96, 7, 12, 228175) Happily, throughout South Africa, very few Indians are incarcerated and, therefore, the question of the diet scale has not hitherto occupied the attention of Indian public bodies, but now, in view of the unusual position that has been created in the Transvaal, the question has become one of very great importance, and, unless the authorities intend to disregard Indian habits and sentiments entirely, my Association submits that an investigation in the manner suggested by me is absolutely necessary.
('9', 96, 7, 13, 228677) I venture also to point out to you that you have omitted to mention that the Natal scale, whilst it retains mealie meal as part of the
('9', 97, 0, 1, 228812) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 97, 1, 2, 228853) diet for British Indians, provides for bread also, thus enabling Indians at least to fall back upon four ounces of bread.
('9', 97, 1, 3, 228975) I beg also to point out that, according to the Natal scale, for prisoners undergoing a sentence beyond 42 days, treacle is added to the ration of mealie meal, and that for others the scale is fairly liberal, much more so than the Transvaal scale.
('9', 97, 1, 4, 229222) My Association, therefore, respectfully trusts that the matter will be reconsidered.
('9', 97, 2, 5, 229307) I have the honour to be,
('9', 97, 4, 6, 229332) Your obedient servant, ESSOP ISMAIL MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 12 9 1908

('9', 98, 3, 4, 231014) In its editorial of the 25th instant, Pretoria News writes that, as it had earlier called upon General Smuts to carry out the terms of the compromise, so does it now urge that the Asiatics who have not registered should do so.
('9', 98, 3, 5, 231241) The Government has fulfilled its promise and it is now for the Asiatics also to fulfil theirs.
('9', 98, 3, 6, 231336) It will not be unreasonable [to insist] that the immigration issue should be taken up for consideration after this has been done.
('9', 98, 3, 7, 231466) In another article following this, under the heading Immigration, the paper says that Asiatics are shabbily treated and that it fully sympathizes with them.
('9', 98, 3, 8, 231623) According to existing laws, low class Russians or Poles or other [Europeans] who speak Greek or have a smattering of one of the Levantine languages can enter the country at will and enjoy full citizenship rights.
('9', 98, 3, 9, 231836) For this purpose, Yiddish and European languages are treated on par, though Yiddish is not a European language.
('9', 98, 3, 10, 231948) Justice demands that there should be an equally difficult qualifying test for all those who enter the Colony.
('9', 98, 3, 11, 232058) The officials of the Immigration Department should be armed with wide powers, and they should be persons of intelligence and integrity.
('9', 98, 3, 12, 232194) They should be paid good salaries so that they are not tempted into taking bribes.

('9', 98, 3, 14, 232369) In short, we suggest that the door which is now closed on the Asiatics should be closed lawfully.
('9', 98, 3, 15, 232467) This country cannot accommodate any more Asiatics.
('9', 98, 3, 16, 232518) We wholly agree with this.
('9', 98, 3, 17, 232545) But we go further and assert that some of the Europeans who are entering the country [unlawfully] may prove more dangerous than Asiatics.
('9', 98, 3, 18, 232683) The Asiatics standard of living is very low and they are [thus] able to compete to their advantage [with Europeans] in trade.
('9', 98, 3, 19, 232809) But they do not add to the crime in the country, whereas the Europeans roam the country for their bread.
('9', 98, 3, 20, 232914) Latterly, their number has increased markedly.
('9', 98, 3, 21, 232961) Their coming in has added to the incidence of theft and the smuggling of gold and diamonds, has encouraged [the growth of ] liquor shops.
('9', 98, 3, 22, 233099) [Because of them,] panders and money lenders flourish and other similar crimes are on the increase.
('9', 98, 3, 23, 233199) We have decisively closed the door on the Asiatics but it should be closed also to this refuse [from Europe].

('9', 110, 2, 12, 259622) 66. THE G. O. M*S BIRTHDAY 1
('9', 110, 3, 13, 259651) It is again our privilege to join with our brethren throughout India and the Colonies on the occasion of the birthday of Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, the greatest living Indian.
('9', 110, 3, 14, 259822) Yesterday 2 he entered upon his eighty fourth year.
('9', 110, 3, 15, 259874) His life has been a strenuous one, devoted to his people and his beloved country.
('9', 110, 3, 16, 259956) Now the aged patriot is living in quiet retire ment in India, enjoying the rest which he has so nobly earned.
('9', 110, 3, 17, 260066) Indians in South Africa, and especially those in Transvaal, may take courage for the fight by remembering that Mr. Dadabhai has spent practically the whole of his life fighting for the rights and freedom of his fellow countrymen.
('9', 110, 3, 18, 260296) Therefore, the greatest honour we in South Africa can do him is to follow his example, never flinching from the struggle until we have gained for ourselves, and for the generations to follow, that complete freedom which is the right of every subject of the King Emperor.

('9', 114, 1, 12, 268512) STORY OF KRUGERSDORP
('9', 114, 2, 13, 268533) Among the Krugersdorp Indians there appears to be a trivial rift, which the authorities intend to exploit.

('9', 114, 2, 15, 268775) The victims have lodged complaints and the offending traders will now be prosecuted.

('9', 114, 2, 20, 269286) Since the case is without any basis, the Government will lose.
('9', 114, 3, 21, 269349) But such rumours may serve to prolong the sufferings of the Indians somewhat.

('9', 114, 4, 30, 269921) Only to the extent that we are unaware of the soul can there be misery and suffering for us.

('9', 115, 1, 2, 270056) STANDERTON LICENCES
('9', 115, 2, 3, 270076) The Licensing Officer asked the Indian traders at Standerton why they had refused to give their thumb impressions.
('9', 115, 2, 4, 270191) In reply, the Committee has said that (i) since thumb impressions are demanded under the obnoxious Act, the Indians will not give them; (ii) the Act is obnoxious because it offends religious susceptibilities and is a symbol of the Indians inferior status; (iii) even if thumb impressions were demandedfor licensing purposesoutside the Act, they would be refused by those who could sign their names.
('9', 115, 2, 5, 270590) For, giving ones thumb impression when one can easily sign ones name will amount to a stigma on oneself for the colour of ones skin.
('9', 115, 2, 6, 270723) There is a difference between a thumb impression given in lieu of a signature and that given when the person can sign his name.

('9', 118, 1, 2, 276476) 69. PETITION TO SECRETARY OF STATE FOR COLONIES 1
('9', 118, 2, 3, 276526) JOHANNESBURG, September 9, 1908
('9', 118, 3, 4, 276558) TO THE RT.
('9', 118, 3, 5, 276569) HONBLE THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES LONDON
('9', 118, 4, 6, 276623) THE PETITION OF THE BRITISH INDIAN
('9', 118, 5, 7, 276658) ASSOCIATION OF THE TRANSVAAL
('9', 118, 6, 8, 276687) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT PRELIMINARY
('9', 118, 7, 9, 276719) 1. The British Indian Association approach His Majestys Government in connection with the British Indian struggle that has now gone on for the past two years in the Transvaal, more particularly in connection with the Asiatic Registration Amendment Act, gazetted in the Transvaal Gazette, dated the 2nd instant.
('9', 118, 7, 10, 277030) 2. The Association represent the British Indian community residing in the Transvaal.
('9', 118, 7, 11, 277115) 3 As His Majestys Government are well aware, the Asiatic Law Amendment Act passed last year by the Transvaal legislature has caused much misery to the British Indians in the Transvaal, and has involved loss of money and the incarceration of over 350 Indians, who have suffered imprisonment for conscience sake.
('9', 118, 7, 12, 277426) HASTY LEGISLATION
('9', 118, 8, 13, 277444) 4. The Act that has now been gazetted was, in the form of a Bill, read a first time on the 20th August, and it passed all the stages through both the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council on the 21st August.
('9', 118, 8, 14, 277663) The bill was never published in the Gazette and it was only after it was gazetted as an Act that it was available to the community represented by the petitioning Association.
('9', 118, 8, 15, 277838) By the courtesy of a member of the Legislative Assembly, a few Indians were able to see the Bill after it had passed through all the stages and the other members of the community had, up to the 2nd instant, to remain satisfied with a summary published in the Transvaal Press.
('9', 118, 9, 16, 278114) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 19 9 1908, under the title Transvaal Indians Petition: To The Imperial Government: The Full Text.
('9', 119, 0, 1, 278252) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 119, 1, 2, 278294) THE ACT GENERALLY ACCEPTABLE
('9', 119, 2, 3, 278323) 5. The petitioning Association are free to admit that the Act under discussion is a very great advance upon the Asiatic Law Amendment Act No.
('9', 119, 2, 4, 278465) 2 of 1907, though it is defective, in that it requires proof of pre war residence for 3 years from those Asiatics who are in the Transvaal but who have not yet received registration certificates.
('9', 119, 2, 5, 278661) Most of these men have entered the country in bona fide manner, and have acquired vested rights.
('9', 119, 2, 6, 278758) There are instances of Asiatics having already received registration certificates, although their residence in the Transvaal before the war did not go beyond even one year.
('9', 119, 2, 7, 278931) It is respectfully contended that the Asiatics who have not yet received registration certificates but who are in the Transvaal should not be treated according to the arbitrary and inflexible limit of three years pre war residence, which is applicable to Asiatics who are still outside the Transvaal.
('9', 119, 2, 8, 279232) 6. The clause as to the granting of licences will depend for smooth working only on a liberal administration as to thumb print requirements.
('9', 119, 2, 9, 279373) FINGER PRINTS
('9', 119, 3, 10, 279387) 7. In moving the second reading of the Bill, the Colonial Secre tary was pleased to say that finger impressions or thumb impressions were not a matter of objection.
('9', 119, 3, 11, 279552) In the humble opinion of the petitioning Association, in making this statement, the Honble Minister was less than fair to the Indian community; for he knew well that a very violent agitation was raised against finger prints by many Asiatics, after the compromise of last January.
('9', 119, 3, 12, 279832) Whilst it is true that finger prints were never treated as a fundamental objection by the leading members of the Indian community, they undoubtedly formed, as they even now do, an insupe rable objection to many Asiatics, especially the Pathans, of whom there are probably over 150 residing in the Colony.
('9', 119, 3, 13, 280137) Finger impressions or thumb impressions were given voluntarily under the compromise, only in order to enable the Government to have a scientific classification, and to show the bona fides of the community, as also its willingness to help the Government.
('9', 119, 3, 14, 280391) This voluntary act has cost the community very dear.
('9', 119, 3, 15, 280444) Both the Chairman and the Secretary had to suffer grievous bodily harm at the hands of their fellow countrymen, 1 by reason of the above help given to the Government.
('9', 119, 3, 16, 280611) After considerable experience, the petitioning Association assure His Majestys Government that the compulsory
('9', 119, 4, 17, 280721) 1 Gandhiji was assaulted on February 10, 1908; vide Letter to Friends, 10 2 1908 & My Reward, 22 2 1908.
('9', 120, 0, 1, 280826) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 121
('9', 120, 1, 2, 280868) taking of finger impressions on any large scale from Asiatics only is bound to give rise to such trouble.
('9', 120, 1, 3, 280974) Nor are they to any extent necessary, the majority of British Indians having once given them to the authorities.
('9', 120, 1, 4, 281087) In any case, a very great amount of latitude will be necessary for the smooth working of that part of the administrative machinery.
('9', 120, 1, 5, 281219) ON REPEAL OF ACT 2 OF 1907
('9', 120, 2, 6, 281246) 8. However acceptable the measure may be in comparison with the Asiatic Act of 1907, as has already been submitted to the local Government, the community represented by the petitioning Association is unable to accept the benefits of the measure until Act 2 to 1907 is removed from the Statute book, and the status of educated Asiatics properly and equitably defined.
('9', 120, 2, 7, 281613) In the humble opinion of the petitioning Association, repeal of the Act is necessary, if only for the honour of the Government.
('9', 120, 2, 8, 281741) PROMISE OF REPEAL
('9', 120, 3, 9, 281759) 9. It is respectfully contended that the Honble the Colonial Secretary had definitely promised repeal on condition that the Asiatic part of the compromise was carried out by the Asiatic communities.
('9', 120, 3, 10, 281958) It is admitted that the Asiatics have more than fulfilled their obligation under the compromise.
('9', 120, 3, 11, 282055) 10. But it has been argued that Justice Solomon, in the course of his judgement 1 on the application for the return of a voluntary registration application, stated that promise of repeal was not proved, and that, therefore, it was not given.
('9', 120, 3, 12, 282297) The petitioning Association venture to draw the attention of His Majestys Government to the fact that the question of repeal was not before the Court and the decision did not turn upon that question at all.
('9', 120, 3, 13, 282504) It was definitely stated before the Court that all the evidence in the possession of the applicant with reference to the repeal was not brought before the Court.
('9', 120, 3, 14, 282666) Sufficient was stated on that subject in the affidavits 2 supporting the application, in order to provide a moral basis, the applicant intending to show that his desire to withdraw his application for voluntary registration was not based on caprice but on what he believed to be a breach of faith by the local Government.
('9', 120, 3, 15, 282988) 11. That repeal of the Act was the goal of the signatories to the letter 3 addressed to the Colonial Secretary, and dated the 29th January, can be inferred from the letter itself, [a] portion of which reads as

('9', 121, 2, 3, 283317) Under these circumstances, we would once more respectfully suggest to the Government that all Asiatics over the age of 16 should be allowed within a certain limited period, say three months, to register themselves, and that to all who so register the Act be not applied.
('9', 121, 2, 4, 283588) The original draft placed before the signatories had the expression the penalties of before the words the Act.

('9', 122, 1, 15, 287860) 16. Lastly, whilst the Colonial Secretary has stated, in his affidavit 3 before the Supreme Court, that he never promised repeal of the Act, and whilst the Registrar of Asiatics had supported that affidavit, the Colonial Secretary does not, as will appear from his speech on the second reading of the Bill, seriously repudiate the

('9', 123, 1, 2, 288312) promise, and, at any rate, admits having freely discussed with the second signatory hereto the question of repeal.
('9', 123, 1, 3, 288427) 17. Several statements made by British Indians, to whom the assurance as to repeal was given by the Registrar of Asiatics, are attached hereto.
('9', 123, 2, 4, 288571) 18. Moreover, the petitioning Association draw the attention of His Majestys Government to the fact that a repealing Bill was actually drawn [up] and ordered to be printed for private circulation by the Colonial Secretary, and was shown to the second signatory, and was only withdrawn, because the second signatory hereto requested that certain amendments should be made therein, all of which, with some modifications, have now been embodied in the Act under discussion, with the exception of that affecting the status of educated Asiatics.
('9', 123, 3, 5, 289112) RETENTION OF ACT UNNECESSARY
('9', 123, 4, 6, 289141) 19. Apart, however, from the promise made by the Colonial Secretary, the retention of two parallel enactments dealing with the same matter cannot but lead to harassing and unfortunate results.
('9', 123, 4, 7, 289334) It has been stated that the intention of the Government is to treat Act 2 of 1907 as a dead letter.
('9', 123, 4, 8, 289434) But it is impossible for the community represented by the petitioning Association to remain in a state of uncertainty after a prolonged and bitter struggle.
('9', 123, 4, 9, 289591) The powers given by the two measures may, in the hands of ignorant, incapable, or prejudiced officials, be used against British Indians with deadly results.
('9', 123, 4, 10, 289748) 20. The petitioning Association may be permitted to remark that the later measure in no way neutralizes the effect of Act 2 of 1907. Either may, at the option of the Government, be used against the Asiatic communities.
('9', 123, 4, 11, 289967) Similarly, it is open to Asiatics to take advantage, if there by any, of either enactment.
('9', 123, 4, 12, 290058) 21. For instance, whilst, under the new measure, Turkish Mahomedans are free from the irksome process of registration, a Turkish Mahomedan entering the Transvaal may be dealt with under Act 2 of 1907. One of the main objections, therefore, of the British Indian community still remains without redress.
('9', 123, 4, 13, 290361) The remarks made by the colonial Secretary that
('9', 123, 5, 14, 290409) they (the Asiatics) put the difficulties in this waythat, under Act 2 of 1907, the definition given of Asiatic in the old Volksraad Act No.
('9', 123, 5, 15, 290549) 3, 1885, was maintained, and in that definition Turkish Mahomedans, subjects of the Turkish Empire, were excluded from this country.
('9', 123, 5, 16, 290682) It was urged that that was not
('9', 123, 6, 17, 290713) 1Vide Report of Natal Immigration Department, 22 2 1908
('9', 124, 0, 1, 290769) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 125
('9', 124, 1, 2, 290811) a provision intended to keep Turks out of the country, but was simply casting a slur and a stigma on the Mahomedan religion, which no white person or the Government has the slightest intention of doing.
('9', 124, 1, 3, 291014) The number of Turks here has always been small, and I am told that there are none now, and in any case there is no danger of any influx from Turkey to this country.
('9', 124, 1, 4, 291179) The only kind of Turkish subjects who do come here are Christians, and they are Syrians and other Levantines, against whom certain hon.
('9', 124, 1, 5, 291315) members have strong objection.
('9', 124, 1, 6, 291346) But they are Christians, and Mahomedan subjects of the Turkish Empire have never threatened, and are never likely to threaten, to invade this country.
('9', 124, 1, 7, 291497) That objection, which was based on sentimental grounds, and which there was no difficulty on material grounds in meeting, we have met, and hon.
('9', 124, 1, 8, 291641) members will see that the Bill now before the House strikes out that restriction which was placed against the immigration of a man simply because he was a Mahomedan subject of the Turkish Empire.
('9', 124, 1, 9, 291837) are wide of the mark.
('9', 124, 1, 10, 291859) 22. Again, whilst the Act under discussion frees minors from personal registration, Act 2 of 1907 can conceivably be used against such minors, and can give rise to endless trouble.
('9', 124, 1, 11, 292040) 23. The offensive liquor clause finds no place in the new measure, but it is open to an Asiatic to apply for a permit of exemp tion under the old Act.
('9', 124, 1, 12, 292191) It will, perhaps, be said that this is manifestly an advantage.
('9', 124, 1, 13, 292255) But, in the humble opinion of the petitioning Associa tion, the implied insult still disfigures the Statute book of the Colony.
('9', 124, 2, 14, 292383) 24. It would be open to the Government to deal with an un registered Asiatic under either Act, and thus subject such an Asiatic to pinpricks at every turn.
('9', 124, 2, 15, 292539) 25. The retention of the old Act opens the way for frauds by un scrupulous Asiatics.
('9', 124, 2, 16, 292624) Whilst the new Act provides for application for registration being made from a place in South Africa outside the Colony, there is nothing to prevent an Asiatic from entering the Colo ny and claiming to remain in it for seven days, under the Act, and, during that time, merging into the community beyond recognition.
('9', 124, 2, 17, 292940) 26. Illustrations like the foregoing can be multiplied.
('9', 124, 2, 18, 292996) But the above, it is trusted, will sufficiently show how precarious the position of British Indians will be rendered, if the old enactment be allowed to remain on the Statute book of the Colony.
('9', 124, 3, 19, 293191) 27. Even whilst the new Act is under consideration by His Majestys Government, the local Government have commenced prose cutions against those who are covered and protected by it.
('9', 124, 3, 20, 293371) Thus, a
('9', 124, 4, 21, 293379) 1Vide Deputation to Lord Elgin, 8 11 1906.
('9', 125, 0, 1, 293422) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 125, 1, 2, 293464) British Indian 1 possessing good educational qualifications and, therefore, easily recognizable, and moreover, possessing a Peace Preservation Ordinance permit and a certificate voluntarily taken out under Lord Milners advice, 2 was arrested, after the passing of the new measure, and tried under the old Act, for being an unregistered Asiatic.
('9', 125, 1, 3, 293809) The Magistrate, although he expressed surprise, had no option but to give him notice to quit the Colony within seven days.
('9', 125, 1, 4, 293932) Thus, it is possible to denude the Colony of many lawfully resident Asiatics by prosecuting them under the old Act, although they are protected by the new Act.
('9', 125, 1, 5, 294092) 28. Another Indian, well known to the authorities, a merchant of Piet Retief, holding residential certificates, has just been tried under the old Act, and sentenced to pay a fine or go to gaol for 14 days without hard labour, not because he is not entitled to reside in the Colony, but because he has refused to give his thumb impression.
('9', 125, 1, 6, 294431) During his trial, the principal witness for the Crown admitted that he knew the merchant to be a resident of the Transvaal, and the solicitor who had accompanied him when he obtained his permit also gave evidence to identify him.
('9', 125, 1, 7, 294661) Mr. Ebrahim Osman (that is the merchants name), rather than pay a fine which he deemed to be an extortion, has elected to suffer imprisonment, and is now serving his term at His Majestys gaol at Volksrust.
('9', 125, 1, 8, 294867) 3 Mr. Ebrahim Osman can read and write English and can give a well formed signature in the Roman character[s].
('9', 125, 1, 9, 294978) 29. Under the circumstances, the petitioning Association trust that His Majestys Government will secure repeal of the old Act before sanctioning the new Act.
('9', 125, 2, 10, 295136) STATUS OF EDUCATED INDIANS
('9', 125, 3, 11, 295163) 30. If the old Act were removed from the Statute book, it would seem that there would be no hindrance to educated Asiatics being placed on the same footing as His Majestys other subjects, so far as immigration is concerned.
('9', 125, 3, 12, 295387) 31. The Immigrants Restriction Act 15 of 1907 imposes a general education test, and, under it, any Asiatic who can pass the education test is not otherwise prohibited and may enter the Colony.
('9', 125, 3, 13, 295580) He then becomes subject to registration under the Asiatic Act, and, if he fails to comply with it, he becomes an unregistered Asiatic, though
('9', 125, 4, 14, 295722) 1 This was Muljibhai G. Patel; vide Trial of Muljibhai G. PatelI, 4 8 1908. 2 Vide The British Indian Association and Lord Milner, 11 6 1903. 3 Vide Johannesburg Letter, 31 8 1908.
('9', 126, 0, 1, 295903) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 127
('9', 126, 1, 2, 295945) not yet a prohibited immigrant.
('9', 126, 1, 3, 295977) Thus, Mr. Sorabji Shapurji entered the Colony under the Immigrants Restriction Act.
('9', 126, 1, 4, 296061) He was allowed to pass through unchallenged.
('9', 126, 1, 5, 296106) After seven days residence in the Colony, he was prosecuted for being unregistered under Act 2 of 1907. 1 Mr. Sorabji had applied for voluntary registration.
('9', 126, 1, 6, 296264) That was refused.
('9', 126, 1, 7, 296282) He was not prepared to submit to Act 2 of 1907. He held excellent testimonials from the Town Clerk of Charlestown and other prominent officials of that town.
('9', 126, 1, 8, 296440) The Magistrate at Volksrust had recommended his application.
('9', 126, 1, 9, 296501) He is educated up to the seventh standard of the Surat High School, and has often acted as Interpreter at the Court at Charlestown.
('9', 126, 1, 10, 296633) On being tried under the Asiatic Act, he received notice to quit the Colony.
('9', 126, 1, 11, 296710) 1 This notice he, as a British subject, declined to comply with.
('9', 126, 1, 12, 296775) He was thereupon prosecuted, and sentenced to imprisonment with hard labour for one month, without the option of a fine.
('9', 126, 1, 13, 296896) 3 Mr. Sorabji served his term, and, on the last day of his imprisonment, was secretly deported.
('9', 126, 1, 14, 296992) 32. The petitioning Association venture respectfully to submit that such method of dealing with inoffensive British subjects in a British Colony is without precedent.
('9', 126, 1, 15, 297159) 33. Mr. Sorabjis case shows that the Immigrants Restriction Act does not create a colour bar.
('9', 126, 1, 16, 297253) The above view seems to be borne out by the case of Rex v.
('9', 126, 1, 17, 297312) Lalloo heard in the Supreme Court of the Transvaal on the 22nd July last.
('9', 126, 2, 18, 297386) 34. It is the Asiatic Act, which is ostensibly only intended to identify those who could not otherwise be easily identified, that stands in the way of educated Indians.
('9', 126, 2, 19, 297555) 35. The petitioning Association respectfully claim that as in the other Colonies, educated Asiatics should have the right of free entry, subject only to general education test applicable to all.
('9', 126, 2, 20, 297750) It would be unreasonable and highly insulting and degrading to expect such Asiatics to undergo processes of identification and carry certificates for which there can never be the slightest necessity.
('9', 126, 2, 21, 297950) 36. The petitioning Association invite the attention of His Majestys Government to the fact that foreigners, if they are Europeans, and the natives of South Africa, provided they pass the education test, can enter the Transvaal.
('9', 126, 2, 22, 298179) Educated British Indians are, therefore, placed lower than either of the two classes above named.
('9', 126, 2, 23, 298277) 37. It is right that the Malays, who are inhabitants of South
('9', 126, 3, 24, 298339) 1 Vide Trial of Sorabji ShapurjiI, 8 7 1908. 2 ibid 3 ibid 4 Vide Letter to Indian Opinion, 24 7 1908.
('9', 127, 0, 1, 298442) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 127, 1, 2, 298484) Africa, should be free to enter the Transvaal, but the petitioning Association fail to see why Indians born in South Africa should not be placed in the same category.
('9', 127, 1, 3, 298651) There are many Indian youths to whom South Africa is their only home, and India a foreign land.
('9', 127, 1, 4, 298747) 38. It has been stated that the keeping of the door open for the entry of educated Indians would flood the Colony with half educated Indian lads, who would compete with the general body of the Europeans in the Colony.
('9', 127, 1, 5, 298965) The petitioning Association have never raised any such contention.
('9', 127, 1, 6, 299032) The severity of the education test will not be questioned.
('9', 127, 1, 7, 299091) It is the class and colour distinction in the laws even with regard to educated Indians that is respectfully resented.
('9', 127, 1, 8, 299210) Natal admits very few Indians per year under the education test.
('9', 127, 1, 9, 299275) 39. What the petitioning Association desire is that educated Indians of high culture, professional men, men with University degrees, should be able to enter the Colony as of right.
('9', 127, 1, 10, 299456) Such men are naturally required for the wants of the resident community.
('9', 127, 1, 11, 299529) 40. Further, it has been suggested that relief for educated Indians is obtainable under Section 16 of the new Act, as it is under the old Act.
('9', 127, 1, 12, 299672) But such is not the case.
('9', 127, 1, 13, 299698) That section contemplates only a temporary permit and does not enable the holder to follow any independent calling.
('9', 127, 1, 14, 299814) That section, the petitioning Association under stand, is intended to provide for the temporary sojourn in the Colony of Asiatics, whether they are educated or not, and contemplated the giving of facility to merchants to import, under temporary permits, clerks and other employees for their wants.
('9', 127, 1, 15, 300112) 41. The relief sought by the petitioning Association is different in kind.
('9', 127, 1, 16, 300187) Educated Indians who can pass a test, no matter how severe, should come under the general immigration law, and should not be subjected to registration, etc.
('9', 127, 1, 17, 300344) 42. If the educated Indians who are already in the Colony have sub mitted to registration, they have done so only to set an example and assist the Government, and to free those few who may be allowed to enter the Colony from galling and needless restrictions on their personal freedom.
('9', 127, 1, 18, 300630) 43. It may be remarked that the immigration of Asiatics was free before the war.
('9', 127, 1, 19, 300711) After the conclusion of peace, it was generally controlled under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('9', 127, 1, 20, 300810) The Asiatic Act of 1907 did not regulate immigration of Asiatics but it provided for the registration of Asiatics already domiciled in the Colony.
('9', 127, 1, 21, 300957) It was still open to Asiatics to receive permits the same as Europeans under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and, as a matter of fact, serveral did receive such permits.
('9', 127, 1, 22, 301129) Then followed the Immigrants Restriction
('9', 128, 0, 1, 301170) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 129
('9', 128, 1, 2, 301212) Act 1which replaced the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and laid down a general education test for newcomers.
('9', 128, 1, 3, 301320) Thus, but for the Asiatic Act, there never has been a legal interruption of the entry of educated Asiatics into the Colony.
('9', 128, 1, 4, 301444) It is, therefore, not true, as has been locally stated, that British Indians are raising any new contention.
('9', 128, 1, 5, 301553) The question was first raised by the Honble the Colonial Secretary when, in his repealing Bill, herein before referred to, he wished so to amend the Immigrants Restriction Act as to prohibit the immigration of all educated Asiatics.
('9', 128, 2, 6, 301786) PASSIVE RESISTANCE
('9', 128, 3, 7, 301805) 44. The petitioning Association feel aggrieved that His Majestys Government were pleased not to listen to the prayer of the Association and the Deputation that was sent to London in 1906 2 and that Act 2 of 1907 was sanctioned.
('9', 128, 3, 8, 302033) 45. The petitioning Association draw the attention of His Majestys Government to the fact that the Deputation placed before them the fourth Resolution of the Mass Meeting of British Indians held at the Empire Theatre in the September of 1906. 3 The resolution runs as follows:
('9', 128, 4, 9, 302310) In the event of the Legislative Council, the local Government, and the Imperial authorities rejecting the humble prayer of the British Indian community of the Transvaal in connection with the Draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance, this Mass Meeting of British Indians here assembled solemnly and regretfully resolves that, rather than submit to the galling, tyrannous, and un British requirements laid down in the above Draft Ordinance, every British Indian in the Transvaal shall submit himself to imprisonment and shall continue so to do until it shall please His Most Gracious Majesty the King Emperor to grant relief.
('9', 128, 4, 10, 302932) 46. The Resolution evidently carried very little weight with His Majestys Government.
('9', 128, 4, 11, 303018) But what has happened since has demons trated the earnestness of the meeting.
('9', 128, 4, 12, 303096) 47. The following passage occurs in a general petition 4 presented to the local Government in 1907:
('9', 128, 5, 13, 303196) Nothing short of total repeal of the Act can meet the difficult situation that has arisen.
('9', 128, 5, 14, 303287) In our humble opinion, the Act is degrading to our self respect, offensive to our religions, and in its incidence it is such as can be thought of only in connection with dangerous criminals.
('9', 128, 5, 15, 303478) Moreover, the solemn
('9', 128, 6, 16, 303499) 1 For text of the Act, vide Vol. VII, Appendix III.
('9', 128, 6, 17, 303551) 2 Vide Deputation to Lord Elgin, 8 11 1906. 3 Vide The Mass Meeting, 11 11 1906. 4 Vide Monster Petition, Before 21 9 1907.
('9', 129, 0, 1, 303675) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 129, 1, 2, 303717) declaration made by us renders it imperative for us, as honest citizens of the Empire and God fearing men, not to submit to the provisions of the Act, irrespective of any consequences which we may have to suffer, and which we understand to be imprisonment, banishment, and/or loss or confiscation of our property.
('9', 129, 1, 3, 304031) 48. In order to secure the object, over 350 Indians have suffered imprisonment.
('9', 129, 1, 4, 304111) Several have allowed their goods to be sold.
('9', 129, 1, 5, 304156) Some have accepted dismissal from Government or private employ, rather than stifle the voice of conscience.
('9', 129, 1, 6, 304264) And almost all have suffered much pecuniary loss, some having been actually reduced to poverty.
('9', 129, 2, 7, 304360) 49. The petitioning Association have chosen this method of drawing attention to the grievous wrong suffered by them as being the method most consistent with their status as British subjects, and with their self respect as men.
('9', 129, 3, 8, 304587) 50. The movement has been described as passive resistance for want of a better term.
('9', 129, 3, 9, 304672) But it amounts to respectful protest against legisla tion which British Indians resent, and in framing which they had no voice.
('9', 129, 4, 10, 304800) 51. It is respectfully submitted that there can be no notion of resistance, as the word is ordinarily understood, in a body of men undergoing personal suffering.
('9', 129, 5, 11, 304962) 52. The petitioning Association have learnt from experience that, within the British Empire, at any rate, subjects of the King Emperor get real redress of grievances only when they show that they are ready and willing to suffer for the sake of obtaining relief.
('9', 129, 6, 12, 305224) 53. British Indians have been taught from their childhood that, in the eye of the law, under the British Constitution, all subjects are equal.
('9', 129, 6, 13, 305367) When, however, they dare to claim such equality in the Colony, they are jeered at or considered impudent.
('9', 129, 7, 14, 305473) 54. British Indians have no franchise and, in the present state of public feeling, they desire none.
('9', 129, 7, 15, 305574) The only remedy left to them, therefore, is to petition the rulers and, as a measure of their earnestness, be prepared to suffer for their opinions.
('9', 129, 8, 16, 305723) 55. So far as the petitioning Association have been able to ascertain the Indian feeling, the determination of the great majority of them is humbly to continue to suffer and refuse to accept the benefits under the new Act, until elementary justice requested by the Indians has been granted.
('9', 130, 0, 1, 306014) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 131
('9', 130, 1, 2, 306056) CONCLUSION
('9', 130, 2, 3, 306067) 56. In conclusion, the petitioning Association respectfully submit and pray that, if His Majestys Government cannot secure justice for British Indians residing in the Colony by securing repeal of Act 2 of 1907 and by having the status of educated Indians established, in consonance with the Principles of the British Constitution, the terms of the gracious Proclamation of 1858 1 may be withdrawn, and they may be told that, for them, the expression British subject is to bear a meaning different to what it possesses for Europeans.
('9', 130, 2, 4, 306600) And for this act, etc., etc.
('9', 130, 2, 5, 306629) ESSOP ISMAIL MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION M. K. GANDHI SECRETARY, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Colonial Office Records: 291/128

('9', 131, 1, 2, 307955) 71. INTERVIEW TO THE STAR
('9', 131, 2, 3, 307981) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 9, 1908
('9', 131, 3, 4, 308015) The sentence of three months hard labour passed by the Volksrust Magistrate yesterday on the Indians who were deported and who re entered the Colony has, according to the Indian method of reasoning, considerably helped their cause, and it is apparent that they hope that such incidents in the campaign will force the Imperial Government to intervene on their behalf.
('9', 131, 3, 5, 308382) There was quite a feeling of optimism pervading Mr. Gandhis office today when a reporter of The Star called on him.
('9', 131, 3, 6, 308498) The leader of the passive resistance movement said: While it is true that we Indians have got what we asked for, it does not reflect any credit on the Government, which makes it almost imperative on the courts to impose such heavy sentences on men who, after all, are political opponents.
('9', 131, 3, 7, 308787) I consider this to be a wicked abuse of power placed in the hands of the Government over an unrepr esented class.
('9', 131, 3, 8, 308901) I think that these sentences mean the end of the deportation farce, but if the farce is to be continued, and if I know the temper of my countrymen correctly, they will certainly continue to re enter and demand their rights as British subjects.
('9', 131, 3, 9, 309145) When I talk of equality of treatment in the eye of the law the idea is jeered at, but I am in good company, as Col.
('9', 131, 3, 10, 309261) Seely himself has advanced the same plea.
('9', 131, 3, 11, 309303) 1 To my mind, it is the only thing that binds the Empire together.
('9', 131, 3, 12, 309370) Immediately the idea of legal inequality is introduced, you sap the foundation of the Empire.
('9', 131, 3, 13, 309464) By this idea I do not mean that the Colonies should not have the right to restrict immigration.
('9', 131, 3, 14, 309560) The late Sir Henry Parkes remarks cannot be questioned, but once you admit people into the Colony, they must enjoy equality of treatment before the law.
('9', 131, 3, 15, 309713) Otherwise, as Mr. Duncan has only recently stated, you create a state of slavery, the result being that the slave owners, that is the governing class, must in the end be much worse off than the slaves.
('9', 131, 4, 16, 309915) John Edward Bernard Seely, Under Secretary of State for the Colonies, had spoken in the House of Commons on July 31 to the effect that: (i) if persons were admitted, they must be given civil rights; (ii) if anyone was admitted under the British flag, he must be a potential citizen and must, sooner or later, be given equal rights with all other men; (iii) those we have with us we must treat well, generously and fairly.
('9', 131, 4, 17, 310337) India, 7 8 1908. Vide Imperial Governments views, 5 9 1908. 2 Patrick Duncan, speaking at the Rosebank Branch of the League of Women, said: It was a very difficult matter in a country where there was supposed to be political freedom to have the largest section of the population entirely deprived of political rightsit was practically a condition of slavery .
('9', 131, 4, 18, 310697) It was bad for the superior race just as much as for the inferior.
('9', 132, 0, 1, 310764) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 133
('9', 132, 1, 2, 310806) History does not show an instance of people having become a free nation and yet remaining slave owners.
('9', 132, 1, 3, 310910) If we are not to be treated as slaves, then we want men whose presence would conduce to our free growth.
('9', 132, 1, 4, 311015) These men are undoubtedly those who have culture and education, and it is for an infinitesimal number of this class that we are pleading for free ingress.
('9', 132, 2, 5, 311170) Asked if the principle were conceded, would the Indians be prepared to submit to a severe education test, Mr. Gandhi said: If the test in the present Immigrants Restriction Law does not admit of a proper stiff test being laid down, which I deny, it can be amended, even as it has been in Australia.
('9', 132, 2, 6, 311469) Under the Immigrants Restriction Act there will then be legal equality, but in administering that Act it will be open to the officials to alter the severity of the test as circumstances may require.
('9', 132, 2, 7, 311668) For instance, in Natal today Europeans are almost passed unchallenged, while Indians are subjected to a rigorous test.
('9', 132, 2, 8, 311787) That administrative difference must continue so long as the prejudice continues.
('9', 132, 3, 9, 311868) On it being pointed out that Mr. Gandhis statement did not advance the situation, he replied that he took his stand on Lord Milners Kimberley speech 1 , Let there be no more pinpricks for the Uitlander,
('9', 132, 4, 10, 312071) and, added Mr. Gandhi: We are now the Uitlanders, strangers in our own home.
('9', 132, 4, 11, 312148) The Star, 9 9 1908

('9', 134, 1, 2, 315098) 74. TRIAL OF RANDAREE 1
('9', 134, 2, 3, 315122) [JOHANNESBURG, Before September 12, 1908]
('9', 134, 3, 4, 315164) In B Court today before Mr. H. H. Jordan, an Indian.
('9', 134, 3, 5, 315217) named Randaree was charged with remaining in the Colony after the expiry of his temporary permit to stay, and after being warned to leave by the authorities.
('9', 134, 4, 6, 315375) He pleaded not guilty, and was defended by Mr. Gandhi.
('9', 134, 5, 7, 315430) Superintendent J.G. Vernon said that on August 15 he called upon the accused to produce his authority for remaining in the transvaal after being warned by the Registrar of Asiatics to quit.
('9', 134, 5, 8, 315620) He replied that he had no authority, but had made a further application to remain.
('9', 134, 5, 9, 315703) On instructions, witness arrested accused.
('9', 134, 6, 10, 315746) James Cody, in the office of the Registrar of Asiatics, Pretoria, said a temporary permit to reside in the Transvaal was granted by the Registrar of Asiatics on the 10th March last for three months.
('9', 134, 6, 11, 315945) Accused applied for an extension on the 9th of June, and this was refused on the 24th July by letter.
('9', 134, 7, 12, 316047) THE MAGISTRATE: You allowed him to stay until then?
('9', 134, 8, 13, 316099) WITNESS: He gave certain reasons for wishing to stay.
('9', 134, 8, 14, 316153) We investigated these reasons, and decided that the permit should be refused.
('9', 134, 8, 15, 316231) MR. GANDHI: Are you aware that the accuseds father is in Johannesburg?
('9', 134, 9, 16, 316302) WITNESS: I cannot say for certain.
('9', 134, 10, 17, 316337) Randaree went into the box.
('9', 134, 10, 18, 316365) [GANDHIJI:] I understand that you intended to leave after the expiry of your permit and re enter the Transvaal under the Immigration Restriction Act?
('9', 134, 11, 19, 316515) [ACCUSED:] Yes, but fortunately I happened to be arrested here.
('9', 134, 12, 20, 316579) The accused asked leave to make a short statement, but the Magistrate pointed out that he had a very able solicitor defending him.
('9', 134, 12, 21, 316710) [GANDHIJI:] It does not matter.
('9', 134, 13, 22, 316742) And the accused went back to the prisoners box.
('9', 134, 14, 23, 316790) The Prosecutor said the position with regard to the accused was as if the Court had ordered him to leave the Colony within seven days and he had refused to do so.
('9', 134, 15, 24, 316953) The Magistrate sentenced the accused to one months hard labour.

('9', 135, 1, 2, 317157) 75. NATAL MEETINGS
('9', 135, 2, 3, 317176) Mass meetings are being held in Natal.
('9', 135, 2, 4, 317215) Also, resolutions are passed at these meetings.
('9', 135, 2, 5, 317263) Petitions will be sent to the Government.
('9', 135, 2, 6, 317305) This is all very well.
('9', 135, 2, 7, 317328) It was necessary to adopt these measures.
('9', 135, 2, 8, 317370) But Natal Indians must realize that petitions are useless unless backed by sanction.
('9', 135, 2, 9, 317455) This is what one learns from experience everywhere.
('9', 135, 2, 10, 317507) And satyagraha is our sanction.
('9', 135, 2, 11, 317539) For Natal, satyagraha means that every Indian should make up his mind to carry on trade without a licence.
('9', 135, 2, 12, 317646) We know of course that the new Bills 1 will not go through.
('9', 135, 2, 13, 317706) But it is necessary to have the old law 2the Act of 1897repealed.
('9', 135, 2, 14, 317772) If it is true that the Indian community has grown in strength, it must petition the Government to the following effect: We propose to carry on trade without licences as long as the Act of 1897 does not provide for appeal [to the Supreme Court], as long as old licences are not protected and as long as the  3 poll tax 3 on indentured labourers is not repealed. This will serve two interests: ones own as well as those of others.
('9', 135, 2, 15, 318201) Ones own because there will be an end to the harassment over licences.
('9', 135, 2, 16, 318272) Others interests in that the poll tax on the long suffering indentured labourers will disappear, and they will be sincerely grateful.
('9', 135, 2, 17, 318406) A pledge by the Indian community that it will not sit back until the hardships of the indentured labourers are ended, that it will suffer with them, will have a profound import.
('9', 135, 2, 18, 318584) If the Indian community takes this pledge sincerely, it is as good as a kingdom won.
('9', 135, 2, 19, 318669) It will mean swarajya.
('9', 135, 2, 20, 318692) Everyone will see that there is no alternative.
('9', 135, 2, 21, 318740) But it may be asked whether concerted action will ever be possible, whether we can ever hope to win.
('9', 135, 2, 22, 318841) It will be folly to ask this question.
('9', 135, 2, 23, 318880) In any great venture, the number of those that take the lead is invariably small.
('9', 135, 2, 24, 318962) At first the Prophet strove aided only by a handful; Jesus had a very small band of followers to begin with.
('9', 135, 2, 25, 319071) Hampden 4 was alone in refus ing to pay the ship money.
('9', 135, 2, 26, 319127) It did not even occur to him to consider whether or not others would follow him.
('9', 135, 2, 27, 319208) The late Mr. Bradlaugh 5

('9', 137, 3, 5, 321989) 77. SALUTE THE COURT
('9', 137, 4, 6, 322010) Sir Henry Bale has made some sharp remarks on saluting.
('9', 137, 4, 7, 322066) He go the impression that a certain Indian who entered his court did no salute him as he came in.
('9', 137, 4, 8, 322164) He therefore remarked that Indians, who were known to be a civilized people, should respect the dignity of the court.
('9', 137, 4, 9, 322282) He added that Indians should show respect to the court by taking off their turbans or their shoes or by salaaming on entering the court room.
('9', 137, 4, 10, 322424) Those who failed to do any of these three things would invite punishment.
('9', 137, 4, 11, 322498) Sir Henry addressed these remarks to all the Indians present and had them translated for their benefit.
('9', 137, 4, 12, 322602) Every Indian must heed this warning.
('9', 137, 4, 13, 322639) It will be a good practice anywhere to salute the court on entering it.
('9', 137, 4, 14, 322711) Many Indians fail to do this through sheer carelessness.
('9', 137, 4, 15, 322768) It is our duty to observe correct etiquette.

('9', 137, 6, 18, 322855) 78. OUR HABIT OF SPEAKING UNTRUTH 1
('9', 137, 7, 19, 322891) Sir Henry Bales remarks in the Indian murder case deserve not to be brushed aside lightly.
('9', 137, 7, 20, 322982) He observed that some Indians make many false statements in support of their plea.
('9', 137, 7, 21, 323065) 2 This sometimes spoils a good case.
('9', 137, 7, 22, 323102) This is often true.
('9', 137, 7, 23, 323122) It will not be right for one to defend Indians by asking whether whites do not act similarly in support of their case.
('9', 137, 7, 24, 323241) Of course, they do make false statements.
('9', 137, 7, 25, 323283) But that is no reason why we should follow suit.
('9', 137, 7, 26, 323332) Instead of worrying about winning or losing the case, we should resolve that we would speak nothing but the truth.
('9', 137, 7, 27, 323447) The best way is not to have to knock at the doors of lawyers or courts.
('9', 137, 7, 28, 323519) Why can we not ensure that civil or criminal cases involving Indians are not taken to court?
('9', 137, 7, 29, 323612) All this should be possible through the satyagraha that we have adopted.

('9', 138, 1, 2, 323904) 79. PETITION TO SECRETARY OF STATE FOR COLONIES 1
('9', 138, 2, 3, 323954) JOHANNESBURG, September 14, 1908 [THE RIGHT HONBLE THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES LONDON] THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED, REPRESENTING THE PATHANS AND THE PUNJABIS RESIDENT IN THE TRANSVAAL
('9', 138, 3, 4, 324154) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT 1. The Petitioners respectfully approach His Majestys Govern ment with reference to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, and the reply given to the Petitioners on the 26th day of March, 1908 in connection with their humble representation, as follows:
('9', 138, 4, 5, 324419) I have the honour, by direction, to inform you that the Petition enclosed in your letter of the 13th January respecting the position of yourself and others under the Asiatic Registration Act has been received by the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('9', 138, 4, 6, 324672) Lord Elgin has requested His Excellency Lord Selborne to inform you that he has perused the Petition with attention but that, especially in view of the recent settlement of the difficulties in connection with registration under the Act, it does not now appear to him to be necessary to take any action with regard to it.
('9', 138, 4, 7, 324993) 2. In the Petition, to which the above reply was sent, the Petitioners [had] prayed as follows:
('9', 138, 5, 8, 325089) His Majestys Indian soldiers cannot, consistent with the dignity of a soldier, degrade themselves by being compelled to register in such a manner, and, should His Majestys Government be unable to obtain just treatment for the King Emperors Indian soldiers in the Transvaal, then they ask as men and British Indian soldiers, who are proud to have risked their lives in the cause of the Empire and have braved the privations of war, to be spared the degradation of imprisonment or deportation, and further wish that the King Emperor will command that they be shot by Generals Botha and Smuts on one of the battle fields of South Africa, where they have been under fire whilst serving their King Emperor and the British Empire.
('9', 138, 5, 9, 325814) 3. As recent events have shown, the settlement to which the reply has reference has fallen through, and the whole of the Indian community is now making representations to His Majestys Government for repeal of the Act, which repeal all Indians were given
('9', 138, 6, 10, 326068) 1 This was published under the caption The Soldiers Petition and was presumably drafted by Gandhiji.
('9', 138, 6, 11, 326169) Vide also Petition to High Commissioner, Before 26 11 1907.
('9', 139, 0, 1, 326229) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 139, 1, 2, 326271) to understand was part of the compromise.
('9', 139, 1, 3, 326313) 4. It was because the whole of the Indian community represented by your Petitioners distrusted the compromise, and felt greatly agitated as to the uncertainty as to the repeal, and because the principle of registration by finger prints was accepted by the leaders of the Indian community, that some of the members of the section represented by your Petitioners showed their resentment of the action by resorting to physical violence.
('9', 139, 1, 4, 326747) Whilst such method of showing resentment cannot be approved by your Petitioners, the suspicion entertained by them was evidently well grounded.
('9', 139, 1, 5, 326891) 5. The position of your Petitioners is briefly as follows: (a) Your Petitioners consider the whole spirit of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act No.
('9', 139, 1, 6, 327034) 2 of 1907 to be degrading to anybody coming under it, much more so for soldiers who have been privileged to wear His Majestys uniform, and who have bled for their Sovereign.
('9', 139, 1, 7, 327208) (b) Your Petitioners are bound by a solemn oath: (i) not to accept the above mentioned Act, and to secure its repeal; (ii) never to give their digit impressions in connection with their identification, irrespective of what other members of the Indian community may choose to do.
('9', 139, 2, 8, 327487) 6. Your Petitioners, in obedience to the advice given by the then Commissioner of Police and other high officials, and on being told that the Act was to be repealed, underwent voluntary registration merely for the sake of peace.
('9', 139, 2, 9, 327716) Further than this your Petitioners are unable to go.
('9', 139, 2, 10, 327769) They consider that, by showing an unmanly attitude and by accepting degradation in order that they might be able to live in the Colony, they would be extremely unsoldier like.
('9', 139, 2, 11, 327945) 7. Your Petitioners venture to submit that their uniform and their discharges should be a sufficient passport in any part of the British Empire, and should constitute their complete identification.
('9', 139, 3, 12, 328143) 8. Your Petitioners do not understand legal subtleties and legal quibbles.
('9', 139, 3, 13, 328218) They have not studied the Asiatic Act.
('9', 139, 3, 14, 328257) They are helpless, except when they are called upon to fight for their Sovereign.
('9', 139, 3, 15, 328339) They do not understand English, but what little they have been able to gather about the Asiatic Act is sufficient to make them condemn the measure.
('9', 139, 4, 16, 328487) 9. Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that, in consonance with the assurance given, the Asiatic Act be repealed, and that they be not called upon to submit to any degradation in the way
('9', 140, 0, 1, 328679) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 141
('9', 140, 1, 2, 328721) of registration or otherwise.

('9', 140, 2, 6, 329175) 80. TRIAL OF V. M. BAGAS AND OTHERS
('9', 140, 3, 7, 329211) [PRETORIA, September 15, 1908]
('9', 140, 4, 8, 329242) Messrs Vally Mahomed Bagas, Ismail Juma, L. Vallabhdas, and Ismail Essopjee Adia appeared before Major Dixon at Pretoria, on the 15th instant, charged with a contravention of the Borough bye laws in that they traded without a grocers licence.
('9', 140, 4, 9, 329485) Mr. Weavind prosecuted on behalf of the Municipality of Pretoria, and Messrs Gandhi and Lichtenstein defended.
('9', 140, 5, 10, 329596) Mr. Ismail Jumas case was first called.
('9', 140, 5, 11, 329636) Mr. Gandhi took exception to the summons before pleading, that it disclosed no offence under Ordinance 58 of 1903, and that the Ordinance did not provide for the framing of a bye law in regard to a general grocers licence.
('9', 140, 5, 12, 329859) The Magistrate overruled the objection.
('9', 140, 5, 13, 329899) The plea was not guilty.
('9', 140, 5, 14, 329924) Mr. Thomas, the Licensing Officer, gave formal evidence as to the accused having carried on the business of a grocer.
('9', 140, 5, 15, 330042) Mr. Gandhi did not call any evidence on behalf of the defence, stating that he rested his case on the legal objection raised.
('9', 140, 5, 16, 330168) The accused was found guilty and fined 5s or three days imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 140, 5, 17, 330255) Mr. Ismail Juma elected to go to gaol.
('9', 140, 6, 18, 330294) Mr. Vally Mahomed Bagas, who is Chairman of the Pretoria branch of the British Indian Association, was next tried.
('9', 140, 6, 19, 330409) Mr. Bagas pleaded not guilty.
('9', 140, 6, 20, 330439) After evidence was given by Mr. Thomas, the Licensing Officer, Mr. Bagas gave evidence to the effect that he held a general dealers licence for the whole year and that he had even tendered the fee for a grocers licence, but it had been refused, as he had declined to give his thumb impression.
('9', 140, 6, 21, 330733) The Magistrate awarded the same penalty.
('9', 140, 6, 22, 330774) There were two charges against Mr. Bagas in respect of two stores, the penalty in each case being the same.
('9', 140, 6, 23, 330882) He, too, cheerfully went to gaol.
('9', 140, 7, 24, 330916) Mess Ismail Adia and L. Vallabhdas were also similarly tried, punished, and went to gaol.
('9', 141, 0, 1, 331006) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 141, 1, 2, 331048) A Chinese trader was called, but he did not appear, and, as he was bailed out, his bail was estreated to the extent of  1.

('9', 141, 4, 5, 331223) ESSOP MIA
('9', 141, 5, 6, 331233) Mr. Essop Mia has resigned, and a vote of thanks for his services was passed at the mass meeting.
('9', 141, 5, 7, 331331) 2 The appreciation of his services will grow with time.
('9', 141, 5, 8, 331387) He assumed the captainship of the Indians ship at a critical juncture.
('9', 141, 5, 9, 331458) It was to help in the implementation of the gaol resolution 3 that he accepted the chairmanship.
('9', 141, 5, 10, 331555) No one then was in a position to say what the Indian community would do.
('9', 141, 5, 11, 331628) Much appeared then to depend on the Chairmans courage.
('9', 141, 5, 12, 331683) Mr. Essop Mia evinced the requisite courage for conducting the affairs.
('9', 141, 5, 13, 331755) He curtailed his business last year in order to join battle against the Government.
('9', 141, 5, 14, 331839) This year he suffered an assault.
('9', 141, 5, 15, 331873) 4 He kept himself ever in readiness for gaol.
('9', 141, 5, 16, 331919) He took to hawking, with two baskets hanging from his shoulders like a gold neck wear or a garland of flowers.
('9', 141, 5, 17, 332030) It is difficult adequately to realize how his action aroused the communitys enthusiasm.
('9', 141, 5, 18, 332118) Through his courage, Mr. Essop Mia has enabled the community to arrive at a stage where the fulfilment of its pledge has become certain.
('9', 141, 5, 19, 332255) What now remains to be done is very important something that the Indian community cannot afford to ignore and which calls for massive resistance.
('9', 141, 5, 20, 332401) But one cannot blame Mr. Essop Mia for leaving the ship at this critical moment.
('9', 141, 5, 21, 332482) Thrice he put off his plans for a pilgrimage in order to attend to three great tasksthe mosque, the madrasah and the campaign against the Government.
('9', 141, 5, 22, 332632) He has now the right to leave.
('9', 141, 5, 23, 332663) If other Indian chairmen can do as much as Mr. Essop Mia, the communitys success is assured.
('9', 141, 6, 24, 332756) AHMED MAHOMED CACHALIA
('9', 141, 7, 25, 332779) Everyone hopes that Mr. Cachalia will prove Mr. Essop Mias equal.

('9', 141, 7, 27, 332900) The office has been thrust upon him, so to say.
('9', 141, 7, 28, 332948) To me at least it appeared

('9', 142, 1, 10, 333865) But the Indian ship is caught in a storm still at its fiercest.
('9', 142, 1, 11, 333929) Nearer the coast, the storm poses a greater danger to the ship than in mid ocean.
('9', 142, 1, 12, 334011) Even if the voyage ahead is only a short one, the task is onerous.
('9', 142, 1, 13, 334078) Maybe the sailors are tired.
('9', 142, 1, 14, 334107) Columbuss mariners mutinied as he was about to reach America.

('9', 142, 1, 23, 334740) He must be prepared to sacrifice money, property and life in the service of the community and he must be entirely honest, fearless, pure, courteous and modest; these are the qualities which the chairman of the Indian community must have.
('9', 142, 1, 24, 334978) Then alone can satyagraha blossom forth into perfect beauty and achieve success that will evoke the admiration of all the world.
('9', 142, 1, 25, 335107) I for one pray to Khuda Ishwar to endow Mr. Cachalia with all these virtues, and I advise all Indians to offer the same prayer.

('9', 152, 2, 3, 356289) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 17, 1908
('9', 152, 3, 4, 356324) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR
('9', 152, 4, 5, 356347) SIR, You will perhaps allow me to state that your persistent misrepresentation of the Indian standpoint appears now to be wilful rather than unconscious.
('9', 152, 4, 6, 356501) You state that I am willing to accept any education test, however severe, provided it is applied impartially to Europeans and Asiatics.
('9', 152, 4, 7, 356637) This is the exact reverse of what I have stated all along.
('9', 152, 4, 8, 356696) My contention is that there should be a general education test in law, but that, in practice, it may be administered not impartially but differentially.
('9', 152, 4, 9, 356849) The law gives the Minister full discretion, to be used by him as he chooses.
('9', 152, 4, 10, 356926) If he does not possess the discretion, Indians are quite willing that the discretion be given.
('9', 152, 4, 11, 357021) 2 This statement I have made before the public and to your representatives not once but very often.
('9', 152, 4, 12, 357121) Nor, as you have stated in a previous leaderette, is there any question of a subterfuge.
('9', 152, 4, 13, 357210) Administrative inequality must always exist so long as people who are
('9', 152, 5, 14, 357280) 1 This appeared in Indian Opinion, 26 9 1908, under the title Mr. Gandhis Reply.
('9', 152, 5, 15, 357361) The Star had commented editorially as follows: we commend...
('9', 152, 5, 16, 357422) this mornings Times.It finds that the weight of the evidence is on the side of the Colonial Secretary and that the root of the present trouble lies in the endeavour of Mr. Gandhito secure concessionsnot contemplated by Mr. Smuts when he entered into the compact of last January.[Mr. Gandhi] is willing to accept any educational test, however severe, provided it is applied impartially to Europeans and Asiatics.
('9', 152, 5, 17, 357834) But he insists that those admitted under the present or a new Immigration Restriction Act must be treated with absolute equality.
('9', 152, 5, 18, 357964) If we make the educational test very severe, we run the risk of excluding many Europeansif we maintain the present standard and repeal the Asiatic Act of 1907, we throw open the portals to countless AsiaticsThere is no room for compromise, especially [since] Mr. Gandhi scouts all idea of discriminatory legislation. 2 The Star, replying to this later, wrote: We emphatically repudiate the charge that we have wilfully misrepresented either Mr. Gandhi or his compatriots.
('9', 152, 5, 19, 358436) Our reply to the foregoing is that no regulation or ministerial decree can override the express terms of an Act of Parliament.

('9', 153, 1, 2, 358847) not of the same grade live under the same flag.
('9', 153, 1, 3, 358895) All I claim is that the law should be no respecter of persons, especially with regard to educated Indians.
('9', 153, 1, 4, 359002) You cite the authority of The Times, but, if you will pardon me saying so, The Times merely trumpets what has been passed on to it by or on behalf of General Smuts.
('9', 153, 1, 5, 359167) The Times is not, at present, in possession of the full facts of the case.
('9', 153, 1, 6, 359242) I emphatically deny that a new question is now being raised by my countrymen.
('9', 153, 1, 7, 359320) The following briefly are the facts: Before the war, the immigration of Indians was free.
('9', 153, 1, 8, 359410) After the conclusion of peace, immigration generally was regulated under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, under which new educated Asiatics were allowed to enter the country.
('9', 153, 1, 9, 359586) The Asiatic Act of 1907 simply provided for registration of those who were entitled to reside in the country, but, according to the admission made by General Smuts, did not regulate immigration.
('9', 153, 1, 10, 359781) The Immigrants Restriction Act replaced the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and laid down a general education test.
('9', 153, 1, 11, 359895) The Asiatic [Registration] Act was then dishonestly, without even mentioning it, brought in to defraud Indians of their just rights, under sub section 4 of section 2; but, as Indians have never accepted the Asiatic Act and have always steadily, persistently, and amid untold suffering, demanded its repeal, how can they be charged with having brought in a new point?
('9', 153, 1, 12, 360262) It was General Smuts who, in complete breach of his promise when the time came for him to repeal the Act, offered repeal on four conditions 1 , three of which he has, yielding to the force of passive resistance, and finding his administration of the law paralyzed, withdrawn.
('9', 153, 1, 13, 360538) The fourth 2 he does not withdraw, and, until that is granted, in the estimation of British Indians and other Asiatics, he must stand guilty of the charge of dishonesty.
('9', 153, 1, 14, 360708) You and, I am sorry to say, the Progressive leaders, who profess to have Imperial interests at heart, and who profess to lead the party of progress, are allied on the side of dishonesty.
('9', 153, 1, 15, 360895) May I draw a parallel?
('9', 153, 1, 16, 360918) With reference to the Vereeniging Treaty, General Botha interpreted the word native to include Asiatics.
('9', 153, 1, 17, 361023) Lord Milner and Sir Richard Solomon repudiated it, but they accepted the interpretation that General Botha put upon it, and Asiatics are today debarred from the municipal franchise because of such interpretation.
('9', 153, 1, 18, 361236) 3 General Botha, again, said that his people were promised immediate self government by Lord Kitchener.
('9', 153, 1, 19, 361340) In order that British honour might remain

('9', 156, 1, 2, 365261) 87. LETTER TO THE STAR 1
('9', 156, 2, 3, 365286) JOHANNESBURG, September 18, 1908
('9', 156, 4, 4, 365319) THE EDITOR
('9', 156, 5, 5, 365330) THE STAR
('9', 156, 6, 6, 365339) SIR, I am delighted that you emphatically repudiate my suggestion that you may have wilfully misrepresented me.
('9', 156, 6, 7, 365451) Your repudiation fills me with hope that I may yet convince you of the justice of the Indian demand.
('9', 156, 6, 8, 365552) I assume now that you would not mind an open door for highly educated Indians.
('9', 156, 6, 9, 365631) If so, the question is not of whether, but of how.
('9', 156, 7, 10, 365682) You reject my solution to be a species of dishonesty unworthy of statesmen.
('9', 156, 7, 11, 365758) And yet it has been resorted to by statesmen all over the world.
('9', 156, 7, 12, 365823) The Peace Preservation Ordinance gave absolute discretion to the Governor as to the issue of permits.
('9', 156, 7, 13, 365925) White British subjects received them for the asking; other Europeans with little difficulty, but not with the same facility; British Indians after the greatest difficulty.
('9', 156, 7, 14, 366097) The Governor went so far as to establish a separate department 2 for administering the same Ordinance for Indians.
('9', 156, 7, 15, 366212) This was unfair, but not dishonest, because it was openly done.
('9', 156, 7, 16, 366276) The Governor had the discretion and he chose to use it in this very partial manner, as he said, in the interests of the predominant race.
('9', 156, 7, 17, 366414) Indians would not have cavilled at the differential administration, if the Department at one time had not been tainted with corruption and always most niggardly regarding the claims of bona fide refugees.
('9', 156, 8, 18, 366619) You have charged General Smuts with having used his discretion unfairly as to filling the vacancies in the Civil Service with Boers, but whether it is statesmanlike or not will depend upon results.
('9', 156, 8, 19, 366817) In Natal, the Immigration Officer has a discretion as to the education test.
('9', 156, 8, 20, 366894) I will take my oath that Europeans as a rule are not even examined.
('9', 156, 8, 21, 366962) Indians, as a rule, are examined and that, too, severely.
('9', 156, 9, 22, 367020) 1 This appeared in Indian Opinion, 26 9 1908, under the title A Solution Possible.

('9', 157, 1, 4, 367489) Mr. Browne felt the ludicrous position, but did not consider the examination to be dishonest.
('9', 157, 1, 5, 367583) The same thing is, today, done at the Cape.
('9', 157, 1, 6, 367627) The fact is that legal inequality would be an insult to the race.
('9', 157, 1, 7, 367693) Administrative difference would be a concession to prejudice, and Indian acceptance of it would be a graceful and, shall I say, statesmanlike recog nition of such prejudice, as also of the fact that, if we want to live in this country, we must submit to the predominance of the European races.
('9', 157, 1, 8, 367987) In any case, if you agree that a handful of educated Asiatics may safely be allowed to enter without molestation, surely the combined wisdom of the Government and the Progressive Party cannot fail to find a solution that will be acceptable to both Europeans and Indians and end a situation which cannot be viewed with unconcern by any lover of the Empire.

('9', 159, 5, 9, 372408) 91. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS
('9', 159, 6, 10, 372442) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 19, 1908
('9', 159, 7, 11, 372477) THE DIRECTOR OF PRISONS PRETORIA
('9', 159, 8, 12, 372510) SIR, My Association has received a letter in Gujarati from a British Indian named Syed Ali, who has just undergone imprisonment at Boksburg.
('9', 159, 8, 13, 372651) I give below a free translation of the material portion of the letter.
('9', 159, 8, 14, 372722) It is dated the 17th instant, and is written from Springs: I write the following, God between us.
('9', 159, 8, 15, 372820) On the 19th day of August, 1908, I was sentenced by the Magistrate to pay a fine of 10[s] or suffer imprisonment for seven days with hard labour for
('9', 159, 9, 16, 372969) 1 This was released to the Press with the Letter to Director of Prisons, vide the following item.
('9', 159, 9, 17, 373067) Rand Daily Mail, 21 9 1908, published them under the heading.
('9', 159, 9, 18, 373129) Life In Prison: An Indians Complaints: Treated Worse Than Kaffirs.
('9', 159, 9, 19, 373196) The correspondence was also published in Indian opinion, 26 9 1908.
('9', 160, 0, 1, 373264) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 161
('9', 160, 1, 2, 373306) trading without a licence.
('9', 160, 1, 3, 373333) I accepted gaol.
('9', 160, 1, 4, 373350) When I was admitted, a Kaffir came to me and asked me to strip myself naked.
('9', 160, 1, 5, 373427) I did so.
('9', 160, 1, 6, 373437) I was then made to walk, in that condition, barefoot, some distance.
('9', 160, 1, 7, 373506) I was then kept, together with Kaffirs, in cold water, for twentyfive minutes.
('9', 160, 1, 8, 373585) I was then taken out and taken to an office.
('9', 160, 1, 9, 373630) I was then given some clothes to wear, but I did not get any sandals.
('9', 160, 1, 10, 373700) I, therefore, asked the gaoler for some.
('9', 160, 1, 11, 373741) At first, he said no, and then he gave me torn sandals.
('9', 160, 1, 12, 373797) I asked for socks.
('9', 160, 1, 13, 373816) and he used abusive language (untranslateable).
('9', 160, 1, 14, 373864) I asked again, and he said Look here, I will sjambok 1 you. I was then frightened and had I spoken again, he would certainly have struck me.
('9', 160, 2, 15, 374005) On the 20th August, the work given to me was that of carrying and emptying closet buckets.
('9', 160, 2, 16, 374096) I complained to the gaoler about this work, and I received a kick and slaps.
('9', 160, 2, 17, 374173) I still persisted in my complaint, and told him that I would be glad to break stones but would like to be relieved from the work of carrying and emptying these buckets.
('9', 160, 2, 18, 374342) I was then kicked again.
('9', 160, 2, 19, 374367) I became helpless and I had to carry those buckets.
('9', 160, 3, 20, 374419) On the 22nd August, Saturday, I was again kept in cold water for nearly half an hour.
('9', 160, 3, 21, 374505) It was extremely cold.
('9', 160, 3, 22, 374528) I was shivering.
('9', 160, 3, 23, 374545) God knows how cold it was.
('9', 160, 3, 24, 374572) I them became, feverish.
('9', 160, 3, 25, 374597) My chest became bad.
('9', 160, 3, 26, 374618) On the 25th, I was discharged.
('9', 160, 3, 27, 374649) The gaoler, on discharging, said Your may come again, if you wish to die and I retorted, All right, you may kill me if you can. I then returned to Springs by the 11 oclock train.
('9', 160, 3, 28, 374828) And ever since I have been ill, and I have been discharging blood from the chest, and am under medical advice.
('9', 160, 4, 29, 374939) I was treated worse than Kaffir prisoners.
('9', 160, 4, 30, 374982) Happily, I was the only Indian.
('9', 160, 4, 31, 375014) I thank God that I was spared.
('9', 160, 4, 32, 375045) All my book debts have become bad, but I do not care.
('9', 160, 4, 33, 375099) I hope the community will be able to preserve its self respect.
('9', 160, 5, 34, 375163) My Association does not know how far the above statement is true, but, on the face of it, in my humble opinion, it calls for a thorough investigation, which I have no doubt you will make.
('9', 160, 5, 35, 375351) In the meanwhile, I venture to inform the Government through you that, assuming the truth of the above statement, the advice given by my Association is, despite all difficulties, to continue to suffer for what it believes to be a principle.
('9', 160, 6, 36, 375592) 1 meaning to flog with a whip of rhinoceros hide
