('9', 161, 2, 4, 376071) 92. LETTER TO W. HOSKEN
('9', 161, 3, 5, 376095) JOHANNESBURG, September 19, 1908 WILLIAM HOSKEN, ESQ., M.L.A. 1
('9', 161, 4, 6, 376159) JOHANNESBURG
('9', 161, 5, 7, 376172) DEAR SIR, We, the undersigned, are deeply grateful to you for the kindly interest you, as a lover of the Empire and a Christian gentleman, take in the present bitter struggle that Asiatics are engaged in.
('9', 161, 5, 8, 376377) You have told us, at the meeting called by you at your office to day, and attended by Mr. Cartwright, Mr. Pollock, and ourselves, that General Smuts genuinely regrets the persecution which the Asiatic communities, the majority of whom are British subjects, are undergoing.
('9', 161, 5, 9, 376650) We appreciate this sentiment.
('9', 161, 5, 10, 376680) You also said that General Smuts thinks that there would be no insuperable difficulty in meeting our request.
('9', 161, 5, 11, 376790) We, therefore, beg to state as follows: A promise should be given by General Smuts and the leader of the Progressive Opposition 2 that the Asiatic Act will be repealed during the next session of Parliament, and that the status of highly educated Indians will be safeguarded in terms of the request made by the British Indian Association.
('9', 161, 5, 12, 377128) As to the latter question, in order to show our bona fides, we would be quite satisfied with the entry, per year, of, say, six such Indians.
('9', 161, 5, 13, 377269) The great point, therefore, is that they should be able to enter under the general education test.
('9', 161, 5, 14, 377368) There should be no legal distinction.
('9', 161, 6, 15, 377406) 1 Ex President of the Association of Chambers of Commerce of South Africa.
('9', 161, 6, 16, 377481) He was sympathetic to the cause of British Indians; Vide The Transvaal Immigration Bill Debate, 20 7 1907, Johannesburg Letter, 31 12 1907 andJohannesburgg Letter, Before 10 1 1908. 2 Party in the Transvaal Parliament
('9', 162, 0, 1, 377699) VOL. 9 : 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 163
('9', 162, 1, 2, 377741) We do not mind an administration of the law such that only the above number can enter.
('9', 162, 1, 3, 377828) Precedent for such administration is not wanting.
('9', 162, 1, 4, 377878) The Cape and Natal are doing so at present.
('9', 162, 1, 5, 377922) In our opinion, such discretion is given under the Immigrants Restriction Act, but if General Smuts holds otherwise, we have no objection to the Act being so amended as to give the widest discretion to him.
('9', 162, 1, 6, 378129) These are the two chief questions outstanding.
('9', 162, 1, 7, 378176) As a matter of fact, the two are even one, because, if Act 2 of 1907 were repealed, the Immi grants Restriction Act would not come in the way of highly educated Indians entering the Colony.
('9', 162, 1, 8, 378366) We separate the question, because we wish to show that we have no desire to take any undue advantage of the facility provided under the Immigrants Restriction Act, but that we are quite sincere in our declaration that we have no desire to have unrestricted Asiatic immigration into the Colony.
('9', 162, 1, 9, 378660) All we say is that, if the resident Asiatics are to be treated justly and if the whole Asiatic nations are not to be insulted, educated Asiatics should be treated under the general immigration law, and should not be called upon to submit to any registration Act.
('9', 162, 1, 10, 378923) The other questions, namely, those of restoring registration certificates to those who have burned them, and the reinstatement of Mr. Sorabjee are, in our opinion, administrative details, and can be easily arranged when the main points are solved.
('9', 162, 1, 11, 379171) We would mention that, whilst the new Act 1, which has just rece ived the Royal sanction, is very reasonable, there are one or two flawsfor instance, in connection with the claims of those who are already in the Colony and who have entered bona fide, they cannot be called upon to submit to a three years residence test, because some who have not given such proof have already been granted registration certificates.
('9', 162, 1, 12, 379588) It is also felt that, unless the widest latitude is given in the regulations with reference to the giving of thumb impressions on application for licences, that particular section would cause the greatest irritation.
('9', 162, 1, 13, 379805) We assume that all those who are now suffering imprisonment will be discharged simultaneously with a settlement going through, if
('9', 162, 2, 14, 379935) 1 Asiatics Registration Amendment Act (1908).
('9', 162, 2, 15, 379981) Speaking on the Bill in the Transvaal Parliament, Hosken had said that, while he thought the Bill provided for all points raised and hoped that the Indian people would accept it, he differed on one point: the education test.
('9', 162, 2, 16, 380206) He thought that not to give residential permits either to teachers of religion or to any other qualified person was such a narrow interpretation that he could not agree to it.
('9', 162, 2, 17, 380382) He was, however, one of the members who supported the Bill.

('9', 163, 1, 2, 380484) such a fortunate result is attained.
('9', 163, 1, 3, 380521) In conclusion, we beg to mention that we have no desire to defy the Government, and we wish to remain in the country with peace and honour and in obedience to the general laws of the Colony.
('9', 163, 1, 4, 380712) We have been obliged, most reluctantly and in obedience to a higher call, to oppose most strenuously the Asiatic Act.
('9', 163, 1, 5, 380830) We need not, at this stage, go into the reasons for it, but we ask that our opposition to that Act may not be interpreted to mean defiance.
('9', 163, 1, 6, 380970) We beg to add that the leaders who are at present at the Volksrust gaol, and who represent the flower of the Indian community in South Africa, as soon as they were sentenced, sent us the message that they were prepared to suffer to the utmost, but that we should not mind their sufferings but continue the struggle until what we think we are justly entitled to is granted.
('9', 163, 1, 7, 381343) In accordance with your desire, we would treat this communication to be strictly confidential, and any message that you may convey to us will also be so regarded.

('9', 164, 2, 4, 382316) 94. JOHANNESBURG LETTER 1
('9', 164, 3, 5, 382342) HARDSHIPS IN GAOL
('9', 164, 4, 6, 382360) It is becoming more certain each day that we shall be made to drain the cup of misery to its dregs.
('9', 164, 4, 7, 382460) Mr. Syed Ali, who has just returned from gaol after seven days imprisonment at Boksburg, had no end of suffering to put up with.
('9', 164, 4, 8, 382589) He had been sentenced to hard labour.
('9', 164, 4, 9, 382627) He was made to carry closet buckets.
('9', 164, 4, 10, 382664) He was made to stay in cold water for a long spell.
('9', 164, 4, 11, 382716) He was kicked.
('9', 164, 4, 12, 382731) How can one bear this?
('9', 164, 4, 13, 382754) Mr. Cachalia has addressed a letter 2 to the Director of Prisons about Mr. Syed Ali.
('9', 164, 4, 14, 382839) It will perhaps get a hearing, but whether or not it has any effect, we will carry buckets and suffer kicks.
('9', 164, 4, 15, 382948) We will regard this as an expression of our nobility.
('9', 164, 4, 16, 383002) Our bonds will be loosened [only] when we [learn to] enjoy carrying buckets.
('9', 164, 4, 17, 383079) Only then may we claim that we understand the meaning of satyagraha.
('9', 164, 4, 18, 383148) Satyagraha consists in not forsaking what we know to be truth, in enduring any suffering for its sake, no matter even if we die in the process.
('9', 164, 4, 19, 383292) We should do no harm to anyone, for by harming others we violate truth.
('9', 164, 4, 20, 383364) True victory will consist in cultivating the ability to bear with all this.
('9', 164, 4, 21, 383440) Once we comprehend this basic principle, we shall surmount any obstacles the Government may set for us.
('9', 164, 4, 22, 383544) I hope therefore that Indians will not be unnerved by [the report of] Mr. Syed Alis suffering but will be ever ready for gaol should the occasion require it.
('9', 164, 5, 23, 383702) NATAL PRISONERS
('9', 164, 6, 24, 383718) The Natal prisoners are no longer being brought out on the roads to break stones.
('9', 164, 6, 25, 383800) I for one feel disappointed at this.
('9', 164, 6, 26, 383837) If they had to submit to the indignity of breaking stones, that would bring freedom nearer.
('9', 164, 6, 27, 383929) They keep sending messages that no one need be anxious on their account.
('9', 164, 6, 28, 384002) They are prepared for, and will indeed be happy with, [further] gaol terms of any duration.
('9', 164, 6, 29, 384094) We must not [they

('9', 168, 2, 3, 390899) MOVING LETTER
('9', 168, 3, 4, 390913) An Indian, who signs himself A Poor Indian Harassed by the Law, writes as follows: Please do something about solving the [problem of this] law, so that we can somehow return to India safely [after the end of our stay here].
('9', 168, 3, 5, 391137) Otherwise we shall be as good as finished.
('9', 168, 3, 6, 391180) In the existing situation, it is the middle classes that suffer most.
('9', 168, 3, 7, 391250) The big businessmen who have a large capital are not refused credit.
('9', 168, 3, 8, 391319) Whites who used to order goods on our behalf ranging in value from 200 to 500 now refuse credit even up to 5 s.
('9', 168, 3, 9, 391431) They say that they will suspend dealings [with us] until a settlement is reached as regards the law.
('9', 168, 3, 10, 391532) If something is done to effect a settlement which will safeguard the interests of us poor folk, we can breathe a sigh of relief.
('9', 168, 3, 11, 391661) Please see to it that we do not have to suffer longer.
('9', 168, 4, 12, 391716) We cannot help sympathizing with the person who wrote this.
('9', 168, 4, 13, 391776) I must say, all the same, that he is mistaken in what he says.
('9', 168, 4, 14, 391839) It is a mistake to assume, as he has done, that the people who have the capital stand to lose nothing.
('9', 168, 4, 15, 391942) The rich have had to suffer heavier losses, the poor, smaller.
('9', 168, 4, 16, 392005) Every Indian soldier [in this campaign] has suffered thus.
('9', 168, 4, 17, 392064) The whites may refuse to supply us goods on credit, but it is not as though they were the [only] hallowed men 1 [that we may not go to others].
('9', 168, 4, 18, 392208) We must of course be prepared for harassment by the whites.
('9', 168, 4, 19, 392268) Financial loss suffered for the countrys sake should not cause us distress.
('9', 168, 4, 20, 392344) Having said this, I do admit that this letter expresses the views of a number of Indians.
('9', 168, 4, 21, 392434) It is in accordance with these that the campaign is being waged.
('9', 168, 4, 22, 392499) The leaders have ensured that the community carries only those burdens which it can bear.
('9', 168, 4, 23, 392589) In view of this, not a single Indian should lose heart.

('9', 169, 1, 2, 392987) ABOUT NEW ACT
('9', 169, 2, 3, 393001) The new Act comes into force from today.
('9', 169, 2, 4, 393042) A notice for taking out registers will not be issued under it.
('9', 169, 2, 5, 393105) It is said that the notice period will extend up to November 30. Indians resident in the Transvaal have to take out permits within that period.
('9', 169, 2, 6, 393249) As for those who are outside the Colony and do not hold the yellow permits, they have to apply within a year.
('9', 169, 2, 7, 393359) There is nothing, let it be remembered, that either of these [categories of persons] need do yet.
('9', 169, 2, 8, 393457) There is no need to hurry.
('9', 169, 2, 9, 393484) Until a settlement is reached, it would not be meet to take advantage of this law.
('9', 169, 2, 10, 393567) It will therefore be necessary to post pickets at the Permit Office.
('9', 169, 2, 11, 393636) If this is done, and no licences are taken out, a settlement will soon be reached.
('9', 169, 3, 12, 393719) CONFUSION
('9', 169, 4, 13, 393729) A number of queries have been received following The Transvaal Leader report that the community would be content to have only six educated Indians admitted into the Colony every year.
('9', 169, 4, 14, 393913) 1 Some say that this is a fight only for securing the admission of six men, others that this is a new issue altogether.
('9', 169, 4, 15, 394033) There is some misunderstanding here.
('9', 169, 4, 16, 394070) Our demand is that, in law, all educated persons should have equal rights.
('9', 169, 4, 17, 394145) We have already agreed that once there is a single law [for all immigrants], the test can be as severe as [the authorities] wish, so that hardly a single Indian may actually qualify for entry.
('9', 169, 4, 18, 394338) That is to say, those who pass the education test prescribed by law will be entitled to enter.
('9', 169, 4, 19, 394433) We cannot then protest if they do not subject the whites to any test, or only to a very simple one, but give the Indians a severe test.
('9', 169, 4, 20, 394569) If this is done, we will not object.
('9', 169, 4, 21, 394606) The question has been asked as to how we stand to gain by this.
('9', 169, 4, 22, 394670) To this we can reply that we do not want the humiliation of a legal bar, even with the provision for the entry of a limited number of Indians.
('9', 169, 4, 23, 394813) It follows from this line of reasoning that not a single Indian may be admitted, instead of which the entry of six is being ensured [in the suggested compromise].
('9', 169, 4, 24, 394976) Our campaign is directed only against the closing of the door [to Asiatics] by law.
('9', 169, 4, 25, 395060) If the door is closed by law, it will be difficult to re open it.
('9', 169, 4, 26, 395126) If it is closed in practice because the
('9', 169, 5, 27, 395166) 1 Transvaal Weekly Illustrated of September 12 had said:  Mr. Gandhi has offered to bind himself and his community to rest content on this part of the case if the Government will permit the entry of not more than six educated Indians per year  Even if the full number of six came every year, we doubt if that formidable invasion would ruin the Transvaal.
('9', 169, 5, 28, 395521) This principle of limitation is almost the rule with other members of the Empire as to Asiatic immigration. Vide also Letter to W. Kosken, 19 11 1908.
('9', 170, 0, 1, 395672) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 171
('9', 170, 1, 2, 395713) official who holds the test does not allow [the would be immigrants] to pass, remedial measures can be found.
('9', 170, 1, 3, 395823) Natal and the Cape have a law of this kind.
('9', 170, 1, 4, 395867) The whites do not have to pass a test.
('9', 170, 1, 5, 395906) The test for Indians grows more severe every year.
('9', 170, 1, 6, 395957) A [similar] law is still in force in Australia; yet whites have been entering in their hundreds.
('9', 170, 1, 7, 396054) The test for Indians is so severe that not a single Indian has been able to get in so far.
('9', 170, 1, 8, 396145) However, when the prejudice among the Australian people dies down, or when the official in charge is considerate, Indians may be allowed to enter after a reasonable test.
('9', 170, 1, 9, 396316) It is therefore to respect the Colonists feelings and demonstrate the Indian communitys reasonableness that a suggestion has been made for limiting the number to six.
('9', 170, 1, 10, 396483) The law should be the same [for all], but it may be administered differentially; that is all that the demand means.
('9', 170, 1, 11, 396599) There is thus no difference between this demand and the one that was put forward at the mass meeting and which was described by General Smuts as an ultimatum 1 (that is, a demand that implied the threa of war).

('9', 174, 1, 2, 403161) 96. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS
('9', 174, 2, 3, 403195) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 25, 1908 THE DIRECTOR OF PRISONS PRETORIA
('9', 174, 3, 4, 403263) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant in regard to the question of the scale of diet in force for Indian prisoners in the Transvaal prisons.
('9', 174, 3, 5, 403451) I learn for the first time that, instead of there being, as my Association supposed, one scale of diet throughout the Transvaal, there are a number of diet scales in force which vary according to the different prisons.
('9', 174, 3, 6, 403670) My Association is of opinion that this principle of differentiation tends to impose great hardship upon those who are differentiated against, and will be glad to learn whether it is the intention of the Government to appoint a fixed scale of diet for Indian prisoners throughout the Transvaal; and this apart altogether from the question of the meagreness of the diet as exemplified in Johannesburg, to which my Association has already drawn repeated attention.
('9', 174, 3, 7, 404132) I would once more demur to the suggestion that the giving of ghee is an act of grace and not a matter of dietary regulation, as I know it to be a fact that ghee, in January last, figured on the printed dietscale at the Johannesburg Gaol.
('9', 174, 3, 8, 404370) My Association will be glad to learn whether it is finally the intention of the authorities to substitute, in regard to Indian prisoners, ghee wherever fat is prescribed in the Regulations, in view of the religious objection existing to the eating of fat by Indians.
('9', 174, 3, 9, 404637) My Association regrets to find from your letter under reply that its suspicions are confirmed that it is the intention of the Government to starve Indians into submission by compelling them to accept a diet totally unsuited to their habits of life.
('9', 174, 4, 10, 404886) I have, etc., A. M. CACHALIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 3 10 1908
('9', 175, 0, 1, 404978) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 175, 1, 2, 405020) 97. HOW NATAL CAN HELP
('9', 175, 2, 3, 405043) Natal greatly helped in the Transvaal campaign last year 1. This time it has surpassed all expectations.
('9', 175, 2, 4, 405148) The leading figures and the educated Indians in that Colony have gone to gaol of their own accord.
('9', 175, 2, 5, 405247) But this has involved Natal deeper in the campaign.
('9', 175, 2, 6, 405299) It has now to bear the same burden as the Transvaal.
('9', 175, 2, 7, 405352) It has become the duty of the Transvaal as much as it is of Natal to ensure the early release of the Natal prisoners 2. What needs to be done by the Transvaal has been indicated in our Johannesburg Letter 3. Let us therefore think to Natal [for the present].
('9', 175, 2, 8, 405611) One of Natals duties is to remit money regularly in order to maintain the [S.A.B.I.] Committee in London.
('9', 175, 2, 9, 405717) For that purpose, collections should be speeded up.
('9', 175, 2, 10, 405769) It is a matter for satisfaction that steps are being taken towards this.
('9', 175, 2, 11, 405842) 4 Its second duty is that those of its remaining leaders, who were formerly residents of the Transvaal, and well educated Indians, such as barristers and physicians, should enter the Transvaal and follow Mr. Dawad Mahomed.
('9', 175, 2, 12, 406065) Also, those holding 3 registers or permits should be sent to the Transvaal.
('9', 175, 2, 13, 406141) None of them should give his thumb impression at the border, and they should thus fill the Transvaal gaols in order to secure the legitimate rights [of Indians].
('9', 175, 2, 14, 406303) If that is done, the agitation is bound soon to come to a successful conclusion, and many Indians will have had the opportunity to test their newlyacquired power.
('9', 175, 2, 15, 406466) In any case, there can be no doubt that steps such as these will benefit Natal greatly.
('9', 175, 2, 16, 406554) It has many more battles to fight yet.
('9', 175, 2, 17, 406593) It has to fight for the repeal of the law about trade, for the ending of the indentured labourers disabilities and for the cancellation of the oppressive 3 poll tax.
('9', 175, 2, 18, 406759) If a large number of leaders put their new power to test, the experience will stand them in good stead when they attempt to achieve all these things.
('9', 175, 2, 19, 406909) When the whites realize that we have acquired this power, they will think twice before they decide to harass us.
('9', 175, 3, 20, 407022) 1 Vide Awakening among Natal Indians, 3 8 1907 & Speech at Congress Meeting, 4 11 1907 .

('9', 177, 3, 4, 408906) SIR, I am informed by Mr. Vassan Ranchhod that he has just been released from the Germiston Gaol, where he was imprisoned for three days with hard labour.
('9', 177, 3, 5, 409061) He informs my Association that the food supplied to him during that time was mealie pap for breakfast, mealies cooked in or mixed with fat for dinner, and mealie pap for supper.
('9', 177, 3, 6, 409239) There was no alternative diet.
('9', 177, 3, 7, 409270) Should these allegations be found correct, my Association would be glad of an immediate assurance from you that ghee will be substituted for fat, wherever used.
('9', 177, 3, 8, 409431) I need not remind you that to an orthodox Mahomedan or Hindu, food cooked with fat is religiously unclean.
('9', 177, 3, 9, 409538) A Mahomedan may only eat fat from an animal ritually killed, a Hindu may not eat fat at all.

('9', 179, 0, 1, 412260) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 179, 1, 2, 412302) 102. INTERVIEW TO THE NATAL MERCURY
('9', 179, 2, 3, 412338) [DURBAN, September 30, 1908]
('9', 179, 3, 4, 412367) Mr. M.K. Gandhi, the doughty champion of the Indians cause in the Transvaal, is at present on a visit to Durban, and was interviewed yesterday by a representative of this journal.
('9', 179, 4, 5, 412547) Asked what his object was in coming to Durban at the present time, he said he was here in connection with the question of those Indians who had a right to return to the Transvaal owing to their having been pre war residents; and, particularly, to see those Indians who were expected by the German steamer Governer, which was bringing a fair number of Indian passengers for the Transvaal.
('9', 179, 5, 6, 412935) In reply to a query as to the present position of Indians in the Transvaal, M. Gandhi said the fight resolved itself into this, that those who were entitled to be in the Transvaal shall be allowed to enter the Colony, but not give the Government any help with reference to identification, until the two outstanding questions were settled.
('9', 179, 6, 7, 413274) How is this attitude reconciled with the law abiding nature of British Indians? queried the interviewer, and Mr. Gandhi replied that he held there was nothing defiant in the Indians attitude.
('9', 179, 6, 8, 413466) It should be remembered that British Indians were not represented in the Transvaal Parliament, and the only effective manner in which they could make themselves heard was to refuse submission to laws in the passing of which they had no hand, and which violated their conscience or their self respect.
('9', 179, 6, 9, 413767) The Indians, he said, held that General Smuts was in honour bound to repeal the Asiatic Act, but he said he would treat it as a dead letter.
('9', 179, 6, 10, 413908) The Indians said that [that] was not enough, and he (Mr. Gandhi) noticed that even now the old Act was by no means a dead latter.
('9', 179, 6, 11, 414038) Under the circumstances, British Indians asked General Smuts to fulfil his promise by repealing the Act, and, until this was done, they had been advised not to accept the benefits accruing from the new Act.
('9', 179, 6, 12, 414245) This, to Mr. Gandhis mind, was an act of renunciation by the Indian community which should be appreciated by the Colonists throughout South Africa.
('9', 179, 7, 13, 414393) But what as to the educational question? was the next query, to which Mr. Gandhi replied that the answer was very simple.
('9', 179, 7, 14, 414515) If the Act were repealed, the immigration law of the Transvaal would be almost the same as that of Natal.
('9', 179, 7, 15, 414621) British Indians stated that the Transvaal should not be allowed by the Imperial Government, and by those who love the Empire, to lay down a new policy of exclusion based purely on race and colour.
('9', 179, 7, 16, 414818) The present immigration law of the Transvaal, with the assistance of the old Asiatic Act brought about such a constitution.
('9', 179, 7, 17, 414942) Indians, therefore, contended that such should not be the case.
('9', 179, 8, 18, 415006) The people of the Transvaal, he said, were frightened with the bogey of an invasion of half educated youths from Natal, but this was due only to ignorance.
('9', 179, 8, 19, 415162) Indians were not fighting for the rights of half educated fellow countrymen.
('9', 180, 0, 1, 415239) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 181
('9', 180, 1, 2, 415280) were fighting for the honour of India, and for a principle the same principle that was laid down by Mr. Chamberlain before the Conference of Colonial Premiers, viz., that restriction should be based on sensible grounds, and not on grounds of colour or race.
('9', 180, 1, 3, 415538) Once, said Mr. Gandhi, the status of educated Indians was established on a footing of equality in the eye of the law, he personally had no quarrel about the severity of the education rest.
('9', 180, 1, 4, 415727) The essential difference seemed to him to be this: The people in the Transvaal, as indeed in South Africa, tolerated British Indians as an evil; Indians, on the other hand, claimed that those who were domiciled in South Africa should form part of the future nation that was coming into being, and that they should be encouraged in every way to make progress towards refinement and culture.
('9', 180, 1, 5, 416117) In making this statement, he was simply paraphrasing what Mr. Patrick Duncan said the other daythat was to say, that, in a free and self governed South Africa, it would not be possible to contemplate a body of human beings living in a state of servility, or studied and legal inferiority.
('9', 180, 2, 6, 416406) In taking this stand against any such degradation, Mr. Gandhi claimed that his countrymen should receive the sympathy and assistance of all who loved South Africa as their home, and who wished well to it.
('9', 180, 2, 7, 416611) He wanted to make one thing perfectly clear, which was that Indians had no desire to have further unrestricted immigration of Asiatics into any part of South Africa, nor did they wish that there should be no [sic] regulations on unenlightened lines of trade licences in general, but, after these two propositions were established, there should certainly be no differential legislation, otherwise he could only repeat what he had said so often, that in South Africa would be sown the seeds of disruption of the Empire.
('9', 180, 2, 8, 417129) They could not have India as the brightest jewel in the British Crown, and yet use that jewel as a target from every point.
('9', 180, 3, 9, 417253) Mr. Gandhi next made the following statement, in reply to a question as to what he thought would be the effect of unification upon Indians in general: This was a question he had answered before a meeting of the Closer Union Society that had been formed in Johannesburg.
('9', 180, 3, 10, 417523) 1 He there stated that a United South Africa meant for British Indians greater restriction of their liberty, unless a unified South Africa meant unification not only of the white races, but of all British subjects, whether Coloured or white, who had chosen South Africa as their permanent home.
('9', 180, 3, 11, 417818) Under such unification, one would expect liberal principles guiding Indian legislation, but one heard often talk of disfranchisement at the Cape, and further disabilities in Natal.
('9', 180, 3, 12, 417999) The goal of unification seemed to be the nearest approached by the Orange River Colony, so far as Asiatic legislation was concerned.
('9', 180, 3, 13, 418132) In that Colony, Asiatics had absolutely no footing, except as domestic servants.
('9', 180, 3, 14, 418213) It must be plain to anybody that Indians who has vested rights, who had children to educate, and families to rear, would not be satisfied with such a status, and that they would carry on a bitter struggle before they accepted a position such as he had described.
('9', 180, 3, 15, 418476) He could not conceive how the Imperial Government could possibly look with approval upon a scheme of unification which
('9', 180, 4, 16, 418595) 1 Vide Speech at Closer Union Society, 20 8 1908.
('9', 181, 0, 1, 418645) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 181, 1, 2, 418687) would mean the reduction of Asiatics and Natives to a state practically of slavery.
('9', 181, 2, 3, 418771) The next point touched upon was embraced in the following query: What is the feeling of British Indians with reference to the local leaders who have been imprisoned in the Transvaal?
('9', 181, 3, 4, 418954) Mr. Gandhi replied that, from what he could see, the feeling was very bitter.
('9', 181, 3, 5, 419032) His countrymen failed to understand why, in a British Colony.
('9', 181, 3, 6, 419094) British Indians should have to suffer imprisonment because they dared to enter the Transvaal.
('9', 181, 3, 7, 419188) The situation would appear much more painful when he said that the three leaders were pre war residents of the Transvaal.
('9', 181, 3, 8, 419310) Three educated Indians were also suffering imprisonment with them who were stretcher bearers, and held the rank of sergeants at the time of the Zulu rebellion.
('9', 181, 3, 9, 419470) 1 It would be remembered that their services were so much valued that Sir Henry McCallum specia lly recognized them, and, of course, those ex sergeants were entitled to their medals, and would receive them on being released.
('9', 181, 3, 10, 419695) It must appear strange to anybody that such men should be imprisoned, with hard labour, for merely daring to enter the Transvaal.
('9', 181, 3, 11, 419825) One of the leaders imprisoned was known to every prominent Durbanite Mr. Dawad Mahomed, the chairman of the Natal Indian Congress; the other, Mr. Parsee Rustomjee, was equally well known and the third, Mr. M.C. Anglia, besides being a prominent merchant, and secretary of the Congress, had received a very good education in English and French.
('9', 181, 3, 12, 420169) The Indians of Durban, therefore, felt that they had to suffer in order that these leaders might be released before their time.
('9', 181, 3, 13, 420297) They were, therefore, considering the advisability of sending up more Indians, who had a right to enter the Transvaal, to share the same fate as the leaders.
('9', 181, 3, 14, 420455) It was quite evident that General Smuts had rendered an indirect service to British Indians throughout South Africa.
('9', 181, 3, 15, 420572) They had been brought together as never before, and they had also begun to understand their own position, and to realize that they must work shoulder to shoulder, and undergo much suffering, if they were to be recognized as self respecting men in South Africa.
('9', 181, 4, 16, 420833) The reports received from these leaders, through prisoners who had been discharged, were to the effect, said Mr. Gandhi, that they were perfectly cheerful, although the Government was simply starving them in regard to their diet, by reason of providing food which was not suited to Indian habits.
('9', 181, 4, 17, 421130) The leaders stated that they would continue to be in gaol until the struggle was over, and the just rights of British Indians in the Transvaal were recognized.
('9', 181, 4, 18, 421290) Most of them had already been sent out in the public roads to break stones.
('9', 181, 4, 19, 421366) Most of the leaders, Mr. Gandhi added, were very delicate, and Mr. Dawad Mahomed was old, and could hardly life a weight, but such was his love for his country, he understood, that he performed the allotted task with the utmost cheerfulness.
('9', 181, 5, 20, 421608) Do you think the trouble here produces any effect in India? further queried the interviewer.
('9', 181, 5, 21, 421701) Mr. Gandhi answered that he certainly thought it did.
('9', 181, 5, 22, 421755) The meeting that was held last January in Bombay under the presidency of His Highness the Aga Khan was very widely attended.
('9', 181, 5, 23, 421880) Anglo Indians and Indians were absolutely united on this
('9', 181, 6, 24, 421937) 1 Vide Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps, Before 19 7 1906.
('9', 182, 0, 1, 421993) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 183
('9', 182, 1, 2, 422034) question, and so were Mahomedans, Hindoos, Christians, and Parsees.
('9', 182, 1, 3, 422102) The protest male at the Bombay meeting was emphatic and unanimous.
('9', 182, 1, 4, 422169) Advice[s] lately received also showed that the treatment in the Transvaal and consequent suffering had affected British India very deeply.
('9', 182, 1, 5, 422308) Mr. T. J. Bennett, who was the proprietor of one of the leading newspapers of India, writing to the London Times.
('9', 182, 1, 6, 422422) the other day, had said that during his recent travels in India he found that Indians, rich and poor, maharajahs and plebeians, resented the treatment very bitterly, and all wondered what the Imperial Government was doing to allow [sic] it.
('9', 182, 1, 7, 422663) There was no doubt that Lord Morley was being pressed, in connection with this question, from many parts of India.
('9', 182, 1, 8, 422778) Those in India who were the warmest friends of the Empire had been moving heaven and earth in order to secure fair treatment in the Transvaal, as, also, indeed, in South Africa.
('9', 182, 2, 9, 422956) Turning now to the local questions affecting Indians, our representative asked Mr. Gandhi what he thought of the Indian Bills passed during the last session.
('9', 182, 3, 10, 423114) To this query, he replied that he would be very much surprised indeed if these Indian Bills received the Royal assent.
('9', 182, 3, 11, 423233) They laid down a principle, not of compensation, but of confiscation.
('9', 182, 3, 12, 423303) An analogy had been drawn between liquor licensing legislation at Home and trade licences.
('9', 182, 3, 13, 423394) Surely there should be no comparison between the two.
('9', 182, 3, 14, 423448) Liquor licences were admitted to be an evil, and the cause of national degradation.
('9', 182, 3, 15, 423532) Everyone wanted to see public houses restricted, if not done away with altogether.
('9', 182, 3, 16, 423615) Naturally, therefore, there would be, or must be, legislation with reference to these licences; indeed, with reference to them, the question was one of compensation or no compensation.
('9', 182, 3, 17, 423800) All parties were agreed that many public houses should be closed, but with reference to trading licences.
('9', 182, 3, 18, 423906) Whatever might be the local prejudices, nobody could seriously contend that they should be treated on the same footing as liquor licences.
('9', 182, 3, 19, 424045) To his mind, so long as the system of inducing indentured labour from India was continued, there certainly would be no rest in Natal, so far as Indians were concerned, Licensing legislation was merely a useless palliative.
('9', 182, 3, 20, 424268) If indentured immigration were stopped, they would find that the Indian question would solve itself.
('9', 182, 3, 21, 424369) There was scope enough for the present population of Natal, and the European population should certainly expand without taking the bread away from the mouths of the free Indian population.
('9', 182, 3, 22, 424558) But if the system of indenture were continued, there must necessarily be a forced addition to the Indian population, and, consequently, agitation.
('9', 182, 3, 23, 424705) Of course, some of the industries of Natal would, at the commencement, suffer, but he could not help thinking that it was much better that these industries should suffer than that they should have an eternal eyesore in the Colony.
('9', 182, 3, 24, 424936) There might be even a way of compensating these particular industries, but indentured labour should be stopped at the earliest possible moment.
('9', 182, 3, 25, 425080) In this, concluded Mr. Gandhi, Indians could always be relied upon; they were just an anxious that the system should be stopped as any Colonist could be, and he only hoped that Mr. Evans, who had commenced his crusade against the system, would not rest satisfied until it was abolished.
('9', 182, 3, 26, 425367) The Natal Mercury, 1 10 1908

('9', 184, 9, 13, 428274) 1 Romer Robinson, a leading solicitor of Durban, wrote in his letter of October 2, 1908 to the Indian Immigration Restriction Officer: I am told further that leave for me to visit these Indians as their legal adviser has been refused so that they are denied even the privilege of a criminal in gaol.

('9', 185, 0, 1, 428855) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 185, 1, 2, 428897) 106. NATAL INDENTURED LABOURERS
('9', 185, 2, 3, 428929) The [Natal] Advertiser, of Durban, is a determined enemy of the Indian community.
('9', 185, 2, 4, 429011) Even so, Its editor could not remain unmoved by the sufferings of the Indian indentured labourers.
('9', 185, 2, 5, 429110) In a lengthy comment, he has shown that the condition of Indians under indenture is not far different from slavery.
('9', 185, 2, 6, 429226) The members of the Immigration Trust, which administers the affairs of indentured labourers, are elected by their white employers.
('9', 185, 2, 7, 429357) It is these members who appoint the physicians to look after indentured labourers.
('9', 185, 2, 8, 429440) Whether the labourers are happy or not depends very largely on the physicians.
('9', 185, 2, 9, 429519) If the latter in their turn depend for their livelihood on the employers of indentured labour, they are not generally free to express their own views.
('9', 185, 2, 10, 429670) For instance, if a physician certifies that a certain Indian is physically unfit, the employer will not only be deprived of the benefit of his labour during the period of his illness, but will also be required to bear the expenses of his treatment.
('9', 185, 2, 11, 429919) A physician who discharges his duty faithfully is thus likely to incur the displeasure of the employer.
('9', 185, 2, 12, 430023) When there is conflict between duty and self interest, most men prefer the latter.
('9', 185, 2, 13, 430106) The Advertiser suggests therefore that the physicians should be free from the control of the employers.
('9', 185, 2, 14, 430210) The Protector of Indians is almost in the same predicament as the physician.
('9', 185, 2, 15, 430287) The Protector is a member of the Trust Board.
('9', 185, 2, 16, 430333) Since many of the members of the Board are themselves employers of indentured labour, the Protector can make himself heard no more than a reed.
('9', 185, 2, 17, 430477) The Advertiser states further that an indentured labourer who deserts work has to suffer imprisonment.
('9', 185, 2, 18, 430580) Ordinarily, when a servant throws up his job, his employer can only file a civil suit against him.
('9', 185, 2, 19, 430679) For the indentured labourer, on the other hand, no better lot is ordained than imprisonment.
('9', 185, 2, 20, 430772) Pointing out that these conditions are the marks of slavery, the editor of the Advertiser urges the whites of the Colony to stop importation of indentured labour from India and to amend the regulations relating to indenture.
('9', 185, 2, 21, 430997) This is a fine opportunity to secure some improvement in the conditions of indentured labourers.
('9', 185, 2, 22, 431094) We believe, however, that no improvement of any real value is possible.
('9', 185, 2, 23, 431166) The best way is to stop the system of indenture.
('9', 185, 2, 24, 431215) Indian newspapers have published the experiences of an indentured labourer in Mauritius.
('9', 185, 2, 25, 431304) We summarize these elsewhere.
('9', 185, 2, 26, 431334) 1 Probably the reports are somewhat exaggerated.
('9', 185, 2, 27, 431383) It is certain, however, that the condition of indentured labourers in utterly miserable.
('9', 185, 2, 28, 431472) Indian indentured labourers
('9', 185, 3, 29, 431500) 1 Not reproduced here
('9', 186, 0, 1, 431522) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 187
('9', 186, 1, 2, 431563) are not found to be happy in any part of the world.
('9', 186, 1, 3, 431615) A study of world history tells us that at first slaves were generally kept as a substitute for cattle and were treated as such, and that as soon as legalized slavery had disappeared, thanks to the powerful influence of the British people, it was reintroduced in other forms.
('9', 186, 1, 4, 431890) In all such places, or in the neighbourhood of such places, where Indians or members of other communities are employed at present to work under a system of indenture, it was the practice formerly to employ slaves.
('9', 186, 1, 5, 432104) It is natural for the rich to want to control others by force.
('9', 186, 1, 6, 432167) The only way to prevent the suffering which may result from this tendency of theirs is to limit their powers by law.
('9', 186, 1, 7, 432284) In other words, the method of exploiting human labour under a system of indenture should be prohibited by law.
('9', 186, 1, 8, 432395) Therefore, the main duty of Natal Indians in this matter is to start an agitation on a big scale, to adopt satyagraha, if necessary, and bring the system of indenture to an end.

('9', 186, 3, 10, 432589) Indian Opinion, 3 10 1908
('9', 186, 4, 11, 432615) 107. REAL EDUCATION
('9', 186, 5, 12, 432635) We have sometimes been told, orally and in writing, that the satyagraha campaign in the Transvaal, which we have been sponsoring and for which we have been making sacrifices, is all a vain effort.
('9', 186, 5, 13, 432832) These advisers of ours argue, moreover, that there is no justification for such an effort for the sake of the handful of Indians who live in South Africa.
('9', 186, 5, 14, 432987) And in any case, [they say,] Indians will have no choice in the end but to leave this country.
('9', 186, 5, 15, 433082) It will then be found that we had been building on foundations of sand.
('9', 186, 5, 16, 433154) Such reflections have given rise to doubts in the minds of some of our readers.
('9', 186, 5, 17, 433234) Let us consider this matter a little.
('9', 186, 5, 18, 433272) We have no hesitation in saying that the argument is entirely fallacious.
('9', 186, 5, 19, 433346) Those who advance it do not understand the deep significance and the marvellous power of satyagraha.
('9', 186, 5, 20, 433447) It is a counsel of despair to say that Indians will be forced to leave South Africa in the end.
('9', 186, 5, 21, 433543) We visualize no such possibility.
('9', 186, 5, 22, 433577) If the Indian community can practise satyagraha even in a small measure, there is no reason why it should have to leave this country.
('9', 186, 5, 23, 433711) But, even if it is obliged to leave the country, it will have already enjoyed the fruits of satyagraha.
('9', 186, 5, 24, 433815) That one can secure ones rights through satyagraha is not the reason why it is practised.
('9', 186, 5, 25, 433905) Securing ones rights is one of the results, but satyagraha can be offered
('9', 187, 0, 1, 433979) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 187, 1, 2, 434021) without thinking of the result.
('9', 187, 1, 3, 434053) As for efforts of other kinds, we count them wasted if there are no results.
('9', 187, 1, 4, 434130) For instance, if a man aims at seizing the property of another by killing him, and fails either to kill him or to get the property, he will feel frustrated and, maybe, will himself have to face death.
('9', 187, 1, 5, 434331) In satyagraha, it makes no difference whether the result is achieved or not.
('9', 187, 1, 6, 434408) For, there is no cause for frustration in the event of failure.
('9', 187, 1, 7, 434472) In the case of the Transvaal agitation, even if the obnoxious law had continued to be in force, those who resorted to satyagraha would have ever remained victorious.
('9', 187, 1, 8, 434638) Their efforts would have done the community no harm.
('9', 187, 1, 9, 434691) Putting the same thing in another way, we can say that satyagraha is a kind of education in the real sense of the term.
('9', 187, 1, 10, 434811) If we undergo education with a specific object in view, such as earning our livelihood, the education that has been received will not be wasted even though we fail to earn our livelihood through it.
('9', 187, 1, 11, 435010) In like manner, the invaluable education the benefit received through the strengthening of will power which results from our adherence to truth and suffering hardships for its sake, is never lost.
('9', 187, 1, 12, 435207) Those who became satyagrahis, and have remained so, will reap the benefits of satyagraha in any part of the world where they may go.
('9', 187, 1, 13, 435340) If, moreover, we look closely into the result of satyagraha, we shall find that it is always the same, that it is invariably good.
('9', 187, 1, 14, 435471) If on any occasion we fail to discover such a result, it will not be because of any imperfection in satyagraha as such, but because people might not have been steadfast in their satyagraha.
('9', 187, 2, 15, 435661) [From Gujarati]

('9', 187, 4, 17, 435703) 108. OUR AIM
('9', 187, 5, 18, 435716) It is the object of those, both whites and Indians, who are engaged in publishing this paper, to serve the entire human race.
('9', 187, 5, 19, 435842) There is an obvious reason why the first duty of the whites and of the Indians living in Phoenix is to serve the Indian community.
('9', 187, 5, 20, 435973) Indians must, of course, serve India.
('9', 187, 5, 21, 436011) If, instead of doing that, anyone were to claim that he was dedicated to the service of mankind as a whole, it would be nothing more than a pretenceit would be no service, or anything that could be called service.
('9', 187, 5, 22, 436225) The whites who have joined us were formerly engaged in their own avocations.
('9', 187, 5, 23, 436302) There was no need for them to offer their services to the white community.
('9', 187, 5, 24, 436377) Wishing to renounce their selfish pursuits and to devote themselves to the service of others, they decided to join the journal.
('9', 187, 5, 25, 436505) That is how we look at the
('9', 188, 0, 1, 436532) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 189
('9', 188, 1, 2, 436573) matter.
('9', 188, 1, 3, 436581) But we cannot be content with merely bringing out a paper.
('9', 188, 1, 4, 436640) Those who have chosen to settle in Phoenix wish to educate themselves and to extend the benefits of their education to the entire Indian people.
('9', 188, 1, 5, 436785) With this end in view, those members of the journals staff who can teach devote a part of their time to the education of the children living in Phoenix.
('9', 188, 1, 6, 436938) That arrangement has been in force for several months past.
('9', 188, 1, 7, 436998) The members engaged in this teaching work neither receive nor expect payment.
('9', 188, 1, 8, 437076) The number of children at Phoenix is so small that it has not been found necessary to have a separate school building for them.
('9', 188, 1, 9, 437204) Mr. Cordes 1 has offered the use of his building for the purpose.
('9', 188, 1, 10, 437270) Teaching is done through both Gujarati and English.
('9', 188, 1, 11, 437322) Attention is paid to the simultaneous development of mind and body.
('9', 188, 1, 12, 437390) Special emphasis is laid on strengthening the moral character of pupils.
('9', 188, 1, 13, 437463) We aim at making such education available to all Indian children.
('9', 188, 1, 14, 437529) Our chief object is to provide education to those children only who may live in Phoenix.
('9', 188, 1, 15, 437618) For, it is not good for children to have one standard of behaviour in the school and another at home.
('9', 188, 1, 16, 437720) Some who have heard of this school have expressed a desire to send their children to Phoenix.
('9', 188, 1, 17, 437814) But we are not in a position to meet their request for want of residential and school accommo dation facilities.
('9', 188, 1, 18, 437927) We do not have the resources for putting up the required buildings.
('9', 188, 1, 19, 437995) The buildings need money.
('9', 188, 1, 20, 438021) We therefore invite the views of those among our readers who believe that a school along the lines indicated above should be established.
('9', 188, 1, 21, 438159) If they offer us monetary help, we shall be prepared to put up a building for the school as also a hostel.
('9', 188, 1, 22, 438266) Trustees may be appointed to supervise the expenditure to be incurred and the accounts of all expenditure on construction of buildings may be published.
('9', 188, 1, 23, 438419) This is a big undertaking and it is after long deliberation, therefore, that we place the matter before our readers.

('9', 193, 6, 10, 447029) 113. WHY IS RELEASE OF BUSINESSMEN DELAYED?
('9', 193, 7, 11, 447073) Many Indians have been asking this question.
('9', 193, 7, 12, 447118) The answer is that our satyagraha is imperfect.
('9', 193, 7, 13, 447166) A satyagraha campaign obeys the rule of three.
('9', 193, 7, 14, 447213) We can load a cart in proportion to its strength.
('9', 193, 7, 15, 447263) If overloaded, the cart may give way.
('9', 193, 7, 16, 447301) The same holds good in the case of the satyagraha cart.
('9', 193, 7, 17, 447357) The businessmen have gone to gaol for the sake of the community.
('9', 193, 7, 18, 447422) To be sure, the cart of their sufferings will carry the load of other Indians happiness.
('9', 193, 7, 19, 447511) But it will move forward rapidly if others put their hands to the wheel.
('9', 193, 7, 20, 447584) If no men come forward for this, the cart will be stranded on the way.
('9', 193, 7, 21, 447655) Not that it will break.
('9', 193, 7, 22, 447679) But it may take time to reach the destination.
('9', 193, 7, 23, 447726) Satyagraha is in no way to blame for this.
('9', 193, 7, 24, 447769) The continued delay shows that the satyagraha is not as intensive as it should be.
('9', 193, 7, 25, 447852) Because of this the cart has slowed down.
('9', 193, 7, 26, 447894) If more men come forward to join satyagraha, the end will come quite soon.
('9', 193, 7, 27, 447969) This is simple enough.
('9', 193, 7, 28, 447992) In Natal, hundreds of Indians went to see the businessmen off.
('9', 193, 7, 29, 448055) Many of them expressed readiness to follow them.
('9', 193, 7, 30, 448104) But now that the time has come, only 13 have come forward.
('9', 193, 7, 31, 448163) Many showed themselves ready for work.
('9', 193, 7, 32, 448202) Now that the time has arrived, they are not to be found anywhere.
('9', 193, 7, 33, 448268) Everyone seems to ask what he himself would gain, forgetting that satyagraha can be offered only to advance the interests of others.
('9', 193, 7, 34, 448401) One need not even be conscious that the interests of others include ones own.

('9', 201, 6, 8, 463513) These days Indias sons go abroad in large numbers.

('9', 201, 6, 12, 463880) Hinduism, in its general spirit, is a religion which everyone will find acceptable.

('9', 203, 2, 8, 467889) 120. TO SOME INDIANS
('9', 203, 3, 9, 467910) [Before October 14, 1908] Some Indians in the Transvaal, Natal and other parts of South Africa have become confirmed addicts to drink.
('9', 203, 3, 10, 468045) Not only is this against religion, but it has also a debilitating effect both on body and mind.
('9', 203, 3, 11, 468141) It will be difficult for those who have formed this evil habit to join the satyagraha campaign.
('9', 203, 3, 12, 468237) We do not wish to write about the evils of drinking.
('9', 203, 3, 13, 468290) Much has been written about the subject already.
('9', 203, 3, 14, 468339) We shall only say that those who have formed this harmful habit should strive to get rid of it.
('9', 203, 3, 15, 468435) If not, they will bring unnecessary suffering to others; and very often they will find themselves unable to give their services to a good cause, however much they may wish.

('9', 204, 7, 9, 469803) These, then, are my thoughts: The struggle in the Transvaal is not without its interest for India.
('9', 204, 7, 10, 469902) We are engaged in raising men who will give a good account of themselves in any part of the world.
('9', 204, 7, 11, 470001) We have undertaken the struggle on the following assumptions: (1) Passive Resistance is always infinitely superior to physical force.
('9', 204, 7, 12, 470135) (2) There is no inherent barrier between Europeans and Indians anywhere.
('9', 204, 7, 13, 470208) (3) Whatever may have been the motives of the British rulers in India, there is a desire on the part of the nation at large to see that justice is done.
('9', 204, 7, 14, 470361) It would be a calamity to break the connection between the British people and the people of India.
('9', 204, 7, 15, 470460) If we are treated as, or assert our right to be treated as, free men, whether in India or elsewhere, the connection between the British people and the people of India can not only be mutually beneficial, but is calculated to be of enormous advantage to the world religiously, and, therefore, socially and politically.
('9', 204, 7, 16, 470778) In my opinion, each nation is the complement of the other.
('9', 204, 7, 17, 470837) Passive Resistance in connection with the Transvaal struggle I should hold justifiable on the strength of any of these propositions.

('9', 205, 2, 4, 471770) 123. TRIAL OF DAWJEE AMOD AND OTHERS 1
('9', 205, 3, 5, 471809) [VOLKSRUST, October 14, 1908]
('9', 205, 4, 6, 471839) On Wednesday last, before Mr. De Villiers, A.R.M., Mr. Mentz prosecuting, Dawjee Amod was charged as a prohibited immigrant for entering the Colony without having previously made application under the new Registration Act (No.
('9', 205, 4, 7, 472066) 36 of 1908) from outside the Colony.
('9', 205, 4, 8, 472103) Mr. Gandhi defended, and pleaded not guilty.
('9', 205, 4, 9, 472148) Accused had previously entered the Colony, producing a permit and registration certificate and had been arrested.
('9', 205, 4, 10, 472262) He had afterwards promised to leave the Colony and apply for registration under the new Act from Natal, but when Corporal Cameron had shown him the form of application, he had refused to leave the Colony, and was re arrested.
('9', 205, 5, 11, 472488) In cross examination, Corporal Cameron admitted that the accused did not fall within sub sections 3, 5, 6, 7 and 8 of section 2 of the Immigration Act, nor was there any removal order against him.
('9', 205, 5, 12, 472685) He had no reason to suppose the documents produced were not the lawful property of the accused.
('9', 205, 6, 13, 472781) Mr. Gandhi said that accused could choose to enter under the unrepealed Asiatic Act, No.
('9', 205, 6, 14, 472870) 2 of 1907, and that he could not be a prohibited immigrant when he produced his permit.
('9', 205, 6, 15, 472958) He did not come under sub section 4 of section 2 of the Immigration Act.
('9', 205, 7, 16, 473031) The Magistrate found the accused guilty, but said he appeared to have been influenced not to leave the Colony.
('9', 205, 7, 17, 473142) Accused was sentenced to pay a fine of 15 or go to gaol with hard labour for one month.
('9', 205, 8, 18, 473230) Karson Jogi and eight others, including two minors, were similarly charged.
('9', 205, 8, 19, 473306) They were similarly sentenced, except Hirji Mulji, a boy of about 12 years, who was sentenced to pay a fine of 5 or go to jail without hard labour for 14 days.
('9', 205, 9, 20, 473466) Ratanji Sodha, Mawji Karsonji, Ravikrishna Talwantsingh, and Ratanji Rugnath were also charged as prohibited immigrants, pleading not guilty.
('9', 205, 9, 21, 473608) The first three claimed to enter the Colony under the education test, whilst the first two and Ratanji Rugnath claimed pre war residence.
('9', 205, 9, 22, 473746) Mawji Karsonji claimed also to enter as an ex member of His Majestys Volunteer Forces, holding a medal issued to him for services rendered during the Boer War.
('9', 205, 9, 23, 473906) Ravikrishna was born in South Africa.
('9', 205, 10, 24, 473944) Giving evidence on behalf of the accused, Mr. Gandhi said he took the sole responsibility for having advised them to enter the Colony.
('9', 205, 10, 25, 474079) They had largely been
('9', 205, 11, 26, 474101) 1 This was published along with the report of Gandhijis trial, under the heading, Volksrust Again: Mr. Gandhi Sentenced, as Special to Indian Opinion.

('9', 206, 1, 2, 474345) influenced by his advice, though no doubt they had used their own judgment.

('9', 206, 9, 22, 476156) There have been differences between the Government and British Indians whom I represent as Secretary of the British Indian.
('9', 206, 9, 23, 476280) Association, over the Asiatic Act, No.
('9', 206, 9, 24, 476319) 2 of 1907, and after due deliberation, I took upon myself the responsibility of advising my countrymen not to submit to the primary obligation imposed by the Act; but still, as law abiding subjects of the State, to accept its sanctions Rightly or wrongly, in common with other Asiatics, I consider that the Act in question, among other things, offends our conscience, and the only way, I
('9', 206, 10, 25, 476707) 1 After the trial of Dawjee Amod and others, vide the preceding item, Gandhijis case came up before the Court.

('9', 209, 6, 13, 480918) 128. LETTER TO MRS.
('9', 209, 6, 14, 480938) KASTURBA GANDHI
('9', 209, 7, 15, 480954) [VOLKRUST GAOL,] November 9, 1908
('9', 209, 8, 16, 480988) BELOVED KASTUR,
('9', 209, 9, 17, 481004) I have received Mr. Wests telegram today about your illness.
('9', 209, 10, 18, 481065) cuts my heart.
('9', 209, 10, 19, 481080) I am very much grieved but I am not in a position to go there to nurse you.
('9', 209, 10, 20, 481156) I have offered my all to the satyagraha struggle.
('9', 209, 10, 21, 481206) My coming there is out of the question.
('9', 209, 10, 22, 481246) I can come only if I pay the fine, which I must not.
('9', 209, 10, 23, 481299) If you keep courage and take the necessary nutrition, you will recover.
('9', 209, 10, 24, 481371) If, however, my ill luck so has it that you pass away, I should only say that there would be nothing wrong in your doing so in your separation from me while I am still alive.
('9', 209, 10, 25, 481546) I love you so dearly that even if you are dead, you will be alive to me.
('9', 209, 10, 26, 481619) Your soul is deathless.
('9', 209, 10, 27, 481643) I repeat what I have frequently told you and assure you that if you do succumb to your illness, I will not marry again.
('9', 209, 10, 28, 481763) Time and again I have told you that you may quietly breathe your last with faith in God.
('9', 209, 10, 29, 481852) If you die, even that death of yours will be a sacrifice to the cause of satyagraha.
('9', 209, 10, 30, 481937) My struggle is not merely political.
('9', 209, 10, 31, 481974) It is religious and therefore quite pure.
('9', 209, 10, 32, 482016) It does not matter much whether one dies in it or lives.
('9', 209, 10, 33, 482073) I hope and expect that you will also think likewise and not be unhappy.
('9', 209, 10, 34, 482145) I ask this of you.

('9', 211, 1, 2, 483731) 131. SPEECH AT JOHANNESBURG RECEPTION
('9', 211, 2, 3, 483769) [JOHANNESBURG, December 12, 1908] Mr. Chairman, delegates from Natal, My Tamil brethren and other friends, I see you today after two months and ten days.
('9', 211, 2, 4, 483923) I feel as if I was outside all the time and not in gaol.
('9', 211, 2, 5, 483980) It is today that I think I have entered a prison.
('9', 211, 2, 6, 484030) Those who are outside have a more important duty to discharge than those in gaol.
('9', 211, 2, 7, 484112) So long as people who are outside do not exert themselves more vigorously, our bonds are not likely to snap.
('9', 211, 2, 8, 484221) When the station master at Volksrust congratulated me on my release, I told him also that it was really on that day that I found myself in prison, and that I was now facing much heavier tasks than those assigned to me while in gaol.
('9', 211, 2, 9, 484454) In a country where people suffer injustice and oppression and are denied their legitimate rights, their real duty lies in suffering imprisonment.
('9', 211, 2, 10, 484600) And further, so long as the bonds that bind us have not been snapped, I think it is better that we spend our days in gaol.
('9', 211, 2, 11, 484723) This, I think, is the true meaning of religion for those who have faith in God.
('9', 211, 2, 12, 484803) I want to say a few words about the scene that was witnessed at the station today.
('9', 211, 2, 13, 484886) My services have pleased the community.
('9', 211, 2, 14, 484926) You have assembled today in such a large number because you wish to express your appreciation of my having worked for a day at breaking stones, of my having suffered imprisonment and of the other things that I did.
('9', 211, 2, 15, 485141) Where there is God there is truth, and where there is truth there is God.
('9', 211, 2, 16, 485215) I live in fear of God.
('9', 211, 2, 17, 485238) I love truth only, and so God is with me.
('9', 211, 2, 18, 485280) Even if the path of truth does not please the community, it pleases God.
('9', 211, 2, 19, 485353) Therefore I will do what pleases God, even if the community should turn against me.
('9', 211, 2, 20, 485437) The enthusiasm that was in evidence today was heartening enough.
('9', 211, 2, 21, 485502) It shows that all of you, like others who could not be present, approve of the satyagraha campaign that we have launched.
('9', 211, 2, 22, 485624) I have said at Standerton, Heidelberg and other places that the outcome of our campaign does not depend upon whether we win or lose in the Supreme Court.
('9', 211, 2, 23, 485778) We should rather, if need be, bear separation from our families, sacrifice our property for the sake of truth, endure whatever other hardships we may encounter and thus make the voice of truth heard in the Divine Court.
('9', 211, 2, 24, 485998) When the echoes of that voice strike the ears of General Smuts, his conscience will be stirred and he will acknowledge our rights, will see that we invite
('9', 212, 0, 1, 486153) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 213
('9', 212, 1, 2, 486194) suffering in order to secure them, that we have suffered more than enough.
('9', 212, 1, 3, 486269) It is then that we shall get what we have been demanding.
('9', 212, 1, 4, 486327) It is not the Imperial Government that will secure you your rights; you will get them only from God.
('9', 212, 1, 5, 486428) If you fight truthfully with Him as witness, your bonds will be loosened in eight days according to your Chairman, but in less than 24 hours according to me.
('9', 212, 1, 6, 486586) God is present everywhere; He sees and hears everything.
('9', 212, 1, 7, 486643) I am sure that we shall be free when that God stirs their [our opponents] conscience.
('9', 212, 1, 8, 486729) We do not sacrifice as much as we should.
('9', 212, 1, 9, 486771) The moment we do so, our fetters will fall away.
('9', 212, 1, 10, 486820) I shall say more tomorrow.
('9', 212, 1, 11, 486847) Today I have nothing more to say.
('9', 212, 1, 12, 486881) I thank all the friends who have assembled here today.
('9', 212, 1, 13, 486936) I want them to inscribe my words in their hearts and to pray to God that He may make everyone feel the same as I do.
('9', 212, 2, 14, 487053) [From Gujarati]
('9', 212, 3, 15, 487069) Indian Opinion, 19 12 1908
('9', 212, 4, 16, 487096) 132. SPEECH AT HAMIDIA ISLAMIC SOCIETY 2
('9', 212, 5, 17, 487137) [JOHANNESBURG,
('9', 212, 6, 18, 487152) December 13, 1908]
('9', 212, 7, 19, 487171) I said yesterday that we had won.
('9', 212, 7, 20, 487205) We have won because of the sufferings of our people.
('9', 212, 7, 21, 487258) A community, 1,500 members of which have been to gaol, must certainly be considered to have emerged victorious.
('9', 212, 7, 22, 487370) That out of a population of 7,000 as many as 1,500 have been to gaol must surely, I think, be counted as a victory.
('9', 212, 7, 23, 487486) As things are reckoned in this world, it can be said that there has been no victory, because we have not yet secured what we demanded from the Government.
('9', 212, 7, 24, 487641) The Chairman said that, as I was the leader of the community, you should do my bidding.
('9', 212, 7, 25, 487729) But that is not right.

('9', 215, 3, 9, 494296) 134. TRIAL OF THE NAIDOOS AND OTHERS 3
('9', 215, 4, 10, 494335) [JOHANNESBURG, December 18, 1908]
('9', 215, 5, 11, 494369) Upon several Indians, it is said, proceeding to the registration office on Von Brandis square yesterday morning (the 18th instant) in order to comply with Act 36 of 1908, the office was immediately picketed by  passive resisters, says The transvaal Leader.
('9', 215, 5, 12, 494626) The police were sent for, and soon after their arrival they arrested four members of the picket, amongst whom was C.K.T. Naidoo.
('9', 215, 5, 13, 494755) The places of the four men were taken by four others, who, in turn, were arrested.
('9', 215, 5, 14, 494838) A crowd of Indians collected; further arrests were made, and eventually about 27 Indians were charged with having refused to produce registration certificates and to give signatures and impressions of thumbs and fingers.
('9', 215, 6, 15, 495059) Later in the day, the arrested Indians were removed for trial to Government Square.
('9', 215, 6, 16, 495143) The news of their detention had got abroad and, when Mr. Gandhi arrived to conduct the defence, he was escorted by about 200 compatriots.
('9', 215, 7, 17, 495281) The first quartette charged consisted of C.K.T. [Naidoo], L.R.[Naidoo] and L.D. Naidoo and A.V. Chetty.
('9', 215, 7, 18, 495385) Pleas of  Not guilty were entered.
('9', 215, 8, 19, 495420) Mr. Samuels, who prosecuted for the Crown, said that the charge was on the lines of that in the Randeria case.
('9', 215, 8, 20, 495531) The circumstances were the same and the question was whether the Crown should proceed pending the result of Randerias appeal.
('9', 215, 9, 21, 495657) 1 Gandhiji spoke at a reception held in honour of Imam Abdool Kadir Bawazeer, some Natal Indians and himself.
('9', 215, 9, 22, 495767) 2 Gandhiji was garlanded before he addressed the audience.
('9', 215, 9, 23, 495826) 3 The report of the trial of C. K. T. Naidoo, L. R. Naidoo, L. D. Naidoo and A. V. Chetty was published in Indian Opinion under the title: Pickets ArrestedLeaders Before the Court.

('9', 217, 0, 1, 498376) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 217, 1, 2, 498418) 135. MIGHTY STRUGGLE
('9', 217, 2, 3, 498439) It is growing clearer every day that this is indeed a mighty struggle that is being carried on in the Transvaal.
('9', 217, 2, 4, 498552) The Act must, of course, be repealed.
('9', 217, 2, 5, 498590) Undoubtedly, this is an important demand.
('9', 217, 2, 6, 498632) But as time passes, we have the advantage of being able to understand the real nature of the conflict.
('9', 217, 2, 7, 498735) We have stated earlier that the Transvaal Indians are not fighting merely against the Transvaal Government; they are fighting against the Imperial Government as well.
('9', 217, 2, 8, 498902) We have also stated that it is not as if the Transvaal Indians were fighting for themselves alone; they are fighting on behalf of all Indians in South Africa, on behalf of all Indians abroad; in fact, they are fighting for the whole of India.
('9', 217, 2, 9, 499145) We have recently received support for this view from England.
('9', 217, 2, 10, 499207) We give elsewhere summaries of a speech by Colonel Seely and Mr. Ritchs reply to it.
('9', 217, 2, 11, 499292) Colonel Seelys statements in that speech deserve notice.
('9', 217, 2, 12, 499349) He says that Indians must not migrate to a region with a good climate.
('9', 217, 2, 13, 499420) The Coloured peoples and the whites cannot mix with each other and both stand to suffer by such mix ing.
('9', 217, 2, 14, 499525) Indians [he says] are rice eaters and the whites cannot successfully compete with them.
('9', 217, 2, 15, 499613) These statements express the views of the Imperial Government.
('9', 217, 2, 16, 499676) They mean only one thing, namely, that in their view Indians are good enough to work merely as slaves of whites.
('9', 217, 2, 17, 499789) Colonel Seely went on to saw that Indians already settled in the Transvaal and in other Colonies should be allowed to live honourably, saying, in the same breath, that General Botha was right in the policy he was following.
('9', 217, 2, 18, 500013) Colonel Seely is therefore hypocritical when he says that we should be treated honourably.
('9', 217, 2, 19, 500104) His speech in fact implies that Indians residing in lands where whites had already settled should be gradually eliminated.
('9', 217, 2, 20, 500227) The Transvaal Indians therefore have to shoulder a burden on behalf of the whole of India.
('9', 217, 2, 21, 500318) We shall show later that they can easily do so, and they certainly will.
('9', 217, 2, 22, 500391) Colonel Seelys views suggest a change [for the worse] in British policy.
('9', 217, 2, 23, 500464) They represent a rather unworthy aspect of British policy and, if they gain currency, they will herald the decline of the Empire, Therefore, the Indians resistance tends to the good of the British Empire, too.
('9', 217, 2, 24, 500674) Colonel Seelys views will be endorsed only by those who wish that the British Empire should be destroyed, All the Colonists belong to that class.
('9', 217, 2, 25, 500820) They are therefore enemies of the British Empire.
('9', 217, 2, 26, 500870) Indian [passive] resisters, who have been opppsing this view and will continue to do so, may be said to be friends of the Empire.
('9', 217, 2, 27, 501000) If our readers consider the matter in this light, they will easily see that the Transvaal struggle is not merely for permits, of no value in
('9', 218, 0, 1, 501141) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 219
('9', 218, 1, 2, 501182) themselves, nor for the entry of a handful of Indians.
('9', 218, 1, 3, 501237) It is a fight for a noble cause.
('9', 218, 1, 4, 501270) It is a battle of principles.
('9', 218, 1, 5, 501300) Indians have pitted themselves against a mighty force.
('9', 218, 1, 6, 501355) Even so, we make bold to say that it is possible for us to win.
('9', 218, 1, 7, 501419) No one should imagine that this is like hoping that a black ant will carry on its head a potful of jaggery.
('9', 218, 1, 8, 501527) The men who say this do not understand the efficacy of satyagrahathe power of truth.
('9', 218, 1, 9, 501612) What can not be done by millions can be done by a handful of men.
('9', 218, 1, 10, 501678) We come acro ss such instances everywhere.
('9', 218, 1, 11, 501721) This is also true of the Transvaal Indians.
('9', 218, 1, 12, 501765) It is because the Indians here are few that they can put up a good fight.
('9', 218, 1, 13, 501839) It may take time to explain the position to most Indians, to convince them of the beauty of satyagraha, to stop dissensions amongst them.
('9', 218, 1, 14, 501977) If, how ever, the seed of truth strikes root in a few men and blossoms forth, its branches can be planted elsewhere and the tree can thus be multiplied indefinitly.
('9', 218, 1, 15, 502142) Let it not be imagined that mustard seeds cannot make a hill.
('9', 218, 1, 16, 502204) This also is possible; in fact, it has often happened.
('9', 218, 1, 17, 502259) That is the greatness of the Lord of this universe.
('9', 218, 1, 18, 502311) The hill is made up of nothing but particles of earth.
('9', 218, 1, 19, 502366) If one were to inquire how this came about, one would simply feel incredulous.
('9', 218, 1, 20, 502445) And yet we know that the thing has happened.
('9', 218, 1, 21, 502490) Not only do we believe that a few Indians can accomplish this task; we have also said that they can do so quite easily.
('9', 218, 1, 22, 502610) Why do we say this?
('9', 218, 1, 23, 502630) As the satya graha campaign progresses, we see that it is the poor alone who can join it.
('9', 218, 1, 24, 502720) The rich find the burden of their wealth too heavy; they are not able to carry the burden of truth.
('9', 218, 1, 25, 502820) This means that the Transvaal Indians must embrace poverty.
('9', 218, 1, 26, 502880) To think that this is impossible is to give up the effort in despair.
('9', 218, 1, 27, 502950) In what way is this difficult?
('9', 218, 1, 28, 502981) We can never rely on wealth.
('9', 218, 1, 29, 503010) We may even be robbed of it.
('9', 218, 1, 30, 503039) Therefore, let us ourselves renounce it and instead take the sword of truth in our hands.
('9', 218, 1, 31, 503129) If we have the strength to think and act thus, we are bound to get what we have been demanding.
('9', 218, 1, 32, 503225) We have already said that the fight will certainly be carried on.
('9', 218, 1, 33, 503291) Is there any reason to believe that it will not be?
('9', 218, 1, 34, 503343) We find that the community on the whole is united.
('9', 218, 1, 35, 503394) Hundreds of Indians have been, as it were, sanctified through anointment in prisons, They have seen the beauty of gaol life and that are not likely to turn back.
('9', 218, 1, 36, 503556) And most of the Transvaal Indians are in any case poor, so that the question of their retreating simply does not arise.
('9', 218, 1, 37, 503676) We place Colonel Seelys speech before such Indians and beg of them not to be defrauded, while they live, of the glory of such a mighty battle, but win immortal fame for themselvesfor Indiathroughout the world.

('9', 219, 6, 7, 504227) 137. BALANCE SHEET
('9', 219, 7, 8, 504246) The year, according to the English calendar, is drawing to a close.
('9', 219, 7, 9, 504314) In our present state, we attach less importance to our own than to the English calendar.
('9', 219, 7, 10, 504403) We plan our affairs with reference to the English or European calendar.
('9', 219, 7, 11, 504475) We do not wish to suggest that this state of affairs is deplorable in itself.
('9', 219, 7, 12, 504553) But as things stand, it is a sign of our degradation.
('9', 219, 7, 13, 504607) The same thing would hardly have been regarded as unusual if we were really free, Since we want to have good relations with all parts of the world, nothing will be wrong in our following the European calender for the convenience of all.
('9', 219, 7, 14, 504844) However, this is a digression.
('9', 219, 7, 15, 504875) The object of this article is to set out the balance sheet for the year.
('9', 219, 7, 16, 504948) Examining conditions in Natal, we find that the Government of the Colony wanted to enact many laws directed against us.
('9', 219, 7, 17, 505068) But the Imperial Government did not sanction them.
('9', 219, 7, 18, 505119) A commission has been appointed to consider the question of the continued import of inden tured labour, There is every possibility of some good coming out of it.
('9', 219, 7, 19, 505281) But the disallowance of the Bills should give us no reason to be particularly happy.
('9', 219, 7, 20, 505366) Considering its internal difficulties, the [Natal Indian] Congress has done well.
('9', 219, 7, 21, 505448) But those who manage its affairs must give thought to its continued financial difficulties.
('9', 219, 7, 22, 505540) There is not enough enthusiasm among the people.
('9', 219, 7, 23, 505589) Trade is ruined.
('9', 219, 7, 24, 505606) Owing to a fall in land prices, many Indians have been reduced to poverty.
('9', 219, 7, 25, 505681) Even servants are put to hardship.
('9', 219, 7, 26, 505716) Cases of murders among Indians are on

('9', 220, 1, 4, 506064) This is an illustration of the fact that Indians are not free, do not even deserve to be free, for they depend on others for the safety of their lives and property.
('9', 220, 1, 5, 506229) There is lack of education for the mind.
