('9', 224, 1, 2, 515380) 142. EXEMPLARY CASE OF SATYAGRAHA
('9', 224, 2, 3, 515414) In Maritzburg, there is a white named Mr. Green.
('9', 224, 2, 4, 515463) He refused to pay the poll tax.
('9', 224, 2, 5, 515495) So he was produce before a magistrate.
('9', 224, 2, 6, 515534) He declared bluntly that, as it was an unjust tax, he was not willing to pay it.
('9', 224, 2, 7, 515615) The Magistrate has sentenced him to imprisonment.
('9', 224, 2, 8, 515665) Mr. Green is at present undergoing the sentence.
('9', 224, 2, 9, 515714) This is an unusual case.
('9', 224, 2, 10, 515739) Mr. Green does not incite others.
('9', 224, 2, 11, 515773) He feels that the poll tax is an oppressive impost.
('9', 224, 2, 12, 515825) He is not much of an orator.
('9', 224, 2, 13, 515854) He, therefore, resolved in his mind that so far as he was concerned, he would never pay that tax.
('9', 224, 2, 14, 515952) He does not mind the sentence of imprisonment imposed on him in consequence.
('9', 224, 2, 15, 516029) This is satyagraha in the true sense of the term.
('9', 224, 2, 16, 516079) Those who love truth never follow others blindly.
('9', 224, 2, 17, 516129) They go on suffering for the sake of truth.
('9', 224, 2, 18, 516173) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 2 1 1909
('9', 224, 3, 19, 516214) 143 MY SECOND EXPERIENCE IN GAOL [ I ] 1
('9', 224, 4, 20, 516255) INTRODUCTORY
('9', 224, 5, 21, 516268) I think my experience in gaol this time was better than in January 1908. It was good education for me personally, and I believe it will prove useful to other Indians.
('9', 224, 5, 22, 516435) A campaign of satyagraha can take many forms, but it is found that gaol going is the most effective means of fighting political disabilities.
('9', 224, 5, 23, 516577) We shall have to go to gaol often enough, I think; it is necessary not only during the present agitation, but is the only course that can be adopted in fighting future disabilities.
('9', 224, 5, 24, 516759) It is the duty of every Indian, therefore, to know all that is worth knowing about gaol life.
('9', 224, 6, 25, 516853) ARRESTED
('9', 224, 7, 26, 516862) When Mr. Sorabji was arrested, I wished what I could follow him to gaol, or that the agitation would end before he was due to be released.
('9', 224, 7, 27, 517001) I was disappointed.
('9', 224, 7, 28, 517021) The same desire came over me again more intensely, when the brave leaders of Natal went to gaol, and [this time] it was fulfilled.
('9', 224, 7, 29, 517152) While returning from Durban, I was arrested at Volksrust Station on October 7 [1908] for being without my certificate of voluntary registration and refusing to give my finger 
('9', 224, 8, 30, 517328) 1 For articles on his first experience, vide Vol. VIII.
('9', 225, 0, 1, 517384) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 225, 1, 2, 517426) impressions.
('9', 225, 1, 3, 517439) My object in going to Durban was to bring [along with me] educated Indians living in Natal and other Indians who had been previously resident in the Transvaal.
('9', 225, 1, 4, 517599) I had hoped that quite a large number of Indians in Natal would show readiness to follow their leaders [to gaol].
('9', 225, 1, 5, 517713) The Government also felt the same way.
('9', 225, 1, 6, 517752) Accordingly, orders had been issued to the gaoler to make arrangements for the accommodation of more than a hundred Indians, and tents, blankets, utensils, etc., had been sent on from Pretoria.
('9', 225, 1, 7, 517946) I also found, as I alighted at Volksrust accompanied by several Indians, that a large number of policemen were present.
('9', 225, 1, 8, 518066) But all this labour proved superfluous.
('9', 225, 1, 9, 518106) The gaoler and the police were disappointed, for only a small number of Indians from Natal had offered to accompany me.
('9', 225, 1, 10, 518226) There were just six in that train.
('9', 225, 1, 11, 518261) Eight more started from Durban by another train on the same day.
('9', 225, 1, 12, 518326) In all, therefore, only fourteen Indians came.
('9', 225, 1, 13, 518373) All of us were arrested and taken to the lock up.
('9', 225, 1, 14, 518423) The next day we were produced before the Magistrate, but the hearing of the case was postponed for seven days.
('9', 225, 1, 15, 518534) We declined to offer bail.
('9', 225, 1, 16, 518561) Two days later, Mr Mavji Karsanji Kothari, who had joined [us] in spite of the fact that he was suffering from piles, was asked to bail himself out, as his trouble had become aggravated and there was need for a picket in Volksrust.
('9', 225, 2, 17, 518793) SITUATION IN GAOL
('9', 225, 3, 18, 518811) There were in gaol, when we arrived there, Mr. Dawad Mahomed, Mr. Rustomjee, Mr. Anglia [and] Mr. Sorabji Adajania who had initiated the second phase of the movement, and about 25 other Indians.
('9', 225, 3, 19, 519006) It being the Ramzan month, Muslim friend had been observing the raza.
('9', 225, 3, 20, 519076) By special permission, food was sent to them in the evening by Mr. Essop Suleman Kazi.
('9', 225, 3, 21, 519163) Due observance of the fast had thus been made possible.
('9', 225, 3, 22, 519219) Though there is generally no provision for lighting in mofussil gaols, orders had been issued in view of the Ramzan to arrange for lights and provide a clock.
('9', 225, 3, 23, 519378) Mr. Anglia led the namaz.
('9', 225, 3, 24, 519404) Those who were observing the fast were subjected to hard labour during the first few days, but later on no hard labour was exacted from them.
('9', 225, 3, 25, 519546) As for the other Indians, permission had been granted for one of them to attend to the cooking.
('9', 225, 3, 26, 519642) This was done by Mr. Umiyashanker Shelat and Mr. Surendrarai Medh, who were joined later by Mr. Joshi when the number of prisoners went up.
('9', 225, 3, 27, 519782) When these gentlemen were deported, cooking was attended to by Mr. Ratanshi Sodha, Mr. Raghavji and Mr. Mavji Kothari, Later still, when the number rose very high, Mr. Lalbhai and Mr. Omar Osman also
('9', 226, 0, 1, 519982) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 227
('9', 226, 1, 2, 520023) joined.
('9', 226, 1, 3, 520031) Those in charge of cooking had to get up at two or three in the morning and keep busy till five or six in the evening.
('9', 226, 1, 4, 520150) When a considerable number of Indians had already been released, Mr. Moosa Essakji and Imam Saheb Bawazeer took charge of cooking.
('9', 226, 1, 5, 520281) I count it as the good fortune of the Indians concerned that they were served food prepared by the Chairman of the Hamidia Islamic Society and a businessman who had in fact had no experience of cooking.
('9', 226, 1, 6, 520484) When the Imam Saheb and his companions were released, they left the legacy of cooking to me.
('9', 226, 1, 7, 520577) Since I knew something of it, I experienced no difficulty.
('9', 226, 1, 8, 520636) The work remained under my charge only for four days.
('9', 226, 1, 9, 520690) It is now (that is, up to the moment of writing) being looked after by Mr. Harilal Gandhi.
('9', 226, 1, 10, 520781) Though the information as to who was in charge of cooking when we arrived in gaol does not fall under the heading [of this paragraph], I have given it here for the sake of convenience.
('9', 226, 1, 11, 520966) When we entered the gaol, Indians were lodged in three bed rooms.
('9', 226, 1, 12, 521032) In this gaol, Indian and Kaffir prisoners were always lodged separately.
('9', 226, 2, 13, 521105) ARRANGEMENTS IN GAOLS
('9', 226, 3, 14, 521127) There are two wards in the prison for males; one for the whites and one for the Kaffirsthe gaol [also] accommodates other non whites.
('9', 226, 3, 15, 521261) Though they were free thus to lodge the Indians in the Kaffir ward, the gaoler had made provision for them in the ward for the whites.
('9', 226, 3, 16, 521396) There are small cells, each with arrangements to accommodate ten or fifteen or even more prisoners.
('9', 226, 3, 17, 521496) The prison is built entirely of stone.
('9', 226, 3, 18, 521535) The cell has a good height.
('9', 226, 3, 19, 521563) The walls are plastered and the floor is washed so that it always stays very clean.
('9', 226, 3, 20, 521647) Moreover, the walls are frequently whitewashed, so that they always appear fresh.
('9', 226, 3, 21, 521729) The area in front is paved with black stone, and is washed every day.
('9', 226, 3, 22, 521799) It has a water spout which enables three men to bathe simultaneously.
('9', 226, 3, 23, 521869) There are two lavatories, and also benches.
('9', 226, 3, 24, 521913) Above, there is a barbedwire covering intended to prevent prisoners from escaping by climbing the walls.
('9', 226, 3, 25, 522018) Every room is well lighted and properly ventilated.
('9', 226, 3, 26, 522070) The prisoners are locked in at six in the evening, and let out at six in the morning.
('9', 226, 3, 27, 522156) The cell is locked from outside during the night.
('9', 226, 3, 28, 522206) This means that, if anyone has a call of nature to answer, he cannot go out of the cell, and hence commodes, filled with water treated with a germicide, are placed in the cell itself.
('9', 226, 5, 29, 522390) At the time of my imprisonment in Volksrust, the Indian
('9', 227, 0, 1, 522446) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 227, 1, 2, 522488) prisoners were served mealie pap in the morning, and rice, with some vegetable, for the midday and evening meals.
('9', 227, 1, 3, 522602) The vegetable served was mostly potato.
('9', 227, 1, 4, 522642) No ghee was allowed at all.
('9', 227, 1, 5, 522670) Under trial prisoners were allowed, in addition, an ounce of sugar with mealie pap in the morning, and half a pound of bread for the midday meal.
('9', 227, 1, 6, 522816) Some of the under trial prisoners used to share a portion of their bread and sugar with the prisoners undergoing sentences after conviction.
('9', 227, 1, 7, 522957) Prisoners were entitled to meat twice [a week]; since, however, it was not given to either the Hindus or the Muslims, they were entitled to a substitute.
('9', 227, 1, 8, 523111) We therefore made a joint petition 1 and as a result it was ordered that we should receive an ounce of ghee and, on meat days, half a pound of beans in place of meat.
('9', 227, 1, 9, 523278) Moreover, there was some tandalja growing by itself in the gaol garden, and we were allowed to pluck its leaves.
('9', 227, 1, 10, 523391) We were also permitted from time to time to gather onions from the garden.
('9', 227, 1, 11, 523466) There remained, therefore, nothing to complain of about food after ghee and beans had been sanctioned.
('9', 227, 1, 12, 523569) The diet in the Johannesburg Gaol is somewhat different.
('9', 227, 1, 13, 523626) There, only ghee is supplied with rice; no vegetables are allowed.
('9', 227, 1, 14, 523693) In the evenings, there are green vegetables and mealie pap twice in the week, beans on three days, and potatoes, with mealie pap, once.
('9', 227, 1, 15, 523829) Though this scale cannot be considered adequate, as judged by our habits, it is not bad in itself.
('9', 227, 1, 16, 523928) Many Indians have a strong dislike of mealie pap and obstinately refuse to have it.
('9', 227, 1, 17, 524012) But personally I think this is an error.
('9', 227, 1, 18, 524053) Mealie pap is a sweet and strength giving food.
('9', 227, 1, 19, 524101) It can be taken in place of wheat in this country.
('9', 227, 1, 20, 524152) It is very tasty when sugar is added to it, but even otherwise it tastes quite good when one is hungry.
('9', 227, 1, 21, 524256) If one can get used to it, the foregoing scale will not prove inadequate nourishment; on the contrary, one may actually thrive on it.
('9', 227, 1, 22, 524390) With some adjustments, it can be a perfect diet.
('9', 227, 1, 23, 524439) But it is a matter of regret that we have grown so fond of good eating and have pampered ourselves into such habits that we are quick to lose our temper if we do not get the food we are used to.
('9', 227, 1, 24, 524634) This was my experience in Volksrust, and it made me very unhappy.
('9', 227, 1, 25, 524700) There was incessant grumbling about food, and very often there were such fretful scenes as if eating and living were the same thing, or as if we lived only to eat.
('9', 227, 1, 26, 524864) Surely it does not become a satyagrahi to behave in this manner.
('9', 227, 1, 27, 524929) It is our duty to try to get some changes made in the diet.
('9', 227, 1, 28, 524989) If we fail, however, we must remain content with whatever is offered and thus demonstrate to the Government our determination not to yield; this also is our duty.
('9', 227, 1, 29, 525152) There are some Indians who are afraid of going to gaol only because of the inconvenience in the matter of food.
('9', 227, 2, 30, 525264) 1 Vide Petition to Resident Magistrate, 11 10 1908
('9', 228, 0, 1, 525315) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 229
('9', 228, 1, 2, 525356) must make a conscious effort to overcome the craving for good food that might have enslaved them.
('9', 228, 2, 3, 525454) SENTENCED TO IMPRISONMENT
('9', 228, 3, 4, 525480) As I mentioned above, all our cases were postponed for seven days, so that they came up for hearing on the 14th, when some of us were sentenced to a month and others to six weeks with hard labour.
('9', 228, 3, 5, 525677) There was a boy eleven years old who was sentenced to 14 days simple imprison ment.
('9', 228, 3, 6, 525761) I was much worried lest the case against me should be withdrawn.
('9', 228, 3, 7, 525826) The Magistrate retired for some time after the other cases had been disposed of, which made me all the more nervous.
('9', 228, 3, 8, 525943) The view generally expressed earlier was that I would be charged with failure to produce my register and refusal to give my thumb impression, and also with inciting other Indians to enter the Transvaal without any right.
('9', 228, 3, 9, 526164) While I was grappling with the problem in my mind, the Magistrate returned to the court and my case was called out.
('9', 228, 3, 10, 526280) I was then sentenced to a fine of Rs. 25 or to two months hard labour.
('9', 228, 3, 11, 526351) This made me very happy, and I congratulated myself on what I considered to be my good fortune in being allowed to join the others in gaol.
('9', 228, 4, 12, 526491) CLOTHES
('9', 228, 5, 13, 526499) After the sentence was passed, we were issued gaol uniforms.
('9', 228, 5, 14, 526560) We were supplied each with a pair of short breeches, a shirt of coarse cloth, a jumper, a cap, a towel and a pair of socks and sandals.
('9', 228, 5, 15, 526696) I think this is a very convenient dress for work.
('9', 228, 5, 16, 526746) It is simple, and wears well.
('9', 228, 5, 17, 526776) We should have nothing to complain about such a dress.
('9', 228, 5, 18, 526831) We should not mind having it even for everyday wear.
('9', 228, 5, 19, 526884) The dress given to the whites is somewhat different.
('9', 228, 5, 20, 526937) They get a rimmed cap, stockings and handkerchief, in addition to two towels.
('9', 228, 5, 21, 527015) Indians, too, need to be supplied with handkerchiefs.

('9', 228, 6, 23, 527128) 144. INTERVIEW TO THE NATAL MERCURY
('9', 228, 7, 24, 527164) [DURBAN, January 5, 1909]
('9', 228, 8, 25, 527190) Mr. Gandhi, the well known leader of the Natal Indians, who has taken a prominent part in the agitation amongst the Indians in the Transvaal during the past year, is at present on a visit to Durban, and yesterday he was interviewed by a
('9', 229, 0, 1, 527427) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 229, 1, 2, 527469) representative of The Natal Mercury.
('9', 229, 2, 3, 527506) Asked to give a sketch of the present position in the Transvaal, and more especially what has led up to the second stageor Passive Resistance Movement, as it is calledMr. Gandhi said: I have read the editorial notes in the Mercury lately, saying that we have not been conducting this campaign with the same grace and dignity with which we started it, and I should like to say that, when I read that I felt rather grieved, because I have always understood that, whether the Mercury differed from the Indians in their struggle or agreed with them, we always received credit for fair fighting and good intentions.
('9', 229, 2, 4, 528117) I may at once state that there has been no falling away from grace and dignity in our struggle.
('9', 229, 2, 5, 528213) When we commenced that struggle, we did so deliberately, with a desire to use the cleanest weapons possible, and we have not departed from the principles then laid down.
('9', 229, 3, 6, 528383) Asked to give a concise definition of these principles, Mr. Gandhi said: Well, we have eschewed resorting to violence in any shape or form, and we are simply trying to show the Government, by our personal sufferings, that we will not submit to a law which, we consider, wounds our consciences, and is otherwise objectionable.
('9', 229, 3, 7, 528709) This is called passive resistance for want of a better term.
('9', 229, 3, 8, 528770) To put it plainly, it is really fighting evil by patience, not returning evil for evil.
('9', 229, 3, 9, 528858) In this struggle, therefore, there can be no question of violence or intimidation.
('9', 229, 3, 10, 528941) At the same time, I am free to confess that some members of the Indian community, in their over zeal for the cause, have not hesitated to use threats against those who have deserted [and decided] to submit to the law, but whenever such acts have come to the notice of the leaders, they have been promptly dealt with, and every effort has been made to dissociate ourselves from any such acts.
('9', 229, 3, 11, 529333) The charge has also been brought against us that we have invited the Natal Indians to take part in the struggle.
('9', 229, 3, 12, 529446) This is not true.
('9', 229, 3, 13, 529464) The Natal Indians who have gone to the Transvaal have rights of residence there, and they have gone there because they felt that they could not reap the results of our sufferings without, a original residents of the Transvaal, taking their share in them.
('9', 229, 3, 14, 529719) They had a right of access there, for under the new law any Indian who has lived in the Transvaal for a period of three years previous to the war is entitled to return.
('9', 229, 3, 15, 529888) I notice it has also been suggested that we are trying, during this second stage of the struggle, to gain an advantage to which we were not entitled when we took up passive resistance, or at the time when the compromise of last January was effected.
('9', 229, 3, 16, 530138) This, too, is wrong.
('9', 229, 3, 17, 530159) The position at the time to the compromise was perfectly clear.
('9', 229, 3, 18, 530223) The Indians were fighting for the
('9', 230, 0, 1, 530257) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 231
('9', 230, 1, 2, 530298) repeal of the Asiatic Act of 1907. This does not mean that we objected to the complete identification of every Asiatic who was entitled to remain in the country.
('9', 230, 1, 3, 530460) What we objected to was the spirit of the Act of 1907, and some of the objectionable sections of that Act.
('9', 230, 1, 4, 530567) It was the methods that we really objected to.
('9', 230, 1, 5, 530614) For instance, with regard to the finger prints questionfor which I actually suffered physicallyI never, at any stage of the struggle, said that the giving of finger prints was objectionable as such.
('9', 230, 1, 6, 530813) It was owing to the utter disregard of every representation made by the Indians, and of every sentiment which they cherished, that the struggle was really undertaken.
('9', 230, 2, 7, 530980) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi dealt with the compromise entered into and said: Whilst it is true, with regard to that compromise, that there was nothing written in so many words as to the repeal of the Asiatic Act of 1907, reading between the lines one can read even the repeal of the Act in the written terms of the compromise, but as I have said often, and repeat now, General Smuts deliberately, but verbally, promised to repeal the Act, if the British Indians fulfilled their part of the compromise, that is to say, underwent voluntary registration.
('9', 230, 2, 8, 531527) As the whole of South Africa knows, we have done so.
('9', 230, 2, 9, 531580) I might also point out that General Smuts repeated his promise in his speech 1 at Richmond three days after the compromise, and that speech, although it has been brought to his notice, he has never contradicted or qualified.
('9', 230, 2, 10, 531805) If this Act had been repealed, there would certainly have been no agitation whatsoever, and there would have been no question either of the status of educated Indians, because, as has been shown by the latest decision of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal, an educated Indian is not a prohibited immigrant under the Immigration Act of the Transvaal, and his right to enter under that Act is affected and taken away only by means of the Asiatic Act of 1907. Therefore, the repeal of the Asiatic Act of 1907 would have meant the re instatement of the educated Asiatics.
('9', 230, 3, 11, 532373) THE INTERVIEWER: You mean, of course, the new comers?
('9', 230, 4, 12, 532427) MR. GANDHI: Yes; and let it be remembered that these educated Indians were not affected, either before the war or after the war, under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, so that the question of the educated Asiatic is in no sense of the term a new question.
('9', 230, 4, 13, 532684) It is now mentioned prominently and separately, because of the controversy that has arisen over the repeal of the Act, and over the offer made by General Smuts to repeal that Act, and the fulfilment of certain other conditions which were not contemplated at the time of the January compromise, one of
('9', 230, 5, 14, 532985) 1 Vide General Smuts Speech in Richmond, 5 2 1908.
('9', 231, 0, 1, 533036) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 231, 1, 2, 533078) which was that we should forego the rights of educated Asiatics and allow them to be considered as prohibited immigrants under the Immigration Act of the Transvaal.
('9', 231, 1, 3, 533243) I claim that no self respecting Indian could accept a bargain of that nature.
('9', 231, 1, 4, 533321) At the present moment the controversy has assumed, so far as the merits of the case are concerned, a purely academic shape.
('9', 231, 1, 5, 533445) Everybody admits that the Act of 1907 is useless, if not actually harmful, even from the Colonial standpoint.
('9', 231, 1, 6, 533555) The Supreme Court, in its two decisions given recently, has said as much.
('9', 231, 1, 7, 533629) It is not required for the identification or registration of Indians.
('9', 231, 1, 8, 533699) The new Act of last year brings about that satisfactorily.
('9', 231, 1, 9, 533758) With reference to these educated Indians, it is admitted that we are entitled to a few highly educated Indians being allowed to enter the Transvaal for our wants, if we are to remain there as a progressive community.
('9', 231, 1, 10, 533975) The only difficulty with reference to the educated Indians is that, whereas General Smuts states that they can only enter on sufferance on temporary permits, we maintain that they should be able to enter as a matter of right, provided that they pass an education rest, which may be imposed by the immigration officer, and we have further added that the test may be so severe as to allow of only six such men being able to enter the Transvaal during any one year.
('9', 231, 1, 11, 534438) That this could be easily done is shown by the practice in Natal and the Cape, and even in Australia, which has not allowed, so far as I know, a single Asiatic to enter that Colony by means of the education test.
('9', 231, 2, 12, 534651) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said: The passive resisters are now told that whilst these two very reasonable demands might have been granted before passive resistance was taken up, they could not now be granted, because of the influence that any yielding to passive resistance might create on the native mind.
('9', 231, 2, 13, 534954) Personally, I consider that that fear is totally groundless.
('9', 231, 2, 14, 535015) In the first place, if our demands are just, they ought to be granted, whether we are passive resisters or not; and, in the second place, if the natives were to adopt our methods, and replace physical violence by passive resistance, it would be a positive gain to South Africa.
('9', 231, 2, 15, 535293) Passive resisters, when they are in the wrong, do mischief only to themselves, When they are in the right, they succeed in spite of any odds.
('9', 231, 2, 16, 535435) It is not difficult to see in Natal, that, if Bambata, instead of murdering Inspector Hunt, had simply taken up passive resistance, because he felt that the imposition of the poll tax was unjustifiable, much bloodshed would have been avoided, and a great deal of money would have been saved; and, at the same time, if the natives as a body did not feel the imposition of the poll tax, Bambatas passive resistance would have been in vain.
('9', 231, 2, 17, 535873) If, on the other hand, the natives did, in any large body, resent the imposition of the tax, no amount of physical violence by
('9', 232, 0, 1, 536000) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 233
('9', 232, 1, 2, 536041) the Government could possibly have been enough to collect such a tax from people who simply sat still and would not pay it.
('9', 232, 1, 3, 536165) So that the South African Colonists should, in my opinion, rather welcome passive resistance in place of physical violence; and, after all, is it not merely the supersession of the Mosaic law of a tooth for a tooth by Christian law of non resistance of evil by evil?
('9', 232, 2, 4, 536432) THE INTERVIEWER: To narrow down the point, I take it that you are insisting upon the promise, if it was made, or whether it was made or notyou are insisting upon the repeal of the Asiatic Act of 1907, because you only want to establish the absolute right of the educated Indian to go into the Transvaal.
('9', 232, 2, 5, 536736) Is that so?
('9', 232, 3, 6, 536748) MR. GANDHI: If he can pass the test, certainly.
('9', 232, 4, 7, 536796) THE INTERVIEWER: But the Imperial Government has taken up the attitude that a self governing Colony can exclude whom it will; at least, broadly, that is the position which has been taken up.
('9', 232, 4, 8, 536987) On the other hand, you claim a right which the Imperial Government says the self governing Colony is entitled to exercise, and say that it cannot exclude a certain class.
('9', 232, 5, 9, 537158) MR. GANDHI: I dont think that the Imperial Government has at any stage taken up the attitude that self governing Colonies have a perfect right to exclude whom they will; but, if that has been stated, then it is a departure from the Colonial policy hitherto followed.
('9', 232, 5, 10, 537425) I dont think the Imperial Government would pass any such law.
('9', 232, 5, 11, 537487) The Imperial Government made a mistake with reference to the Immigration Law of the Transvaalthat is to say, in no section was there any mention of Asiatics, except in the most indirect manner; but the Govern ment of the Transvaal has placed an interpretation upon one section which brings about that result, and the Imperial Government, having accepted that, now finds it most difficult to intervene effectively.
('9', 232, 5, 12, 537901) If the Imperial Government is now going to say that the self governing Colonies have a perfect right to exclude whom they will, then that is an innovation in Colonial policy hitherto followed.
('9', 232, 5, 13, 538094) You know that, in 1897, the late Mr. Escombe actually submitted to Mr. Chamberlain a draft law to exclude Asiatics from this Colony, and Mr. Chamberlain then said that he would not pass it, and suggested that any exclusion law should not be racial, but should be of a general character.
('9', 232, 5, 14, 538381) That suggestion was adopted, and since then the Natal Act has been copied everywhere throughout the Colonies.
('9', 232, 5, 15, 538491) But, with regard to what members of the Imperial Ministry have said as to the rights of the Colonies to exclusion of whom they will, I dont think you will find any definite pronouncement.
('9', 232, 6, 16, 538679) Asked what was the position to day in the Transvaal, Mr. Gandhi said:
('9', 233, 0, 1, 538749) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 233, 1, 2, 538791) The position to day is that the Indians have gone through the struggle for the last two years, and over 2000 have gone through the prisons of the Transvaalthat is to say, nearly one third of the actual resident Indian population of the Transvaal, and one sixth of the possible Indian population of the Transvaal.
('9', 233, 1, 3, 539104) This has also carried conviction amongst some representative Europeans, and, as a result, a small Committee has been formed, with Mr. W. Hosken as Chairman, which Committee has pledged itself to support the British Indians in their struggle, even to the extent of facing imprisonment, if need be, until the claims put forward by the Indians, which these friends consider to be just, are granted.
('9', 233, 1, 4, 539500) The Government considers that it will be able to starve us into submission.
('9', 233, 1, 5, 539576) It is perfectly true that some may become exhausted and yield, but I believe that we have amongst ourselves a very large and sufficient number to carry on the struggle, in the face of all odds.
('9', 233, 1, 6, 539770) There are some who have al ready sold out their businesses, given up everything, and are merely carry ing on the struggle because they consider that a great principle is involv ed, and if my estimate is true, I can only say that the conclusion can be but one, viz., that our demands will be granted.
('9', 233, 1, 7, 540070) How early or how late that will come about will depend upon our own strength.
('9', 233, 1, 8, 540148) Then, in Eng land we have the South Africa British Indian Committee, with Lord Ampthillsometime acting Viceroy of Indiaas chairman, also working for the same object, and that Committee has on it many influential An glo Indians of wide experience, and I think that, if we are patient enough we will be able to gain sympathy from all quarters.
('9', 233, 1, 9, 540490) Meanwhile, the Transvaal Government has again begun to take active steps.
('9', 233, 1, 10, 540564) I have a telegram saying that nearly 30 Indians have already been deported to Natal, and they have immediately re entered the Transvaal, and now await trial there.
('9', 233, 1, 11, 540728) This time, I understand, they will be charged under a different section, and will, therefore, suffer imprisonment.
('9', 233, 1, 12, 540843) The Natal leaders and 33 others will be brought before the Magistrate, probably to morrow.
('9', 233, 1, 13, 540934) They will share the same fate, so that the process of filling the gaols of the Transvaal has now commenced, and it remains to be seen whether they are equal to the task or not.
('9', 233, 1, 14, 541111) The Government evidently thinks that by these drastic measures, and by the magistrates imposing the fullest penalties provided by the law, the Indians will succumb and submit to it, but I do not think so.
('9', 233, 2, 15, 541316) THE INTERVIEWER: Has the law abiding Indian, rightly in the Transvaal, any substantial grievance against the laws there as they stand today?
('9', 234, 0, 1, 541457) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 235
('9', 234, 1, 2, 541498) MR. GANDHI: Certainly.
('9', 234, 1, 3, 541521) Although we are not now fighting on the ground of any such grievances, there are grievances, For instance, the most law abiding Indian is deprived of the ownership of land, and can not possess a piece of land in the country, except in special Locations.
('9', 234, 1, 4, 541775) That may be said to be a most tangible grievance.
('9', 234, 1, 5, 541825) But that is apart from what we are fighting for.
('9', 234, 1, 6, 541874) The principle involved in this struggle is, or was, at one time, religious, that is to say, the law of 1907 strikes at the religious sentiment of the people, but the principal object now is on account of the honour of the Indian race, for we are to be treated as an integral part of the Empire, or we are not.
('9', 234, 2, 7, 542184) THE INTERVIEWER: That is a very wide principle, but, as I understand it, the real crux of the whole thing is this question of the right of educated Indians to enter the Transvaal.
('9', 234, 2, 8, 542364) In that case there is the statement already referred to as to the Imperial Government not being prepared to quarrel with a.
('9', 234, 2, 9, 542488) self governing Colony which denies that right of entry.
('9', 234, 3, 10, 542544) MR. GANDHI: Then, in that case, we fight both the local Government and the Imperial Government.
('9', 234, 3, 11, 542640) But I still believe that the Imperial Government is with us.
('9', 234, 4, 12, 542701) THE INTERVIEWER: Well, it is a certain impasse just now.
('9', 234, 4, 13, 542758) You are simply fighting to make the position so unbearable that some Imperial action will be taken.
('9', 234, 5, 14, 542858) MR. GANDHI: Well, I have so great a faith in the spirit of the struggle, that I feel that, before the Imperial Government, intervenes, all the Colonies in South Africa will say No, we must grant those just demands. There are already signs of that in the Transvaal, and some prominent Europeans who had at first deprecated our entering on the second struggle are now strongly supporting us.
('9', 234, 5, 15, 543248) The Natal Mercury, 6 1 1909
('9', 234, 6, 16, 543276) 145. SHOPKEEPERS VERSUS HAWKERS
('9', 234, 7, 17, 543308) STOMACH VERSUS LIMBS
('9', 234, 8, 18, 543329) Once upon a time a great quarrel arose between the stomach and the limbs of the body.
('9', 234, 8, 19, 543415) The hands said, We shall do no work.
('9', 234, 8, 20, 543452) We are tired of working.
('9', 234, 8, 21, 543477) We carry food to the mouth every time, but it is the stomach that eats it and wastes it.
('9', 234, 8, 22, 543566) We get no help from the stomach. The legs said, We shall not walk a step.
('9', 234, 8, 23, 543640) We have fruitlessly slaved for the stomach.
('9', 234, 8, 24, 543684) It is only the stomach that really enjoys itself.
('9', 234, 8, 25, 543734) The stomach is honoured like the king.
('9', 234, 8, 26, 543773) It has fallen to us to do the drudgery. The other limbs of the body also made similar
('9', 235, 0, 1, 543859) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 235, 1, 2, 543901) complaints.
('9', 235, 1, 3, 543913) The stomach did a good deal of explaining, saying, The work I put in is not visible.
('9', 235, 1, 4, 543998) The hands merely carry the food to the mouth, and their work is then over.
('9', 235, 1, 5, 544073) The legs enjoy rest after fetching the food.
('9', 235, 1, 6, 544118) But I have to work twenty four hours a day, though you may not be able to see it.
('9', 235, 1, 7, 544200) If I take rest even for a minute, all of you stop working.
('9', 235, 1, 8, 544259) You yourselves will be the first to suffer if you stop working.
('9', 235, 1, 9, 544323) So far as I am concerned, I can carry on my work for some time, though, without you, I too shall have to die ultimately.
('9', 235, 1, 10, 544444) But if you stop working, know for certain that you are virtually dead before I die. However, the limbs were not convinced.
('9', 235, 1, 11, 544567) They stopped working.
('9', 235, 1, 12, 544589) In twenty four hours, the hands, the feet and the other limbs of the body became weak.
('9', 235, 1, 13, 544676) They repented.
('9', 235, 1, 14, 544691) As the stomach did not receive any food, they became worried.
('9', 235, 1, 15, 544753) In the end, they were convinced of the truth of what the stomach had said.
('9', 235, 1, 16, 544828) They realized that the work done by the stomach was not inconsiderable, and that because the stomach worked for many limbs, [the benefit of] its work was spread all over, with the result that it could not be noticed by any particular limb.
('9', 235, 1, 17, 545068) But when the limbs stopped working, they discovered that it was they who were the first victims.
('9', 235, 2, 18, 545165) We were reminded of this story by some letters which we have received.
('9', 235, 2, 19, 545236) The correspondents accuse businessmen in a number of ways.
('9', 235, 2, 20, 545295) Some have gone to the length of abusing them, while others hold out threats against them.
('9', 235, 2, 21, 545385) Many of them put forward religion as the excuse, quite late in the day, for not going to gaol.
('9', 235, 2, 22, 545480) As the limbs in the story became jealous of the stomach, all these persons have become envious of the shopkeepers.
('9', 235, 2, 23, 545595) They charge the Transvaal shopkeepers with having betrayed the hawkers and ruined them.
('9', 235, 2, 24, 545683) The businessmen are enjoying themselves [they say], having sent the hawkers to gaol.
('9', 235, 2, 25, 545768) One of the correspondents, while he refers to hawkers in respectful terms on the one hand, states on the other that they cannot voice their views, freely at meetings because they are afraid of the shopkeepers.
('9', 235, 2, 26, 545978) We have not published these letters, for they are not such as will enhance the prestige of the community.
('9', 235, 2, 27, 546084) The reason for these charges is the fact that some traders have transferred their businesses to the names of their wives or of some whites.
('9', 235, 2, 28, 546224) It behoves these traders to be generous, like the stomach, and reason with the hawkers gently.
('9', 235, 2, 29, 546319) The community has submitted to slavery for a very long time and has never tasted independence.
('9', 235, 2, 30, 546414) Now that we have reached the threshold of independence with the help of the weapon of satyagraha, and are being freed from slavery, everyone, great or small,
('9', 236, 0, 1, 546572) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 237
('9', 236, 1, 2, 546613) finds it difficult to adjust himself naturally to the new situation.
('9', 236, 1, 3, 546682) We envy those whom we find to be superior to the rest.
('9', 236, 1, 4, 546737) There is nothing surprising about this.
('9', 236, 1, 5, 546777) Every nation which has attained freedom has passed through such a stage of heart burning.
('9', 236, 1, 6, 546867) Before a child is delivered, the mother suffers pangs which are like agonies of death.
('9', 236, 1, 7, 546954) It is then that the child is born.
('9', 236, 1, 8, 546989) In the same way, before we see the birth of freedom, not only shall we have to suffer the pangs inflicted by the Government, but also those of our own making.
('9', 236, 1, 9, 547148) The charges against the traders mentioned above are ill conceived.
('9', 236, 1, 10, 547215) Those of them who have transferred their businesses to whites did so neither out of greed nor out of fear of going to gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 11, 547339) Most of them are in fact ready to go to gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 12, 547385) The only object of transferring businesses was to see that we did not ourselves place in the hands of the Government the ammunition that it might use against us.
('9', 236, 1, 13, 547547) We must remind the hawkers that when hands were laid on Indians in January [1908], it was mainly the businessmen who were first attacked.
('9', 236, 1, 14, 547685) Almost all the traders of Standerton have been to gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 15, 547741) The Chairman of the Association, Mr. Cachalia, has been to gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 16, 547806) Mr. Aswat and Mr. Nagadi, who had got themselves arrested with great difficulty, have completed their term of imprisonment and likewise Mr. Ebrahim Kazi is in gaol now; and he too got the opportunity only when he transferred his business to a white.
('9', 236, 1, 17, 548056) Mr. Bhabha went to gaol in Middelburg, and Mr. Belim in Christiana.
('9', 236, 1, 18, 548124) At present Mr. Mahomed Mia is in gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 19, 548163) Thus, a large number of traders have suffered imprisonment.
('9', 236, 1, 20, 548223) Those who came specially from Natal to help us are also leading merchants of the Colony.
('9', 236, 1, 21, 548312) It is therefore not proper to accuse the traders.
('9', 236, 1, 22, 548362) The hawkers ought to see that they do not envy the traders.
('9', 236, 1, 23, 548422) They should be satisfied if the traders go to gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 24, 548474) To say that the traders have ruined them suggests that they think they themselves made a mistake in going to gaol.
('9', 236, 1, 25, 548589) In fact, we should believe that those who are responsible for sending us to gaol have done us good.
('9', 236, 1, 26, 548689) Those who have gone to gaol have been the gainers.
('9', 236, 1, 27, 548740) Those who have not gone to gaol have been the losers.
('9', 236, 1, 28, 548794) Those who have sacrificed their wealth for the sake of their motherland have in reality earned it.
('9', 236, 1, 29, 548893) Those who betrayed their country, their prestige and their pledge, and clung to their money are, really speaking, poor in spite of their riches, We hope therefore that those who have written letters to us and those who hold similar views will ponder over our words and will persist in the fight rather than, by abandoning it, lose the game that we are about to win.
('9', 236, 1, 30, 549259) If it behoves the hawkers to realize this, the traders too cannot be
('9', 237, 0, 1, 549328) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 237, 1, 2, 549370) let off.
('9', 237, 1, 3, 549379) We cannot say that they are entirely blameless.
('9', 237, 1, 4, 549427) No doubt there are some among them who are cowards, to whom their money is their God.
('9', 237, 1, 5, 549513) Their heart is not in the movement.
('9', 237, 1, 6, 549549) Some make big speeches and nothing more.
('9', 237, 1, 7, 549590) All the traders should follow the example of the stomach.
('9', 237, 1, 8, 549648) It gives more to the limbs than it keeps for itself of what it digests.
('9', 237, 1, 9, 549720) Whereas the limbs work only for some time, the stomach slaves all the twenty four hours, not for its own sake but for the sake of the limbs.
('9', 237, 1, 10, 549861) In the same way, it is up to the traders to safeguard the interests of hawkers and their dependants.
('9', 237, 1, 11, 549962) Though they are big men, they must learn to be humble and, though masters, they must act as servants.
('9', 237, 1, 12, 550064) One may transfer ones business to anothers name if it cannot be helped.
('9', 237, 1, 13, 550136) But this is only the last resort, fit enough for half cowards.
('9', 237, 1, 14, 550199) We hope that those who are resolved to be lions, who are brave satyagrahis, will never take out licences in the names of third parties, but help the cause of the community by winding up their businesses and embracing poverty for the present.
('9', 237, 1, 15, 550441) That is the only right way for a man who claims the privilege of social status, of wealth.
('9', 237, 1, 16, 550532) We cannot say that the hawkers have had no reason to complain; no one would have any ground for complaint if every businessman did his duty and sacrificed self interest for the common good.
('9', 237, 1, 17, 550722) The Indians in South Africa have their eyes fixed at present on the Transvaal merchants.
('9', 237, 1, 18, 550811) The hawkers have to fight their battle independently, but in case they give in, the traders will also share part of the blame for that.
('9', 237, 1, 19, 550947) Day by day, the situation in the Transvaal is getting more delicate.
('9', 237, 1, 20, 551016) We pray to God to show the right path to the traders, the hawkers and all other Indians, to keep them resolute, to give them the courage to bear all the hardships that their heroic undertaking may entail.
('9', 237, 1, 21, 551221) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 9 1 1909
('9', 237, 2, 22, 551262) 146. OTHER LEADERS OF NATAL
('9', 237, 3, 23, 551290) Every Indian will want to know what the leaders of Natal have been doing, apart from those who have sacrificed their all for the sake of the country and proceeded to the Transvaal.
('9', 237, 3, 24, 551471) The question that our Johannes burg correspondent has posed for Natal is worth pondering over.
('9', 237, 3, 25, 551566) Every Indian in South Africa is morally bound to help the Transvaal struggle.

('9', 240, 4, 14, 557401) BOARDING
('9', 240, 5, 15, 557410) Those in Phoenix who live with their families can take in up to eight boarders.
('9', 240, 5, 16, 557490) It is intended that the boys who may be accepted as boarders will be treated as ones own children.

('9', 240, 5, 19, 557770) Indians of any caste or community will be admitted.
('9', 240, 5, 20, 557822) No distinctions will be made in such matters as food, etc.

('9', 240, 5, 22, 557957) It will be, in effect, as under: Half a bottle of milk, two ounces of ghee, flour, mealie meal, pulse, rice, fresh fruit, green vegetables, sugar bread, nuts (mainly groundnut).

('9', 241, 2, 3, 558507) The diet does not include tea, coffee or cocoa.
('9', 241, 2, 4, 558555) It is our view, based on our knowledge and experience, that things such as tea are harmful even to adults, and much more so to children.
('9', 241, 2, 5, 558692) Some medical men think that the introduction of tea, etc., has led to an increase in the incidence of ill health.
('9', 241, 3, 6, 558806) Moreover, tea, coffee and cocoa are produced through the labour of men who work more or less in conditions of slavery.
('9', 241, 3, 7, 558925) In Natal, for instance, it is the indentured labourers who work on tea and coffee plantations.
('9', 241, 3, 8, 559020) Cocoa is produced in the Congo, where indentured Kaffirs are made to work beyond all limits of endurance.
('9', 241, 3, 9, 559126) We think that slave labour is used even in the production of sugar.
('9', 241, 3, 10, 559194) Though it is not possible to look too deeply into these matters, we are firmly of the view that these three things should be used as sparingly as possible.

('9', 245, 6, 22, 568368) 151. MY SECOND EXPERIENCE IN GAOL [ II]
('9', 245, 8, 23, 568408) The Government can exact nine hours labour daily from those sentenced to rigorous imprisonment.
('9', 245, 8, 24, 568504) The prisoners are locked in every day at six oclock.
('9', 245, 8, 25, 568557) At half past five in the morning, there is a bell to wake them up, and the cell doors open at six.
('9', 245, 8, 26, 568656) The prisoners are counted when they are locked in and again when the are let out.
('9', 245, 8, 27, 568738) In order that the counting may be orderly and speedy, every prisoner is
('9', 245, 9, 28, 568810) 1 Vide the preceding item.

('9', 246, 1, 2, 568878) required to stand at attention near his bed.

('9', 246, 1, 4, 569025) Then, at seven, work starts.
('9', 246, 1, 5, 569054) The work assigned is of various kinds.
('9', 246, 1, 6, 569093) On the first day, we had to dig up the soil in a field near the main road for purposes of cultivation.
('9', 246, 1, 7, 569196) 1 About 30 Indians were there.
('9', 246, 1, 8, 569227) No one was thus compelled to work if he was not fit enough.
('9', 246, 1, 9, 569287) We were taken there along with the Kaffirs.
('9', 246, 1, 10, 569331) The soil was very hard, and since it had to be dug up with spades, the labour involved was strenuous.
('9', 246, 1, 11, 569433) The day was very hot.
('9', 246, 1, 12, 569455) The place of work must have been at a distance of about one and a half miles from the gaol.
('9', 246, 1, 13, 569547) All the Indians set to work with great energy.
('9', 246, 1, 14, 569594) But only a few of them were used to hard work, so that we were all quite.

('9', 246, 1, 18, 569858) As the day advanced, we found the task quite hard.
('9', 246, 1, 19, 569909) The warder was rather sharp of temper.

('9', 246, 1, 22, 570067) I even saw some of them in tears.
('9', 246, 1, 23, 570101) One, I noticed, had a swollen foot.
('9', 246, 1, 24, 570137) I was sorely distressed at this.

('9', 246, 1, 26, 570257) I too got exhausted.
('9', 246, 1, 27, 570278) There were large blisters on the palms, the lymph oozing out of them.

('9', 246, 1, 30, 570584) Placing my trust in Him, I went on with the work.
('9', 246, 1, 31, 570634) The warder started rebuking me.
('9', 246, 1, 32, 570666) He did so because I was resting.
('9', 246, 1, 33, 570699) I told him that there was no need to shout at me, that I would do my best and work to the utmost limit of endurance.

('9', 248, 1, 2, 573837) 152. LETTER TO RAND DAILY MAIL 1
('9', 248, 2, 3, 573870) PHOENIX, January 9, 1909 THE EDITOR RAND DAILY MAIL [JOHANNESBURG]
('9', 248, 3, 4, 573937) SIR, I notice that there still exists some doubt as to what is wanted by my countrymen in the Transvaal, who have now been fighting against tremendous odds for the past two years.
('9', 248, 3, 5, 574117) I will, therefore, with your per mission, endeavour to state the Indian submission as briefly as possible.
('9', 248, 3, 6, 574224) What we want is the following: (1) Repeal of Act 2 to 1907; (2) Legal recognition of the right of highly educated Indians to enter the Transvaal like any other immigrant, under the education test provided by the Immigration Act of the Colony with such administrative severity in applying the education test as to exclude all but six highly educated Indians in one year.
('9', 248, 3, 7, 574594) Repeal of the old Act is necessary, (1) for the honour of the country, because it is claimed that General Smuts is under promise to repeal the Act.
('9', 248, 3, 8, 574742) (2) Act 2 to 1907 is in conflict with the new Act of 1908, and, a recent decision of the Supreme Court has shown, the running together of the two dissimilar Acts having the same purpose may lead to dangerous results.
('9', 248, 3, 9, 574959) (3) Recent events have shown that Act 2 to 1907 is not meant, [as] was stated by General Smuts at one time, to be a dead letter.
('9', 248, 3, 10, 575088) (4) The Act, being still on the Statute book of the Colony, constitutes an offence to the Turkish Mahomedans, and,
('9', 248, 4, 11, 575203) 1 This letter appears to have been addressed to Rand Daily Mail.
('9', 248, 4, 12, 575268) It has the superscription scored out and the words Statement for Mr. Cartwright substituted.
('9', 248, 4, 13, 575361) The office copy available is imperfect and words in square brackets have been supplied in some places by conjecture.
('9', 249, 0, 1, 575478) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 249, 1, 2, 575520) therefore, continues to offend the religious susceptibilities of Indian Mahomedans.
('9', 249, 1, 3, 575604) (5) It is open to the Government, if they wish to harass British Indians, to enforce the most objectionable clauses of the Act.
('9', 249, 1, 4, 575732) As to the educated British Indians, General Smuts [stated that there will be no] objection raised [to the entry] of such persons, if they apply under the Asiatic Registration Act.
('9', 249, 1, 5, 575912) This is highly unsatisfactory, because (1) the powers granted by the Asiatic Act refer only to temporary permits; (2) such temporary permits, even though they may be of long duration, would still make the holders prohibited immigrants; (3) the permits, therefore, would prevent the holders [from] carrying on their profession; (4) temporary permits would leave their holders at the mercy of the Government.
('9', 249, 1, 6, 576319) What Indians want, in place of such makeshifts, is the retention of the undoubted right of highly educated Indians to enter the Transvaal as free immigrants, provided that they pass any education test that the authorities may impose.
('9', 249, 1, 7, 576553) If it be objected that there is no such power reserved in law as to enable the Minister to impose severe or discriminating testsI deny that the present law is not enough for the purposemy countrymen will offer no objection to administrative discrimination against them.
('9', 249, 1, 8, 576823) Thus, power can be given to the Minister to set any education test, even different tests for different classes, the Ministers decision in such cases being final and not appealable to the Supreme Court.
('9', 249, 1, 9, 577025) Under such a severe test, it will be competent for the Government to limit the entry of highly educated Indians to only six in any one year.
('9', 249, 1, 10, 577166) My countrymen resent a racial bar as regards educated Indians, it being deemed a national dishonour.
('9', 249, 1, 11, 577267) Whilst, therefore, the matter with General Smuts is largely sentimental, with Indians it is one of vital principle.
('9', 249, 1, 12, 577383) Repeal of Act 2 of 1907 is necessary, whether we demand it or not.
('9', 249, 1, 13, 577450) Amendment of the Immigration Act is necessary, because of the severe condemnation by the Supreme Court of its several clauses.
('9', 249, 1, 14, 577577) Why not, then, at the time of amending it, free it from the taint of the
('9', 250, 0, 1, 577650) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 251
('9', 250, 1, 2, 577691) Asiatic Act, and alter it so as to give the Minister additional powers regarding the imposition of the education test?
('9', 250, 1, 3, 577810) Indians on their part will undertake not to raise passive resistance over the administration of the education test, so long as six highly educated Indians are passed under the test during any single year.
('9', 250, 2, 4, 578015) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('9', 251, 4, 11, 580251) 155. MY SECOND EXPERIENCE IN GAOL [III]
('9', 251, 5, 12, 580291) We were advised to make a sincere attempt to do our best.
('9', 251, 5, 13, 580349) The work assigned to us was also light.
('9', 251, 5, 14, 580389) We had to dig up pits and fill them on municipal land adjoining the main road.
('9', 251, 5, 15, 580468) This allowed occasional rest.
('9', 251, 5, 16, 580498) But I found from experience that, left to our conscience and our God, we are shirkers.
('9', 251, 5, 17, 580585) For I observed that the men slackened in their work.
('9', 251, 5, 18, 580638) It is my confirmed belief that we get a bad name because of this habit of shirking work and also that this habit is one of the reasons why our struggle is being prolonged.
('9', 251, 5, 19, 580810) Satyagraha is a difficult as well as an easy method Our bona fides must not be in doubt.
('9', 251, 5, 20, 580899) We bear no ill will to the Government.
('9', 251, 5, 21, 580938) We do not regard it as our enemy.
('9', 251, 5, 22, 580972) If we are fighting it, it is with a view to correcting its errors and making it mend its ways.
('9', 251, 5, 23, 581067) We would not be happy to see it in difficulties.
('9', 251, 5, 24, 581116) We believe that even our resistance is for its good.
('9', 251, 5, 25, 581169) It follows from this line of reasoning that we at any rate should work to the best of our ability in gaol.
('9', 251, 5, 26, 581276) If we believe that we have no moral obligation to work [hard], it is not right that we put in the full amount of work in the presence of the warder.
('9', 251, 5, 27, 581425) If it is not just that we should work, then we should not submit to the warder, but resist him rather and suffer any further term of imprisonment that may be awarded to us in consequence.
('9', 251, 5, 28, 581613) But there is no Indian who holds such a view.
('9', 251, 5, 29, 581659) If some of them do not work [hard enough], there is no more to it than mere laziness and desire to shirk work.
('9', 251, 5, 30, 581770) It does not become us thus to be lazy or to shirk work.
('9', 251, 5, 31, 581826) As satyagrahis, it is our duty to do whatever work is given to us; if we worked [as well as we could] without any fear of the warder, we would
('9', 252, 0, 1, 581969) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 253
('9', 252, 1, 2, 582010) be spared all harassment.
('9', 252, 1, 3, 582036) There would then be no question of our being made to overwork ourselves.
('9', 252, 1, 4, 582109) Because of the habit of shirking work, people were put to some difficulties in gaol.
('9', 252, 1, 5, 582194) After this digression, let us return to the main story.
('9', 252, 1, 6, 582250) As days passed, our work became lighter, as I have pointed out above.
('9', 252, 1, 7, 582320) The batch which included me was next assigned the task of maintaining cleanliness in the gaol garden and looking after its cultivation.
('9', 252, 1, 8, 582456) Our work was mainly to sow maize seeds, clear the potato bed and dust the potato plants.
('9', 252, 1, 9, 582545) And then, for two days, they took us to dig a municipal tank.
('9', 252, 1, 10, 582607) Our work there consisted of digging, piling up the earth and carrying it away in barrows.
('9', 252, 1, 11, 582697) This again was hard work.
('9', 252, 1, 12, 582723) We had a taste of it only for two days.
('9', 252, 1, 13, 582763) I had a swollen wrist, which was cured when treated with earth.
('9', 252, 1, 14, 582827) The place being at a distance of four or five miles, we used to be taken there in a trolley.
('9', 252, 1, 15, 582920) We had to cook our meal near the tank, so that we also carried with us the necessary provisions and fuel.
('9', 252, 1, 16, 583026) Here, too, the contractor was not satisfied.
('9', 252, 1, 17, 583071) We could not equal the Kaffirs.
('9', 252, 1, 18, 583103) After making us work on the tank for two days, they gave us some other work.
('9', 252, 1, 19, 583180) Hitherto they used to take out mostly such Indians as were strong enough for work.
('9', 252, 1, 20, 583263) Now, however, they were formed into groups.
('9', 252, 1, 21, 583307) Some of them were sent to dig out the weeds that had shot up round the soldiers tombs.
('9', 252, 1, 22, 583394) Others were sent to clean the graveyard.
('9', 252, 1, 23, 583435) This arrangement continued for some time.
('9', 252, 1, 24, 583477) Meanwhile, after the Barberton case, nearly 50 Indians were released.
('9', 252, 1, 25, 583547) During the remaining period, we were assigned work in the garden.
('9', 252, 1, 26, 583613) This included digging, reaping, sweeping, etc.
('9', 252, 1, 27, 583660) This cannot be considered to be heavy work; rather, it was conductive to vigour of health.
('9', 252, 1, 28, 583751) One may at first get bored when engaged on such work for nine hours at a stretch, but one doesnt feel it after getting used to it.
('9', 252, 1, 29, 583882) Apart from the kind of work described above, it is the duty of the men in every cell to carry the bucket for urine, etc., placed in it.
('9', 252, 1, 30, 584018) I observed that our people are unwilling to do such work.
('9', 252, 1, 31, 584076) In fact, there is no reason why one should mind it.
('9', 252, 1, 32, 584128) It is wrong to think of any work as humiliating or degrading.
('9', 252, 1, 33, 584190) Moreover, those who have offered themselves for imprisonment cannot afford to stand on prestige thus.
('9', 252, 1, 34, 584292) I saw that sometimes there was some argument as to who should carry the urine bucket.
('9', 252, 1, 35, 584378) If we have understood the full meaning of satyagraha, we would compete with one another in offering to do such
('9', 253, 0, 1, 584489) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 253, 1, 2, 584531) work, instead of making difficulties about it, and one would feel honoured if the work fell to ones lot.
('9', 253, 1, 3, 584636) That is to say, the honour would not consist in being required by the Government to work, but, since the work had in any case to be attended to, he who was the first to offer himself would deserve special honour.
('9', 253, 1, 4, 584849) Since we have resolved to bear all suffering, each one of us may as well come forward to suffer more than others, and he who suffers most should feel most honoured.
('9', 253, 1, 5, 585014) An example of this was once set by Mr. Hassan Mirza.
('9', 253, 1, 6, 585067) He has been suffering from a very bad disease of the lungs.
('9', 253, 1, 7, 585127) He is delicate of health.
('9', 253, 1, 8, 585153) All the same, he gladly took upon himself whatever work fell to his lot from day to day.
('9', 253, 1, 9, 585242) Furthermore, he gave no thought to his health.
('9', 253, 1, 10, 585289) Once, Kaffir warder asked him to clean the chief warders privy, which he instantly started doing.
('9', 253, 1, 11, 585387) As he had never done such work, he vomited.
('9', 253, 1, 12, 585431) He was not upset by this.
('9', 253, 1, 13, 585457) while he was cleaning another privy, I happened to come up and see him engaged upon the work.
('9', 253, 1, 14, 585551) I was astonished.
('9', 253, 1, 15, 585569) To be sure, I felt great affection for him.
('9', 253, 1, 16, 585613) On inquiry, I learnt about the first privy.
('9', 253, 1, 17, 585657) Another time, the same Kaffir warder was ordered by the chief [warder] to find two Indians to clean the latrines specially set apart for the Indians.
('9', 253, 1, 18, 585807) The warder approached me about this and asked me to name two persons.
('9', 253, 1, 19, 585877) I thought I was the best person for such work, and so I went myself.
('9', 253, 1, 20, 585946) Personally, I feel no shame in this kind of work.
('9', 253, 1, 21, 585996) I think we should accustom ourselves to it.
('9', 253, 1, 22, 586040) Because of the dislike we feel for such work, not only do we find the front of our houses and our lavatories generally dirty, but also originate, or spread, epidemics such as the plague, etc.
('9', 253, 1, 23, 586232) We assume that lavatories are bound to be unclean, and thus we frequently invite the charge of being dirty.
('9', 253, 1, 24, 586340) Once an Indian was sentenced to solitary confinement, that is to say, he was locked up in a cell by himself, for refusing to do such work.
('9', 253, 1, 25, 586479) Of course, I see nothing wrong in our having to submit to any kind of sentence.
('9', 253, 1, 26, 586559) But, in this particular case, the penalty could have been avoided.
('9', 253, 1, 27, 586626) It is, moreover, not proper that we should hold ourselves back from such work.

('9', 253, 1, 31, 587072) If we are hurt by the nature of the work assigned to us, we cannot take part in any fight worth the name.

('9', 255, 3, 23, 591249) He asked me in broken English why I had been brought there in that fashion.

('9', 255, 3, 25, 591379) Then came a Chinese.
('9', 255, 3, 26, 591400) He appeared to be worse.
('9', 255, 3, 27, 591425) He came near the bed and looked closely at me.
('9', 255, 3, 28, 591472) I kept still.
('9', 255, 3, 29, 591486) Then he went to a Kaffir lying in bed.
('9', 255, 3, 30, 591525) The two exchanged obscene jokes, uncovering each others genitals.
('9', 255, 3, 31, 591591) Both these prisoners had charges of murder and larceny against them.
('9', 255, 3, 32, 591660) Knowing this, how could I possibly sleep?
('9', 255, 3, 33, 591702) Thinking that I would bring this to the notice of the Governor the next day, I fell asleep for a while late in the night.

('9', 256, 1, 3, 592347) All these are indirect benefits of satyagraha.
('9', 256, 1, 4, 592394) As soon as we rose the following day, I was taken to where the other prisoners were lodged, so that I had no chance to complain to the Governor about what had happened.
('9', 256, 1, 5, 592563) I have, though, resolved in my mind on an agitation to ensure that Indian prisoners are not lodged with Kaffirs or others.
('9', 256, 1, 6, 592686) When I arrived at the place, there were about 15 Indian prisoners.
('9', 256, 1, 7, 592753) Except for three, all of them were satyagrahis.
('9', 256, 1, 8, 592801) The three were charged with other offences.
('9', 256, 1, 9, 592845) These prisoners were generally lodged with Kaffirs.

('9', 256, 1, 12, 593174) This is a matter of shame to us.

('9', 260, 2, 6, 601740) 158. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('9', 260, 3, 7, 601767) JOHANNESBURG, January 20, 1909
('9', 260, 4, 8, 601798) [SIR,] The Indian community is now entering upon the third and, perhaps, the final stage of the struggle, which has now been raging for the last two and a half years.
('9', 260, 4, 9, 601965) Hitherto, it has not been necessary for the British Indian merchants to sacrifice their goods entirely, and to reduce themselves to poverty.
('9', 260, 4, 10, 602106) They have, in order to free themselves for the struggle, largely contracted their businesses, but not given them up entirely.
('9', 260, 4, 11, 602232) The saying that, under an unjust Government, only those who countenance and participate in their injustice can enrich themselves or retain their riches is about to be realised in the present case.
('9', 260, 4, 12, 602429) In order further to circumvent us, and seeing that gaols have ceased to have any terrors for us, rules 2 have been framed under the Criminal Procedure Code, laying down the mode of selling the goods of those who may be fined by Magistrates without the alternative of imprisonment.
('9', 260, 4, 13, 602710) This move is clearly aimed at Indian merchants.
('9', 260, 4, 14, 602758) They have, therefore, to face voluntary poverty, enforced poverty, or disgrace, They have no desire to enrich what is to them an unjust
('9', 260, 5, 15, 602894) 1 This appeared in Indian Opinion, 23 1 1909. Gandhiji was present at the meeting of Cachalias creditors on January 22 and presumably drafted this letter.
('9', 260, 5, 16, 603049) Vide also Letter to Rand Daily Mail, 22 1 1909.
('9', 260, 6, 17, 603097) 2 These rules framed by the Judges of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal under the provisions of Section 280 of Ordinance No.
('9', 260, 6, 18, 603223) 1 of 1903 provided for the execution of a warrant for the levy of a fine as in civil cases, for the Crown to be in the position of the judgement creditor, for the bailiff to attach goods sufficient to cover the costs of execution as well as the amount of the warrant and for the term of imprisonment to be reduced in the proportion of the amount of fine realized.
('9', 260, 6, 19, 603587) Vide Indian Opinion, 9 1 1909.
('9', 261, 0, 1, 603618) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 261, 1, 2, 603660) Government at the expense of their creditors or themselves.
('9', 261, 1, 3, 603720) They have no desire to face disgrace.
('9', 261, 1, 4, 603758) My advice, therefore, to my coutrymen, both as a merchant and as Chairman of the British Indian Association, is that they must all for the present cease to be merchants, and return the goods they have to their creditors, if any, or otherwise close down their stores.
('9', 261, 1, 5, 604025) To set an example, I have myself decided to take the first step, and I am doing so with the greatest deliberation, though not without some hesitation.
('9', 261, 1, 6, 604176) No formal vote of the Association will be or can be taken as to the momentous step.
('9', 261, 1, 7, 604260) It is most difficult to expect all Indian storekeepers, who have remained hitherto true to the struggle, to sell their all and follow the narrow path chosen by some of us.
('9', 261, 1, 8, 604432) If they cannot rise to the occasion, I think that, even then, they will have deserved well of their countrymen, if not of the Colonists, in that they have braved dangers and difficulties during the past thirty months.
('9', 261, 1, 9, 604650) Yet, if we prize our principle better than our pockets, the only advice that I can tender to my countrymen is that they should rise to the occasion and take this final step.
('9', 261, 1, 10, 604824) Then will the Colonists realise, if they cho[o]se to, that this is not, so far as the Indians are concerned, a struggle for retaining our hold of the trade we have, or for unfair competition, or for bringing into the country men who have no right to be in it.
('9', 261, 1, 11, 605084) The only question, so far as we are concerned, is that of national honour and our conscience.
('9', 261, 1, 12, 605178) 1 In other words, we are endeavouring to show that we are worthy to be citizens of South Africa.
('9', 261, 1, 13, 605275) It is likely that many Indians, during the last stage of the struggle, may fall.
('9', 261, 1, 14, 605356) We see, also, that the struggle will be prolonged.
('9', 261, 1, 15, 605407) Attempts are being made by ill disposed persons within our own ranks and by interested Europeans to sow dissensions in our own camp.
('9', 261, 1, 16, 605540) All these things we expected, but they cannot deter us from the course we have adopted; and whether, after many have fallen, we are a small or a large body, our sufferings will continue until justice is satisfied.
('9', 261, 2, 17, 605754) I am, etc.,

('9', 262, 1, 2, 606335) 159. LETTER TO CREDITORS 1
('9', 262, 2, 3, 606362) [JOHANNESBURG, January 20, 1909] [GENTLEMEN,] I regret to inform you that a meeting of my creditors will be called, at the Offices of the British Indian Association, 21 24 Court Chambers, Corner of Rissik and Anderson Streets, as 3 p.m., on Friday, the 22nd inst.
('9', 262, 2, 4, 606626) My financial position is not the cause of calling this meeting, but I, as Chairman of the British Indian Association, in view of the determination of the Government to ruin the British Indian merchants who declined to accept the Asiatic Registration Act until the promise of General Smuts is redeemed, and until the status of the educated Indians is placed upon a firm footing, can no longer continue to carry on my trade with safety to my creditors or myself.
('9', 262, 2, 5, 607087) I may state that, evidently on instructions from the Law Department, the magistrates are now imposing heavy fines upon merchants who trade without licences, without the alternative of imprisonment.
('9', 262, 2, 6, 607285) Rules have been gazetted, laying down the manner in which goods are to be sold for these fines.
('9', 262, 2, 7, 607381) In saying this, I do not complain either about the magistrates imposing severe penalties or about the Government framing these rules.
('9', 262, 2, 8, 607515) They are in their own estimation entitled to compel submission to their laws.
('9', 262, 2, 9, 607593) I only claim that the British Indians are in their turn entitled to resist by their sufferings laws which they consider are in conflict with their national honour and conscience.
('9', 262, 2, 10, 607772) Under these circumstances, so long as the struggle lasts, there is no course left open to me but to hand over what I possess to my creditors, rather than allow those possessions which, after all, I hold in trust for themto be sold.
('9', 262, 2, 11, 608004) I am aware that I should also consider myself responsible to convert these goods into money, and pay my creditors in cash, but my private interests have to give way to the public interest, and seeing that I cannot sell my possessions by auction, to the advantage of my creditors, I have decided to call them together and place my position before them, and ask them to take over the goods and my other assets.
('9', 262, 2, 12, 608413) Should the struggle happily come to an end in the near future, or
('9', 262, 3, 13, 608479) 1 Signed by A. M. Cachalia, Chairman, British Indian Association, it is possible that this and the preceding item were written at the same time.
('9', 263, 0, 1, 608624) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 263, 1, 2, 608666) whenever it ends, I should be pleased to take over the goods as they are, and sell them for the benefit of my creditors.
('9', 263, 1, 3, 608787) But as to the disposal of my possessions at the forthcoming meeting, I shall place myself entirely in my creditors' hands.
