('9', 265, 1, 2, 612205) 162. LETTER TO RAND DAILY MAIL 1
('9', 265, 2, 3, 612238) JOHANNESBURG, January 22, 1909
('9', 265, 3, 4, 612269) TO THE EDITOR
('9', 265, 5, 5, 612283) Perhaps you will allow me to pass a few comments upon your leaderette 2 and the remarks made upon what you are pleased to call thelatest move of the British Indian community.
('9', 265, 5, 6, 612458) I will not go into many side issues that arise out of your remarks; but I venture to say that either you do not understand the spirit of the struggle that my countrymen have been carrying on, or you do not care to understand it.
('9', 265, 5, 7, 612687) The latest move is not intended to coerce European merchants into taking action.
('9', 265, 5, 8, 612768) Your interviewer received the replies to the questions he asked.
('9', 265, 5, 9, 612833) 3 There are, therefore, many gaps to fill up.
('9', 265, 5, 10, 612879) He took away from me only one side of the question.
('9', 265, 6, 11, 612931) In the latest move, Indian merchants do not desire that a single European merchant shall suffer.
('9', 265, 6, 12, 613028) On the contrary, they have undertaken voluntarily to suffer even on behalf of their creditors.
('9', 265, 6, 13, 613123) In giving the notice to his creditors, Mr. Cachalia has sinply informed the creditors of the danger in which the goods entrusted to his care have been placed by the action of the Governmentyou will perhaps add by the action of the British Indians as well.
('9', 265, 6, 14, 613379) Mr. Cachalia presented to the meeting of his creditors 4 a balance sheet of which any debtor would be proud, and he made a statement before his creditors which I hold to be perfectly honourable.
('9', 265, 6, 15, 613574) He has shown not olny 20s in the  on paper, but he has also stated that he does not desire to receive from his creditors a clean discharge against the handing over of his stock to them, but he added that he was willing, in the event of any loss being incurred on these assets, to make good the loss to the creditors out of his future earnings, if he is allowed to make any by the Government of the country of his adoption.
('9', 265, 7, 16, 613997) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 30 1 1909, under the title Letter from Mr. Gandhi.
('9', 265, 7, 17, 614088) 2 Vide Comments by Rand Daily Maily 30 1 1909.
('9', 265, 8, 18, 614135) 3 The report of this interview is not available.
('9', 265, 8, 19, 614184) 4 Vide the preceding item.
('9', 266, 0, 1, 614211) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 267
('9', 266, 1, 2, 614252) Nor does the latest move consist in British Indian merchants simply calling a meeting of their creditors, and associating them by force of circumstances in their sufferings to some slight extent.
('9', 266, 1, 3, 614448) All British Indian merchants are not debtors of Europeans only; perhaps 50% of Mr. Cachalias creditors are Indian.
('9', 266, 1, 4, 614563) In any case, British Indian merchants may be divided as follows: (a) those who have European as well as Indian creditors, (b) those who have European creditors only, (c) those who have no creditors.
('9', 266, 1, 5, 614762) All these three classes have been advised to close down their businesses and dispose of their belogings.
('9', 266, 1, 6, 614867) You will therefore see that only to a small extent will British Indians have to trouble their European creditors.
('9', 266, 1, 7, 614981) The latest move, therefore, is not a matter of any coercion at all.
('9', 266, 1, 8, 615049) If you imply that European creditors will now have to take greater interest in the question, I admit the charge; but it only means that the suffering of my countrymen have again told.
('9', 266, 1, 9, 615233) Passive resistance consists purely and simply in the undergoing of every variety of suffering by passive resisters.
('9', 266, 1, 10, 615349) To call this defiance is a prostitution of terms; and how can the surrendering of all their belongings, including their profits, by British Indian merchants, the consequent pecuniary loss, and the acceptance of voluntary poverty be called a degeneration!
('9', 266, 2, 11, 615604) You have also remarked upon picketing, and called it intimidation.
('9', 266, 2, 12, 615671) Picketing, in the case of the Indians, will deserve to be called intimidation, when the missionary efforts of the Salvation Army and other such philanthropic bodies merit the term of open defiance, coercion and intimidation.
('9', 266, 3, 13, 615896) I am, etc.,
('9', 266, 4, 14, 615908) M. K. GANDHI
('9', 266, 5, 15, 615921) Rand Daily Mail, 23 1 1909
('9', 267, 0, 1, 615948) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 267, 1, 2, 615990) 163. WHAT DOES THE STRUGGLE MEAN?
('9', 267, 2, 3, 616024) The Transvaal struggle can be said to have entered on its third phase.
('9', 267, 2, 4, 616095) It will be observed from our news letters that some Indians are now giving in.
('9', 267, 2, 5, 616174) It also appears that there are rifts among them.
('9', 267, 2, 6, 616223) This need not depress us.
('9', 267, 2, 7, 616249) It is so in every conflict.
('9', 267, 2, 8, 616277) It is very difficult to climb the last steps.
('9', 267, 2, 9, 616323) There are very few horses in a race; even then, not all of them remain on the course till the endthey cannot.
('9', 267, 2, 10, 616433) Some of them just stall.
('9', 267, 2, 11, 616458) Some others get exhausted.
('9', 267, 2, 12, 616485) Some die while running; only a few reach the destination.
('9', 267, 2, 13, 616543) The same thing happens in the history of every community.
('9', 267, 2, 14, 616601) There is, therefore, no cause for disappointment in the developments mentioned above.
('9', 267, 2, 15, 616687) In a campaign which produced thousands of Indians who have held out with determination for two years, there are bound to be some who will reach the goal.
('9', 267, 2, 16, 616841) We have yet to secure the repeal of the obnoxious Act and to safeguard the rights of the educated.
('9', 267, 2, 17, 616940) But that is not the only purpose of the struggle.
('9', 267, 2, 18, 616990) That we should get training in organizing a movement, learn to be resourceful and demonstrate that we are not cowards but menthis also is a part of the meaning of our struggle, but not the whole of it.
('9', 267, 2, 19, 617192) The main object of this fight is that we should learn to be men, to be a nation, to cease being the goats that we are and be lions, and to show to the world that we are one people, that we are the children of India ready to lay down our lives for her.
('9', 267, 2, 20, 617444) The great Thoreau said that one sincere man is more than a hundred thousand insincere men.
('9', 267, 2, 21, 617535) We want to know how many of us are sincere.
('9', 267, 2, 22, 617579) This the fight will tell us.
('9', 267, 2, 23, 617608) Thus, to learn to be sincere is far more difficult than to secure repeal of the Act.
('9', 267, 2, 24, 617693) It is wrong for us to get demoralized when we see others giving in.
('9', 267, 2, 25, 617761) It is such behaviour that is the true mark of cowardice.
('9', 267, 2, 26, 617818) The white nations taunt us with being brave enough to start with, but betraying lack of purpose at the critical moment.
('9', 267, 2, 27, 617938) We want to prove that we are nothing of the kind.
('9', 267, 2, 28, 617988) The all too powerful Government of the Transvaal will not succeed in proving that we are [pliable] like wax.
('9', 267, 2, 29, 618097) True religion consists in learning all this, and hence we are prepared to sacrifice our lives in this righteous war.
('9', 267, 2, 30, 618214) To show that we
('9', 268, 0, 1, 618230) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 269
('9', 268, 1, 2, 618271) are so prepared is one of the objects of the struggle; in fact, that is the main object.
('9', 268, 1, 3, 618360) As for other things, they will follow as a matter of course.
('9', 268, 1, 4, 618421) Success in such a big task will require an equally big effort.
('9', 268, 1, 5, 618484) In what way?
('9', 268, 1, 6, 618497) Businessmen are the most important Indians in the Transvaal.
('9', 268, 1, 7, 618558) They must prove their worth and be prepared to embrace poverty in the process.
('9', 268, 1, 8, 618637) It is only by embracing poverty that they can serve their own interests as well as those of the community.
('9', 268, 1, 9, 618744) In a tyrannical state, only those who subserve its purposes can be happy or grow prosperous.
('9', 268, 1, 10, 618837) In such a state, it is not straightforward men who can amass wealth.
('9', 268, 1, 11, 618906) They can live in such a state only if they are prepared to suffer.
('9', 268, 1, 12, 618973) That is the position of the Transvaal Indians.
('9', 268, 1, 13, 619020) The Transvaal Government wants to rob the Indians of their honour and wealth.
('9', 268, 1, 14, 619098) Why should they allow that?
('9', 268, 1, 15, 619126) In former times, when in any part of the world the subjects rebelled against their oppressive rulers, before joining battle they would first kill their womenfolk in order to save them from dishonour.
('9', 268, 1, 16, 619326) At the present moment, the Transvaal Indians are engaged in the battle of satyagraha.
('9', 268, 1, 17, 619412) They will have to sacrifice their money, as women were sacrificed [in the olden days].
('9', 268, 1, 18, 619499) If not, they will be dishonoured and find their money as bitter as poison.
('9', 268, 1, 19, 619574) No religion believes it possible to worship God and Mammon at the same time.
('9', 268, 1, 20, 619651) Every religion teaches that if one wants to devote oneself to God, one must forsake wealth.
('9', 268, 1, 21, 619743) Since we started this struggle with faith in God and with prayerful hearts, we must be prepared to renounce wealth.
('9', 268, 1, 22, 619859) When we stand in need of wealth, that same God will see that we get it.
('9', 268, 1, 23, 619931) In Italy, 300,000 men were buried together with their possessionssuch is divine Providence.
('9', 268, 1, 24, 620023) Keeping that in view, let us always be mindful of our honour.
('9', 268, 1, 25, 620085) To preserve our honour is in our hands.
('9', 268, 1, 26, 620125) It is not so with regard to wealth.
('9', 268, 1, 27, 620161) We hope that the Indians will sacrifice wealth and preserve their honour.
('9', 268, 1, 28, 620235) [From Gujarati] Indian opinion, 23 1 1909
('9', 268, 2, 29, 620277) 164. MY SECOND EXPERIENCE IN GAOL [ IV]
('9', 268, 3, 30, 620317) I had one further unpleasant experience in the Johannesburg Gaol.
('9', 268, 3, 31, 620383) In this gaol, there are two different kinds of wards.
('9', 268, 3, 32, 620437) One ward is for Kaffir and Indian prisoners sentenced to hard labour.
('9', 268, 3, 33, 620507) The other is for prisoners who are called as witnesses and those who have been sentenced to imprisonment in civil proceedings.
('9', 268, 3, 34, 620634) Prisoners sentenced to hard labour have no right to go into this second ward.
('9', 268, 3, 35, 620712) We slept in it,
('9', 269, 0, 1, 620728) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 269, 1, 2, 620770) but we could not use its lavatory as of right.
('9', 269, 1, 3, 620817) In the first ward, the number of prisoners wanting the use of the lavatory is so large that a visit to it is a great nuisance.
('9', 269, 1, 4, 620944) Some Indians find this a source of great inconvenience.
('9', 269, 1, 5, 621000) I was one of them.
('9', 269, 1, 6, 621019) I was told by the warder that there would be no harm in my using a lavatory in the second ward.
('9', 269, 1, 7, 621115) I therefore went to one of the lavatories in this ward.
('9', 269, 1, 8, 621171) At these lavatories, too, there is usually a crowd.
('9', 269, 1, 9, 621223) Moreover, the lavatories have open access.
('9', 269, 1, 10, 621266) There are no doors.
('9', 269, 1, 11, 621286) As soon as I had occupied one of them, there came along a strong, heavily built, fearful looking Kaffir.
('9', 269, 1, 12, 621391) He asked me to get out and started abusing me.
('9', 269, 1, 13, 621438) I said I would leave very soon.
('9', 269, 1, 14, 621470) Instantly he lifted me up in his arms and threw me out.
('9', 269, 1, 15, 621526) Fortunately, I caught hold of the door frame, and saved myself from a fall.
('9', 269, 1, 16, 621602) I was not in the least frightened by this.
('9', 269, 1, 17, 621645) I smiled and walked away; but one or two Indian prisoners who saw what had happened started weeping.
('9', 269, 1, 18, 621746) Since they could not offer any help in gaol, they felt helpless and miserable.
('9', 269, 1, 19, 621825) I heard later that other Indians also had to go through similar tribulations.
('9', 269, 1, 20, 621903) I acquainted the Governor with what had happened and told him there was urgent need for separate lavatories for Indians.
('9', 269, 1, 21, 622024) I also told him that Indian prisoners should never be lodged with Kaffirs.
('9', 269, 1, 22, 622099) The Governor immediately issued an order for a lavatory for Indians to be sent on from the Central Gaol.
('9', 269, 1, 23, 622204) Thus, from the next day the difficulty about lavatories disappeared.
('9', 269, 1, 24, 622273) 1 As for myself, I had no motions for four days, and hence I suffered in health somewhat.
('9', 269, 1, 25, 622363) While in Johannesburg, I was taken to the court three or four times.
('9', 269, 1, 26, 622432) I was allowed to see Mr. Polak and my son there.
('9', 269, 1, 27, 622481) Others also came sometimes.
('9', 269, 1, 28, 622509) I was even free, when in the court, to have food brought to me from home and accordingly Mr. Kallenbach used to bring bread, cheese, etc., for me.
('9', 269, 1, 29, 622656) When I was in this gaol, the number of satyagrahi prisoners in it mounted very high.
('9', 269, 1, 30, 622741) At one time, there were more than 50. Many of them were asked to pound gravel with a small hammer, sitting on a stone.
('9', 269, 1, 31, 622860) About 10 men were employed in mending torn clothes.
('9', 269, 1, 32, 622912) I was given the work of stitching caps with a [sewing] machine.
('9', 269, 1, 33, 622976) I learnt sewing for the first time here.
('9', 269, 1, 34, 623017) It was not difficult work and therefore I learnt it in no time.
('9', 269, 1, 35, 623081) Most of the Indians were employed in pounding gravel.
('9', 269, 1, 36, 623135) I also asked for the same work.
('9', 269, 1, 37, 623167) But the warder said that he had orders from
('9', 269, 2, 38, 623211) 1 The incident was later discussed in the Press; vide Appendix X.
('9', 270, 0, 1, 623277) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 271
('9', 270, 1, 2, 623318) the chief warder not to let me out, and accordingly he did not allow me to go out for pounding gravel.
('9', 270, 1, 3, 623421) One day it so happened that I had no sewing work to do on the machine or other work.
('9', 270, 1, 4, 623506) I therefore started to read.
('9', 270, 1, 5, 623535) The rule is that every prisoner must do some work or other assigned to him in the gaol.
('9', 270, 1, 6, 623623) The warder therefore called me and inquired whether I was ill.
('9', 270, 1, 7, 623686) I replied: No.
('9', 270, 2, 8, 623701) Q. Why are you then not doing any work?
('9', 270, 3, 9, 623741) A. I have finished the work assigned to me.
('9', 270, 3, 10, 623785) I do not wish merely to pretend being busy with work.
('9', 270, 3, 11, 623839) If you give me any work, I shall be glad to do it.
('9', 270, 3, 12, 623890) Otherwise, what harm is there if I read, having nothing else to do?
('9', 270, 4, 13, 623958) Q. That is true, but it will be better it you remain in the store when the chief warder or the Governor comes round.
('9', 270, 5, 14, 624075) A. I dont like to do so.
('9', 270, 5, 15, 624100) I am going to tell the Governor also that there isnt sufficient work in the store and that I should therefore be taken out to pound gravel.
('9', 270, 6, 16, 624240) Q. All right.
('9', 270, 6, 17, 624254) I cannot on my own send you out for that.
('9', 270, 7, 18, 624296) A little later, the Governor came.
('9', 270, 7, 19, 624331) I told him everything.
('9', 270, 7, 20, 624354) He did not allow me to go out for pounding gravel, but informed me that it was not necessary either, since I was to be sent back to Volksrust the following day.
('9', 270, 7, 21, 624515) MEDICAL EXAMINATION  UNDRESSING OF PRISONERS
('9', 270, 8, 22, 624560) The freedom from some regulations which is permitted in the mofussil gaol of Volksrust is not possible in the Central Gaol of Johannesburg.
('9', 270, 8, 23, 624700) For instance, in Volksrust Mr. Dawad Mahomed was allowed to have a shawi as head dress, and breeches were allowed to others as well.
('9', 270, 8, 24, 624833) Mr. Rustomjee, Mr. Sorabji and Mr. Shapurji were permitted to wear their own caps.
('9', 270, 8, 25, 624916) This will not be easy in the Johannesburg Gaol.
('9', 270, 8, 26, 624964) Similarly, when prisoners first come to gaol, they are examined by the physician.
('9', 270, 8, 27, 625046) This is done in order to find out if any of them suffers from a contagious disease and, if anyone does, to give him treatment and isolate him from the others.
('9', 270, 8, 28, 625205) For this reason, the prisoners are examined with great care.
('9', 270, 8, 29, 625266) Some of the prisoners are found to suffer from diseases like syphilis, and therefore everyone of them has his genitals examined.
('9', 270, 8, 30, 625395) For this purpose, the prisoners are totally undressed, while being examined.
('9', 270, 8, 31, 625472) Unlike the others, Kaffirs are kept standing undressed for nearly 15 minutes so as to save the
('9', 271, 0, 1, 625567) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 271, 1, 2, 625609) physicians time.
('9', 271, 1, 3, 625626) Indian prisoners are made to lower their breeches only when the physician approaches them.
('9', 271, 1, 4, 625717) The other garments have to be removed in advance.
('9', 271, 1, 5, 625767) Almost every Indian resents having to lower his breeches, but most of them do not create any difficulty in the interest of our movement, though at heart they feel ill at ease.
('9', 271, 1, 6, 625943) I told the physician about this.
('9', 271, 1, 7, 625976) As a special case, he examined some of the prisoners in the store but declined to adopt that as a practice.
('9', 271, 1, 8, 626084) The Association has written about this, 1 and the matter is under correspondence.
('9', 271, 1, 9, 626166) We are justified in making an issue of this.
('9', 271, 1, 10, 626211) This is an old practice of these people, 2 which is not likely to be changed all at once.
('9', 271, 1, 11, 626301) All the same, the matter deserves attention.
('9', 271, 1, 12, 626346) When in the presence of men only, there should be on need to conceal any parts of our anatomy.
('9', 271, 1, 13, 626441) There is no reason to believe, moreover, that others will keep staring at the parts which we generally hide.
('9', 271, 1, 14, 626550) We need not have any false sense of shame.
('9', 271, 1, 15, 626593) If we are pure in our own minds, where is the need to be particular about hiding what is a part of our natural endowment?
('9', 271, 1, 16, 626715) I know that these ideas will sound strange to every Indian, but I do feel that one must go deep into the matter and learn the right attitude to take.
('9', 271, 1, 17, 626865) By raising difficulties of this nature, we harm our cause in the long run.
('9', 271, 1, 18, 626940) Formerly, Indian prisoners were not examined by the physician at all.
('9', 271, 1, 19, 627010) But once two or three Indians were interrogated.
('9', 271, 1, 20, 627059) They replied that they had no disease.
('9', 271, 1, 21, 627098) The physician examined them nevertheless, having felt somewhat suspicious, and found that they had not spoken the truth.
('9', 271, 1, 22, 627219) He decided thenceforth to examine even Indian prisoners.
('9', 271, 1, 23, 627276) We can thus see that whenever we are in some trouble, it is generally of our own making.
('9', 271, 2, 24, 627365) RETURN FROM JOHANNESBURG
('9', 271, 3, 25, 627390) As I said above, I was taken back to Volksrust on November 4. This time, too, I was accompanied by a warder.
('9', 271, 3, 26, 627499) I was dressed in the prisoners uniform, but on this occasion, instead of being made to
('9', 271, 4, 27, 627586) 1 In two letters, dated November 24 and December 1, 1908, the British Indian Association protested to the Governor of the Transvaal Gaol against the practice of keeping prisoners undressed for over an hour in public for medical examination.
('9', 271, 4, 28, 627827) The Director of Prisons, replying to these representations, denied that the prisoners were kept in such condition longer than necessary for the check up.
('9', 271, 4, 29, 627981) This correspondence was published in Indian Opinion, 19 12 1908. The Transvaal Ministers, also, in a minute dated January 30, 1909 refuted the allegation.
('9', 271, 4, 30, 628136) 2 This might also have been intended to mean: the prejudice against undressing in public is an old sentiment of our people which cannot be given up all at once.
('9', 272, 0, 1, 628297) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 273
('9', 272, 1, 2, 628338) walk, I was taken in a cab.
('9', 272, 1, 3, 628366) However, instead of second, third class tickets were provided.
('9', 272, 1, 4, 628429) By way of provisions for the journey, I was given half a pound of bread and bully beef.
('9', 272, 1, 5, 628517) I refused the latter, giving up my claim to it.
('9', 272, 1, 6, 628565) On the way, I was permitted by the warder to buy some other food.
('9', 272, 1, 7, 628631) When I reached the station, I found some Indian tailors present.
('9', 272, 1, 8, 628696) They noticed me.
('9', 272, 1, 9, 628713) Of course, talking was not allowed.
('9', 272, 1, 10, 628749) Observing my dress, etc., some of them were filled with tears.
('9', 272, 1, 11, 628812) Since I was not free even to tell them that I did not mind my dress or anything else, I merely remained a silent spectator.
('9', 272, 1, 12, 628936) The two of us were assigned a separate compartment.
('9', 272, 1, 13, 628988) There was a tailor travelling in the adjoining compartment, who passed on some of his food to me.
('9', 272, 1, 14, 629086) At Heidelberg, Mr. Somabhai met me.
('9', 272, 1, 15, 629122) He bought for me some eatables on the station.
('9', 272, 1, 16, 629169) The woman from whom he bought them at first refused to accept any money, showing her sympathy for our cause.
('9', 272, 1, 17, 629278) When Mr. Somabhai insisted on paying, she merely accepted a nominal sum of six pence.
('9', 272, 1, 18, 629364) Since Mr. Somabhai had also sent a telegram to Standerton, several Indians had gone to the station there too, carrying some food with them.
('9', 272, 1, 19, 629504) The warder and I had therefore more than our fill on the way.
('9', 272, 1, 20, 629566) As soon as we reached Volksrust, I was met by Mr. Nagadi and Mr. Kazi at the station.
('9', 272, 1, 21, 629652) Both of them walked with me part of the way.
('9', 272, 1, 22, 629697) They were permitted to walk at some distance from us.
('9', 272, 1, 23, 629751) I was again made to walk the distance from the station [to the gaol], and carry my luggage.
('9', 272, 1, 24, 629843) The matter even provoked much comment in newspapers.
('9', 272, 1, 25, 629896) All the Indians were happy to find me back in Volksrust.
('9', 272, 1, 26, 629953) I was locked up in Mr. Dawad Mahomeds cell for the night, so that we kept awake till a late hour narrating our experiences to each other.
('9', 272, 2, 27, 630091) SITUATION OF INDIAN PRISONERS
('9', 272, 3, 28, 630121) When I returned to Volksrust, the situation of Indian prisoners had assumed a new aspect altogether.
('9', 272, 3, 29, 630222) The number of prisoners had risen from about 30 to about 75. There was no way of accommodating such numbers in that gaol.
('9', 272, 3, 30, 630344) Eight tents had therefore been pitched.
('9', 272, 3, 31, 630384) For cooking, a special chula had been sent from Pretoria.
('9', 272, 3, 32, 630442) Moreover, the prisoners were often allowed to go to a river nearby for a bath.
('9', 272, 3, 33, 630521) The men looked like soldiers rather than prisoners.
('9', 272, 3, 34, 630573) This was not a prison, but a camp of satyagrahis.
('9', 272, 3, 35, 630623) What, then, did it matter whether we were treated well or ill by the warders?
('9', 272, 3, 36, 630701) In fact, most of the warders were on the whole reasonable men.
('9', 272, 3, 37, 630764) Mr. Dawad Mahomed had given a nick name to every warder.
('9', 272, 3, 38, 630821) One was called 
('9', 273, 0, 1, 630837) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 273, 1, 2, 630879) Oakly, another  Mafuto, and so on.
('9', 273, 2, 3, 630914) VISITORS
('9', 273, 3, 4, 630923) We used to get a good number of Indian visitors in Volksrust gaol.
('9', 273, 3, 5, 630990) Mr. Kazi was always hanging around.
('9', 273, 3, 6, 631026) He looked after the prisoners affairs outside, putting his whole heart into the work, and seized every opportunity to visit us.
('9', 273, 3, 7, 631154) Mr. Polak used to come almost every week on official work.
('9', 273, 3, 8, 631213) Mr. Mahomed Ibrahim and Mr. Kharsani came specially from Natal in connection with contributions to the Congress funds by Main Line Indians.
('9', 273, 3, 9, 631353) On Id day, about a hundred Indian businessmen from Natal must have paid us a visit.
('9', 273, 3, 10, 631437) There was also a shower of telegrams on that day.
('9', 273, 4, 11, 631487) SOME OBSERVATIONS
('9', 273, 5, 12, 631505) Prisons are generally kept very clean.
('9', 273, 5, 13, 631544) If this were not so, there would be epidemics before long.
('9', 273, 5, 14, 631603) But there is also lack of cleanliness in some respects.
('9', 273, 5, 15, 631659) Blankets are constantly interchanged.
('9', 273, 5, 16, 631697) A blanket that has been used by the dirtiest of Kaffirs may later fall to an Indians lot.
('9', 273, 5, 17, 631787) Frequently, the blankets are found to be full of lice.
('9', 273, 5, 18, 631842) They have a nasty smell.
('9', 273, 5, 19, 631867) Under the rules, they must be exposed to sunlight for half an hour every day, if the sky is clear.
('9', 273, 5, 20, 631966) But this is rarely done.
('9', 273, 5, 21, 631991) The difficulty about blankets is not a trivial matter to a man of clean habits.
('9', 273, 6, 22, 632071) The same thing often happens about dress.
('9', 273, 6, 23, 632113) The uniform worn by a prisoner is not always washed after he is released, but is given to another prisoner to wear in the same dirty condition.
('9', 273, 6, 24, 632257) This is a disturbing state of affairs.
('9', 273, 6, 25, 632296) Moreover, there was considerable crowding of prisoners.
('9', 273, 6, 26, 632352) In Johannesburg, where the accommodation was just sufficient for 200 prisoners, nearly 400 were lodged.
('9', 273, 6, 27, 632456) Thus, twice the number of prisoners permitted under the rules was often lodged in a cell, and sometimes there were not enough blankets to go round.
('9', 273, 6, 28, 632604) This was not an inconsiderable difficulty.
('9', 273, 6, 29, 632647) But it is a law of nature that man adjusts himself to any situation in which he is placed by circumstances beyond his control.
('9', 273, 6, 30, 632774) This happened with the Indian prisoners too.
('9', 273, 6, 31, 632819) Even in the midst of the very real difficulties mentioned above, Mr. Dawad Mahomed, especially, remained in good spirits the whole day and kept the Indian prisoners amused all the time by his wit and humour.
('9', 273, 6, 32, 633027) There was an incident in the gaol which made one unhappy.
('9', 274, 0, 1, 633085) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 275
('9', 274, 1, 2, 633126) Once a Kaffir warder approached some Indians who were sitting in a group.
('9', 274, 1, 3, 633200) He asked for two Indians to go with him and do some grass mowing.
('9', 274, 1, 4, 633266) No one spoke for some time.
('9', 274, 1, 5, 633294) Mr. Imam Abdool Kadir then offered himself for the work.
('9', 274, 1, 6, 633351) Even then,no one got ready to accompany him.
('9', 274, 1, 7, 633396) On the contrary, they told the warder that Mr. Kadir was their priest and asked him not to set him any task.
('9', 274, 1, 8, 633505) This made matters twice as bad.
('9', 274, 1, 9, 633537) For one thing, everyone ought to have offered himself for the work, instead of which, when the Imam Saheb came forward, out of consideration for the good name of the community, they divulged his status.
('9', 274, 1, 10, 633740) By indicating their unwillingness to take up the work even when the Imam Saheb was ready for it, they proved that wethe community as a wholeare a shameless lot.

('9', 275, 2, 4, 635605) 166. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('9', 275, 3, 5, 635632) JOHANNESBURG, January 23, 1909 [SIR,] As one time Secretary of the Indian Association, and as a merch ant, I beg to congratulate Mr. A. M. Cachalia on the most self sacrificing step he has tuken.
('9', 275, 3, 6, 635828) In my opinion , he deserves the best thanks of the Bri tish Indian community and, more especially, of the British Indian mer chants, for having pointed the way out to them.
('9', 275, 3, 7, 636001) The best manner in whi ch I can express my approval of Mr. Cachalias action is to follow him, and I have, therefore, placed myself in communication with my creditors.
('9', 275, 3, 8, 636168) I notice that the morality of the step taken by Mr. Cachalia has been questioned, 2 and that it has been construed into a desire on the part of the British Indian merchants to coerce European wholesale houses.
('9', 275, 3, 9, 636378) 3 As to the morality or immorality of the step, it is largely a matter of opi nion.
('9', 275, 3, 10, 636462) According to the view taught by my religion, a merchant who does his best to pay his creditors 20/ in the , and warns them of any danger in which their goods may be placed, is considered to have performed a meritorious act deserving of warm approbation from the community in which his lot is cast.
('9', 275, 3, 11, 636760) With reference to coercion, I am sure that those who have used the term have done so hastily.
('9', 275, 3, 12, 636854) It is quite clear that if [the] British Indian merchants do not take out licences to trade, they must be very properly prosecuted for trading without licences.
('9', 275, 3, 13, 637014) The Government have every right, as they consider that their position is just, to impose every form of hardship on those traders who trade in disregard of the Licensing Law.
('9', 275, 3, 14, 637188) What is an Indian debtor with a large stock on hand and with a conscience to keep to do?
('9', 275, 3, 15, 637277) He has not cash enough to pay out his creditors immediately.
('9', 275, 3, 16, 637338) He cannot, with any regard for his
('9', 275, 4, 17, 637373) 1 This was presumably drafted by Gandhiji and signed by E. M. Aswat.
('9', 275, 4, 18, 637442) 2 In a resolution of the Executive Committee of the Johannesburg Chamber of Commerce on January 22 3 Vide Letter to Rand Daily Mail, 22 1 1909
('9', 276, 0, 1, 637585) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 277
('9', 276, 1, 2, 637626) creditors, and without their consent, sell his goods by auction.
('9', 276, 1, 3, 637691) He finds he has assets enough to pay out his creditors.
('9', 276, 1, 4, 637747) Apart from any political considerations, I cannot but think that the only honourable course for a debtor, placed in the position above described, is to take his creditors into his confidence, and place himself at their disposal, telling them that, short of compro mising his conscience, he is willing to do everything that the creditors may consider desirable in their interests.
('9', 276, 1, 5, 638127) That my action will bear a political interpretation is unavoidable, for the simple reason that it is based upon the situation created by the Government; but, speaking for myself, I can assure the public that the action that I have taken is irres pective of whatever the European wholesale houses may do, so far as the political aspect is concerned.
('9', 276, 1, 6, 638476) My desire is simply to protect my creditors, and certainly also to frustrate the design of the Government, in so far as they wish to receive monetary aid from me in order to bend me and my other countrymen to their wishes, which I hold to be unjust, immoral, and unrighteous.

('9', 279, 3, 7, 644716) [ENCLOSURE] STATEMENT OF THE INDIAN POSITION
('9', 279, 4, 8, 644761) FOR SUBMISSION TO THE RIGHT HONBLE LORD CURZON
('9', 279, 5, 9, 644808) THE INDIAN CLAIM
('9', 279, 6, 10, 644825) Apart from matters of detail, the following are the two outs tanding questions between the Local Government and British Indians: 1. Repeal of the Asiatic Act No.
('9', 279, 6, 11, 644987) 2 of 1907. 2. The status of educated Indians.
('9', 279, 7, 12, 645033) ARGUMENT ON THE CLAIMS
('9', 279, 8, 13, 645056) As to the first, the Indian contention is that General Smuts was under promise to repeal the Asiatic Act.
('9', 279, 8, 14, 645162) The promise was not reduced to writing, but, three days after the completion of the compromise of January, 1908, 1 General Smuts, in his speech 2 at Richmond, which has never been contradicted, stated as follows: He had told them that the law would not be repealed so long as there was an Asiatic in the country who had not registered, and, again, Until every Indian in the country had registered, the law would not be repealed. Apart, however, from the promise, the above Act has been decla red to be unworkable.
('9', 279, 8, 15, 645676) The recent decisions of the Supreme Court have emphasised the opinion; and the Act of 1908, which was passed in partial fulfilment of the promise, in effect superseded the Asiatic Act 2 of 1907. That the Indians understood that a promise had been made to
('9', 279, 9, 16, 645931) 1 Vide Interview to The Transvaal Leader, 30 1 1908. 2 Vide General Smuts speech in Richmond, 5 2 1908
('9', 280, 0, 1, 646034) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 281
('9', 280, 1, 2, 646075) repeal the Act as against voluntary registration can no longer be doubted, and it was in that faith that British Indians submitted to voluntary registration.
('9', 280, 1, 3, 646233) The leading Indians, in their eagerness to carry out the Indian part of the compromise, did so at much personal risk, as even the voluntary giving of finger impressions was resented by many Indians.
('9', 280, 1, 4, 646432) The Secretary of the Association was, on his way to the Registration Office, brutally assaulted, and, later, the then Chairman of the Association was also assaulted for the same reason.
('9', 280, 1, 5, 646618) The giving of finger impressions as such was never made a funda mental objection.
('9', 280, 1, 6, 646700) The objection was raised against the spirit of the Act, based, as it was, on a false charge of an organized entry, on a large scale, into the Transvaal of British Indians who had no right to be in the country.
('9', 280, 1, 7, 646910) As to the status of educated Indians, it is contended that General Smuts puts upon the Immigrants Restriction Act of the Transvaal an interpretation whereby British Indians possessing the necessary educational qualifications become prohibited immigrants; and this prohibition is brought about by means of the Asiatic Act of 1907. British Indians submit that such prohibition, based on racial lines, is a departure from the Imperial policy; that when the Immigrants Restriction Act was sanctioned, such a departure was not intended; and that, in any case, British Indians hold that they cannot accept such racial desqualification involving, in the words of Mr. Chamberlain 1,an affront upon millions of His Majestys subjects.
('9', 280, 1, 8, 647635) British Indians state that, legal equality for Indians possessing educational qualifications being retained, they do not mind such an administration of the Law as would, under a strict examination test, prohibit the entry of all but six Indians of high educational attainments.
('9', 280, 1, 9, 647913) Such administrative inequality is today in vogue at the Cape, [in] Natal and Australia; and British Indians, recognizing the prejudice, have submitted to it, but they claim that the importing of a racial difference in the matter of immigration would be intolerable.
('9', 280, 2, 10, 648179) PASSIVE RESISTANCE
('9', 280, 3, 11, 648198) In order to attain this end, British Indians have exhausted all their resources, by way of petitions and deputations.
('9', 280, 3, 12, 648316) At one of their mass meetings, 2 they took a solemn oath not to submit to the Asiatic Act of 1907 and not to receive the benefits of the Act of 1908, until
('9', 280, 4, 13, 648472) 1 Joseph Chamberlain (1836 1914); Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1895 1903 2 Vide Mass Meeting at Pretoria, 6 7 1907.
('9', 281, 0, 1, 648596) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 281, 1, 2, 648638) the above redress was granted.
('9', 281, 1, 3, 648669) Many Indians have, therefore, in virtue of the oath, suffered imprisonment.
('9', 281, 1, 4, 648745) The struggle has lasted now for over two years; and over 2,000 Indians have undergone imprisonment, mostly with hard labour.
('9', 281, 1, 5, 648870) Hundreds have been deported, only to return immediately.
('9', 281, 1, 6, 648927) Many families have been ruined pecuniarily.
('9', 281, 1, 7, 648971) Many Indian merchants have suffered enormous loss.
('9', 281, 1, 8, 649022) Some have even closed [down] their businesses.
('9', 281, 1, 9, 649069) The Chairman of the Association, in order to avoid confiscation of his property by the Government under fines imposed for trading without licences, has accepted sequestr ation of his estate.
('9', 281, 1, 10, 649260) 1 Several Indian merchants are ready to follow his example.
('9', 281, 1, 11, 649320) Some Indians have, no doubt, owing to their weakness accepted the Asiatic Acts, and more are likely to succumb; but, after a very careful examination, the Executive of the British Indian Association as a whole will remain solid in offering passive resistance until justice is done.

('9', 285, 4, 15, 658422) 174. ENGLISH INFLUENCES IN THE AIR
('9', 285, 5, 16, 658457) In these days of swadeshi, it is necessary to bear in mind a few simple things.
('9', 285, 5, 17, 658537) We observe that some Indian youths, having acquired a smattering of English, use it even when it is not necessary to do so, as if they had forgotten their own language or wanted to suggest how much more difficult it was to speak English, or for some similar reason.
('9', 285, 5, 18, 658803) When talking among themselves, they use broken English rather than pure Gujarati, Hindi or Urdu.
('9', 285, 5, 19, 658900) They even carry on their correspondence in English.
('9', 285, 5, 20, 658952) These young men emphasize their spirit of swadeshi by using difficult English words which they themselves do not understand, and then take pride in what they do.
('9', 285, 5, 21, 659114) This is a simple, and yet, a grave fault.
('9', 285, 5, 22, 659156) Any nation that cherishes its individuality must love its own language and feel proud of it.
('9', 285, 5, 23, 659249) Let us consider the example of the Boers themselves.
('9', 285, 5, 24, 659302) We are not concerned with their moral principles.
('9', 285, 5, 25, 659352) Their patriotism, at any rate, is wonderful.
('9', 285, 5, 26, 659397) That is the only thing that calls for emulation.
('9', 285, 5, 27, 659446) Though it is very useful for Dutch children to learn English, they are taught their own dialect, a local variety of Dutch called Taal.
('9', 285, 5, 28, 659581) There are very few books in this language.
('9', 285, 5, 29, 659624) But they are confident that in the course of time they will enrich that language.
('9', 285, 5, 30, 659706) It is possible to do so.
('9', 285, 5, 31, 659731) It is because of this spirit of theirs that they have succeeded in gathering
('9', 286, 0, 1, 659808) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 287
('9', 286, 1, 2, 659849) the reins of government in their own hands.
('9', 286, 2, 3, 659893) The Jews love their language, Yiddish, very much, though not as much as the Dutch love theirs.
('9', 286, 2, 4, 659988) Until a few years ago; that language was only an uncultivated dialect.
('9', 286, 2, 5, 660059) Some eminent Jews believe that only when they cultivate a real love for Yiddish will they be united as a people.
('9', 286, 3, 6, 660172) In our case, we already have a language of our own; what is necessary is to cultivate respect for it.
('9', 286, 3, 7, 660274) It is our duty to enrich it, to read a great many books written in it, to write books in it and also to encourage others to write them.
('9', 286, 4, 8, 660410) This does not mean that we need not learn English or can be in different to it.
('9', 286, 4, 9, 660490) It is the language of the Government, and has also be come an international language, and hence it is necessary for everyone to learn it.
('9', 286, 4, 10, 660628) One must learn to use it well, when it has to be used.
('9', 286, 4, 11, 660683) One must learn to read and write in it with facility.
('9', 286, 4, 12, 660737) But no useful purpose is served by behaving as some young men have been doing.
('9', 286, 4, 13, 660816) There is no point in writing to another in English when that other person knows as little English as one does oneself.
('9', 286, 4, 14, 660935) It would only lead to a total mis understanding, apart from encouraging a bad habit.
('9', 286, 4, 15, 661020) The right approach would be to use English [only] when the other person does not know our mother tongue.
('9', 286, 4, 16, 661125) English may be learnt, but ones mother tongue must not be ignored.
('9', 286, 4, 17, 661192) The learning of English must come second to learning ones mother tongue.
('9', 286, 4, 18, 661265) Or, one may learn both the languages simultaneously, remembering, however, the general rule mentioned above.
('9', 286, 4, 19, 661374) We do not believe that those who are not proud of their own language, who are not proficient in it, can have the true spirit of swadeshi.

('9', 286, 4, 21, 661689) It is for the Gujaratis to strive for the development of Gujarati.

('9', 287, 1, 2, 661906) 175. EXAMPLE OF TURKEY
('9', 287, 2, 3, 661929) The moment a parliament was established in Turkey, the British became respectful.
('9', 287, 2, 4, 662011) more than 300 members of the House of Commons sent a message of goodwill to the [Turkish] Parliament.
('9', 287, 2, 5, 662113) Mr. Asquith, who is a minister, was also among the signatories.
('9', 287, 2, 6, 662177) It is reported that all the members who were present gave their signatures.
('9', 287, 2, 7, 662253) Newspapers are now reporting the names of those whose efforts for the establishment of the Parliament were thus crowned with success.
('9', 287, 2, 8, 662387) In the conflict that Austria provoked with Turkey, the latter gave it a resounding slap in the face without unsheathing its sword, or firing a single shot.
('9', 287, 2, 9, 662543) Readers will recall that the Turkish people organized a boycott of Austrian goods, which has not yet been relaxed, though Austria has climbed down somewhat.
('9', 287, 2, 10, 662700) According to newspaper reports, Austrian estimates place the loss Austria has incurred in such a short time at  1,700,000. Turkish estimates place the figure at  3,000,000. When the ships carrying Austrian goods arrived [at the Turkish port], the Austrian Ambassador made frantic efforts[to have the cargoes unloaded], but the Turkish Government took no notice.
('9', 287, 2, 11, 663062) Even the porters sacrificed their wages, and not a single Turk was found ready to unload the Austrian goods.
('9', 287, 2, 12, 663171) The Austrian Government thereupon lodged a strong protest with His Majesty the Sultan.
('9', 287, 2, 13, 663258) The Turkish people concluded from this the that Austria had received an unbearable blow; in the result, the boycott became more intense; First, the fez (the Turkish cap) and matches imported from Austria were boycotted.
('9', 287, 2, 14, 663478) The boycott was then extended to other articles, as the people came to know what other goods were inported from Austria.
('9', 287, 2, 15, 663599) Ahmed Reza Pasha, the well known leader of Young turkey, stated when questioned in Paris, that they had certainly boycotted Austria, and that the boycott would continue still.
('9', 287, 2, 16, 663775) It was not their duty [he added] to think of the losses that Austria would suffer.
('9', 287, 2, 17, 663858) They had acted in self defence, only raising their hands to ward off a blow.
('9', 287, 2, 18, 663935) Austria [he said] had struck the first blow.
('9', 287, 2, 19, 663980) It might as well enjoy the fruit [of what it had done].
('9', 287, 2, 20, 664036) Newspapers report that it was because of this extensive boycott that negotiations started between Istambul and Vienna for a rapprochement.
('9', 287, 2, 21, 664175) This was a struggle for national honour, and neither the poor nor the rich gave a thought to their own losses in defence of that honour; that is the reason why Austria was brought to its knees so
('9', 288, 0, 1, 664371) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 289
('9', 288, 1, 2, 664412) easily.
('9', 288, 1, 3, 664420) The Transvaal Indians ought to turn this example over and over again in their minds.
('9', 288, 1, 4, 664505) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 30 1 1909
('9', 288, 2, 5, 664547) 176. MY SECOND EXPERIENCE IN GAOL [V]
('9', 288, 3, 6, 664585) MORAL DILEMMA
('9', 288, 4, 7, 664599) When I had completed about half the term of my imprisonment, there was a telegram from Phoenix saying that Mrs. Gandhi was seriously ill and asking me to go down immediately.
('9', 288, 4, 8, 664774) 1 Everyone was unhappy at this.
('9', 288, 4, 9, 664806) I had no doubt as to my duty.
('9', 288, 4, 10, 664836) When the gaoler asked me whether I would agree to pay the fine to obtain my release, I replied without the slightest hesitation that I would never do so, and that it was implied in our movement that we should bear separation from out kith and kin.
('9', 288, 4, 11, 665084) The gaoler smiled at this, but felt sorry too.
('9', 288, 4, 12, 665131) On a superficial view of the matter, this attitude would appear to be rather harsh, but personally I am convinced that that is the only right attitude to adopt.
('9', 288, 4, 13, 665292) I think of my love for the motherland as an aspect of my religion.
('9', 288, 4, 14, 665359) It is, of course, not the whole of religion.
('9', 288, 4, 15, 665404) But religion cannot be considered to be complete without it.
('9', 288, 4, 16, 665465) If necessary, we should bear separation from our family in order to be able to follow the dictates of our religion.
('9', 288, 4, 17, 665581) We may even have to lose them.
('9', 288, 4, 18, 665612) Not only is there no cruelty in this but it is actually our duty to do so.
('9', 288, 4, 19, 665687) If it is true that we have pledged ourselves to fight unto death, there is nothing further to think of.
('9', 288, 4, 20, 665791) Lord Roberts lost his only son for a cause inferior to ours and, being on the front, could not even attend his funeral.
('9', 288, 4, 21, 665911) This history of the world is full of such instances.
('9', 288, 5, 22, 665964) QUARRELS AMONG KAFFIRS
('9', 288, 6, 23, 665987) There are some dangerous murderers among the Kaffir prisoners in gaol.
('9', 288, 6, 24, 666058) We find these prisoners constantly engaged in disputes.
('9', 288, 6, 25, 666114) After they are locked up in the cell, they quarrel among themselves.
('9', 288, 6, 26, 666183) Sometimes, they openly defy the warder.
('9', 288, 6, 27, 666223) One warder was twice assaulted by the prisoners.
('9', 288, 6, 28, 666272) Indian prisoners are obviously in danger when locked up in the same cell with these.
('9', 288, 6, 29, 666357) So far, Indians have not been placed in such a situation.
('9', 288, 6, 30, 666415) But so long as Indian
('9', 288, 7, 31, 666437) 1Vide Letter to A. H. West.
('9', 288, 7, 32, 666465) 9 11 1908
('9', 289, 0, 1, 666475) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 289, 1, 2, 666517) prisoners are classed with the Kaffirs, the danger will remain.
('9', 289, 1, 3, 666581) ILLNESS IN GAOL
('9', 289, 2, 4, 666597) There was for the most part no serious illness among the prisoners.
('9', 289, 2, 5, 666665) I have already mentioned Mr. Mavjis case.
('9', 289, 2, 6, 666707) There was a Tamil named Mr. Raju, who had acute dysentery.
('9', 289, 2, 7, 666766) He was very much pulled down.
('9', 289, 2, 8, 666796) The reason he gave for this was that he used to take 30 cups of tea [every day], and he got dysentery because he did not get them.
('9', 289, 2, 9, 666927) He asked for tea.
('9', 289, 2, 10, 666945) Of course, the request was rejected.
('9', 289, 2, 11, 666982) But he was given some medicine, and the medical officer in the gaol ordered two pounds of milk and bread [for him].
('9', 289, 2, 12, 667098) This restored him to full health.
('9', 289, 2, 13, 667132) Mr. Ravikrishna Talevantsingh kept indifferent health till the end.
('9', 289, 2, 14, 667200) Mr. Kazi and Mr. Bawazeer were ill all the time.
('9', 289, 2, 15, 667249) Mr. Ratanshi Sodha was observing a religious vow for the four months of the rainy season, and therefore he had only one meal a day.
('9', 289, 2, 16, 667381) Since the food was not quite satisfactory, he nearly starved himself and as a result got oedema.
('9', 289, 2, 17, 667478) A part from these, there were other cases of minor illness.
('9', 289, 2, 18, 667538) On the whole, however, we found that even those Indians who fell ill were not broken in spirit.
('9', 289, 2, 19, 667634) They were happy to bear this particular kind of hardship for the sake of the motherland.
('9', 289, 3, 20, 667723) SOME DIFFICULTIES
('9', 289, 4, 21, 667741) It was observed that the more irritating difficulties were those of our own making rather than those created by others.
('9', 289, 4, 22, 667861) There were occasions in the gaol when one sensed in the air distinctions between Hindus and Muslims, between high and low castes.
('9', 289, 4, 23, 667991) Indians of all communities and castes lived together in the gaol, which gave one an opportunity to observe how backward we are in the matter of self government.
('9', 289, 4, 24, 668152) It was also discovered, however, that we were not altogether incapable of self government, for whatever difficulties cropped up were always overcome in the end.
('9', 289, 4, 25, 668313) Some Hindus said that they were not prepared to take food pre pared by Muslims or by certain individuals.
('9', 289, 4, 26, 668419) Men who hold such views should never stir out of India.
('9', 289, 4, 27, 668475) I also observed that no objection was raised if any Kaffir or white touched our food.
('9', 289, 4, 28, 668561) It so happened once that someone objected to sleeping near a certain person on the ground that the latter belonged to the scavenger caste.
('9', 289, 4, 29, 668700) This again was humiliating to us.
('9', 289, 4, 30, 668734) On probing deeper into the matter, it was found that the objection was raised not because the man [who had raised the objection] was himself particular about it, but because he was afraid of
('9', 290, 0, 1, 668925) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 291
('9', 290, 1, 2, 668966) being declared an outcaste should other members of his community in India come to hear of it.
('9', 290, 1, 3, 669060) Thanks to these hypocritical distinctions of high and low and to the fear of subsequent caste tyranny, we have, I think, turned our back on truth and embraced falsehood.
('9', 290, 1, 4, 669230) How can we be called satyagrahis if, knowing that it is wrong to despise the scavenger, we still do so out of an unreasonable fear of members of our caste or other men?
('9', 290, 1, 5, 669399) I wish that Indians who join this movement also resort to satyagraha against their caste and their family and against evil wherever they find it.
('9', 290, 1, 6, 669545) As for myself, I am convinced that it is because we do not act in this way that the successful outcome of our struggle is being delayed.
('9', 290, 1, 7, 669682) If it is true that we are all Indians, how can we cling to false distinctions and so quarrel among ourselves and, at the same time, demand our rights?
('9', 290, 1, 8, 669833) How can we hope to achieve success in our struggle if, out of fear of what may happen to us in India,we do not do what we believe to be right?
('9', 290, 1, 9, 669976) It is the mark of a coward to shrink from anything out of mere fear, and Indians who are cowards will not hold out to the last in this great war that is being waged against the Government.
('9', 290, 2, 10, 670165) WHO CAN GO TO GAOL?
('9', 290, 3, 11, 670185) We see from these facts that those who are slaves to bad habits, who observe vain distinctions of caste and community, who are quarrel some, who are not able to look on Hindus and Muslims with an equal eye and those who are diseased in bodysuch men cannot go to gaol or remain in gaol for any length of time.
('9', 290, 3, 12, 670494) It follows therefore that those who want to go to gaol as a matter of honour and with a view to the welfare of the motherland must be healthy in body, mind and soul.
('9', 290, 3, 13, 670660) An ailing man will find himself exhausted in the end; those who are conscious of Hindu Muslim differences, who think themselves superior to others, who are slaves to bed habits, who are possessed by a craving for tea, smoking or such other things, are incapable of fighting till the bitter end.
('9', 290, 4, 14, 670955) WHAT I READ IN GAOL
('9', 290, 5, 15, 670975) Though the entire day is taken up with work, one can find time for some reading in the mornings and evenings, as also on Sundays and, since there is nothing else to tax ones attention in gaol, it is possible to read with a peaceful mind.
('9', 290, 5, 16, 671213) Though I had limited time on my hand, I managed ot read two books by the great Ruskin, the essays of the great Thoreau, some portions of the Bible, life of Garibaldi (in
('9', 291, 0, 1, 671383) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 291, 1, 2, 671425) Gujarati), essays of Lord Bacon (in Gujarati), and two other books about India.
('9', 291, 1, 3, 671505) We can find the doctrine of satyagraha in the writings of Ruskin and Thoreau.
('9', 291, 1, 4, 671583) The Gujarati books were sent by Mr. Diwan for all of us to read.
('9', 291, 1, 5, 671648) Apart from these works, I read the Bhagavad Gita almost every day.
('9', 291, 1, 6, 671715) All this reading had the effect of confirming my belief in satyagraha, and I can say today that life in gaol is not in the least boring.
('9', 291, 1, 7, 671852) TWO ATTITUDES
('9', 291, 2, 8, 671866) We can take two different attitudes to what I have written above.
('9', 291, 3, 9, 671932) First, why should we bear such hardships, submit ourselves, for instance, to the restrictions of gaol life, wear coarse and ungainly dress, eat food which is hardly food, starve ourselves, suffer being kicked by the warder, live among the Kaffirs, do every kind of work, whether we like it or not, obey a warder who is only good enough to be our servant, be unable to receive any friends or write letters, go without things that we may need, and sleep in company with robbers and thieves?
('9', 291, 3, 10, 672421) Better die than suffer this.
('9', 291, 3, 11, 672450) Better pay the fine than go to gaol.
('9', 291, 3, 12, 672487) Let no one be punished with gaol.
('9', 291, 3, 13, 672521) Such an attitude will make a man quite weak and afraid of imprisonment, and he will achieve nothing good by being in gaol.
('9', 291, 3, 14, 672644) Alternatively, one may consider oneself fortunate to be in gaol in the cause of the motherland, in defence of ones honour and ones religion.
('9', 291, 3, 15, 672785) Gaol life, one may think,involves no [real] suffering.
('9', 291, 3, 16, 672840) Outside, one has to carry out the will of many, whereas one has only the warder to reckon with in gaol.
('9', 291, 3, 17, 672944) One has no anxieties in gaol, no problem of earning ones livelihood, no worry about getting ones bread, for that is provided regularly by others.
('9', 291, 3, 18, 673090) Ones person is protected by the Government.
('9', 291, 3, 19, 673134) None of these things has to be paid for.
('9', 291, 3, 20, 673175) By way of exercise, one gets ample work to do and, without any effort on ones part, all of ones bad habits fall away.
('9', 291, 3, 21, 673293) The mind enjoys a sense of freedom.
('9', 291, 3, 22, 673329) One has ready to hand the benefit of being absorbed in devotions to God.
('9', 291, 3, 23, 673402) The body is held in bondage, but the soul grows more free.
('9', 291, 3, 24, 673461) One is in full enjoyment of the use of ones limbs.
('9', 291, 3, 25, 673512) The body is looked after by those who hold it in bondage.
('9', 291, 3, 26, 673570) Thus, from every point of view, one is free.
('9', 291, 3, 27, 673615) One might, perhaps, be in difficulties, be manhandled by a wicked warder, but then one learns to be patient.
('9', 291, 3, 28, 673724) One feels glad to have an opportunity of dissuading [him] from such behaviour.
('9', 291, 3, 29, 673803) It is up to us to adopt such an attitude and think of gaol as a holy and happy place and to make it such.
('9', 291, 3, 30, 673909) In short, happiness and
('9', 292, 0, 1, 673933) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 293

('9', 292, 2, 5, 674358) 177. THE TRANSVAAL STRUGGLE
('9', 292, 3, 6, 674386) The Transvaal campaign is now in full swing.
('9', 292, 3, 7, 674431) The Chairman of the [British Indian] Association is in gaol.
('9', 292, 3, 8, 674492) Almost all the leaders of the Madrasi community are installed there.
('9', 292, 3, 9, 674561) Thus, Thoreaus statement that in a tyrannical state those who do not wish to submit to its tyranny have their place in gaol is proved true.
('9', 292, 4, 10, 674701) This time, the sentences of imprisonment are not just for a week or two.
('9', 292, 4, 11, 674774) 1 Our Johannesburg correspondent reports that the other leaders will be arrested shortly.
('9', 292, 4, 12, 674864) We think all this is as it should be.
('9', 292, 4, 13, 674902) If we had gained our object by a mere pretence of suffering, by being in gaol for a few days, we would not have been able to retain what we had gained, or derive any benefit therefrom.
('9', 292, 4, 14, 675087) As a rule, we can hold on to anything in the world by the same means by which we gain it.
('9', 292, 4, 15, 675177) The commonest illustration of this is that of territories acquired by force, which can be retained only by force.
('9', 292, 4, 16, 675291) Following this logic, some arrogant, power drunk and thoughtless Englishmen believe that India, which was conquered with the power of the sword, can be held only with the same power.
('9', 292, 4, 17, 675474) This is an obvious fallacy.
('9', 292, 4, 18, 675502) We have mentioned it here only as an illustration of the general rule referred to above.
('9', 292, 4, 19, 675591) We shall therefore say no more than this about it, that they conquered Indianot with the power of the sword, but by employing the strength of our own people [against themselves], thanks to the disunity prevailing among them.
('9', 292, 4, 20, 675816) Therefore, according to the rule mentioned above, India can be retained only by perpetuating that disunity and employing the strength of our people [against themselves].
('9', 292, 5, 21, 675986) 1 Gandhiji himself was sentenced to three months on February 25.
('9', 293, 0, 1, 676051) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 293, 1, 2, 676093) taking this line of argument a step further, we see that if Hindus and Muslims in India were to unite and refuse to hold down their own people, the country would not remain dependent.

('9', 295, 0, 1, 680445) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 295, 1, 2, 680487) 179. CONVENTION
('9', 295, 2, 3, 680503) The report of the Convention which met to evolve a single Government for South Africa has been published.
('9', 295, 2, 4, 680609) It is divided into 10 parts, and contains 153 sections.
('9', 295, 2, 5, 680665) The report will be presented to all the four Parliaments in South Africa on March 30. If it is approved, the Convention will meet again in May at Bloemfontein and present its final report in June, It will be approved by the Parliaments.
('9', 295, 2, 6, 680902) Dele gates will then take the report to England and the new Parliament of South Africa will meet within a year thereafter.
('9', 295, 2, 7, 681025) To some extent, the whites can be proud of all this.
('9', 295, 2, 8, 681078) We congratulate them on having display ed a unity of purpose and sacrificed their individual interests.
('9', 295, 2, 9, 681182) It should not be surprising that men who are capable of acting in this manner should succeed in their aims; whether or not, as a result of their action, others stand to suffer is a different question.
('9', 295, 2, 10, 681383) In so far as the Convention itself is concerned, it has proved that men who unite for concerted action, for an unworthy or evil object, will always achieve some measure of success.
('9', 295, 3, 11, 681564) The Convention will lead to the establishment of a single Parliament and a single High Court for South Africa.
('9', 295, 3, 12, 681675) Subordinate to the Parliament, there will be a council for each of the present Colonies for its internal affairs.
('9', 295, 3, 13, 681789) The council will have power to enact ordinary laws.
('9', 295, 3, 14, 681841) There will be uniform customs and a single railway.
('9', 295, 3, 15, 681893) Pretoria will be the permanent capital, but one session of Parliament will be held in Cape Town.
('9', 295, 3, 16, 681990) The new High Court will be located at Bloemfontein.
('9', 295, 3, 17, 682042) There will be one Governor General for South Africa.
('9', 295, 3, 18, 682095) Parliament will have two Houses, the Senate and the Assembly.
('9', 295, 3, 19, 682157) There will be 40 members in the Senate, of which eight will be nominated by the Government.
('9', 295, 3, 20, 682249) The rest will be elected by the several provinces.
('9', 295, 3, 21, 682300) The Assembly will have 121 members, 51 from the Cape, 17 from Natal, 36 from the Transvaal, and 17 from the Orange Free State.
('9', 295, 4, 22, 682427) The proposed Union has dangerous implications for Indians and other Coloured races.
('9', 295, 4, 23, 682511) They will be left with no voting rights anywhere, and care has been taken to provide in the report that they should be deprived of whatever little measure of such rights they enjoy in the Cape.
('9', 295, 4, 24, 682705) But franchise is a mere trifle.
('9', 295, 4, 25, 682737) Where we are not allowed even standing room, voting rights can be of little avail.
('9', 295, 4, 26, 682820) In a place where some are slaves and others masters of slaves, they may
('9', 296, 0, 1, 682892) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 297
('9', 296, 1, 2, 682933) have the same voting rights for the purpose of appointing supervisors over them both, the slaves vote will be of no use to him.
('9', 296, 1, 3, 683061) Before the right can be of profit, the slave must be made free and educated to value his freedom.
('9', 296, 1, 4, 683159) Otherwise, voting rights will hardly be worth the name.
('9', 296, 1, 5, 683215) In this land, we are in a state of slavery.
('9', 296, 1, 6, 683259) We have not even been educated to understand the meaning of freedom.
('9', 296, 1, 7, 683328) We must have both at the same time.
('9', 296, 1, 8, 683364) It is not likely that those who are our masters will break our bonds.
('9', 296, 1, 9, 683434) Therefore, we have to educate ourselves and win freedom for ourselves by our own efforts.
('9', 296, 1, 10, 683524) Till that is done, the franchise, in our opinion, will have no value.
('9', 296, 1, 11, 683594) Let us therefore come to the other kinds of shackles [being forged for us] by the Convention.
('9', 296, 1, 12, 683688) The existing laws of the several provinces will remain intact, that is, whatever laws against us exist in the Orange River Colony, the Transvaal and elsewhere will remain unchanged.
('9', 296, 1, 13, 683870) We shall be allowed no right of movement from one province to another; moreover, the new Parliament will be empowered to enact fresh legislation.
('9', 296, 1, 14, 684016) The result will be that the harshest laws that exist in any of the Colonies or provinces will be taken as models elsewhere.
('9', 296, 1, 15, 684140) It is evident from the report of the Convention that it has not solved the Indian question in the Transvaal.
('9', 296, 1, 16, 684249) And should the Indians remain inactive, they would be reduced to a miserable condition all over South Africa.
('9', 296, 1, 17, 684359) Any Indian who would rather not live as a slave in South Africa must understand this and, if he belongs to the Transvaal, must join the fight, staking his head on it; if he is from outside the Transvaal, he must extend all possible support and encouragement to the Transvaal Indians.
('9', 296, 2, 18, 684643) [From Gujarati]
('9', 296, 3, 19, 684659) Indian Opinion, 13 2 1909
('9', 296, 4, 20, 684685) 180. TO THE FALLEN
('9', 296, 5, 21, 684704) Potchefstroom and Klerksdorp have fallen.
('9', 296, 5, 22, 684746) It appears that Indians in other towns have also given in.
('9', 296, 5, 23, 684805) Potchefstroom has even sent a report to newspapers to the effect that since that town, which has been so firm, has fallen, other towns are bound to follow suit and that [consequently] there will be no more of satyagraha.
('9', 296, 5, 24, 685026) To those who have fallen, we want to give some idea of the duty that they owe.
('9', 296, 5, 25, 685105) They know of course that the movement is worth carrying on.
('9', 296, 5, 26, 685165) They gave in because they could not bear the sacrifices it
('9', 297, 0, 1, 685224) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 297, 1, 2, 685266) involved.
('9', 297, 1, 3, 685276) Those who have fallen in this way must not think of bringing down others.
('9', 297, 1, 4, 685350) They can even inform the Government that they have surrendered owing to their weakness, that they wish success to those who are standing firm and that they will do everything they can to strengthen these.
('9', 297, 1, 5, 685555) This much they can certainly do.
('9', 297, 1, 6, 685588) If they do not, it will be assumed that they did not give in out of weakness, but that they deliberately turned enemies of the motherland.
('9', 297, 1, 7, 685727) They can give statements in newspapers to say that, though they have themselves fallen, they do not want that others should do the same.
('9', 297, 1, 8, 685864) If they do not act in this manner, the campaign will certainly not be wound up for that reason.
('9', 297, 1, 9, 685960) It will continue.
('9', 297, 1, 10, 685978) But it will be prolonged if they range themselves on the opposite side.
('9', 297, 1, 11, 686050) If they admit their weakness in having surrendered, to that extent they will have helped the cause.
('9', 297, 1, 12, 686150) The campaign will be the shorter for that.
('9', 297, 1, 13, 686193) Moreover, even those who have fallen can go to gaol, if they choose.
('9', 297, 1, 14, 686262) When, in Italy, the people had the spirit of patriotism flowing in every vein of theirs, those who did not join the fighting would not obstruct it but, admitting their weakness, remained aloof and even helped in many other ways.
('9', 297, 1, 15, 686491) The Indians who have surrendered can do likewise.
('9', 297, 1, 16, 686541) They ought to heed these suggestions.
('9', 297, 1, 17, 686579) They ought to have thought of Mr. Dawad Mahomed and others and remained firm.
('9', 297, 1, 18, 686657) Since they have not done so, they can at any rate act as suggested above and so refrain from adding to the sufferings of these men.

('9', 298, 2, 15, 688420) 182. DUNCANS VIEWS
('9', 298, 3, 16, 688439) Mr. Patrick Duncan was Colonial Secretary in the Transvaal before it received self goverment.
('9', 298, 3, 17, 688533) Recently, he took a leading part in the Convention.
('9', 298, 3, 18, 688585) State is an important monthly journal in South Africa.
('9', 298, 3, 19, 688640) Only very prominent persons write for it.
('9', 298, 3, 20, 688682) It is patronized by white millionaires.
('9', 298, 3, 21, 688722) To this monthly, Mr. Duncan has contributed an article on the Asiatic question that is of serious import and worth reading.
('9', 298, 3, 22, 688846) They author, moreover, is a man of such vast influence that he can [if he chooses] get the Indian demands accepted.
('9', 298, 3, 23, 688962) Those who know English may read this article in that language.
('9', 298, 3, 24, 689025) We do not have space enough to give a translation, nor is it necessary to do so.
('9', 298, 3, 25, 689106) Much of it is past history, which is quite familiar to all Indians.
('9', 298, 3, 26, 689174) What is remarkable in the article is that is concedes that our demand is reasonable.
('9', 298, 3, 27, 689259) It also shows conclusively that Mr. Smuts had entertained the thought of repealing the Act.
('9', 298, 3, 28, 689351) It points out, further, that the Government felt heavily the pressure of satyagraha.
('9', 298, 3, 29, 689436) In brief, the article offers conclusive proof that the Government cannot but yield to that pressure.
('9', 298, 3, 30, 689537) All this is important.
('9', 298, 3, 31, 689560) But the most important point is that the article shows why the Government has not yielded so far.
('9', 298, 3, 32, 689658) Well, Mr. Duncan asserts categorically that the problem of [the immigration of] educated Indians is a serious one.
('9', 298, 3, 33, 689773) Whether they should be given in
('9', 299, 0, 1, 689805) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 299, 1, 2, 689847) law the same freedom of immigration as the whites is the main issue.
('9', 299, 1, 3, 689916) How can it be allowed?
('9', 299, 1, 4, 689939) Mr. Duncan argues that if South Africa is to be settled by a predominantly white population, such freedom cannot be allowed.
('9', 299, 1, 5, 690064) He says, moreover, that the problem is not limited to the Transvaal, but concerns the whole of South Africa, This realization led the Imperial Government to sanction the Immigration Law.
('9', 299, 1, 6, 690251) It is the same realization which has led all the whites to resist [the Indian demand], and which accounts for the continuation of the [Indian] campaign.
('9', 299, 1, 7, 690404) If the Transvaal Indians withdraw their campaign, there will be identical legislation in the Cape, Natal and Rhodesia.
('9', 299, 1, 8, 690523) If the Transvaal Indians continue the struggle, it will not be possible to enact such a law for the whole of South Africa.
('9', 299, 1, 9, 690646) Mr. Duncan has discussed these ideas at great length.
('9', 299, 1, 10, 690700) One may infer from this that the solution of the Indian question will be found only after the Convention has concluded its labours.
('9', 299, 2, 11, 690832) However, before that stage is reached, we already hear people saying that the satyagraha has collapsed.
('9', 299, 2, 12, 690936) If there is to be no more of satyagraha, why brother about the Convention?
('9', 299, 2, 13, 691011) We are, of course, not bothered about the Convention, but satyagraha will not on that account be abandoned.
('9', 299, 2, 14, 691119) All the Indians who fought for two years got a taste of this way of fighting.
('9', 299, 2, 15, 691197) They realized something of its beauty.
('9', 299, 2, 16, 691236) It is possible that they may give up fighting now.
('9', 299, 2, 17, 691287) But evven if a majority of Indians give up the fight, that will not mean the end of the movement.
('9', 299, 2, 18, 691385) It will go on so long as there is one single person to carry it on.
('9', 299, 2, 19, 691453) It is, however, our duty to commend this article of Mr. Duncans to the attention of those who have not yielded so far, and they, on their part, must note Mr. Duncans words and carry on the fight.

('9', 299, 5, 22, 691691) 183. DAWAD MAHOMEDS PATRIOTIC SERVICES
('9', 299, 6, 23, 691730) Mr. Dawad Mahomed, though nearing old age, has been rendering wonderful services to the community.
('9', 299, 6, 24, 691829) They deport him, but he is not deterred.
('9', 299, 6, 25, 691870) Imprisonment holds no terrors for him.
('9', 299, 6, 26, 691909) No matter at what point on the border the Government sets me free, [ I shall go where I like, even as cattle do].
('9', 299, 6, 27, 692023) He has smilingly repeated this remark to a number of men.
('9', 299, 6, 28, 692081) Serving repeated terms of imprisonmment and indifference to wealth are no longer rare among
('9', 300, 0, 1, 692173) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 301
('9', 300, 1, 2, 692214) Indians in South Africa.
('9', 300, 1, 3, 692239) We have already written about the invaluable services of Sorabji, who opened the second stage of the stayagraha.
('9', 300, 1, 4, 692352) He goes on doing his duty silently, whether inside the goal or outsidde it.
('9', 300, 1, 5, 692428) But this time it is of Mr. Dawad Mahomeds services especially that we wish to write.
('9', 300, 1, 6, 692513) A mans work may be appreciated in two ways.
('9', 300, 1, 7, 692557) First, with reference to its intrinsic wortth, and second, with reference to the results, that is, by an asseessment of its likely effects on other men in future.
('9', 300, 1, 8, 692720) From this second point of view, no one can equal the services of Mr. Dawad Mahomed.
('9', 300, 1, 9, 692804) It is not merely that he is the President of the Natal Indian Congress.
('9', 300, 1, 10, 692876) He is a resident of South Africa of long standing.
('9', 300, 1, 11, 692927) There must be very few Indians in South Africa who are his equals in resourcefulness.
('9', 300, 1, 12, 693013) He is so intelligent that, had he known English, he would be occupying a big position today.
('9', 300, 1, 13, 693106) He has a remarkable power of raillery with which he can chaff a great many people with effortless ease.
('9', 300, 1, 14, 693210) He has had a long experience.
('9', 300, 1, 15, 693240) He has been free with his money in helping people.
('9', 300, 1, 16, 693291) He has done good turns to a number of men, either by putting in a good word for them or by offering them monetary help.
('9', 300, 1, 17, 693411) He is a staunch Muslim, and exerts a powerful influence on the Surati community.
('9', 300, 1, 18, 693492) For these reasons, his activities have proved to be of immense value from the point of view of their effect.
('9', 300, 1, 19, 693601) We do not believe that any Indian in South Africa can be content to leave Mr. Dawad Mahomed in gaol.
('9', 300, 1, 20, 693702) His continued imprisonment has made it the duty of the Indian community to intensify the campaign.
('9', 300, 1, 21, 693801) The reader will now see why it is that Mr. Dawad Mahomeds part [in the movement] should be considered so very important, and we hope that every reader will be of this view and do his best to help the struggle.

('9', 302, 1, 2, 696667) 186. THE STRUGGLE
('9', 302, 2, 3, 696685) Readers of this journal will see from our columns this week that the Government have now begun to single out those passive resisters who have proved themselves strong, staunch and true.
('9', 302, 2, 4, 696871) In this we think the Government deserve congratulations from all parties.
('9', 302, 2, 5, 696945) At the rate the Government are going on, we should soon have most, if not all, of the passive resisters in gaol.
('9', 302, 2, 6, 697058) We should find out the true from the false, and the Government will have provided a demonstration for themselves and also for the Colony that real passive resisters are not concerned with an Asiatic influx into the Colony.
('9', 302, 2, 7, 697281) They are not concerned with bolstering up fraud.
('9', 302, 2, 8, 697330) All they care for and all they are fighting for is the good name of the community to which they belong, and if it suits the Government to keep such men in gaol for the term of their physical lives, it will suit passive resisters also admirably.
('9', 302, 2, 9, 697575) The honour of the community will be safe in their keeping, even though they may be in gaol.
('9', 302, 2, 10, 697667) They will have kept their sacred oath.
('9', 302, 2, 11, 697706) They will have lived up to the religion they professed.
('9', 302, 2, 12, 697762) More cannot be expected of man.
('9', 302, 2, 13, 697794) The Government may then, if they choose, pat themselves on the back for having put passive resisters out of harms way, but the world will have then seen the righteousness of the struggle in a manner it could not have done otherwise.
('9', 302, 2, 14, 698027) There is no such word as defeat in the dictionary of passive resisters, for the simple reason that, in passive resistance, there is no trial of brute strength in which one must necessarily yield.
