('9', 304, 3, 16, 702424) 189. WILL INDIANS YIELD?
('9', 304, 4, 17, 702449) Picking up some newspapers just now, we read how 500 men,
('9', 304, 5, 18, 702507) who had gone to see a play in Mexico, were burnt to death in a fire in the theatre, and how 200 miners were buried [in a mine] in Durham in Britain owing to an explosion.
('9', 304, 5, 19, 702678) It is only a few days ago that we read about the death of a large number of men when heavy rains caused the flooding of some mines near Johannesburg.
('9', 304, 6, 20, 702828) Though we receive such mysterious warnings from time to time,
('9', 304, 7, 21, 702890) we turn back from the tasks that we may have resolved on.
('9', 304, 7, 22, 702948) We fail to accomplish them either through fear of pecuniary loss, danger to our lives or other similar misfortunes.
('9', 304, 7, 23, 703064) Day and night we are busy guarding out bodies from harm, though we cannot take their safety for granted even for an hour.
('9', 304, 7, 24, 703186) For reasons such as these, the Transvaal Indians are turning back just when the ship is about to gain the shore; such behaviour brings no credit to Indians, is indeed unworthy of them.
('9', 304, 7, 25, 703371) The greatest charge against us is that we lack the spirit of manliness, that we make a big effort for a while, but soon set tired of it, and that we do not put all our heart into anything that we do.
('9', 304, 7, 26, 703571) It is one of the objects of the Trans vaal movement that this charge should be disproved.
('9', 304, 7, 27, 703661) From it is very nature, the movement will test most of the virtues of Indians or expose their faults.
('9', 304, 7, 28, 703763) Naturally, therefore, a
('9', 305, 0, 1, 703787) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 305, 1, 2, 703829) number of things are involved in it.
('9', 305, 1, 3, 703866) Indians ought to realize that in this campaign no one is to wait for a lead from others [or] to point to others in justification of ones own lapses.
('9', 305, 1, 4, 704015) Everyone must put his own courage to the test.
('9', 305, 1, 5, 704062) We must remember that the people whom we are fighting have themselves passed through many sufferings.
('9', 305, 1, 6, 704164) Only 300 year ago, they had heroes who preferred being burnt alive to betraying their principles.
('9', 305, 1, 7, 704262) There was a white man of holy character, John Bunyan 1 by name, whom the whites adore today, but who in his life time suffered much, having had to serve a harsh term of twelve years imprisonment.
('9', 305, 1, 8, 704458) In those days, gaols were veritable dungeons.
('9', 305, 1, 9, 704504) It was only for his principles that John Bunyan suffered.
('9', 305, 1, 10, 704562) In his time, men were put into prison if they did not attend a particular church.
('9', 305, 1, 11, 704644) John Bunyan would not attend under compulsion even the most hallowed church.
('9', 305, 1, 12, 704721) And for this he suffered imprisonment.
('9', 305, 1, 13, 704760) He was as happy in gaol as if it were a palace.
('9', 305, 1, 14, 704808) While there, he wrote a book which hundreds of thousands of whites read with great devotion.
('9', 305, 1, 15, 704901) It is believed that there are very few books like it in other languages.
('9', 305, 1, 16, 704974) This John Bunyan did not concern himself with what others did.
('9', 305, 1, 17, 705037) All that mattered to him was his own principles; these he refused to betray, preferring to remain in gaol.
('9', 305, 1, 18, 705144) He won, nevertheless.
('9', 305, 1, 19, 705166) Even today, those who threw him into prison are despised by the world.
('9', 305, 1, 20, 705237) Moreover, the imprisonment of a man like John Bunyan won freedom for his people.
('9', 305, 1, 21, 705318) It is with the fellow countrymen of such a man that we have to deal.
('9', 305, 1, 22, 705387) We take that to be our good fortune.
('9', 305, 1, 23, 705424) We cannot learn respect for a principle from a man who has much less of it than we have.
('9', 305, 1, 24, 705513) In the company of a jackal, one can learn to be a jackal and nothing better, but in a lions company one must learn to roar like a lion or face annihilation.
('9', 305, 1, 25, 705670) We find ourselves thrown among such lion like whites, who are extremely oppressive in their dealings with us.
('9', 305, 1, 26, 705780) If we look at the matter in the right perspective, we shall succeed in holding our own against them, shall save ourselves from being reduced to slavery and live in freedom as their equals in the Transvaal.
('9', 305, 1, 27, 705986) We have ventured through this campaign to claim equality with them, and success in the venture requires true knowledge and true education.
('9', 305, 1, 28, 706125) True knowledge is not mere literacy, and true education, not mere reading of books.
('9', 305, 1, 29, 706209) True knowledge and true education consist in knowing and understanding our true state, and in fashioning our lives and conduct in the light of that knowledge.

('9', 308, 1, 2, 710110) 192. TRIAL AT VOLKSRUST 1
('9', 308, 2, 3, 710136) VOLKSRUST, Thursday [February 25, 1909]
('9', 308, 3, 4, 710176) Today Messrs M. K. Gandhi, Somabhai Patel and six others were sentenced under the Regulations for refusing to produce certificates of registration and to give finger prints or other means of identification, to a fine of fifty pounds or to undergo imprison ment for three months with hard labour.
('9', 308, 3, 5, 710472) All went to gaol.
('9', 308, 4, 6, 710490) Addressing the Court, Mr. Gandhi said: It is my misfortune that I have to appear before the Court for the same offence the second time.
('9', 308, 4, 7, 710626) 2 I am quite aware that my offence is deliberate and wilful.
('9', 308, 4, 8, 710687) I have honestly desired to examine my conduct in the light of past experience and I maintain the conclusion that, no matter what my countrymen do or think, as a citizen of the State and as a man who respects conscience above everything, I must continue to incur the penalties so long as justice, as I conceive it, has not been rendered by the State to a portion of its citizens.
('9', 308, 4, 9, 711066) I consider myself the greatest offen der in the Asiatic struggle, if the conduct that I am pursuing is held to be reprehensible.
('9', 308, 4, 10, 711195) I, therefore, regret that I am being tried under a clause which does not enable me to ask for a penalty which some of my fellow objectors received, but I ask you to impose on me the highest penalty.
('9', 308, 4, 11, 711394) I desire to thank the Court and the Public Prosecutor for the courtesy exte nded to me in granting so long a delay on account of my wifes illness.
('9', 308, 5, 12, 711541) The Magistrate, in passing sentence, said: As I stated before, it is a matter of opinion.
('9', 308, 5, 13, 711631) You have your opinion.
('9', 308, 5, 14, 711654) I can only act in accordance with the law.
('9', 308, 5, 15, 711697) As you do not ask for different treatment, I shall treat you as I have treated others in the same position.
('9', 308, 6, 16, 711805) Indian Opinion, 27 2 1909
('9', 308, 7, 17, 711831) 1 The report of the trial was published as From Our Own Correspondent with the caption: Mr. Gandhi Goes to GaolThree Months Hard Labour for Refusing to Degrade His Honour and Conscience. 2 For the first trial at Volksrust, vide 14 10 1908.

('9', 309, 1, 2, 712113) 193. MESSAGE TO INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('9', 309, 2, 3, 712155) [JOHANNESBURG, February 25, 1909] I am happy that I am going to gaol again.
('9', 309, 2, 4, 712231) The only regret is that I received only three months imprisonment, whereas other satyagrahi patriots have received six months.
('9', 309, 2, 5, 712358) As I go to gaol, I see that many Indians have given in.
('9', 309, 2, 6, 712414) It is left only to a few Indians to continue the campaign now.
('9', 309, 2, 7, 712477) I am undeterred by this fact.
('9', 309, 2, 8, 712507) In some ways, it can be more vigorous now.
('9', 309, 2, 9, 712550) Those who have fallen can rise again.
('9', 309, 2, 10, 712588) They can [still] go to gaol.
('9', 309, 2, 11, 712617) I hope they will rise.
('9', 309, 2, 12, 712640) Even if they cannot, they can offer monetary help, and send statements to newspapers to say that, though they have surrendered, they are in favour of the fight and wish it success.
('9', 309, 2, 13, 712821) Men of education outside the Transvaal can enter and be installed in gaol.
('9', 309, 2, 14, 712896) If they do not do this, they can serve as volunteers at meetings wherever they are.
('9', 309, 2, 15, 712980) It is the duty of all Indians in South Africa to hold meetings, pass resolutions and send telegrams.
('9', 309, 2, 16, 713081) This is a fight on behalf of religion, that is, on behalf of the [universal] religion which underlies all religions.
('9', 309, 2, 17, 713198) Had I not believed so, I would never have advised the community to invite grievous suffering on itself, I believe that sacrificing ones all in a struggle like this should in no way be difficult.
('9', 309, 2, 18, 713393) It is the duty of every Indian to forget all thought of relatives and friends, to sacrifice wealth and life, in this struggle.
('9', 309, 2, 19, 713520) I pray to God, and beg of Indians that all of them fulfil this duty.
('9', 309, 2, 20, 713589) It lies in our own hands to shorten the campaign.

('9', 310, 4, 5, 713940) TO MY TAMIL BRETHREN BEFORE GOING TO GAOL FOR TH E THIRD TIME
('9', 310, 5, 6, 714002) IN OUR STRUGGLE
('9', 310, 6, 7, 714018) I have addressed a letter in Gujarati 2 to our countrymen, but, as I do not know the beautiful Tamil language sufficiently, I write to you in English, hoping that I may reach some of you.
('9', 310, 6, 8, 714206) The struggle has not reached the most critical stage.
('9', 310, 6, 9, 714260) Whilst the majority of the other sections of the community have fallen, being too weak, the majority of the Tamils and the Parsis have stood firm.
('9', 310, 6, 10, 714407) The brunt of the battle must, therefore, fall upon their shoulders.
('9', 310, 6, 11, 714475) I pray to God that He may give you sufficient strength to bear it.
('9', 310, 6, 12, 714542) You have discharged yourselves brilliantly hitherto.
('9', 310, 6, 13, 714595) Remember that we are descendants of Prahlad 3 and Sudhanva, both passive resisters of the purest type.
('9', 310, 6, 14, 714698) They disregarded the dictates even of their parents, when they were asked to deny God.
('9', 310, 6, 15, 714785) They suffered extreme torture rather than inflict suffering on their persecutors.
('9', 310, 6, 16, 714867) We in the Transvaal are being called upon to deny God, in that we are required to deny our manhood, go back upon our oath, and accept an insult to our nation.
('9', 310, 6, 17, 715026) Shall we in the present crisis do less than our forefathers?
('9', 310, 7, 18, 715087) M. K. GANDHI
('9', 310, 8, 19, 715100) Indian, Opinion, 6 3 1909
('9', 310, 9, 20, 715126) 1 Indian Opinion, 6 3 1909, published this message under the caption: Message to the Madrassis: Mr. Gandhis Last Exhortation.
('9', 310, 9, 21, 715252) The African Chronicle translated this into Tamil and published it as a supplement for free circulation through the British Indian Association, Transvaal 2 Vide the preceding item.
('9', 310, 10, 22, 715432) 3 A child saint, who resisted his father, King Hiranyakashipu, and affirmed his faith in God despite persecution.

('9', 311, 3, 6, 715757) Please read good writings and poems to her.
('9', 311, 3, 7, 715801) Always write to me after consulting her and let the letters be signed by both Manilal and you.
('9', 311, 3, 8, 715896) You may ask Ba what she has to say and let me know that also.
('9', 311, 3, 9, 715958) Let me know about your own health as well as the condition of your right ear, feet and cough.

('9', 311, 3, 12, 716159) Feed Rami at the breast for a few days more.
('9', 311, 3, 13, 716204) Take sufficient food after feeding her also.
('9', 311, 3, 14, 716249) Your health will not improve so long as you do not get open air.
('9', 311, 3, 15, 716314) I neet not write more.
('9', 311, 3, 16, 716337) Ask Willie 1 not to do any mischief at all.
('9', 311, 3, 17, 716381) If Ramdas has a sore throat, apply an earth bandage.

('9', 311, 7, 23, 716643) 196. M. A. EXAMINATION
('9', 311, 8, 24, 716666) Much is at stake in the Transvaal struggle, and therefore we have been writing on it frequently and at some length.
('9', 311, 8, 25, 716782) That seems to be the only right thing to do.
('9', 311, 8, 26, 716827) We submit to all Indians that the community will not chance upon such a struggle again.
('9', 311, 8, 27, 716915) It is no small matter that the fight has reached the present stage.
('9', 311, 9, 28, 716983) 1 Cordess son
('9', 312, 0, 1, 716997) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 313
('9', 312, 1, 2, 717038) But some Indians have been asking: Hundreds have yielded.
('9', 312, 1, 3, 717096) What is the point in continuing the fight? We think this betrays lack of understanding.
('9', 312, 1, 4, 717184) If some Indians have yielded, the same thing has been true of other armies.
('9', 312, 1, 5, 717260) There is nothing unusual in that.
('9', 312, 2, 6, 717294) The fight in which we are engaged at present is a kind of examination which we are to take.
('9', 312, 2, 7, 717386) We have been studying [as it were].
('9', 312, 2, 8, 717422) Everyone came forward to study.
('9', 312, 2, 9, 717454) Thousands went through the first grade.
('9', 312, 2, 10, 717494) Some got tired of their studies when they came to the second grade.
('9', 312, 2, 11, 717562) They left off.
('9', 312, 2, 12, 717577) In this manner, we reached the seventh grade.
('9', 312, 3, 13, 717623) Things became rather difficult.
('9', 312, 3, 14, 717655) A large number gave up.
('9', 312, 3, 15, 717679) Even so, a considerable number reached the matriculation stage.
('9', 312, 3, 16, 717743) But only a few had the courage to venture beyond that, though the number was not very low.
('9', 312, 4, 17, 717834) And now we are on the last stage.
('9', 312, 4, 18, 717868) We are to qualify ourselves for the M. A. degree.
('9', 312, 4, 19, 717918) That surely cannot be done by people in their hundreds.
('9', 312, 4, 20, 717974) Only a few will succeed.
('9', 312, 4, 21, 717999) Can it be said that those who appear at this examination are defeated because the rest did not offer themselves for it?
('9', 312, 4, 22, 718119) No; it cannot.
('9', 312, 4, 23, 718134) Those who take the M.A. degree will certainly have emerged victorious; not only that, but those who lagged behind will also share in the glory.
('9', 312, 5, 24, 718278) Thus, we liken the satyagrahis who still remain staunch to candidates for the M.A. degree.
('9', 312, 5, 25, 718369) They should not in the least feel disheartened; rather, they should be proud that they have remained steadfast so long.
('9', 312, 5, 26, 718489) There can be only a few highly educated men in any community.
('9', 312, 5, 27, 718551) But, though small in number, they are of the greatest help.
('9', 312, 5, 28, 718611) That is the situation in the Transvaal.
('9', 312, 5, 29, 718651) Maybe there are only a few Indians still who are left fighting; but the highest value should be attached to the part they are playing.
('9', 312, 6, 30, 718786) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 27 2 1909
('9', 312, 7, 31, 718828) 1 The last stage of the High School course.
('9', 313, 0, 1, 718872) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 313, 1, 2, 718914) 197. HELP FROM NATAL
('9', 313, 2, 3, 718935) We congratulate the [Natal Indian] Congress on having held a meeting in support of the Transvaal campaign.
('9', 313, 2, 4, 719042) In our view, the meeting was rather thinly attended, not much enthusiasm having been in evidence, and it had not been called as expeditiously as it should have been, so that we rest content with the mere fact of the meeting having been held, on the principle that something is better than nothing.
('9', 313, 2, 5, 719340) 1 All the same, the Natal leaders will be blamed for their lapse to the extent that they were found wanting.
('9', 313, 2, 6, 719449) We believe that they ought not to rest content merely with a meeting.
('9', 313, 2, 7, 719519) The Government will arrest as many persons as it wants to, and then watch the fun.
('9', 313, 2, 8, 719602) But Indians outside the Transvaal cannot afford to sit back.They must send frequent cable reports to India, revive the spirit of those in the Transvaal who have fallen and by such means focus public attention on the struggle all over the world.
('9', 313, 2, 9, 719847) If that is done, the gods of heaven will descend to watch the battle that will ensue.
('9', 313, 2, 10, 719933) If not, Indians will be ridiculed and lose their foothold in South Africa in the near future.
('9', 313, 2, 11, 720027) We spoke of a Natal meeting.
('9', 313, 2, 12, 720056) Really speaking, it was only a Durban meeting.
('9', 313, 2, 13, 720103) What has happened to Maritzburg and the other towns in Natal?
('9', 313, 2, 14, 720165) Why should they not hold meetings?
('9', 313, 2, 15, 720200) The main Line dispute has not yet been resolved.
('9', 313, 2, 16, 720249) People are preoccupied with questions of prestige and dignity while their brethren are in gaol.
('9', 313, 2, 17, 720345) This is not dignified behaviour.
('9', 313, 2, 18, 720378) The Main Line dispute ought to be resolved.
('9', 313, 2, 19, 720422) Even if it is not, work can be carried on in the other main towns of Natal.
('9', 313, 2, 20, 720498) What is Natals duty is also the duty of the Cape, Delagoa Bay and other places.
('9', 313, 2, 21, 720578) Cablegrams should be dispatched to England from all these places.
('9', 313, 2, 22, 720644) Money too will be needed for such an agitation; for this regular provision should be made.
('9', 313, 2, 23, 720735) It every Indian does his duty and performs the communitys tasks in the same spirit that he does his own, it will not be surprising to see India being forged into a nation in South Africa.
('9', 313, 2, 24, 720923) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 27 2 1909
('9', 313, 3, 25, 720965) 1 The Gujarati saying used here literally means, A squint eyed uncle is better than no uncle.

('9', 314, 1, 2, 721100) 198. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('9', 314, 2, 3, 721126) PRETORIA PRISON,
('9', 314, 3, 4, 721143) TRANSVAAL, March 4, 1909
('9', 314, 4, 5, 721168) MY DEAR WEST, I am still left handed.
('9', 314, 4, 6, 721206) The right hand I can use only with difficulty.
('9', 314, 5, 7, 721253) The authorities will not grant permission for me to write to Mrs. Gandhi in Gujarati.
('9', 314, 5, 8, 721339) I am sorry for her and Harilals wife.
('9', 314, 5, 9, 721377) I do not know whether wife would like me to write in English.
('9', 314, 5, 10, 721439) I know that I can write nothing new.
('9', 314, 5, 11, 721476) She wants to read my own writing.
('9', 314, 5, 12, 721510) I feel that it is more dignified not to take advantage of a privilege grudgingly given.
('9', 314, 5, 13, 721598) You may write to me, or Manilal may, in English how she progresses from day to day and also about Harilals wife.
('9', 314, 5, 14, 721711) If they wish to, they will let me have these letters and I shall know something about the health of the patient.
('9', 314, 6, 15, 721824) Please tell Mrs. G[andhi] that I am all right.
('9', 314, 6, 16, 721871) 1 She knows that my happiness depends more upon my mental state than upon physical surroundings.
('9', 314, 6, 17, 721968) Let her cherish this thought and not worry about me.
('9', 314, 6, 18, 722021) For the sake of the children, she should help herself to get better.
('9', 314, 6, 19, 722090) She should have the bandages regularly and add hip baths if necessary.
('9', 314, 6, 20, 722161) She should adhere to the diet that I used to give.
('9', 314, 6, 21, 722212) She ought not to start [walking] 2 till she is quite restored.
('9', 314, 7, 22, 722275) Harilals wife has all the directions.
('9', 314, 7, 23, 722313) I shall be glad to learn that she follows them.
('9', 314, 7, 24, 722361) She ought on no account to omit sago and milk in the morning.
('9', 314, 7, 25, 722423) Let Manilal watch that she takes it.
('9', 314, 7, 26, 722460) Rami should have the breast yet for a month.
('9', 314, 7, 27, 722505) She can only be gradually weaned.
('9', 314, 8, 28, 722539) I am told that even if a letter in Gujarati were passed, it would take quite ten days before it could be transmitted.
('9', 314, 8, 29, 722657) With regards all round,
('9', 314, 9, 30, 722681) Yours sincerely,
('9', 314, 10, 31, 722698) M. K. GANDHI

('9', 315, 3, 5, 722984) 199. DRAFT PETITION TO GAOL GOVERNOR 1
('9', 315, 4, 6, 723023) [PRETORIA, After March 11, 1909] Your Petitioner is a British Indian, undergoing a sentence of three months imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 315, 4, 7, 723162) Your Petitioner received last week, as has been discovered, by mistake, one ounce of ghee every day with the rice that was issued to him for supper.
('9', 315, 4, 8, 723311) Your Petitioner was admitted to this gaol on the 3rd instant.
('9', 315, 4, 9, 723373) Since last Sunday, the issue of ghee for supper as above has been stopped.
('9', 315, 4, 10, 723448) Your Petitioner tried to take the rice without ghee on Sunday last but found it difficult.
('9', 315, 4, 11, 723539) Since Monday last, your Petitioner has had no supper at all, he having been obliged to return the rice issued to him.
('9', 315, 4, 12, 723657) Your Petitioner complained of the absence of ghee to the Chief Warder, who referred your Petitioner to the regulations and suggested that your Petitioner could see the Medical Officer if he so wished.
('9', 315, 4, 13, 723858) On the 11th instant, your Petitioner saw the Medical Officer who as a special concession was prepared to order a ration of bread for supper.
('9', 315, 4, 14, 723999) Your Petitioner, while appreciating the concession, has been unable to avail himself of it, not being desirous of receiving any special concession in regard to diet as apart from his Indian fellow prisoners placed under similar circumstances.
('9', 315, 4, 15, 724242) Your Petitioner was shown the printed diet scale which provides for one ounce of fat with rice as supper for Indian prisoners.
('9', 315, 4, 16, 724369) The scale provides under Indian diet meat twice a week.
('9', 315, 4, 17, 724425) Your Petitioner has been informed that this scale has been changed and Indian prisoners now receive one [ounce] of rice without
('9', 315, 5, 18, 724553) 1 This was drawn up during Gandhijis incarceration in Pretoria Gaol.
('9', 316, 0, 1, 724622) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 317
('9', 316, 1, 2, 724663) fat for supper and rice with one ounce of ghee in lieu of meat for dinner on meat days.
('9', 316, 2, 3, 724751) Your Petitioner in common with the majority of Indians is prohibited by religion from taking meat or mutton fat or such other fat.
('9', 316, 2, 4, 724882) Indian Mahomedans cannot take meat or fat not religiously killed.
('9', 316, 2, 5, 724948) Indian Hindus with certain exceptions cannot at all take meat or fat.
('9', 316, 3, 6, 725018) In the humble opinion of your Petitioner, the change above referred to is a change for the worse.
('9', 316, 3, 7, 725116) It is most difficult to take rice without some adjunct.
('9', 316, 3, 8, 725172) Moreover, the scale is deficient in nutrition with only two ounces of ghee per week.
('9', 316, 4, 9, 725257) Your Petitioner has noticed that Natives receive one ounce of fat per day in addition to meat twice a week or at least once a week.
('9', 316, 5, 10, 725389) In the humble opinion of your Petitioner, reversion to the old scale with the substitution of ghee for fat and substitution of vegetables for meat on meat days will meet the ends of justice.
('9', 316, 6, 11, 725580) If the above prayer is considered unreasonable, your Petitioner fears that he will suffer in health for want of sufficient nutrition.
('9', 316, 7, 12, 725714) Your Petitioner ventures to draw your attention to the fact that the change prayed for is in accordance with the scale at the Johannesburg gaol.
('9', 316, 8, 13, 725859) If the Governor is (not) 1 empowered in law to grant the petition, your Petitioner requests that the petition may be forwarded to the Director of Prisons for consideration.
('9', 316, 9, 14, 726032) And for this act, etc.
('9', 316, 10, 15, 726055) M. K. G.

('9', 317, 4, 5, 726363) MY DEAR SON, I have a right to write one letter per month and receive also one letter per month.
('9', 317, 4, 6, 726460) It became a question with me as to whom I should write to .
('9', 317, 4, 7, 726520) I thought of Mr. Ritch, Mr. Polak and you.
('9', 317, 4, 8, 726563) I chose you, as you have been nearest my thoughts in all my reading.
('9', 317, 4, 9, 726632) As for myself I must not, I am not allowed to, say much.
('9', 317, 4, 10, 726689) I am quite at peace and none need worry about me.
('9', 317, 4, 11, 726739) I hope mother is now quite well.
('9', 317, 4, 12, 726772) I know several letters from you have been received but they have not been given to me.
('9', 317, 4, 13, 726859) The Deputy Governor however was good enough to tell me that she was getting on well.
('9', 317, 4, 14, 726944) Does she now walk about freely?
('9', 317, 4, 15, 726976) I hope she and all of you would continue to take sago and milk in the morning.
('9', 317, 4, 16, 727055) And how is Chanchi 1?
('9', 317, 4, 17, 727077) Tell her I think of her everyday.
('9', 317, 4, 18, 727111) I hope she has got rid of all the sores she had and that she and Rami are quite well.
('9', 317, 4, 19, 727197) I was much struck by one passage in Nathuramjis 2 introduction to the Upanishads.
('9', 317, 4, 20, 727279) He says that the Brahmacharya stagei.e., the first stageis like the last, i.e., the Sanyasin stage.
('9', 317, 4, 21, 727379) This is true.
('9', 317, 4, 22, 727393) Amusement only continues during the age of innocence, i.e., up to twelve years only.
('9', 317, 4, 23, 727478) As soon as a boy reaches the age of discretion, he is taught to realise his responsibility.
('9', 317, 4, 24, 727570) Every boy from such age onward should practise continence in thought and deed, truth likewise and the not taking of any life.
('9', 317, 4, 25, 727696) This to him must not be an irksome learning and practice but it should be natural to him.
('9', 317, 4, 26, 727786) It should be his enjoyment.
('9', 317, 4, 27, 727814) I can recall to my mind several such boys in Rajkot.
('9', 317, 4, 28, 727867) Let me tell you that when I was younger than you are, my keenest enjoyment was to nurse my father.
('9', 317, 4, 29, 727966) 3 Of amusement after I was twelve, I had little or none.
('9', 317, 4, 30, 728023) If you practise the three virtues 4, if they become

('9', 318, 1, 2, 728345) part of your life, so far as I am concerned, you will have completed your educationyour training.
('9', 318, 1, 3, 728443) Armed with them, believe me, you will earn your bread in any part of the world and you will have paved the way to acquire a true knowledge of the soul, yourself and God.

('9', 323, 0, 1, 739122) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 323, 1, 2, 739164) 202. INDIANS AND ALCOHOL 1
('9', 323, 2, 3, 739191) [PRETORIA GAOL, Before April 10, 1909] I have seen your letter addressed to the British Indian Association regarding its evidence to be submitted to the Commission.
('9', 323, 2, 4, 739356) I have not been able, my movement[s] having been uncertain, to submit my statement earlier.
('9', 323, 2, 5, 739448) Nor has it been possible to call a meeting of the Association to consider the evidence to be given.
('9', 323, 2, 6, 739548) The Chairman 2 and the Acting Chairman 3 of the Association are in gaol.
('9', 323, 2, 7, 739621) The statement, therefore, that I am about to submit represents my personal views only.
('9', 323, 2, 8, 739708) I have been in South Africa now for the last fifteen years, and having, almost throughout that period, been officially connected with Indian public bodies, I have come in contact with all classes of Indians.
('9', 323, 2, 9, 739916) Since 1903, I have been practising as an attorney in Johannesburg, and have held the office of Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association.
('9', 323, 2, 10, 740065) The Transvaal has a population of not more than 13,000 adult male Indians.
('9', 323, 2, 11, 740140) Indians actually resident in the Colony since the war have probably never been more than 10,000 at any time.
('9', 323, 2, 12, 740249) At the present moment, owing to the Asiatic struggle, there are probably not more than 5,000 in the Colony.
('9', 323, 2, 13, 740357) These are chiefly Mahomedans and Hindoos.
('9', 323, 2, 14, 740399) For the purposes hereof, I do not consider the Christians and the Parsees, as they form, though an important, a numerically small section of the Indian community.
('9', 323, 2, 15, 740562) Both Mahomedans and Hindoos are prohibited by their respective religions from taking intoxicating liquors.
('9', 323, 2, 16, 740669) The Mahomedan section has very largely conformed to the prohibition.
('9', 323, 2, 17, 740738) The Hindoo section, I am sorry to say, contains an appreciable number who, in this Colony, have disregarded the prohibition of religion.
('9', 323, 2, 18, 740875) The method adopted by Indians who indulge in alcoholic drinks
('9', 323, 3, 19, 740937) 1 This statement was sent by Gandhiji from Pretoria Gaol by courtesy of the Governor as written evidence to the Transvaal Liquor Commission, Johannesburg.
('9', 323, 3, 20, 741092) It was published with editorial comments, under the sub title Mr. Gandhis Views, as Special to Indian Opinion.
('9', 323, 3, 21, 741203) 2 A. M. Cachalia 3 E. I. Aswat
('9', 324, 0, 1, 741234) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 325
('9', 324, 1, 2, 741275) is generally to secure the assistance of some unscrupulous whites.
('9', 324, 1, 3, 741342) There are other methods, also, which I do not care to go into.
('9', 324, 2, 4, 741405) I am of opinion that the legal prohibition should continue.
('9', 324, 2, 5, 741465) I think, however, that the prohibition has not succeeded in preventing Indians, who have wanted it, from obtaining liquor.
('9', 324, 2, 6, 741588) The only use I see in continuing the prohibition is to let those of my countrymen, who indulge in it, retain the sense of shame they have in drinking liquor.
('9', 324, 2, 7, 741746) They know that it is wrong for them both in religion and in law to obtain and drink liquor.
('9', 324, 2, 8, 741838) This enables temperance workers to appeal to their law abiding sentiment.
('9', 324, 2, 9, 741912) I draw a fundamental distinction between wrongful law breaking and a conscientious breach of man made law in obedience to a higher law.
('9', 324, 2, 10, 742048) Happily, those Indians who break the liquor law know that it is wrong for them to do so.
('9', 324, 3, 11, 742137) I am aware that some of my countrymenthemselves ardent temperance mensee in the liquor legislation one more disqualification based on the ground of colour.
('9', 324, 3, 12, 742293) Superficially speaking, they would be right.
('9', 324, 3, 13, 742338) But I believe that this legislation has little to do with colour.
('9', 324, 3, 14, 742404) It is, in my opinion, a recognition on the part of the predominant race that the drink habit is an evil which, while they themselves are yet unable to get rid of, they do not want other races to contract.
('9', 324, 3, 15, 742609) Viewing the position in this manner, I believe liquor prohibition among the Asiatic and Coloured races to be the forerunner of general prohibition.
('9', 324, 4, 16, 742757) Whether, however, general prohibition becomes an accomplished fact or not, so long as the predominant race continue to indulge in alcoholic drinks, be it ever so moderately, partial prohibition such as we now have cannot be of much practical use.
('9', 324, 4, 17, 743004) This, it is submitted, is a forcible illustration of one of the evil incidents of contact between the European and other races.
('9', 324, 4, 18, 743132) And unless those who preach abstinence are themselves ready to practise it, all liquor legislation must largely be a makeshift.
('9', 324, 4, 19, 743260) I wish the Commission could see their way to point out to the electors of the Transvaal what a serious responsibility rests on their shoulders.
('9', 324, 4, 20, 743404) They make it impossible for their representatives to pass legislation that is so desirable.
('9', 324, 4, 21, 743496) It is they who must take the responsibility for the breaking up of many a home.
('9', 324, 4, 22, 743576) I am writing under a full sense of my own responsibility.
('9', 324, 4, 23, 743634) I know only too well how many Indian youths who never knew the taste of spirituous liquors have succumbed, after having come to South Africa or the Transvaal.
('9', 325, 0, 1, 743793) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 325, 1, 2, 743835) If the Commission desire me to answer any question, I shall be pleased to do so.

('9', 328, 2, 8, 750881) I find on my release that those who are brave will stand firm.

('9', 330, 3, 4, 755102) He said that he had been released from gaol, but he felt no pleasure at that, many of the stalwarts among his compatriots had still to serve their sentences, and his own son had six months to do, but for all that, the struggle must go on until the Government granted them relief to which they were entitled; their sufferings must continue until justice was done.
('9', 330, 3, 5, 755465) Those Indians who could not bear the hardships of gaol should give what assistance they could in other ways, for he took it that no single Indian could possibly approve of the harsh measures of the Government or fail in sympathy of one sort or another with the struggle which was now proceeding.
('9', 330, 3, 6, 755761) There could only be one end to the struggle, and that end would be hastened or delayed by the strength displayed by the British Indian community.
('9', 330, 3, 7, 755907) They were now in the hottest part of the fight, and it was possible that they might not carry all their countrymen with them, but that only meant that the brunt of the battle would fall on the shoulders of the few, but, concluded Mr. Gandhi: whether our members be large or small, I earnestly pray God that He will give us strength to carry the burden until we have reached the goal.

('9', 334, 3, 18, 766550) 209. LETTER TO THE PRESS 2
('9', 334, 4, 19, 766577) JOHANNESBURG, May 26, 1909
('9', 334, 5, 20, 766604) SIR, As there has been much talk, during my last incarceration, regarding the treatment I underwent, I shall thank you to publish the following statement.
('9', 334, 5, 21, 766759) When I was sentenced to undergo imprisonment for three months with hard labour at Volksrust, and taken to the gaol there, I found myself in the company of over fifty fellow workers, including my son.
('9', 334, 5, 22, 766959) This, in itself, was to me a great pleasure.
('9', 334, 5, 23, 767004) The food supplied was nice and clean, and included 1 oz.
('9', 334, 5, 24, 767061) of ghee (clarified butter) per day, and was cooked by Indian cooks.
('9', 334, 5, 25, 767129) All Indian prisoners
('9', 334, 6, 26, 767150) 1 The meeting was later addressed by Rev.
('9', 334, 6, 27, 767192) J. J. Doke and Chettiar, Chairman, Tamil Benefit Society.
('9', 334, 6, 28, 767250) 2 The letter was addressed generally to the Transvaal Press.
('9', 334, 6, 29, 767311) It was published in Indian Opinion under the caption Mr. Gandhis Experiences in the Pretoria Gaol.
('9', 335, 0, 1, 767410) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 335, 1, 2, 767452) were completely separated from the Natives, and had separate sanitary accommodation also.
('9', 335, 1, 3, 767542) Those who occupied cells had bed boards, in addition to the usual supply of blankets, etc., and all had a pillow each issued to them.
('9', 335, 1, 4, 767676) The work was out door work, and consisted for about thirty of us in road repair or weed ing the school ground, either of which, so far as I was concerned, was very agreeable and healthy, I was sentenced on the 25th February last.
('9', 335, 2, 5, 767906)  ISOLATED
('9', 335, 3, 6, 767916) On the 2nd March, I was ordered to be removed to Pretoria.
('9', 335, 3, 7, 767975) I had to travel in a third class compartment, and, as most of the travelling was done during the night, it was naturally cold, more so as no blankets are issued, evidently, to prisoners.
('9', 335, 3, 8, 768162) Arriving at Pretoria on the 3rd March, I was, after the usual formalities had been gone through, locked up in a cell.
('9', 335, 3, 9, 768280) For, I think, five days, I had to pass the whole of the time in the cell or the corridor, except when I was allowed out for bathing and for such other purposes.
('9', 335, 3, 10, 768441) My cell door was marked isolated and I found, too, that I was isolated along with four other prisoners, one of whom was convicted of having made an attempt to murder, two of having committed sodomy, and one bestiality.
('9', 335, 3, 11, 768660) Here there was no pillow and no bed board issued, and, for food, there was no ghee allowed except on Wednesdays and Sundays.
('9', 335, 3, 12, 768785) The work given to me consisted in polishing the floor of my own cell and polishing the cell doors in the corridor of the section in which I was accommodated, along with the Native prisoners.
('9', 335, 3, 13, 768976) It was during this time that Mr. Lichtenstein 1 visited me, and I told him that I considered the treatment to be brutal, and that there was evidently an intention on the part of General Smuts to bend me, but that I was not likely to succumb.
('9', 335, 3, 14, 769218) Subsequently, I was given half hours exercise twice a day, and the work was altered to that of blanket quilting, or such other tailoring work.
('9', 335, 4, 15, 769361) ONE MEAL PER DAY
('9', 335, 5, 16, 769378) I went practically without any breakfast, because the mealie meal was not cooked sufficiently for my taste.
('9', 335, 5, 17, 769486) I made no complaint about it, as all the other prisoners, I noticed, took their porridge with relish.
('9', 335, 5, 18, 769588) I went without supper, because the rice issued contained no ghee.
('9', 335, 5, 19, 769654) I complained about the absence of ghee to the Chief Warder,
('9', 335, 6, 20, 769714) 1 Lawyer and a professional colleague of Gandhiji

('9', 336, 3, 20, 771566) I would also mention here gratefully that I was allowed an unrestricted use of books, which to me were a source of the greatest consolation.
('9', 336, 3, 21, 771707) The tailoring work in my cell, which required bending to it for nearly seven hours per day, began to tell upon my health.
('9', 336, 3, 22, 771829) I, therefore, requested that I should have more active work, or, at least, that I should be allowed to do the tailoring in the open.
('9', 336, 3, 23, 771962) Both the requests were at first rejected.

('9', 336, 3, 25, 772164) On repeating my request, I was allowed to do the tailoring work in the open air.

('9', 337, 1, 2, 772343) GOVERNMENT ALONE TO BLAME
('9', 337, 2, 3, 772369) The opinion I expressed to Mr. Lichtenstein about General Smuts underwent a change upon further observation, and I felt that he had directly nothing to do with the treatment described above.
('9', 337, 2, 4, 772560) Indeed, I gratefully recall here the sending by him of two nice books for me to read, testifying, as I took it, to the fact that he entertained no personal ill will against me, and that he gave me credit for doing what I believed to be right.
('9', 337, 2, 5, 772803) Nor do I blame any of the officials for what I had to undergo.
('9', 337, 2, 6, 772866) They were all courteous and kind, and I cannot be sufficiently thankful to the section warders, who seemed to realise the peculiar position in which I was placed, and showed me every consideration.
('9', 337, 2, 7, 773064) And yet I must adhere to the opinion that the treatment itself was brutal.
('9', 337, 2, 8, 773139) My sentence was imprisonment with hard labour, but, for the larger part of the term, it was practically solitary confinement.
('9', 337, 2, 9, 773265) The officials of the Prison Department could do no otherwise bacause, Indians being classed with Native prisoners, I could only be placed in the Native section.
('9', 337, 2, 10, 773426) The same, however, can hardly be said of the Government, who, having so many Indian prisoners on hand, gave no thought to the matter.
('9', 337, 2, 11, 773560) They must have known, when I was cruelly separated from my fellow prisoners at Volksrust, that, at Pretoria, I would be obliged to undergo hardships not warranted by the sentence imposed upon me.
('9', 337, 2, 12, 773756) I do not say that Indian prisoners should be classed with Europeans.
('9', 337, 2, 13, 773825) Their lot would, then, probably, be much worse than it is now.
('9', 337, 2, 14, 773888) But I do say that they should be separately classed and separately accommodated.
('9', 337, 2, 15, 773969) I may be told that, having invited imprisonment for myself, I can hardly complain of the prison system with any justification.
('9', 337, 2, 16, 774096) This taunt is inapplicable, because, I submit, avoidable misery was inflicted upon me, and, in any case, it is as well for the public, in whose name the Government is supposed to be acting, to know what is being done to Indian passive resisters.
('9', 337, 3, 17, 774342) OTHER PRISONERS
('9', 337, 4, 18, 774358) After my discharge I learnt that, if I fared somewhat ill, the majori ty of the other passive resisters fared no better, if not worse; for the majo rity of the Indian passive resisters at the Johannesburg Fort were removed to the penal settlement at Diepkloof, and the majority of those at Volksrust to Heidelberg, at both of which places, in the initial stages, they had to undergo hardships for which there was no

('9', 338, 1, 2, 774815) warrant.
('9', 338, 1, 3, 774824) The Indian prisoner may not complain about the labour to which he is put so long as it is tolerable, but I think that he has every right to complain about improper, unsuitable, or insufficient diet.
('9', 338, 1, 4, 775023) It is hardly any credit to the Colony that one of the bravest and the truest of Indians in the Colony, an Indian who has occupied the position of Acting Chairman of the British Indian Association, and who is a well know merchant, has been made to carry slop pails.
('9', 338, 1, 5, 775288) No amount of harassing that may be applied will turn those who have passed through their experience during the last few months from their purpose.
('9', 338, 1, 6, 775435) Several have already again been imprisoned, one young man of nineteen for the fifth time.
('9', 338, 1, 7, 775525) The public has no knowledge of the fact that an Indian is nearly every day arrested and imprisoned for three months with hard labour, at Vereeniging, for managing the store belonging to Mr. Aswat, who is himself locked up at Diepkloof.
('9', 338, 1, 8, 775761) Eight such Indians have already been offered up as a sacrifice, and volunteers are still forthcoming to take charge of this store.
('9', 338, 1, 9, 775892) Passive resistance is not then dead.

('9', 338, 1, 11, 775973) Indian Opinion, 5 6 1909
('9', 338, 2, 12, 775998) 210. WHO CAN OFFER SATYAGRAHA?
('9', 338, 3, 13, 776029) The satyagraha campaign in the Transvaal has lasted so long and has been so conducted that we have been able to seelearna great many things from it.
('9', 338, 3, 14, 776178) Many have had personal experience of it.
('9', 338, 3, 15, 776219) This much at least has been realized by everyonethat, in a struggle of this kind, there is no room for defeat.
('9', 338, 3, 16, 776330) If, on any occasion, we fail, we shall discover that the failure was due to some deficiency in the satyagrahi and did not argue the inefficacy of satyagraha as such.
('9', 338, 3, 17, 776496) The point needs to be carefully grasped.
('9', 338, 3, 18, 776537) No such rule can be applied to physical fighting.
('9', 338, 3, 19, 776587) When two armies engage in such fighting, defeat [of either] will not necessarily be the result of the inferior fighting quality of the troops.
('9', 338, 3, 20, 776730) The combatants may have a high morale, and yet, insufficiency in other matters may lead to defeat.
('9', 338, 3, 21, 776829) For instance , one side may have better arms than the other, or may be favourably placed in the battle field, or may command superior technical skill.There are many such extraneous factors which account for the victory or defeat of the parties to a physical fight.
('9', 338, 3, 22, 777094) But such factors offer no difficulties to those fighting the battle of satyagraha.
('9', 338, 3, 23, 777177) Their deficiency alone can come in their way.
('9', 338, 3, 24, 777223) Moreover, in the usual kind of fighting, all the members of the losing side should be deemed to have been defeated,
('9', 339, 0, 1, 777339) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 339, 1, 2, 777381) and in fact they do think that way.
('9', 339, 1, 3, 777417) In satyagraha, the victory of a single member may be taken to mean the victory of all, but the defeat of the side as a whole does not spell defeat for the person who has not himself yielded.
('9', 339, 1, 4, 777608) For instance, in the Transvaal fight, even if a majority of Indians were to submit to the obnoxious Act, he who remains unyielding will be victorious indeed, for the fact remains that he has not yielded.
('9', 339, 1, 5, 777812) That being so, it is necessary to inquire as to who can offer so admirable a battleone which admits of no defeatwhich can have only one result.
('9', 339, 1, 6, 777956) The inquiry will enable us to understand some of the results of the Transvaal campaign, and to decide how and by whom a campaign of this kind can be fought elsewhere or on some other occasion.
('9', 339, 1, 7, 778149) If we inquire into the meaning of satyagraha, we find that the first condition is that anyone who wants to engage in this kind of fighting should show a special regard for truthshould have the strength that flows from truthfulness.
('9', 339, 1, 8, 778381) That is to say, such a man should depend on truth alone.
('9', 339, 1, 9, 778438) One cannot have the best of both worlds.
('9', 339, 1, 10, 778479) 1 A man who attempts to have it so will be crushed under pressure of both kinds.
('9', 339, 1, 11, 778560) 2 Satyagraha is not a carrot, to be played on as a pipe.
('9', 339, 1, 12, 778617) 3 Anyone who thinks that it is, so that he may play on it if he can or bite it off if he cannot, will find himself lost in the end.
('9', 339, 1, 13, 778749) It is absurd to suggest that satyagraha is being resorted to only by those who are deficient in physical strength or who, finding physical strength unavailing, can think of no alternative but satyagraha.
('9', 339, 1, 14, 778953) Those who hold such a view, it may be said, do not know what this fight means.
('9', 339, 1, 15, 779032) Satyagraha is more potent than physical strength, which is as worthless as straw when compared with the former.
('9', 339, 1, 16, 779144) Essentially, physical strength means that a man of such strength fights on the battle field with little regard for his body, that is to say, he knows no fear.
('9', 339, 1, 17, 779303) A satyagrahi, on his part, gives no thought whatever to his body.
('9', 339, 1, 18, 779369) Fear cannot touch him at all.
('9', 339, 1, 19, 779399) That is why he does not arm himself with any material weapons, but continues resistance till the end without fear of death.
('9', 339, 1, 20, 779523) This means that the satyagrahi should have more courage than the man who relies on physical strength.
('9', 339, 1, 21, 779625) Thus, the first thing
('9', 339, 2, 22, 779647) 1 The Gujarati saying used here literally means, One cannot have one foot in curds and the other in milk. 2 Of physical strength and moral argument 3 The reference is to a Gujarati saying, denoting a course of action that one expects to be profitable either way, whether one succeeds or fails.
('9', 340, 0, 1, 779941) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 341
('9', 340, 1, 2, 779982) necessary for a satyagrahi is pursuit of truth, faith in truth.
('9', 340, 2, 3, 780046) He must be indifferent to wealth.
('9', 340, 2, 4, 780080) Wealth and truth have always been in conflict with each other, and will remain so till the end of time.
('9', 340, 2, 5, 780184) We have found from many examples of Indians in the Transvaal that he who clings to wealth cannot be loyal to truth.
('9', 340, 2, 6, 780300) This does not mean that a satyagrahi can have no wealth.
('9', 340, 2, 7, 780357) He can, but he cannot make his wealth his God.
('9', 340, 2, 8, 780404) Money is welcome if one can have it consistently with ones pursuit of truth; otherwise one must not hesitate even for a mo ment to sacrifice it as if it were no more than dirt on ones hand.
('9', 340, 2, 9, 780594) No one who has not cultivated such an attitude can practise satyagraha.
('9', 340, 2, 10, 780666) Moreover, in a land where one is obliged to offer satyagraha against the rulers, it is not likely that the satyagrahi will be able to own wealth.
('9', 340, 2, 11, 780812) The power of a king may be unavailing against an individual.
('9', 340, 2, 12, 780873) But it can touch his pro perty, or play on his fear of losing it.
('9', 340, 2, 13, 780939) The king bends the subjects to his will by threatening them with loss of property or physical harm.
('9', 340, 2, 14, 781039) There fore, under the rule of a tyrannical king, for the most part, it is only those who make themselves accomplices in his tyranny can retain or amass wealth.
('9', 340, 2, 15, 781199) Since a satyagrahi cannot allow himself to be an accomplice in tyranny, he must, in such circumstances, be content to think himself rich in his poverty.
('9', 340, 2, 16, 781352) If he owns any wealth, he must hold it in some other country.
('9', 340, 3, 17, 781414) A satyagrahi is obliged to break away from family attachments.
('9', 340, 3, 18, 781477) This is very difficult to do.
('9', 340, 3, 19, 781507) But the practice of satyagraha, if satyagraha is to be worthy of its name, is like walking on the edge of a sword.
('9', 340, 3, 20, 781622) In the long run, even the breaking away from family attachm ents will prove beneficial to the family.
('9', 340, 3, 21, 781724) For, the members of the family will come to feel the call for satyagraha, and those who have felt such a call will have no other desire left.
('9', 340, 3, 22, 781866) When faced with suffering of any kindloss of wealth or imprisonmentone need not be concerned about the future of ones family.
('9', 340, 3, 23, 781992) He who has given us teeth will provide us with food to eat.
('9', 340, 3, 24, 782052) If He provides for such dangerous creatures as the snake, the scorpion, the tiger and the wolf, He is not likely to be unmindful of mankind.
('9', 340, 3, 25, 782193) It is not a pound of millets or a handful of corn that we hanker after, but the delights of the palate; not just the clothes that we need to enable us to bear cold, but garments of brocaded silk.
('9', 340, 3, 26, 782389) If we abandon all this restless craving, there will hardly be any need for anxiety as to the means for maintaining ones family.
('9', 341, 0, 1, 782517) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 341, 1, 2, 782559) In this connection, it is worth while to bear in mind that many of these things have to be sacrificed even if physical force is resorted to.
('9', 341, 1, 3, 782700) One is obliged to suffer hunger and thirst, to bear heat and cold, to sacrifice family bonds, to put up with pecuniary loss.
('9', 341, 1, 4, 782825) The Boers went through all this when they resorted to physical force.
('9', 341, 1, 5, 782895) The one great difference between the physical resistance that they offered and our resistance based on truth is that the game they played was in the nature of a gamble.
('9', 341, 1, 6, 783064) Physical strength, moreover, has made them proud.
('9', 341, 1, 7, 783114) Their partial success made them forgetful of their former condition.
('9', 341, 1, 8, 783183) Having fought with deadly arms against a deadly enemy, they are bearing hard upon us as deadly tyrants.
('9', 341, 1, 9, 783287) When a satyagrahi wins in battle, his success cannot but be beneficial to him and to others.
('9', 341, 1, 10, 783380) A satyagrahi, if he is to remain loyal to truth, can never be a tyrant.
('9', 341, 1, 11, 783452) This inquiry, then, leads at last to the conclusion that he alone can offer satyagraha who has true faith in religion.
('9', 341, 1, 12, 783571) The name of Rama on the lips, and a dagger nuder the arm 1that is no faith.
('9', 341, 1, 13, 783647) It is no religion to speak in its name and to do exactly the opposite of what it teaches.
('9', 341, 1, 14, 783737) But anyone who has true religion and faith in him can offer satyagraha.
('9', 341, 1, 15, 783809) In other words, he who leaves everything to God can never know defeat in this world.
('9', 341, 1, 16, 783894) Such men are not defeated in fact simply because people say that they are defeated.
('9', 341, 1, 17, 783978) So also one cannot claim success simply because people believe that one has succeeded.
('9', 341, 1, 18, 784065) [There can be no arguing about this;] if you know the difference, you know it, else you dont.
('9', 341, 1, 19, 784159) This is the real nature of satyagraha.
('9', 341, 1, 20, 784198) The Transvaal Indians have partially understood it.
('9', 341, 1, 21, 784250) Having done so, they have been faithful to it in practice, again partially.
('9', 341, 1, 22, 784326) Even so, we have been able to taste its priceless sweetness.
('9', 341, 1, 23, 784387) He who has sacrificed everything for satyagraha has gained everything, for he lives in contentment.
('9', 341, 1, 24, 784487) Contentment is happiness.
('9', 341, 1, 25, 784513) Who has ever known any happiness other than this?
('9', 341, 1, 26, 784563) Every other kind of happiness is but a mirage.
('9', 341, 1, 27, 784610) The nearer we approach it, the farther it recedes.
('9', 341, 1, 28, 784661) We hope that every Indian will think of the matter this way and make himself a satyagrahi.
('9', 341, 1, 29, 784752) If we learn the use of the weapon of satyagraha, we can employ it to overcome all hardships originating from injustice.
('9', 341, 1, 30, 784872) It is not here [in South Africa] alone that the weapon is useful; it will be more so in our home country.
('9', 341, 1, 31, 784978) Only we must know its true nature, which is easy to do, and yet difficult.
('9', 341, 1, 32, 785053) Men of great physical strength are rare.
('9', 341, 1, 33, 785094) Rarer still must be those who derive their strength from truth.

('9', 342, 2, 3, 785296) VOLKSRUST
('9', 342, 3, 4, 785306) When, on February 25, I was sentenced to three months imprisonment with hard labour and I embraced my fellow prisoners and my son in the Volksrust Gaol, I did not imagine that I would have much to say or write about this pilgrimage to gaol.
('9', 342, 3, 5, 785547) But my expectation, like many other expectations of man, proved false.
('9', 342, 3, 6, 785618) The experience I had this time was somethings new altogether.
('9', 342, 3, 7, 785680) What I have learnt from this I would not have been able to learn even from years of study.
('9', 342, 3, 8, 785771) I think these three months have been of inestimable value to me.
('9', 342, 3, 9, 785836) In that brief period, I had many vivid experiences of satyagraha and I think I am a better satyagrahi today than I was three months ago.
('9', 342, 3, 10, 785973) For all this, thanks are due to the local (the Transvaal) Government.
('9', 342, 3, 11, 786043) Some officers had sworn that I should in no circumstances get less than six months imprisonment this time.
('9', 342, 3, 12, 786150) My fellow prisoners elderly and prominent Indiansand my sonwere all serving a six monthsterm each, so that I wanted the officerswish to be fulfilled.
('9', 342, 3, 13, 786300) However, since I had been charged under the Regulations framed under the Act, 1 I was afraid that three months would be the utmost I might get, and that is what happened .
('9', 342, 3, 14, 786472) After the sentence had been passed, it was a pleasure to join Mr. Dawad Mahomed, Mr. Rustomjee, Mr. Sorabji, Mr. Pillay, Mr. Hajurasingh, Mr. Lalbahadursingh and other veterans.
('9', 342, 3, 15, 786650) Except ten of them, all were provided with beds in tents pitched on the ground in front of the gaol.
('9', 342, 3, 16, 786751) The scene had therefore the appearance of an armed camp rather than a gaol.
('9', 342, 3, 17, 786827) Everyone liked sleeping in a tent.
('9', 342, 3, 18, 786862) Arrangements for food were satisfactory.
('9', 342, 3, 19, 786903) As on previous occasions, cooking was in our own hands.
('9', 342, 3, 20, 786959) It was therefore possible to prepare food to our taste.
('9', 342, 3, 21, 787015) In all there were about 77 (satyagrahi) prisoners.
('9', 342, 3, 22, 787066) Those who were taken outside for work were set a rather difficult task.

('9', 342, 3, 24, 787198) This required quarrying out stone, digging into heaps of stones that had been piled up, and carrying them in loads.

('9', 344, 1, 19, 790807) It was a cell of the kind intended for one prisoner at a time.
('9', 344, 1, 20, 790870) It measured, I believe, ten feet long and seven broad.
('9', 344, 1, 21, 790925) The floor was covered with black pitch.
('9', 344, 1, 22, 790965) The warders were constantly engaged in keeping it shining.
('9', 344, 1, 23, 791024) For ventilation, it had a very small glass window, with iron bars.
('9', 344, 1, 24, 791091) It was provided with an electric light for keeping a watch on the prisoner during the night.
('9', 344, 1, 25, 791184) The light is not meant for the prisoners use, for it is not powerful enough to read by.
('9', 344, 1, 26, 791272) Standing close to it, I could read a book printed in large type.
('9', 344, 1, 27, 791337) The light is put out exactly at eight.
('9', 344, 1, 28, 791376) But it is switched on five or six times in the night when the warders have a look at the prisoner through the watch hole mentioned above.
('9', 344, 2, 29, 791514) After eleven, the Deputy Governor came.
('9', 344, 2, 30, 791554) I asked for three things from him: books, permission to write to my wife who was ill, and a small bench to sit on.
('9', 344, 2, 31, 791669) As to the first, the reply was: I shall see; as to the second: Yes; as to the third: No. When, however, I wrote in Gujarati, the letter was returned to me with the remark that I should write in English.

('9', 344, 2, 33, 792020) In spite of this, however, I did not get the permission.

('9', 344, 2, 35, 792142) The same evening my books were handed over to me.
('9', 344, 3, 36, 792192) When the midday meal arrived, I had to eat it in the cell standing, with the doors shut.
('9', 344, 3, 37, 792281) At about three, I asked permission to take a bath.

('9', 344, 3, 39, 792401) The warder replied: All right.

('9', 348, 3, 25, 802174) So they found some other work for me, such as knitting a sweater, stitching purses for holding tickets, etc.

('9', 348, 3, 27, 802540) Moreover, one might suffer in health through worry.

('9', 351, 4, 9, 807641) 214. WHO CAN GO TO GAOL?
('9', 351, 5, 10, 807666) Last week we briefly considered the question: Who can be a satyagrahi?
('9', 351, 5, 11, 807737) In the Transvaal, satyagraha consists for the most part in going to gaol.
('9', 351, 5, 12, 807811) But imprisonment is not the end of the matter.
('9', 351, 5, 13, 807858) Satyagrahis have had to mount the gallows, 1 embrace a pillar of red hot iron 2, suffer being rolled down a mountain, swim in boiling oil in a big frying pan, 3 walk through a blazing forest 4, suffer loss of a kingdom and be sold [as slave] in a low born family 5 and stay in a lions den.
('9', 351, 5, 14, 808148) Thus, satyagrahis have had to pass through different ordeals in different parts of the world.
('9', 351, 6, 15, 808242) In the Transvaal, the ordeal for the satyagrahis consists merely in going to gaol.
('9', 351, 6, 16, 808325) Hence, it will be useful to inquire as to who can go to gaol.
('9', 351, 6, 17, 808387) Some Indians were willing to go to gaol, but did not do so could not do soowing to one reason or another.
('9', 351, 6, 18, 808493) What could have been those reasons?
('9', 351, 6, 19, 808529) This question will answer itself it we find out who can go to gaol.
('9', 351, 7, 20, 808597) Every person, then, who wants to go to gaol must have, in some measure, the qualities which, as we have seen, are essential in a satyagrahi.
('9', 351, 7, 21, 808738) But, in addition, he should have the following strong points: (1) Freedom from addiction to harmful things.
('9', 351, 7, 22, 808846) (2) A well disciplined body.
('9', 351, 7, 23, 808875) (3) Disregard for comfortable seat or bed.
('9', 351, 7, 24, 808918) (4) Extreme simplicity in food habits.
('9', 351, 7, 25, 808957) (5) Total freedom from false sense of prestige or status.
('9', 351, 8, 26, 809015) 1 The reference probably is to the crucifixion of Jesus.
('9', 351, 8, 27, 809072) 2 These are references to legends of Prahlad, Sudhanva, Nala Damayanti and Harishchandra, respectively.
('9', 351, 8, 28, 809176) 3 ibid 4 ibid 5 ibid
('9', 352, 0, 1, 809197) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 353
('9', 352, 1, 2, 809238) (6) Fortitude.
('9', 352, 1, 3, 809253) Friends who would go to gaol must particularly have these qualities, (which we may call the six forms of wealth in a prison.) Let us examine each of them.
('9', 352, 1, 4, 809408) It was our experience that those prisoners who were addicted to smoking, drinking, betel nuts or even tea found the strain of gaol life too much.
('9', 352, 1, 5, 809554) In consequence, they either managed to get these things surreptitiously in gaol, that is, abandoned [the path of] truth, or gave up speaking of going to gaol again.
('9', 352, 1, 6, 809719) One must therefore avoid every form of addiction.
('9', 352, 1, 7, 809769) One addiction alone is permissible, and that is repeating the name of the Lord in prayer.
('9', 352, 1, 8, 809859) Cowards can never become satyagrahis.
('9', 352, 1, 9, 809897) Likewise, a physical wreck will not generally be able to bear gaol life.
('9', 352, 1, 10, 809970) There have been many cases of men who, though physically weak, have braved hardships through sheer will power.
('9', 352, 1, 11, 810081) These are exceptions.
('9', 352, 1, 12, 810103) As a general rule, one must have a healthy and sound constitution; lacking this, some of the prisoners were unable to bear the strain [of gaol life].
('9', 352, 1, 13, 810253) A satyagrahi knows that his body is [as it were] lent to him on hire.
('9', 352, 1, 14, 810323) He should prove a worthy tenant by keeping it clean and glowing with health.
('9', 352, 1, 15, 810400) One can understand that a man who is accustomed to a spring cot with a soft mattress cannot all at once bring himself to sleep on the floor.
('9', 352, 1, 16, 810541) One must therefore get rid of this pampering of the body.
('9', 352, 1, 17, 810599) Diet, it seems, has proved to be much the most important problem.
('9', 352, 1, 18, 810665) That also is not surprising.
('9', 352, 1, 19, 810694) He who has his tongue under control, being both sparing in speech and moderate in his taste for good food, must be reckoned to have achieved a great conquest.
('9', 352, 1, 20, 810853) We hardly come across anyone who does not relish good food.
('9', 352, 1, 21, 810913) Even the poor Kaffirs die with craving for good food.
('9', 352, 1, 22, 810967) Of course, this is not a simple problem.
('9', 352, 1, 23, 811008) However those who want to offer themselves for imprisonment in a public cause must learn to master their palate.
('9', 352, 1, 24, 811121) The proper thing is to offer thanks to God for whatever we get.
('9', 352, 1, 25, 811185) Every Indian must ponder over the fact that, in India, thirty million out of a population of three hundred million get only one meal a day, and that, too, nothing more than roti and salt.
('9', 352, 1, 26, 811373) Compared to this, it is not much of a hardship to have to maintain oneself in gaol on three meals a day, each different from the other.
('9', 352, 1, 27, 811509) Hunger accepts everything.
('9', 352, 1, 28, 811536) Though one may not feel at ease for a few days, by and by one does come to like gaol food.
('9', 352, 1, 29, 811627) Any Indian who wants to be a satyagrahia prisonermust accustom himself to simple food as quickly as
('9', 353, 0, 1, 811727) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 353, 1, 2, 811769) possible.
('9', 353, 2, 3, 811779) A person with a false notion of prestige or status cannot afford to go to gaol.
('9', 353, 2, 4, 811859) One is subjected there to the authority of the warder and is asked to do work which is thought rather degrading.
('9', 353, 2, 5, 811972) If one refuses to do such work, considering it dishonourable, or on the ground that one has never done it before, the result will be unwelcome.
('9', 353, 2, 6, 812116) Whether on thinks of anything as a mark of servitude or not depends entirely on ones mind.
('9', 353, 2, 7, 812207) He who is free in his mind will feel as free as a king even when carrying buckets [of night soil].
('9', 353, 2, 8, 812306) Rather than feel that carrying of buckets is a mark of servitude, such a man will consider it a matter of honour in the present circumstances.
('9', 353, 3, 9, 812449) And last, Lady Fortitude.
('9', 353, 3, 10, 812475) Everyone starts counting days the moment he is in gaol, with the result that they appear to grow inordinately long.
('9', 353, 3, 11, 812591) Years wore on while we were outside and were lost to us for ever.
('9', 353, 3, 12, 812657) And yet we did not think much of that.
('9', 353, 3, 13, 812696) In gaol, three days appeared to be as long as three years.
('9', 353, 3, 14, 812755) The answer is that we were not happy to be in gaol.
('9', 353, 3, 15, 812807) Just as a mother takes pleasure in suffering for the sake of the child, so also must we take pleasure in suffering for the motherlandfor truth.
('9', 353, 3, 16, 812951) One must patiently serve out the full term of ones imprisonment, bearing always in mind that one could never have passed ones days outside in the same manner as in gaol and put the time to good use, that is, spent the days in devotion to God, in good thoughts, in self examination.
('9', 353, 3, 17, 813233) In this way, going along a single path one will have accomplished two tasks.
('9', 353, 4, 18, 813310) These six qualities, therefore, a [satyagrahi] prisoner must have.

('9', 353, 8, 24, 813607) OTHER CHANGES
('9', 353, 9, 25, 813621) As I mentioned above, the warder in charge of me was somewhat harsh in his behaviour.
('9', 353, 9, 26, 813707) This did not last long.
('9', 353, 9, 27, 813731) When he saw that with the Government itself I took up a fighting attitude about food, etc., but carried out all his orders his manner changed, and I was allowed to

('9', 354, 1, 5, 814090) His successor was a happy go lucky man.

('9', 354, 1, 8, 814247) I am myself something of a fighter.

('9', 354, 2, 11, 814509) This exercise was continued even after I was allowed to sit outside for work.
('9', 354, 2, 12, 814587) The rule about exercise applies to all prisoners who have to do work sitting.
('9', 354, 3, 13, 814665) And then the bench which had been refused to me was later sent by the Chief Warder of his own accord.
('9', 354, 3, 14, 814767) Meanwhile, I received from General Smuts two books on religion, and I inferred from this that it was not under his orders that I had been subjected to hardships, but that it was the result of his negligence and that of others, as also a consequence of the fact that we are equated with the Kaffirs.
('9', 354, 3, 15, 815066) One thing appeared certain, that the only object of isolating me was to see that I had no opportunity of talking to anyone.
('9', 354, 3, 16, 815190) With some effort, I could also secure a pencil and a note book.
('9', 354, 4, 17, 815254) DIRECTORS VISIT
('9', 354, 5, 18, 815270) Within a few days of my being brought to Pretoria, Mr. Lichtenstein came to see me with special permission.
('9', 354, 5, 19, 815378) He had come on official business, but he made inquiries about my health, etc.
('9', 354, 5, 20, 815456) I was reluctant to give a reply, but, being pressed, I said to him: Without going into details, I shall only say that I am being subjected to brutal treatment.
('9', 354, 5, 21, 815616) General Smuts wants to bend me, but I am not likely to succumb.
('9', 354, 5, 22, 815680) I am prepared to suffer everything.
('9', 354, 5, 23, 815716) My mind is at peace.
('9', 354, 5, 24, 815737) Please do not make this public.

('9', 355, 1, 5, 816501) In fact, Indians are more comfort loving than whites in regard to sitting and sleeping.

('9', 355, 2, 15, 817248) HANDCUFFED

('9', 356, 2, 4, 818928) MAGIC POWER O F SATYAGRAHA
('9', 356, 3, 5, 818955) Some of the facts which I have given above will appear rather trivial, but they have been described in such detail in order to show that satyagraha is feasible in every situation, serious or otherwise.
('9', 356, 3, 6, 819157) The result of my having submitted to the physical hardships inflicted by the junior warder was that I could preserve my peace of mind.
('9', 356, 3, 7, 819292) Not only that, the warders themselves removed all those hardships.
('9', 356, 3, 8, 819359) If I had resisted, that would have distracted my energies from the bigger tasks on hand and the warders would have become my enemies.
('9', 356, 3, 9, 819493) On the question of food also, I remained firm in my principles and bore some hardships initially, with the result that this difficulty, too, disappeared.
('9', 356, 3, 10, 819647) The same thing can also be seen [to have happened] in respect of the smaller difficulties.
('9', 356, 3, 11, 819738) The biggest gain, however, has been that I find myself, beyoud any shadow of doubt, to have grown in mental strength in consequence of having endured physical suffering.
('9', 356, 3, 12, 819908) I believe that the last three months have been of great profit to me and I am ready today to bear much heavier suffering without flinching.
('9', 356, 3, 13, 820048) I see that satyagraha is assured of divine help, and that in testing a satyagrahi the Creator imposes on him at every step only as much burden as he can bear.
('9', 356, 4, 14, 820207) MY READING
('9', 356, 5, 15, 820218) The story of my suffering or of my happiness, or rather of both, ends here.
('9', 356, 5, 16, 820294) But I had a great many benefits in the course of these three months.
('9', 356, 5, 17, 820363) One of the most important, to be sure, was that I got an opportunity for reading.

('9', 359, 2, 4, 825997) 216. SPEECH AT GERMISTON 1
('9', 359, 3, 5, 826024) [GERMISTON, June 7, 1909]
('9', 359, 4, 6, 826050) Mr. Gandhi, who was well received, on rising, said that, although he had chosen passive resistance as his subject that evening, he did not wish to deal with the Indian question, except in so far as it might be necessary to illustrate any proposition.
('9', 359, 4, 7, 826301) Passive resistance, the speaker proceeded, was a misnomer.
('9', 359, 4, 8, 826360) But the expression had been accepted as it was popular and had been for a long time used by those who carried out in practice the idea denoted by the term.
('9', 359, 4, 9, 826516) The idea was more completely and better expressed by the term soul force.
('9', 359, 4, 10, 826590) As such, it was as old as the human race.
('9', 359, 4, 11, 826632) Active resistance was better expressd by the term body force.
('9', 359, 4, 12, 826694) Jesus Christ, Daniel and Socrates represented the purest form of passive resistance or soul force.
('9', 359, 4, 13, 826793) All these teachers counted their bodies as nothing in comparison to their souls.
('9', 359, 4, 14, 826874) Tolstoy was the best and brightest exponent of the doctrine.
('9', 359, 4, 15, 826935) He not only expounded it, but lived according to it.
('9', 359, 4, 16, 826988) In India, the doctrine was understood and commonly practised long before it came into vogue in Europe.
('9', 359, 4, 17, 827091) It was easy to see that soul force was infinitely superior to body force.
('9', 359, 4, 18, 827165) If people in order to secure redress of wrongs resorted to soul force, much of the present suffering would be avoided.
('9', 359, 4, 19, 827284) In any case, the wielding of this force never caused suffering to others.
('9', 359, 4, 20, 827358) So that, whenever it was misused, it only injured the users and not those against whom it was used.
('9', 359, 4, 21, 827458) Like virtue, it was its own reward.
('9', 359, 4, 22, 827494) There was no such thing as failure in the use of this kind of force.
('9', 359, 4, 23, 827563) Resist not evil meant that evil was not to be repelled by evil but by good; in other words, physical force was to be opposed not by its like but by soul force.
('9', 359, 4, 24, 827723) The same idea was expressed in Indian philosophy by the expression freedom from injury to every living thing.
('9', 359, 4, 25, 827833) The exercise of this doctrine involved physical suffering on the part of those who practised it.
('9', 359, 4, 26, 827930) But it was a known fact that the sum of
('9', 359, 5, 27, 827970) 1 At the invitation of the Germiston Literary and Debating Society, Gandhiji spoke on The Ethics of Passive Resistance at the Council Chamber.
('9', 359, 5, 28, 828113) Linton Jones, President of the Society, presided.
('9', 359, 5, 29, 828163) The audience was representative of Germistons leading citizens.The report appeared in Indian Opinion as.
('9', 359, 5, 30, 828268) From Our Own Reporter.
('9', 360, 0, 1, 828291) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 361
('9', 360, 1, 2, 828332) such suffering was greater rather than less in the world.
('9', 360, 1, 3, 828390) That being so, all that was necessary for those who recognized the immeasurable power of soul force was to consciously and deliberately accept physical suffering as their lot, and, when this was done, the very suffering became a source of joy to the sufferer.
('9', 360, 1, 4, 828650) It was quite plain that passive resistance, thus understood, was infinitely superior to physical force and that it required greater courage than the latter.
('9', 360, 1, 5, 828807) No transition was, therefore, possible from passive resistance to active or physical resistance.
('9', 360, 1, 6, 828904) The Colonists would, therefore, see that no exception could be taken to Indians making use of this force in order to obtain a redress of their grievances.
('9', 360, 1, 7, 829059) Nor could such a wcapon, if used by the Natives, do the slightest harm.
('9', 360, 1, 8, 829131) On the contrary, if the Natives could rise so high as to understand and utilize this force, there would probably be no native question left to be solved.
('9', 360, 1, 9, 829285) The one condition of a successful use of this force was recognition of the existence of the soul as apart from the body, and its permanent and superior nature.
('9', 360, 1, 10, 829445) And this recognition must amount to a living faith and not a mere intellectual grasp.
('9', 360, 1, 11, 829531) The speaker illustrated his lecture with several modern illustrations.

('9', 361, 2, 4, 831304) The Transvaal Leader, 12 6 1909
('9', 361, 3, 5, 831336) 218. SOME SUGGESTIONS
('9', 361, 4, 6, 831358) Satyagraha will end some day, no matter when.
('9', 361, 4, 7, 831404) But, meanwhile, we give below instances, without offering any argument, of the benefits the Indian community has already derived and the fruits it has tasted; every Indian should ponder over these: (1) The Rhodesian law has been defeated.
('9', 361, 4, 8, 831643) (2) Lord Crewe has clearly stated that the [Rhodesian] Act has been disallowed because of the satyagraha campaign in the Transvaal.
('9', 361, 4, 9, 831775) (3) Lord Crewe has stated in the same communication that the Imperial Government did not feel happy in giving assent to the Transvaal Act.
('9', 361, 4, 10, 831914) (4) In the Blue book recently issued, Lord Crewe has recommended that both demands of the Indians should be conceded.
('9', 361, 4, 11, 832032) (5) The Transvaal Government in its reply has not rejected the recommendation [outright], but has explicitly stated that the satyagraha campaign has for the most part collapsed and that, if Lord Crewe waited, the remaining Indians would also give in.
('9', 361, 4, 12, 832283) (This is a clear indication that, if satyagraha had been continued by a large number of Indians, our demands would have been met long before this.) (6) Many whites who knew nothing about Indians till now have not only come to know what they are, but have also been working for our cause.
('9', 361, 4, 13, 832571) Each of these instances will suggest a number of reflections.
('9', 362, 0, 1, 832633) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 363
('9', 362, 1, 2, 832674) shall elaborate them some time later for the benefit of our readers.
('9', 362, 1, 3, 832743) Meanwhile, we hope that many Indians will ponder over and derive fresh strength from them.
('9', 362, 1, 4, 832834) It is clear, at any rate, that it depends on us whether or not we shall win.
('9', 362, 1, 5, 832911) We fail, then, to understand why so many Indians have been disheartened.
('9', 362, 2, 6, 832984) [From Gujarati]
('9', 362, 3, 7, 833000) Indian Opinion, 12 6 1909
('9', 362, 4, 8, 833026) 219. INDIANS IN THE CAPE
('9', 362, 5, 9, 833051) Indians in the Cape have been slumbering.
('9', 362, 5, 10, 833093) The Immigration Officer is wide awake.
('9', 362, 5, 11, 833132) The immigration report of the Cape is worth reading and pondering over by every Indian in the Colony.
('9', 362, 5, 12, 833234) Here we intend to emphasize only two points.
('9', 362, 5, 13, 833279) Mr. Cousins (the Chief Officer) states that many Indians bring in others children representing them as their own, and give wrong information about their ages.
('9', 362, 5, 14, 833438) Under these circumstances, Mr. Cousins suggests that the law be so amended as to require every Indian to bring with him a (Government) certificate from India testifying to the boys age and stating that the boy is his own son.
('9', 362, 5, 15, 833664) The two facts are related to each other as cause and effect.
('9', 362, 5, 16, 833725) It is because some Indians practise deception, as stated above, that Mr. Cousins has put forward a new suggestion.
('9', 362, 5, 17, 833840) We are bound to suffer so long as we continue to resort to falsehood.
('9', 362, 5, 18, 833910) It is always harmful to violate a law on the sly.
('9', 362, 5, 19, 833960) Should we disapprove of any law, it would be to our advantage to violate it openly, if we have the courage to do so.
('9', 362, 5, 20, 834077) We should know when to violate a law in this way.
('9', 362, 5, 21, 834127) the Cape Indians need to act with great caution; first, to cast out the falsehood in us, should there be any, and, second, to represent to the Government without the slightest delay that Mr. Cousins suggestion is improper.
('9', 362, 5, 22, 834350) We shall give elsewhere the other facts mentioned in the report.
