('9', 363, 2, 3, 834524) VISIT TO HOUTPOORT PRISONERS
('9', 363, 3, 4, 834553) Indian prisoners in Houtpoort Gaol, near Heidelberg, were visited by Mr. Gandhi, Mr. and Ms.
('9', 363, 3, 5, 834646) Vyas and Mr. Shelat.
('9', 363, 3, 6, 834667) All the prisoners were found to be in good health.
('9', 363, 3, 7, 834718) It was also observed that, for some time past, the officers there have been behaving rather well.
('9', 363, 3, 8, 834816) Mr. Nanalal Shah is in this gaol.
('9', 363, 3, 9, 834850) His being sentenced to six months imprisonment, because he refrained from using his certificates, proves him to be a man of courage; likewise, his work and conduct in gaol have been excellent.
('9', 363, 3, 10, 835043) He has endeared himself to everyone.
('9', 363, 3, 11, 835080) He also gives to everyone portions from his own quota of food.
('9', 363, 3, 12, 835143) All the prisoners released from the gaol testify to this.
('9', 363, 3, 13, 835201) Mr. Manji Nathubhai, Mr. Khimchand Shah and Mr. Parbhu Kuber are unanimous in their praise of Mr. Nanalal Shah.
('9', 363, 3, 14, 835313) Though Mr. Bhayat is in gaol, prisoners continue to receive help from his store.
('9', 363, 3, 15, 835394) Whenever a prisoner is released, a carriage is generally sent to receive him.
('9', 363, 3, 16, 835472) I use the word generally because when Mr. Manji, Mr. Khimchand and Mr. Parbhu were released, no carriage was sent to receive them.
('9', 363, 3, 17, 835603) Since Mr. Manji had been fasting and Mr. Khimchand was in poor health, they were put to considerable hardship.
('9', 363, 3, 18, 835714) Moreover, as the telegram intimating their arrival in Johannesburg was not received in time, no one could go to the station to receive them.
('9', 363, 3, 19, 835855) Such hardships need not frighten any satyagrahi.
('9', 363, 3, 20, 835904) These too must be borne.
('9', 363, 3, 21, 835929) Mistakes will always happen through oversight.
('9', 363, 4, 22, 835976) ASWATS GREATNESS
('9', 363, 5, 23, 835993) Mr. Aswat endured much suffering in the Diepkloof Gaol.
('9', 363, 5, 24, 836049) He has lost about 30 pounds in weight.
('9', 363, 5, 25, 836088) It seems he acted in perfect conformity with the spirit of satyagraha.
('9', 363, 5, 26, 836159) He did not even so much as touch food other than what he got in gaol.
('9', 363, 5, 27, 836229) He was a confirmed smoker, but he did not smoke even once during the three months [of his imprisonment].
('9', 363, 5, 28, 836334) Indifferent to his business, he has offered to go to gaol again.
('9', 363, 5, 29, 836399) While I am writing about Mr. Aswat, it occurs to me that Mr. Thambi Naidoo has given up smoking, tea and coffee for ever, though, before he went to gaol, he could not do without any of these things even for an hour.
('9', 363, 5, 30, 836615) He has, moreover, pledged himself not to
('9', 364, 0, 1, 836656) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 365
('9', 364, 1, 2, 836697) allow his moustache to grow so long as the struggle is on.
('9', 364, 1, 3, 836756) So long as the community has such heroes among its members, the fight is bound to countinue and ultimate victory is assured.
('9', 364, 2, 4, 836881) THE MORAL
('9', 364, 3, 5, 836891) It has come to my knowledge that some of the satyagrahi prisoners have learnt to resort to underhand ways in gaol.
('9', 364, 3, 6, 837006) Formerly they would not eat anything which was not openly available for all or which others could not get; now they do so.
('9', 364, 3, 7, 837129) Those who were not used to chewing tobacco or smoking have now learnt to do so.
('9', 364, 3, 8, 837209) Such prisoners should be ashamed of themselves, and ought to emulate the examples of Mr. Aswat and Mr. Naidoo.
('9', 364, 3, 9, 837320) The more faithfully the community observes the spirit of satya graha, the earlier will come the end, and the more indifferent it grows, the more will satyagraha be prolonged.
('9', 364, 3, 10, 837495) The reasoning is simple enough.
('9', 364, 4, 11, 837527) DEPORTATION
('9', 364, 5, 12, 837539) Prompt steps are being taken about deportations to India.
('9', 364, 5, 13, 837597) Mr. Isaac has been sent to Delagoa Bay in connection with that.
('9', 364, 5, 14, 837661) I hope Delagoa Bay Indians will help him.
('9', 364, 5, 15, 837703) At the same time, correspondence is also going on with the Government.
('9', 364, 5, 16, 837774) Mr. Narottam Kalidas, who was sentenced to deportation, has been released and is enjoying himself in Johannesburg.
('9', 364, 5, 17, 837889) However, there is no reason why we should be afraid even of deportation.
('9', 364, 5, 18, 837962) Men with courage, even if deported, can continue the fight in the home country as well.
('9', 364, 5, 19, 838050) Telegrams have been sent to India to have proper arrangements made for those who, though they are satya grahis, have nevertheless been deported or may be deported in future.
('9', 364, 5, 20, 838224) Be sides, Mr. Somabhai Patel, who was only recently released and has gone to India on some work, has decided to do his best about this in Bombay.

('9', 369, 6, 12, 849370) 222. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING 1
('9', 369, 7, 13, 849400) [JOHANNESBURG, June 16, 1909]
('9', 369, 8, 14, 849430) MR. CHAIRMAN, LADIES, GENTLEMEN AND FRIENDS, We have met here this afternoon under somewhat exceptional circumstances, but I cannot say that these circumstances were unexpected.
('9', 369, 8, 15, 849608) For some weeks the chief members of the Indian community have been discussing among themselves the advisability of sending a deputation to England, in view of the approaching visit to England of Generals Botha and Smuts in connection with unification 2. The European Committee that has been formed in the Transvaal, in order to sympathise with us and to help us in every legitimate way, has also advised that such a deputation should proceed to England.
('9', 369, 9, 16, 850062) 1 A mass meeting of about 1,500 to 2,000 British Indians was held in the rounds of the Hamidia Mosque, Fordsburg, on June 16, to appoint delegates to go to England and to India to explain the present state of affairs in the Transvaal.
('9', 369, 9, 17, 850297) Delegates from all over the Transvaal were present.
('9', 369, 9, 18, 850349) E. S. Coovadia, Acting Chairman of the British Indian Asso ciation, presided and made a few introductory remarks in Gujarati.
('9', 369, 9, 19, 850475) Gandhiji spoke next.
('9', 369, 9, 20, 850496) 2 The reference is to the proposed Union of the four Colonies in South Africa.
('9', 370, 0, 1, 850575) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 371
('9', 370, 1, 2, 850616) you know, a large Committee meeting 1 was held last Sunday, and after much debate a resolution was come to by a large majority that a passive resistance deputation should proceed to London Next Monday.
('9', 370, 1, 3, 850818) That Committee nominated Mr. Cachalia, the Chairman of the British Indian Association, Mr. Chettiar, representing the Tamil section and Chairman of the Tamil Benefit Society, Mr. Hajee Habib who, although he has not been able to see eye to eye with us up to now, declared himself a passive resister, was also nominated , and myself.
('9', 370, 1, 4, 851151) There was also a submission made to the meeting that, simultaneously with the English deputation, a deputa tion should proceed to India, in order that the true situation might be placed before the Indian public, and other names were submitted.
('9', 370, 1, 5, 851395) Among them were the names of Mr. Polak, the Assistant Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association, Mr. N. Gopal Naidoo, Mr. N. A. Cama, and a fourth name was not given then, but it will be submitted at this meeting, and that is, Mr. Coovadia.
('9', 370, 1, 6, 851647) To day we find that the Government have laid their hand upon Mr. Cachalia, and Mr. Cachalia is locked up in the Johannesburg Gaol.
('9', 370, 1, 7, 851778) He has been sentenced to three months impri sonment with hard labour unless he paid a fine of 50. Mr. Cachalia is now in gaol in connection with this struggle for the fourth time.
('9', 370, 1, 8, 851958) Mr. Chettiar also has been arrested, and he is undergoing imprisonment for three months.
('9', 370, 1, 9, 852047) The brave Thambi Naidoo is also in gaol.
('9', 370, 1, 10, 852088) Mr. Vyas was arrested yesterday.
('9', 370, 1, 11, 852121) He has been released on bail because he has to meet perhaps a dying brother who is dangerously ill.
('9', 370, 1, 12, 852221) His case is adjourned for a fortnight.
('9', 370, 1, 13, 852260) Mr. Nadeshir Cama, who was to have proceeded to India if duly elected by this meeting, has also been arrested, and his case has been adjourned for similar reasons.
('9', 370, 1, 14, 852424) Our worthy Chairman whose name is included in the Indian deputation, was arrested at 2 oclock.
('9', 370, 1, 15, 852519) His case has been remanded in order to enable him to wind up his business, but him also three months imprisonment stares in the face, and Omarji Sale, the Vice Chairman of the British Indian Association, as also Mr. Dildar Khan has been arrested and they are released on bail, but them also the same punishment awaits.
('9', 370, 1, 16, 852838) Such are the circumstances under which we have ass embled here .
('9', 370, 1, 17, 852903) I do not know what displeasure I have incurred that the Government have not arrested me yet, but I do declare that if this meeting chooses to pass the resolution with reference to the English deputation, the Government will find me

('9', 371, 2, 7, 854109) 223. RESOLUTIONS AT MASS MEETING 1
('9', 371, 3, 8, 854144) [JOHANNESBURG, June 16, 1909] [RESOLUTION 1:] This mass meeting of Transvaal British Indians hereby confirms the appointment, made by the Committee of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal, of Messrs A. M. Cachalia, Hajee Habib, V. A. Chettiar, and M. K. Gandhi, as a deputation to proceed to England and place before the authorities and the British public the true situation with regard to the present Asiatic struggle and the British Indian view of the coming union of South Africa.
('9', 371, 3, 9, 854639) [RESOLUTION 2:] This mass meeting of British Indians hereby elects Messrs N. A. Cama, N. Gopal Naidoo, E. S. Coovadia, and H. S. L. Polak, as a deputation to proceed to India, and to place before the authorities and the Indian public the true situation with regard to the present Asiatic struggle in the Transvaal.
('9', 371, 3, 10, 854954) [RESOLUTION 3:] This meeting respectfully protests against the sudden and unwarranted arrest of Messrs Cachalia, Coovadia, Cama, and Chettiar who were, as the Government well knew, appointed or to

('9', 372, 3, 4, 855945) 224. LETTER TO THE STAR 1
('9', 372, 4, 5, 855971) JOHANNESBURG, June 18, 1909 TO THE EDITOR THE STAR JOHANNESBURG
('9', 372, 5, 6, 856035) SIR, You have always generously opened your columns to a discussion of public questions, whether your views coincided with those of your correspondents or not.
('9', 372, 5, 7, 856195) I know you will extend that generosity to those who are engaged in the Asiatic struggle, until,in the fulness of time, it is over, but I trust that you will see your way to give your opinion of the latest phase of it.
('9', 372, 6, 8, 856413) The Chairman of the British Indian mass meeting 2 of Wednesday telegraphed the purport of the resolutions passed at that meeting to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary, requesting suspension of the sentences passed upon and the abjourned cases of those who have been elected as delegates composing the English and Indian deputations.
('9', 372, 6, 9, 856749) The following is the Colonial Secretarys reply:
('9', 372, 7, 10, 856797) With reference to your telegram this morning, the Colonial Secretary desires me to state that when instructions were given for the arrest of the persons you name, for non compliance with the registration provisions of the law, nothing was known of the likelihood of their being selected as delegates.
('9', 372, 7, 11, 857098) While anxious not to interfere in any way with the freedom of action of members of the deputation,he regrets it is impossible for him to comply with your request and interfere with the course of the law.
('9', 372, 8, 12, 857302) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 26 6 1909 under the title: Imprisonment of the Delegates: Government Refuses to Release Them.
('9', 372, 8, 13, 857437) 2 Vide Speech at Mass Meeting, 16 6 1909 and also the preceding item.
('9', 373, 0, 1, 857507) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 373, 1, 2, 857549) The public do not know that the Government have dotted the Colony with their spies, who watch the movements of those who are actively engaged in the struggle.
('9', 373, 1, 3, 857708) They have sent to them the reports of every meeting, public or private, that is held by British Indians.
('9', 373, 1, 4, 857813) The names of the members who were elected last Wednesday have been before the Government for some time.
('9', 373, 1, 5, 857917) The names of the delegates were finally fixed at a committee meeting last Sunday, which was attended by nearly three hundred Indians.
('9', 373, 1, 6, 858051) The Press came to know of this appointment, and an inquiry was made at the offices of the Association on Monday.
('9', 373, 1, 7, 858164) The names were published on Tuesday in the local Press.
('9', 373, 1, 8, 858220) The four delegates,Messrs Cachalia, Coovadia, Cama and Chettiar were arrested on Wednesday.
('9', 373, 1, 9, 858312) It is impossible therefore to believe that the Government knew nothing as to the selection of these delegates.
('9', 373, 1, 10, 858423) The text of the Colonial Secretarys telegram, in the light of the facts given above, is quite clear.
('9', 373, 1, 11, 858524) When he says nothing was known of the likelihood of their being selected as delegates, he simply means that the mass meeting had not yet passed them, and he did not know whether it would confirm the nomination of the committee referred to above.
('9', 373, 1, 12, 858770) One is justified in concluding that the Government did know that those names were to be submitted to the mass meeting, and that the nomination of three hundred Indians was not likely to be overridden by the mass meeting.
('9', 373, 1, 13, 858991) Why did not the Government stop proceedings, or wait until the decision of the mass meeting was known?
('9', 373, 1, 14, 859094) Every Indian believes that the Government intended that, at the time of discussing the South African Draft Act in London, there should be no Indian deputation; that they, by striking terror, into the hearts of British Indians, wished to make the mass meeting a fiasco, and that they have left free the remaining members of the deputation only because they got frightened of themselves.
('9', 373, 1, 15, 859480) Not only have they arrested four of the Indian delegates out of seven, but they have also picked out some of the best workers and the staunchest men among the Indian community, making a total of seventeen men.
('9', 373, 1, 16, 859690) Some of these have passed through the gaols of the Colony more than four times, are married, and have left behind them weeping wives and children.
('9', 373, 1, 17, 859837) The refusal to suspend the sentences or the cases of the delegates is as heartless as the proceedings which were taken with such suddenness and in violation of the ordinary rules of fair play and decency.
('9', 373, 1, 18, 860042) My countrymen consider that Sir George Farrar, Sir Percy Fitzpatrick and other members of the Progressive Party are just as
('9', 374, 0, 1, 860166) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 375
('9', 374, 1, 2, 860207) responsible for the savage action as Generals Botha and Smuts.
('9', 374, 1, 3, 860270) They, however, act in the name of the electors.
('9', 374, 1, 4, 860318) I ask them, and I ask you, as representing the Press, and also as an elector,whether you and they, who are about to receive a liberal Constitution, will use the power which will be shortly given to you and to them in prosecuting men who are fellow subjects with you and them, but who happen to wear a brown skin.
('9', 374, 1, 5, 860631) Apart from the merits of the case, is it too much for the public to demand from the Government a release of the chosen leaders of the Indian people under the security offered?
('9', 374, 2, 6, 860807) I am, etc.,
('9', 374, 3, 7, 860819) M. K. GANDHI The Star, 19 6 1909
('9', 374, 4, 8, 860852) 225. DEPUTATION
('9', 374, 5, 9, 860868) The decision of the Transvaal Indians to send a deputation is a very important move.
('9', 374, 5, 10, 860953) The significant thing is that it has been decided so send a deputation consisting of satyagrahis.
('9', 374, 5, 11, 861051) It appears somewhat incongruous that those who have been defying laws should go to England to seek redress.
('9', 374, 5, 12, 861159) Hence, one can understand why there was a difference of opinion on this point.
('9', 374, 5, 13, 861238) This deputation cannot be defended as being consistent with the principles of satyagraha.
('9', 374, 5, 14, 861328) Satyagrahis must only suffer.
('9', 374, 5, 15, 861358) They should depend on God alone.
('9', 374, 5, 16, 861391) A satyagrahis success consists in the very fact of his offering satyagraha.
('9', 374, 5, 17, 861467) But all satyagrahis do not have the same spirit and the same trust in God.
('9', 374, 5, 18, 861542) Moreover, many Indians have not been able to continue satyagraha.
('9', 374, 5, 19, 861608) They are nonetheless with the satyagrahis.
('9', 374, 5, 20, 861651) They want our struggle to come to an early conclusion.
('9', 374, 5, 21, 861706) So long as Mr. Dawad Mahomed, Mr. Rustomjee and others are in gaol, they cannot rest in peace.
('9', 374, 5, 22, 861801) The satyagrahis who have been released must also have something to do.
('9', 374, 5, 23, 861872) The Government will not re arrest them immediately.
('9', 374, 5, 24, 861924) What, then, should they do?
('9', 374, 5, 25, 861952) Thus considered, the deputation idea appears justified.
('9', 374, 5, 26, 862008) Sending deputations to both countries 1 cannot but bring some benefit.
('9', 374, 5, 27, 862079) Our struggle is not properly understood either in England or in India.
('9', 374, 5, 28, 862150) If it can be properly explained in both the countries, that by itself will surely mean much.
('9', 374, 5, 29, 862243) It will lead to increased help from both
('9', 374, 6, 30, 862284) 1 England and India
('9', 375, 0, 1, 862304) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 375, 1, 2, 862346) countries, and to that extent the duration of the struggle may be shortened.
('9', 375, 1, 3, 862423) Moreover, since this movement is cited as a model, it is our duty to see that it is fully understood in India.
('9', 375, 1, 4, 862534) From this point of view also, the idea of a deputation appears to be justified.
('9', 375, 1, 5, 862614) The deputation to India will prove immensely helpful to that going to England.
('9', 375, 1, 6, 862693) It will compel even Lord Crewe to think, and force Lord Morley to realize his duty.
('9', 375, 2, 7, 862777) It is our view that the right persons have been elected as members of the deputation.
('9', 375, 2, 8, 862863) It was a great thing that Mr. Hajee Habib declared himself ready to join satyagraha.
('9', 375, 2, 9, 862948) Some members of the community had lost courage because of his having withdrawn from the struggle.
('9', 375, 2, 10, 863046) Now that he has decided to throw in his weight, that may revive the strength of the other Indians too.
('9', 375, 2, 11, 863149) Be that as it may, it was a matter of regret for many Indians that Mr. Hajee Habib, who had served the community over many years, had shown himself weak.
('9', 375, 2, 12, 863303) Now that he is in full form again, the community feels happy.
('9', 375, 2, 13, 863365) We pray to God to give him sufficient strength to carry on to the end, and to welcome imprisonment cheerfully should the need arise.
('9', 375, 2, 14, 863498) About Mr. Cachalia, who is a member of the deputation, there is no need at all to say anything.
('9', 375, 2, 15, 863594) The fact that there are Tamil members on both the deputations does honour to that community.
('9', 375, 2, 16, 863687) The Tamils performance has been so very good that no deputation can proceed unless they are represented on it.
('9', 375, 3, 17, 863798) The community is not unaware of the valuable services of Mr. Cama.
('9', 375, 3, 18, 863865) Much work, indeed, awaits him in India, and there is no doubt that he will acquit himself well.
('9', 375, 3, 19, 863961) It reflects credit on the community that it has thought of sending Mr. Polak to India.
('9', 375, 3, 20, 864048) His services have not yet been fully appreciated by it.
('9', 375, 3, 21, 864104) They will bein due time.
('9', 375, 3, 22, 864129) Mr. Polaks visit to India will open Indias eyes somewhat.
('9', 375, 3, 23, 864187) By sending him we can also prove that the Coloureds and the whites can work together and that, in the present circumstances, India can make better progress with the help of whites.
('9', 375, 3, 24, 864368) One should know how to utilize such help.
('9', 375, 4, 25, 864410) After saying this about the deputation, we must ask the community not to build high hopes on it.
('9', 375, 4, 26, 864507) It is on pure satyagraha that we should really depend.
('9', 375, 4, 27, 864562) The sending of the deputation does not imply the end of satyagraha.
('9', 375, 4, 28, 864630) It must continue.
('9', 375, 4, 29, 864648) We hope that by the time the deputation reaches [its destination], quite a number of
('9', 376, 0, 1, 864733) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 377
('9', 376, 1, 2, 864774) Indians will have gone to gaol.
('9', 376, 1, 3, 864806) The deputations task is difficult and, should it return empty handed, we must find comfort in the thought that the effort had been worth making.
('9', 376, 1, 4, 864951) The deputation will have some weight only if the community discharges its duty during the time that it is away.
('9', 376, 1, 5, 865063) Meetings must be held all over South Africa to express support.
('9', 376, 1, 6, 865127) The resolutions [passed in these meetings] should be forwarded directly to Lord Crewe.
('9', 376, 1, 7, 865214) Since this article was written, the Government has arrested some prominent Indian leaders, among them members of the deputation.
('9', 376, 1, 8, 865343) Consequently, it appears likely that the struggle will be only intensified right here.

('9', 378, 2, 6, 869492) 228. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('9', 378, 3, 7, 869517) [Before June 21, 1909]
('9', 378, 4, 8, 869540) BRITISH INDIAN CONCILIATION COMMITTEE
('9', 378, 5, 9, 869578) A deputation of this Committee, consisting of Messrs Abdool Ganie, Hajee Ojer Ally, Habib Motan, S. V. Thomas, Ally Khamisa, Jusab Ebrahim Gardi and George Godfrey, waited on General Smuts at 12 oclock on Saturday.
('9', 378, 5, 10, 869793) General Smuts gave nearly half an hour to the Committee.
('9', 378, 5, 11, 869850) It submitted the following demands: That the obnoxious Act be repealed, that the educated [Indians] be granted the same rights of immigration as the whites, that, in case there are more partners than one [in a firm], all the partners should not be required to be present when applying for a licence, that educated persons should not be required to give thumb impressions, that applications for registration should be permitted from within the Transvaal, that temporary permits should be issued freely, that those who do not hold permits should not be required to adduce proof of three years domicile, that there should be provision for an appeal to the Supreme Court against the decision of a magistrate, etc.
('9', 378, 6, 12, 870560) I understand that General Smuts has given the following reply to these demands: The obnoxious Act will not be repealed, though it will not be enforced; in deserving cases permission will be given to educated men to enter, as in the case of Mr. James Godfrey, but the law will not be amended; if it is true that there is delay in
('9', 378, 7, 13, 870889) 1 Literally, grandfather 2 These demands were embodied in a petition presented to the Colonial Secretary on June 19.
('9', 379, 0, 1, 871006) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 379, 1, 2, 871048) issuing permits, permission [to enter] will be conveyed by telegram; all the partners of a firm will not be required to attend, and so on.
('9', 379, 1, 3, 871187) A written reply has been promised.
('9', 379, 1, 4, 871222) 1 There will be no modification of the provision regarding three years residence, since, as General Smuts claims, Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Quinn had agreed to its introduction.
('9', 379, 1, 5, 871393) If this is the whole of the reply, I must say that it takes us now here.
('9', 379, 1, 6, 871466) This is only a repetition of what happened in 1907. General Smuts has refused to make any concessions on essential points, and offered tri vial ones which it did not require a deputation to secure.
('9', 379, 1, 7, 871664) It will hardly be necessary even to amend the Regulations in order to effect the changes [he has offered to make].
('9', 379, 1, 8, 871779) The Conciliation Committee was set up only with one object, namely, to secure the release of the Indian prisoners still serving their terms of imprisonment.
('9', 379, 1, 9, 871936) This can be brought about only through the repeal of the obnoxious Act.
('9', 379, 1, 10, 872008) That General Smuts has declined to con sider.
('9', 379, 1, 11, 872054) Conciliation means peace.
('9', 379, 1, 12, 872080) Since this has not been secured, I for one would advise that the Committee be dissolved.
('9', 379, 1, 13, 872169) It has become super fluous, as it has no more work to do.
('9', 379, 1, 14, 872227) Those who are anxious to hasten the end of the struggle but cannot bring themselves to court arrest should patiently help those who are in gaol.
('9', 379, 1, 15, 872372) They can do this by contributing to funds and extending their support by holding meetings.
('9', 379, 1, 16, 872463) Those who have joined the Committee in the hope of doing some good to the community should be careful that they do not, on the contrary, harm it.
('9', 379, 1, 17, 872609) Many persons seem to think that the provision regarding three years [domicile] introduced in the new law [of 1908] makes the position much worse than it was under the obnoxious Act [of 1907].
('9', 379, 1, 18, 872801) This is a misapprehension.
('9', 379, 1, 19, 872828) Under the latter, those who held permits were alone eligible for registration.
('9', 379, 1, 20, 872907) Whether or not others should be registered was entirely within the discretion of the Registrar.
('9', 379, 1, 21, 873003) Under the new law, the right granted to those with three years domicile is an additional provision.
('9', 379, 1, 22, 873103) Why it should be three years and not two and why there should be any time limit at all are separate questions.
('9', 379, 2, 23, 873214) 1 This was received on June 23. In its acknowledgment of June 25, the Committee regretted that the Honble Colonial Secretary has not seen his way clear to grant any relief on the grievances The Committee forwarded to the Colonial Office resolutions to similar effect adopted at a meeting on June 24. The correspondence was published in Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909.
('9', 380, 0, 1, 873576) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 381
('9', 380, 1, 2, 873617) point was included in the Associations petition.
('9', 380, 1, 3, 873666) 1 But the point to be noted is that, under the obnoxious Act, the rights of pre war residents of the Transvaal were liquidated entirely, while the new law recognizes the rights of those with three years domicile.
('9', 380, 1, 4, 873879) Of course, we must ask for as many more rights as possible.
('9', 380, 1, 5, 873939) But such rights cannot be secured as long as the basic demand has not been conceded.
('9', 380, 1, 6, 874024) If our two demands are accepted, it will be easy to secure the rest.
('9', 380, 1, 7, 874093) It should also be remembered that, if the obnoxious Act did in fact recognize the rights of Indians with pre war residence, that Act is still on the Statute book.
('9', 380, 1, 8, 874256) Why is it that such Indians are not able to come in under that Act?
('9', 380, 1, 9, 874324) If it is true that their rights are implied in that Act, we can as well fight to avail ourselves of them as long as the Act is in force.
('9', 380, 1, 10, 874461) But anyone who looks into the Act will see that it recognizes no such rights.
('9', 380, 1, 11, 874539) Personally, I would advise those who are out to secure miscellaneous concessions to remember that, if the trunk is cut off, the branches will wither away as a matter of course, and hence they should apply themselves to the task of felling the trunk.

('9', 383, 1, 2, 880595) 229. LETTER TO HABIB MOTAN
('9', 383, 2, 3, 880622) [JOHANNESBURG, Before June 21, 1909]
('9', 383, 3, 4, 880659) DEAR MR. HABIB MOTAN, Here is my reply to your letter dated 17th June: 1
('9', 383, 4, 5, 880732) I do not know exactly what the demands of the Muslim League are, for I was in gaol at the time, and I have not yet acquainted myself with what happened during my imprisonment.
('9', 383, 4, 6, 880908) I think it reasonable that a Muslim should be appointed to the Viceroys Council.
('9', 383, 4, 7, 880989) If Lord Morley has ordered such an appointment, I think he is justified.
('9', 383, 4, 8, 881062) I make no distinction between Hindus and Muslims.
('9', 383, 4, 9, 881112) To me both are sons of Mother India.
('9', 383, 4, 10, 881149) My personal view is that, since numerically Hindus are in a great majority, and are, as they themselves believe, better placed education ally, they should cheerfully concede to their Muslim brethren the utmost they can.
('9', 383, 4, 11, 881369) As a satyagrahi, I am emphatically of the view that the Hindus should give to the Muslims whatever they ask for, and willingly accept whatever sacrifice this may involve.
('9', 383, 4, 12, 881540) Unity will be brought about only through such mutual generosity.
('9', 383, 4, 13, 881605) If Hindus and Muslims observe, in their dealings with one another, the same principles that govern the relations of blood brothers, there will be unbroken harmony [between the two communities], and then alone will India prosper.
('9', 383, 5, 14, 881834) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI [From Gujarati]
('9', 383, 6, 15, 881877) Indian Opinion, 26 6 1909
('9', 383, 7, 16, 881903) 1 In Habib Motans letter, the following questions were raised: Were the demands put forward by the Muslim League deputation which waited on Lord Morley in London reasonable?
('9', 383, 7, 17, 882077) Was the demand for the inclusion of a Muslim in the Viceroys Council justi fied and what was Gandhijis reaction to Lord Morleys decision to concede it?
('9', 383, 7, 18, 882229) Should a Hindu or a Muslim be appointed?
('9', 383, 7, 19, 882270) How could Hindu Muslim unity be achieved?

('9', 385, 1, 2, 883941) 232. INTERVIEW TO CAPE TIMES 1
('9', 385, 2, 3, 883972) [CAPE TOWN, June 23, 1909]
('9', 385, 3, 4, 883999) [GANDHIJI:] We are going to England particularly in connection with the Asiatic struggle which has been going on in the Transvaal.
('9', 385, 3, 5, 884130) We consider this a most suitable opportunity for placing the whole of the situation before the Imperial Government and the British public.
('9', 385, 3, 6, 884269) We also feel that this is essentially a matter in which mutual personal discussion can do a great deal.
('9', 385, 4, 7, 884373) [REPORTER:] Will you act in any way with the Native and Coloured
('9', 385, 5, 8, 884438) deputations which are also proceeding to England?
('9', 385, 5, 9, 884488) It all depends, what opportunity offers itself, and in this connection we shall naturally be very largely guided by Lord Ampthills 2 Committee in London.
('9', 385, 6, 10, 884642) What is your particular objection to the Act of Union?
('9', 385, 6, 11, 884697) Personally, I have no fault to find with the Constitution if the full liberties of British Indian subjects who are domiciled in South Africa are guaranteed.
('9', 385, 6, 12, 884854) I hold that Union should not be merely a union of the white British subjects, but of all British subjects who are domiciled here.
('9', 385, 6, 13, 884984) The great fear of British Indians is that under the Constitution, It will be a union of white races against British Indians
('9', 385, 7, 14, 885108) 1 Cape Town Indians held a reception for Gandhiji and Hajee Habib on board the Kenilworth Castle before they left on deputation to England.
('9', 385, 7, 15, 885248) Gandhiji was interviewed by representatives of the Cape Times and the Cape Argus.
('9', 385, 7, 16, 885330) The interviews, which were later reproduced in Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909, were substantially the same.
('9', 385, 7, 17, 885432) The report in the Cape Argus, however, carried this introductory paragraph: Interviewed by the Argus, just before leaving, Mr. Gandhi hinted that he had half expected to be arrested by the Transvaal authorities, but no obstacle had been placed in his way.
('9', 385, 7, 18, 885688) He added that the actions of himself and his fellow delegate, Hajee Habib, would be guided by the S. A. British Indian Committee in London.
('9', 385, 7, 19, 885828) All that they wanted was to secure guarantees that their rights would be safeguarded.
('9', 385, 7, 20, 885914) He was confident of a successful result of their mission. 2 Arthur Oliver Villiers Russell, Second Baron of Ampthill (1869 1936); Governor of Madras, 1899 1906; acted as Viceroy and Governor General of India in 1904: took active interest in Indian struggle in South Africa and was President of S.A.B.I. Committee.
('9', 385, 7, 21, 886228) He wrote the introduction to Dokes biography of Gandhiji.
('9', 386, 0, 1, 886286) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 387
('9', 386, 1, 2, 886327) and the Coloured races, 1
('9', 386, 2, 3, 886353) and if that happens, I think it will be a most unfortunate thing in every way, and it will be the duty of the British Indian deputation to leave no stone unturned to guard against any such Imperial calamity.
('9', 386, 3, 4, 886561) How about the restriction of the franchise in the Transvaal?
('9', 386, 3, 5, 886622) Personally, I am not laying any great deal of stress on the matter of the franchise.
('9', 386, 3, 6, 886707) What I am now thinking of is the genesis of a situation which is undoubtedly against the Coloured races of South Africa.
('9', 386, 3, 7, 886828) I have studied all that has been said about it; I have studied the Parliamentary discussions, and all these undoubtedly go to show that Union spells, perhaps, ruin to the Coloured races, especially the Asiatics, unless the Imperial Government obtained full guarantees with regard to these matters.
('9', 386, 4, 8, 887126) In what respect will they be worse off under Union?
('9', 386, 4, 9, 887178) In this way, for the simple reason that the Union Parliament will speak with the united voice of South Africa, and the Imperial Government would be very slow to object to any legislation passed by the Union Parliament.
('9', 386, 4, 10, 887397) As it is, each individual Colony brings such tremendous power to bear upon the English Government that the latter rarely exercises its right of veto in connection with measures affecting the Coloured population and it would be still less inclined to do so when that legislation came with the sanction of a Union Parliament of South Africa.
('9', 386, 5, 11, 887737) Mr. Gandhi, who expects to be absent about three months, also referred to the arrest of Indians in the Transvaal, and said that he himself hardly expected to be allowed to cruss the border without arrest, but no obstacle was placed in his way.
('9', 386, 5, 12, 887981) He arrived here by the mail train a couple of hours or so before the steamer left.
('9', 386, 5, 13, 888064) Cape Times, 24 6 1909
('9', 386, 6, 14, 888086) 1 Touching on this point of the interview, Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909, observed in an editorial note: There exists a colour bar in the Draft Act of Union, and existing legislation concerning the movements of Indians within the Union is maintained unaltered, until such time as the Union Parliament may choose to interfere, and modify it either for the better or the worse.
('9', 386, 6, 15, 888457) We have no doubt what the tendency will be.
('9', 386, 6, 16, 888501) The last ten years have not shouted their warning for nothing in South Africa.
('9', 386, 6, 17, 888580) And, under Union, the comparatively liberal minded Cape members will be snowed under by the large Transvaal, Orangia, and Natal contingent of Indophobes.
('9', 386, 6, 18, 888734) Undoubtedly, the spirit of artificial race segregation is in the air, and at the back of the Indian hostility to most of the South African Governments is the firm rooted conviction that, sooner or later, the policy of confinement in latter day ghettos or bazaars will be put into operation against British Indians, together with other Asiatics.
('9', 387, 0, 1, 889079) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 387, 1, 2, 889121) 233. DEPUTATIONS VOYAGE [I]
('9', 387, 2, 3, 889149) [ After June 23, 1909]
('9', 387, 3, 4, 889172) A COMPARISON
('9', 387, 4, 5, 889185) When the Indian community sent a deputation to England in October 1906, the circumstances were different from what they are today.
('9', 387, 4, 6, 889316) In 1906, the Indian community had pledged itself to go to gaol, but no one was sure who would do so if there was no redress from the Government.
('9', 387, 4, 7, 889461) Now we know of men who are saturated with [love of] gaol.
('9', 387, 4, 8, 889519) In 1906, the Indian community did not realize its own latent strength.
('9', 387, 4, 9, 889590) This time the whole world knows about it.
('9', 387, 4, 10, 889632) Nevertheless, the deputations task in 1906 was comparatively easy.
('9', 387, 4, 11, 889699) It is difficult this time.
('9', 387, 4, 12, 889726) We have to secure the repeal of an Act which has already been sanctioned.
('9', 387, 4, 13, 889800) In 1906, we did not know the Imperial Governments attitude.
('9', 387, 4, 14, 889860) This time it has indicated this.
('9', 387, 4, 15, 889893) Even then the deputation is proceeding, unconcerned.
('9', 387, 4, 16, 889946) For we are to a great extent indifferent to what will happen in England.
('9', 387, 4, 17, 890019) It is with our tried weapon of satyagraha that we are to fight.
('9', 387, 5, 18, 890083) PREPARATIONS
('9', 387, 6, 19, 890096) Preparations for the deputation had been under way for several days past.
('9', 387, 6, 20, 890170) But the community is faced with a situation so difficult that till the very last day it was not certain whether the deputation would proceed or not.
('9', 387, 6, 21, 890319) Sufficient funds had not been collected either.
('9', 387, 6, 22, 890367) The tickets for the voyage were bought at eleven in the morning of the very day of departure (Monday, June 21).
('9', 387, 6, 23, 890479) Even after that, it was not certain that it would leave.
('9', 387, 6, 24, 890536) The Government was free, if it chose, to arrest the other members of the deputation.
('9', 387, 6, 25, 890621) Some thought that the arrests might take place even as the members were about to board the train.
('9', 387, 6, 26, 890719) All the same, the deputation started on its way.
('9', 387, 6, 27, 890768) But it is mutilated, having lost one of its legs.
('9', 387, 6, 28, 890818) Mr. Cachalia and Mr. Chettiar are the deputations right leg.
('9', 387, 6, 29, 890879) Both these friends are in gaol, while we two, Mr. Hajee Habib and I, are proceeding.
('9', 387, 6, 30, 890964) Neither of us is happy over this.
('9', 387, 6, 31, 890998) But I am sure that Mr. Cachalia and Mr. Chettiar will speak for us more eloquently from gaol than they could have done in England.
('9', 387, 6, 32, 891129) They will be happier in gaol than we on our journey, though travelling first class.
('9', 387, 6, 33, 891213) A satyagrahi cannot even conceive otherwise.
('9', 388, 0, 1, 891258) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 389
('9', 388, 1, 2, 891299) own experience proves the same thing, as I shall show more clearly afterwards.
('9', 388, 2, 3, 891378) AT THE STATION
('9', 388, 3, 4, 891393) Park Station was crowded with Indians.
('9', 388, 3, 5, 891432) About 500 Indians must have assembled.
('9', 388, 3, 6, 891471) Mr. Aswat and Mr. Nagadi, who had gone to Krugers dorp to raise funds, had managed to reach the station.
('9', 388, 3, 7, 891576) The police had made special arrangements.
('9', 388, 3, 8, 891618) They were not seen shoving the people about.
('9', 388, 3, 9, 891663) A number of Indians were made to stand quite at the back.
('9', 388, 3, 10, 891721) There were many who had brought bouquets and garlands.
('9', 388, 3, 11, 891776) This at least could be observed, that every face was lit up with the hope that the deputation might meet with success.
('9', 388, 3, 12, 891895) Mr. Kallenbach, his partner Mr. Kennedy, Mr. MacIntyre, Miss Olive Doke, Miss Schlesin and Mr. Polak were also there.
('9', 388, 3, 13, 892013) The train started exactly at 6 15 p.m.
('9', 388, 4, 14, 892052) ON THE WAY
('9', 388, 5, 15, 892063) At Vereeniging, almost the whole of the local Indian community had turned up at the station.
('9', 388, 5, 16, 892156) They greeted the deputation with great warmth.
('9', 388, 5, 17, 892203) They had brought for us a basketful of fruit, which is still not exhausted.
('9', 388, 5, 18, 892279) Mr. Haffejee gave us a bottle of Indian scent.
('9', 388, 6, 19, 892326) At Worcester Station, there were many Indians who had come all the way from Robertson.
('9', 388, 6, 20, 892413) They too had brought flowers and fruit.
('9', 388, 6, 21, 892453) In Robertson, the Indian population consists mainly of Tamils.
('9', 388, 6, 22, 892516) At Worce ster, therefore, it was mainly the South Indian friends who were present.
('9', 388, 6, 23, 892599) On the way, Mr. Hajee Habib suffered from some infection in the left eye.
('9', 388, 6, 24, 892673) It has been with him from before he left Johannesburg.
('9', 388, 6, 25, 892728) The eye was a violent red and watered profusely.
('9', 388, 6, 26, 892777) A wash with hot saline water gave him relief, but not much.
('9', 388, 6, 27, 892837) We have had to consult the physician on board the ship.
('9', 388, 6, 28, 892893) Even at the moment of writing, the pain has not subsided completely, though there is considerable relief.
('9', 388, 6, 29, 892999) I put eye drops every day twice or thrice, in addition to which ice cold compresses are also being applied.
('9', 388, 6, 30, 893107) The physician is very solicitous.
('9', 388, 7, 31, 893141) IN CAPE TOWN
('9', 388, 8, 32, 893154) The train reached Cape Town half an hour late.
('9', 388, 8, 33, 893201) There were a few Indians at the station.
('9', 388, 8, 34, 893242) The rest came on board the ship to meet us.
('9', 388, 8, 35, 893286) A fare well dinner had been arranged in honour of Mr. Anglia, who was leaving for Durban the same day.
('9', 388, 8, 36, 893389) Many Indians were busy with the function.
('9', 388, 8, 37, 893431) Here, too, the Indian community gave us a send off with
('9', 389, 0, 1, 893487) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 389, 1, 2, 893529) fruit and flowers.

('9', 390, 2, 13, 896438) DO SOMETHING REGARDING UNION
('9', 390, 3, 14, 896467) Many Indian friends have urged the deputation not to forget the question of the Union.

('9', 390, 3, 16, 896695) On the ship, I have been able to give further thought to the subject, and discuss it [with others].
('9', 390, 3, 17, 896795) The Union Bill makes no refe rence to us at all.
('9', 390, 3, 18, 896844) The Act will unite all the Colonies.

('9', 390, 3, 22, 897045) If, after the Union is formed, they attempt any legislation against us, we can fight out the question then.

('9', 390, 3, 25, 897284) But we cannot oppose a Union merely on the ground that we might be ruined under it.
('9', 390, 3, 26, 897368) The main point is that even the white population of the Colonies acts as our enemy.

('9', 390, 3, 29, 897561) We certainly can not prevent them from being united.
('9', 390, 3, 30, 897614) No one comes forward to say that, as our enemies are uniting, so must we, the Indians.
('9', 390, 3, 31, 897701) That is the real solution.
('9', 390, 3, 32, 897728) Ignoring that, Indians have been begging for something to be brought to them from England [as a gift].
('9', 390, 3, 33, 897831) This shows our utter helplessness.

('9', 392, 2, 26, 902593) 234. MR. POLAK AND HIS WORK
('9', 392, 3, 27, 902621) In view of the departure of Mr. H. S. L. Polak as a delegate on behalf of the Transvaal British Indians to proceed to India, in order to educate public opinion there, and to rouse India to a sense of her duty, our readers will be glad to have a short sketch of Mr. Polaks life.
('9', 392, 3, 28, 902899) Mr. Henry Salomon Leon Polak was born just 27 years ago at
('9', 393, 0, 1, 902958) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 393, 1, 2, 903000) Dover, England, and is the son of Mr. J. H. Polak, J. P., who is a member of the South Africa British Indian Committee in London.
('9', 393, 1, 3, 903130) Mr. Polak is an undergraduate of London University, and is the holder of many certificates, in literary and economic subjects, issued by the London Chamber of Commerce and other educational bodies.
('9', 393, 1, 4, 903328) He completed his education at the Ecole de Commerce, Neuchatel, Switzerland, whereafter he was appointed Assistant Secretary of the Society of Chemical Industry, in London.
('9', 393, 1, 5, 903501) For reasons of health, Mr. Polak came to South Africa, in the early part of 1903. Before he became identified with the Indian cause and accepted the editorship of this journal, which was and still is purely a labour of love, he was engaged in journalistic work.
('9', 393, 1, 6, 903763) Desiring to realise some of his ideals, he left what might be termed a lucrative appointment, with promise of further pecuniary advancement and, in 1904, joined the phoenix scheme, under which the members receive only just enough to support themselves in the simplest manner possible.
('9', 393, 1, 7, 904048) The scheme, as readers of this journal are aware, is intended to put into practice the essential teaching of Tolstoy and Ruskin, and, in its outward manifestation, to assist in removing the grievances of British Indians in South Africa.
('9', 393, 1, 8, 904285) Owing to the exigencies of Indian public work in the Transvaal, and in order the better to enable him to carry on his duties in connection with this journal, Mr. Polak took articles with Mr. M. K. Gandhi in the year 1906 and, in 1908, was admitted as Attorney of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal.
('9', 393, 1, 9, 904584) Since the year 1906, he has acted as Assistant Hon.
('9', 393, 1, 10, 904636) Secretary of the Transvaal British Indian Associationa period that has marked a most critical stage in the history of British Indians in South Africa, and which has demanded from those who, like Mr. Polak, have been intimately connected with the passive resistance movement, the most unremitting zeal and devotion.
('9', 393, 1, 11, 904951) During the last three years, Mr. Polak has known no rest.
('9', 393, 1, 12, 905009) He has, besides using his able pen freely for the cause, travelled throughout South Africa, either making collections in aid of the passive resistance struggle, or addressing public meetings and enlightening Indians in different parts of the sub continent as to the nature of the struggle.
('9', 393, 1, 13, 905299) His knowledge of the different questions affecting British Indian settlers and Asiatic legislation in South Africa is almost unrivalled.
('9', 393, 1, 14, 905436) In his eagerness to possess himself with accurate knowledge, he has considered nothing too unimportant to study, and in order to have a proper perspective of the whole situation, during what leisure he has been able to find, he has studied also modern Indian history.
('9', 393, 1, 15, 905704) Mr. Polak has kept himself in touch with the current
('9', 394, 0, 1, 905757) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 395
('9', 394, 1, 2, 905798) Indian thought by contributing to several leading newspapers and magazines in India.
('9', 394, 1, 3, 905883) He, therefore, goes to India by no means unknown to the Indian public.
('9', 394, 1, 4, 905954) The people of India will no doubt be glad to learn that, in order to know the inner side of Indian life and character, throughout his travels in South Africa, Mr. Polak has always lived with Indians in their homes like one of themselves.
('9', 394, 1, 5, 906192) He has acquired such a hold on their affections that, during the incarceration of the Indian leaders, his advice was eagerly sought and implicitly followed.
('9', 394, 1, 6, 906349) Mr. Polak was married in 1905, and the Indian community in South Africa owes not a little to Mrs. Polak sharing her husbands self sacrifice and public spirit.
('9', 394, 1, 7, 906508) Latterly, she herself has taken up the organising of Indian womens meetings, and has thrown herself heart and soul into her work.
('9', 394, 1, 8, 906638) Two children have been born to them in South Africa.
('9', 394, 1, 9, 906691) Mr. Polak belongs to an ancient Jewish family and, being a member of a race which has undergone much oppression, considers it a privilege to help in alleviating the sufferings of British Indians in South Africa.
('9', 394, 1, 10, 906903) When he was yet quite a youth, ethics had a fascinating attraction for him.
('9', 394, 1, 11, 906979) With him religion and ethics are convertible terms.
('9', 394, 1, 12, 907031) He, therefore, naturally attached himself to the South Place Ethical Society in London, of which he is still an associate, and it was from an ethical standpoint that he felt himself called upon to take up Indian work.
('9', 394, 1, 13, 907249) Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909

('9', 395, 1, 2, 907620) 236. DEPUTATIONS VOYAGE [ II ]
('9', 395, 2, 3, 907651) [ Before July 9, 1909]
('9', 395, 3, 4, 907674) LIFE ON SHIP AND LIFE IN PRISON: A COMPARISON
('9', 395, 4, 5, 907720) As I have stated already, it is far better to be in prison than travel first class on a ship.
('9', 395, 4, 6, 907814) Mr. Bhikhubhai Dayalji Malia is travelling third class.
('9', 395, 4, 7, 907870) Both of us see him every day.
('9', 395, 4, 8, 907900) That has given us some experience of what third class travel means.
('9', 395, 4, 9, 907968) I am of the opinion that the freedom and comfort available in the third class are not to be found in the first class.
('9', 395, 4, 10, 908086) But even that cannot match what is available in gaol.
('9', 395, 4, 11, 908140) The servants in a ship are happierif only they knew itthan the passengers.
('9', 395, 4, 12, 908215) First class passengers are looked after by servants as though they were so many babies.
('9', 395, 4, 13, 908303) There is something to eat every two hours.
('9', 395, 4, 14, 908346) We cannot even lift a glass of water with our own hands.
('9', 395, 4, 15, 908403) At the table it is considered beneath ones dignity to reach out ones hand for a spoon lying at some distance.
('9', 395, 4, 16, 908513) Hands must be washed every now and then all through the day, on the ground that they must be kept clean.
('9', 395, 4, 17, 908618) As for work, they have hardly any, so that they are growing altogether delicate and soft.
('9', 395, 4, 18, 908708) It vexes me to observe the present state of my hands and compare it with what they were like in gaol.
('9', 395, 4, 19, 908810) I envy the servants at their work.
('9', 395, 4, 20, 908845) Here I have neither the peace nor the freedom I enjoyed in gaol.
('9', 395, 4, 21, 908910) On the contrary, I have to live hedged in on all sides.
('9', 395, 4, 22, 908966) My prayers here lack the depth, the serenity and concentration they had when I was in gaol.
('9', 395, 4, 23, 909058) I am not writing all this in a frivolous mood, but after deep reflec tion.
('9', 395, 4, 24, 909133) I think of these things every day.
('9', 395, 4, 25, 909168) Whatever I have read and am read ing I put to the test of experience.
('9', 395, 4, 26, 909238) I have realized that those who wish to serve God cannot afford to pamper themselves or to run after luxury.
('9', 395, 4, 27, 909346) Pra yers do not come easily in an atmosphere of luxuries.
('9', 395, 4, 28, 909404) Even if we do not ourselves share the luxuries, we cannot escape their natural influence.
('9', 395, 4, 29, 909494) The energy that we spend in resisting that influence is at the cost of our devo tional efforts.
('9', 395, 4, 30, 909590) I am having a personal experience of this at the moment.
('9', 395, 4, 31, 909647) I do not write this to suggest that I want myself or anyone else to spend all his days in gaol or that I consider travelling by first class to be wrong always and in all circumstances.
('9', 395, 4, 32, 909832) I write this only to point out that we would all profit from the kind of simplicity and solitude we find in gaol.
('9', 395, 4, 33, 909946) I think it is better to travel by third class than by first class, except when we need
('9', 396, 0, 1, 910033) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 397
('9', 396, 1, 2, 910074) certain facilities or when there are some special reasons which make first class travel necessary.
('9', 396, 1, 3, 910173) In South Africa, however, there are several reasons why I would prefer Indians to travel first class or second class.
('9', 396, 1, 4, 910291) We must rebut the charge of miserliness that is levelled against us.
('9', 396, 1, 5, 910360) Moreover, we generally value simplicity in such matters, so that we are not likely to be puffed up with vanity if we travel first or second.
('9', 396, 1, 6, 910501) For those who have amassed wealth, first or second class travel would appear to be necessary even for maintaining their status.
('9', 396, 1, 7, 910629) All the same, at a time like this when we are engaged in a mighty fight, I would unhesitatingly ask all Indians to take the view that it is better for an Indian to be in gaol rather than be travelling in a class even higher than the first.
('9', 396, 2, 8, 910869) HOW WE LIVE
('9', 396, 3, 9, 910881) I have known Mr. Hajee Habib for the last fifteen years.
('9', 396, 3, 10, 910938) But I never had any opportunity of living with him as I am doing today.
('9', 396, 3, 11, 911010) Hajee Saheb is a man of strict religious principles.
('9', 396, 3, 12, 911063) He keeps the namaz hours punctually.
('9', 396, 3, 13, 911100) He carefully follows the religious injunctions about food and drink.
('9', 396, 3, 14, 911169) He has often told me that he has no difficulty in doing so on this occasion.
('9', 396, 3, 15, 911246) He allows me to decide for him the menu for every meal.
('9', 396, 3, 16, 911302) I know what will prove acceptable to him.
('9', 396, 3, 17, 911344) In the morning he has porridge, eggs and tea.
('9', 396, 3, 18, 911390) At noon he has boiled potatoes, sometimes fish, a vege table called lettuce, much like the moola, some variety of pudding, fruit and coffee, and in the evening some leafy vegetable, pudding, fruit and coffee, It is a constant thought with him how to make the deputation a success, and we frequently come together to apply our minds to the prob lem.
('9', 396, 3, 19, 911739) The ghee and pickles given to him [when he started], he has passed on to Mr. Bhikhubhai.
('9', 396, 3, 20, 911828) The passengers on board the ship seem to think that we are brothers.
('9', 396, 3, 21, 911897) I have, as usual, two meals a day.
('9', 396, 3, 22, 911932) I avoid pudding as it contains eggs.
('9', 396, 3, 23, 911969) I also avoid tea and coffee as far as possible, since they are the produce of slave labour.
('9', 396, 3, 24, 912061) In other respects, my diet is the same as above, except for fish.
('9', 396, 3, 25, 912127) I am growing more convinced every day, as my body hardens, that I can do with still simpler food.
('9', 396, 3, 26, 912225) On this voyage I do not feel a craving for delicacies as I did on the previous occasion.
('9', 396, 3, 27, 912314) Most of the day is spent in reading.
('9', 396, 3, 28, 912351) The statement 1 to be submitted in England has already been drafted, and approved by Mr.
('9', 396, 4, 29, 912440) 1 Vide Statement of the Transvaal Indian Case, 16 7 1909

('9', 397, 1, 2, 912539) Hajee Habib.
('9', 397, 1, 3, 912552) He made some suggestions, which have been incor porated.
('9', 397, 2, 4, 912609) MEETING WITH MERRIMAN
('9', 397, 3, 5, 912631) There have been meetings with some of the whites on board ship.
('9', 397, 3, 6, 912695) Merriman was one of them.
('9', 397, 3, 7, 912721) From what I gathered about his views in the course of a long discussion with him, I could see that our efforts against the Union were bound to fail.
('9', 397, 3, 8, 912870) When I pointed out to him that the Transvaal problem did not have much connection with the question of unification, he studied it in greater detail and promised to do his best in regard to it.
('9', 397, 3, 9, 913063) I found him full of sympathy for the satyagrahi prisoners.
('9', 397, 3, 10, 913122) There was a meeting with Mr. Jagger also.
('9', 397, 3, 11, 913164) He too appeared to hold views similar to Mr. Merrimans.
('9', 397, 3, 12, 913220) The Union has come to stay.
('9', 397, 3, 13, 913248) If the Transvaal problem can be solved without prejudice to the question of unification, he will also be prepared to help.
('9', 397, 3, 14, 913371) He was filled with indignation when he was told of the sacrifices of Mr. Cachalia and Mr. Aswat, and he implied by his remarks that the dispute would have been settled by now it the other Indian businessmen had followed in their footsteps.
('9', 397, 3, 15, 913611) He was sorry, as well as surprised, to hear that his own firm had acted against Mr. Cachalia.
('9', 397, 4, 16, 913705) When I spoke to these gentlemen about Mr. Dawad Mahomed and Mr. Parsee Rustomjee, they seemed both deeply impressed.
('9', 397, 4, 17, 913822) They deplored it all and wanted that some kind of solution should be found.
('9', 397, 4, 18, 913898) When they were told of our demands, both admitted that they were quite reasonable.
('9', 397, 5, 19, 913981) The subject of the Cape Immigration Act was raised with Mr. Jagger.
('9', 397, 5, 20, 914049) He was surprised to hear that Indians resident in the Cape had to take out temporary permits when leaving it.
('9', 397, 5, 21, 914159) Had the Cape Indians exerted themselves sufficiently, this clause would not have been retained in the law.
('9', 397, 5, 22, 914266) It is still their duty to bestir themselves in regard to this.
('9', 397, 5, 23, 914329) I am sure that most of the Cape members are entirely ignorant of this absurd clause.
('9', 397, 6, 24, 914414) I had also had a meeting with Mr. Sauer, who is a member of the Cape Cabinet.
('9', 397, 6, 25, 914492) He was full of sympathy and has promised all possible help.
('9', 397, 6, 26, 914552) He admitted that the demands of a community that undergoes voluntary suffering as we do can hardly be unreasonable and that it was the duty of every liberal minded person to help that community.
('9', 397, 7, 27, 914747) I regard this also as one of the results of our satyagraha.
('9', 397, 7, 28, 914807) Men like him would not have cared to listen to us had we not gone to gaol.
('9', 398, 0, 1, 914882) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 399
('9', 398, 1, 2, 914923) There is, moreover, another white with whom we have had frequent discussions.
('9', 398, 1, 3, 915001) He is himself a passive resister.
('9', 398, 1, 4, 915035) He is secretary of some association.
('9', 398, 1, 5, 915072) According to him, we have far excelled the English passive resisters in our capacity to suffer.
('9', 398, 1, 6, 915168) He has promised a letter of recommendation and also other help.
('9', 398, 1, 7, 915232) All these things are a testimony to the success of satyagraha.
('9', 398, 1, 8, 915295) Everyone is touched by the story of the suffering which satyagraha has entailed.
('9', 398, 1, 9, 915376) They are all amazed to hear that we have had no redress so far.
('9', 398, 1, 10, 915440) The sympathies of all these men spring from their conviction that our cause is just and that we are sincere.
('9', 398, 1, 11, 915549) With Mr. Hajee Habibs help, I have been reading a book named Kasassul Ambia.
('9', 398, 1, 12, 915626) In it I read how it was commanded of Azazil that should he fail, after 600,000 years of prayers to God, to bow to Him even on a single occasion, all his prayers would be as though they had never been.
('9', 398, 1, 13, 915827) The point is, first, that it is what we do when we reach the last stage which will provide the test of our sincerity.
('9', 398, 1, 14, 915945) Secondly, we can make no conditions with God.
('9', 398, 1, 15, 915991) We must live as He may order us.
('9', 398, 1, 16, 916024) If, having gone to gaol ten times, we refuse to do so on the eleventh occasion, the ten previous terms of imprisonment will have been in vain and we shall be laughed at.

('9', 399, 5, 17, 917894) 238. INTERVIEW TO REUTER 2
('9', 399, 6, 18, 917921) [SOUTHAMPTON, July 10, 1909] Our deputation was to consist of four, but two are now in prison.
('9', 399, 6, 19, 918016) Our movements depend largely upon the advice of Lord Ampthill and his Committee.
('9', 399, 6, 20, 918097) We feel, we must take this opportunity when so many South African statesmen are in this country to see whether something cannot be done to relieve the very acute suffering which British Indians in the Transvaal have been undergoing for the past two and a half years.
('9', 399, 6, 21, 918364) Our mission does not seriously affect the question of unification except that every Indian feels that the Imperial Government should take full guarantee regarding the status of British

('9', 400, 1, 2, 918713) Indians in South Africa under the Union.
('9', 400, 1, 3, 918754) What we are chiefly concerned in is the settlement of outstanding questions between the Transvaal Government and the Indian community which, when boiled down, really means the question of the status of highly cultured Indians, and whether they may or may not enter the Transvaal under the general immigration law of the day.
('9', 400, 1, 4, 919079) We contend that the present legislation insults the whole of India in that it creates a racial bar for the first time in the his tory of Colonial legislation, and in order to remove this bar, hundreds of British Indians have suffered imprison ment.
('9', 400, 1, 5, 919328) Even to day some of the best Indians in the Transvaal are in gaol as conscientious objectors.

('9', 401, 1, 2, 920014) 240. DEPUTATION NOTES [III] 1
('9', 401, 2, 3, 920044) [After July 10, 1909]
('9', 401, 3, 4, 920066) WE ARRIVE
('9', 401, 4, 5, 920076) I have reported what happened up to the time of our arrival at Madeira.
('9', 401, 4, 6, 920148) We arrived at Southampton on the 10th.
('9', 401, 4, 7, 920187) We were met by a Reuter representative.
('9', 401, 4, 8, 920227) 2 We gave him a brief statement of facts, and the report has appeared in most newspapers.
('9', 401, 4, 9, 920317) We reached London at about 10.30 a.m.
('9', 401, 4, 10, 920355) But there was no one at the station.
('9', 401, 4, 11, 920392) This was quite surprising.
('9', 401, 4, 12, 920419) After conveying our luggage to Hotel Cecil, we went to see Mr. Ritch.
('9', 401, 4, 13, 920489) We found him with Abdul Caadir 3. They were both surprised.
('9', 401, 4, 14, 920549) In the absence of any cable, Mr. Ritch had given up hopes of our arrival.
('9', 401, 4, 15, 920623) What happened was that Reuter had cabled the news [about the deputation] from Johannesburg and it was expected to be published in the newspapers; hence no separate cable was sent to Mr. Ritch.
('9', 401, 4, 16, 920816) Newspapers nowadays rarely publish Reuter cables on the Transvaal.
('9', 401, 4, 17, 920883) The cable about the deputation having left was not published.
('9', 401, 4, 18, 920945) The cable reporting the arrests of the delegates was [however] published.
('9', 401, 4, 19, 921019) Mr. Ritch concluded from this that the idea of sending a deputation must have been given up for the moment.
('9', 401, 4, 20, 921127) No one, therefore, expected our arrival.
('9', 401, 5, 21, 921168) WE SET TO WORK
('9', 401, 6, 22, 921183) Soon after we had seen Mr. Ritch, we set to work the moment we had had our lunch.
('9', 401, 6, 23, 921265) We, the two brothers, accompanied by Mr. Abdul Caadir, Mr. Ritch and Mr. Hussain Dawad, who had run up to Mr. Ritchs office, called on Mr. Bhownaggree.
('9', 401, 6, 24, 921417) After consulting among our selves there, we wrote to Lord Ampthill, and so the round of interviews began.
('9', 401, 6, 25, 921523) The whole day is taken up in interviewing people and writing let ters, and we have to keep working even at night.
('9', 401, 6, 26, 921637) Being free, Miss Polak 4 has been entrusted with typing work.
('9', 401, 6, 27, 921699) She works very

('9', 403, 1, 2, 924420) FIRST SACRIFICE
('9', 403, 2, 3, 924436) There have been a large number of cables about meetings in South Africa.
('9', 403, 2, 4, 924509) This is something to be happy about.
('9', 403, 2, 5, 924546) There is not a single cable from Natal.
('9', 403, 2, 6, 924586) Mr. Nagappens martyrdom 1 has made Mr. Hajee Habib and me very unhappy.
('9', 403, 2, 7, 924658) This has been, even otherwise, a time of mourning for us, and it is all the more so now.
('9', 403, 2, 8, 924747) However, there is no reason to be sad if we think of the community.
('9', 403, 2, 9, 924815) We have known all along that we may have to make any sacrifice, including that of life, and that, too, cheerfully.
('9', 403, 2, 10, 924930) This is exactly what we have to learn in this fight, that in the interest of the community we must bear every kind of suffering, and that only by doing so can we find a solution to our problems.
('9', 403, 2, 11, 925125) As I get more experience here, I gradually come to see that the deputation which has been sent represents only our weakness.
('9', 403, 2, 12, 925250) The energy and the time that are spent in seeing various people and in cultivating their goodwill would, if spent merely in suffering, ensure a very early solution.
('9', 403, 2, 13, 925415) I can make no guess as to the result.
('9', 403, 2, 14, 925453) But it will be enough if we learn from this struggle the lesson I have indicated above.
('9', 403, 3, 15, 925541) We have also had news of Mr. Dawad Mahomeds release on account of ill health.
('9', 403, 3, 16, 925619) Looking at the matter from his point of view, I feel sorry.
('9', 403, 3, 17, 925679) But looking at it from the communitys point of view, I congratulate him.
('9', 403, 3, 18, 925752) We think nothing of inviting illness for ourselves through overindulgence and soft living, or by exerting ourselves overmuch in the pursuit of self interest.
('9', 403, 3, 19, 925910) It is, moreover, our own fault that we fall ill in this manner.
('9', 403, 3, 20, 925974) If, then, anyone falls ill while doing his duty by the community, he surely deserves congratulations on that.
('9', 403, 3, 21, 926084) That has been so, and will always be so.
('9', 403, 3, 22, 926125) His example is being followed by Mr. Hussain Mia here.
('9', 403, 3, 23, 926180) It should make one happy to observe his habits.
('9', 403, 3, 24, 926228) Besides he has a noble regard for the community.

('9', 409, 1, 2, 937988) 242. LETTER TO J. X. MERRIMAN
('9', 409, 2, 3, 938018) LONDON, July 15, 1909
('9', 409, 3, 4, 938040) DEAR MR. MERRIMAN 1 , I have taken the liberty of speaking to Lord Ampthill 2 regarding the interest you have taken in our struggle, and his Lordship has promised to seek an interview with you.
('9', 409, 3, 5, 938234) I hope that something will come out of your private effort.
('9', 409, 3, 6, 938294) I need hardly say that the whole thing has been kept absolutely confidential.
('9', 409, 3, 7, 938372) We have just received a cablegram saying that the struggle has taken its first victim.
('9', 409, 3, 8, 938459) A young Indian 3 who was serving imprisonment as a passive resister, was discharged in a dying condition and died six days after his discharge.
('9', 409, 3, 9, 938603) There are at present about 100 Indians in the Transvaal gaols and during the struggle, over 2,500 Indians have passed through them.
('9', 409, 3, 10, 938735) The question as I have told you, is exceedingly simple.
('9', 409, 3, 11, 938791) All we want is repeal of the Asiatic (Registration) Act, which is now considered no longer necessary by General Smuts: the repeal, placing the status of highly educated Indians on a footing of equality under the Immigration Law, leaving it open to the administration under the education test, to make it so severe as to debar from the Colony more than say six persons per year.
('9', 409, 3, 12, 939169) What we bitterly resent is the racial bar, involving as it does a national insult.
('9', 409, 3, 13, 939252) I hope you will not mind my troubling you in this matter.
('9', 409, 4, 14, 939310) I remain,
('9', 409, 5, 15, 939320) Yours faithfully,
('9', 409, 6, 16, 939338) M. K. GANDHI J. X. MERRIMAN REFORM CLUB, LONDON
('9', 409, 7, 17, 939386) The correspondence of John X. Merriman.

('9', 410, 4, 6, 940236) 2 The meeting was convened by the British Indian Association and was attended by nearly 1,500 Indians.
('9', 410, 4, 7, 940339) The Rev.

('9', 410, 4, 11, 940634) 2. Two days 3 prior to the Mass Meeting a meeting of over 300 British Indians was held on the premises of the Chairman of the Associa tion, the delegates for the Indian deputation finally nominated, and the names of delegates for a simultaneous Indian deputation discussed.
('9', 410, 5, 12, 940908) 3. Of late most Indian meetings have been attended by Government detectives.
('9', 410, 5, 13, 940985) 4. The names of the delegates to be submitted to the mass meeting were published in The Transvaal Leader of the 15th June.

The purport of the resolutions was telegraphed to the Government, to which the Government replied that they had no knowledge, at the time of giving instructions for the arrests above referred to, that the delegates included in the list of the Indians to be arrested would be elected.
('9', 412, 1, 3, 944580) 9. After the formal election by the mass meeting and on the 17th June last, however, Mr. Gopal Naidoo, one of the delegates of India, was also arrested, together with many other Tamil Indians.
('9', 412, 1, 4, 944773) Thus, out of seven Indian delegates (the eighth, Mr. Polak, being an Englishman), five were arrested, and two only, the undersigned, were left free by the authorities to proceed on their mission.
('9', 412, 1, 5, 944969) WHO ARE THE DELEGATES?
('9', 412, 2, 6, 944992) 10. Mr. Amad Mohamed Cachalia is a British Indian merchant of over 18 years standing in the Transvaal, is married and is living in Johannesburg, together with his wife and children.
('9', 412, 2, 7, 945174) He is one of the trustees of the Pretoria Mosque, as also of the Hamidia Mosque at Johannesburg, and of the Dabhel Madressa Trust.
('9', 412, 2, 8, 945305) He has for the past nine months held the office of Chairman of the British Indian Association and is now, for the third time, serving imprisonment for conscience sake.
('9', 412, 2, 9, 945473) When he found that the Government were selling the goods of Indian merchants for payment of fines imposed under the Asiatic Registration Act, he felt called upon to hand over to his creditors the goods which were bought by him on credit.
('9', 412, 2, 10, 945711) The creditors, however, took a political view of the step and forcibly sequestrated his estate, although it was fully worth 20s in the .
('9', 412, 2, 11, 945848) Mr. Cachalia submitted to the process, and his estate has already paid his creditors in full, though a forced realization has left him practically penniless.
('9', 412, 2, 12, 946006) 11. Mr. Chettiar is an old man over fifty, has been settled in Johannesburg with his family for over ten years.
('9', 412, 2, 13, 946118) He is a Tamil (Madras) leader and is now in gaol for the second time in connection with the Indian struggle.
('9', 412, 2, 14, 946227) His son, about nineteen years old, is also in one of the Transvaal gaols in the same causefor the fifth time.
('9', 412, 2, 15, 946337) 12. Mr. Hajee Habib migrated to South Africa twenty nine years ago, and has been connected with important Indian businesses.
('9', 412, 2, 16, 946462) He was married in the Transvaal and lives in Johannesburg with his children.
('9', 412, 2, 17, 946539) He has held the office of the Honorary Secretary of the local Indian Committee at Pretoria for the last fifteen years and has been intimately connected with Indian public movements is the Transvaal during the
('9', 413, 0, 1, 946748) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 413, 1, 2, 946790) whole of that period.
('9', 413, 1, 3, 946812) He is permanent Honorary Secretary of the Pretoria Mosque and President of the Pretoria Anjuman Islam.
('9', 413, 1, 4, 946915) He is a member of that portion of the Indian community which, from the beginning, submitted to the Asiatic Registration Act, after having vainly attempted to obtain relief from the Government.
('9', 413, 1, 5, 947108) But its submission was due largely to the inability or unwillingness of the community to undergo the heavy pecuniary losses that were involved in non submission.
('9', 413, 1, 6, 947270) His community has, however, never relaxed its efforts, in common with the other Indians, to obtain relief.
('9', 413, 1, 7, 947377) But Mr. Hajee Habib is unable any longer to enjoy the security of life and property, when hundreds of his countrymen continue for the common good to suffer untold hardships.
('9', 413, 1, 8, 947551) He has, therefore, bound himself, should the efforts of the deputation fail to secure relief, to throw in his lot with the other sufferers and no longer to make use of the registration certificate obtained by him.
('9', 413, 1, 9, 947765) He was the founder and Chairman of the British Indian Conciliation Committee that was formed during the month of June to intercede between the Govern ment and the active sufferers.
('9', 413, 1, 10, 947946) The Committee was intended to bring about conciliation, by affording the Government an opportunity of gracefully conceding the very just demands of the Indian community.
('9', 413, 1, 11, 948116) A petition was submitted to the Government and a deputation waited upon General Smuts on the 19th June last, but General Smuts stated that he could not grant the Indian prayer on the two main points hereinafter referred to.
('9', 413, 1, 12, 948340) 13. Mr. Gandhi, the fourth delegate, has been settled in South Africa for the last sixteen years, is a Barrister of the Inner Temple, Advocate of the Supreme Court of Natal and Attorney of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal.
('9', 413, 1, 13, 948565) He has resided and practised his profession in the Transvaal since 1903. He is Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal and has been identified with the Indian public work in South Africa since 1893. He served at the time of the late war as Assistant Superintendent of the Indian Volunteer Ambulance Corps 1 and was mentioned in General Bullers despatches.
('9', 413, 1, 14, 948951) He also served with the Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps 2 raised by the Indian community at the time of the late Zulu rebellion and held the rank of Sergeant Major.
('9', 413, 1, 15, 949114) He was co delegate to London with Mr. H.
