('9', 414, 1, 7, 950033) 14. It is worthy of note that the delegation has been largely insisted upon by those British Indians who hitherto have been too weak to risk pecuniary loss and imprisonment, and therefore have been compelled to submit to the Asiatic Act, but that they have volunteered to pay the out of pocket expenses of the delegates shows how keenly they desire relief.
('9', 414, 1, 8, 950390) A BRIEF HISTORY OF THE STRUGGLE
('9', 414, 2, 9, 950422) 15. It is generally recognised that the British Indian position before the War was better than it has been at any time since, as will more fully appear from Note A 1 .
('9', 414, 2, 10, 950590) Since the advent of the British flag in the Transvaal, it has been steadily growing worse.
('9', 414, 2, 11, 950681) Law 3 of 1885 (which requires every Asiatic entering the Transvaal to pay  3 and take out a receipt therefor; deprives Asiatics of the right to own landed property, save in locations; confines their residence to such locations; and disquali fies them from becoming burghers), which was accepted by the Imperial Government under a misapprehension and when there were only about thirty Indians resident, was never fully enforced by the late Boer Govern ment.
('9', 414, 2, 12, 951138) Indian merchants were not interfered with in their business, and the location regulations were never carried out.
('9', 414, 2, 13, 951252) Notices issued to Indians to remove to locations were, under the advice of British Agents, ignored or disregarded, and under the same advice, Indian merchants traded without licences.
('9', 414, 2, 14, 951436) They were even arrested for so doing, but were discharged on the intervention of the British Agent.
('9', 414, 2, 15, 951536) Indian immigration was unrestric ted, except that those Indians who settled in the State for purposes of trade had to pay 3 once for all, and in this way get their names registered.
('9', 414, 2, 16, 951718) This was in no way
('9', 414, 3, 17, 951737) 1 Vide Statement of Transvaal Indian Case, 16 7 1909 .
('9', 414, 3, 18, 951792) This was added according to Lord Ampthills suggestion, vide Appendix XIV.
('9', 415, 0, 1, 951866) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 415, 1, 2, 951908) intended as a measure of identification.
('9', 415, 1, 3, 951949) 16. After British occupation all this was altered.
('9', 415, 1, 4, 952000) A measure called the Peace Preservation Ordinance was passed in 1902 to prevent the entry of persons dangerous to the peace and good government of the Colony.
('9', 415, 1, 5, 952159) This Ordinance made no distinction between Europeans and Asiatics.
('9', 415, 1, 6, 952226) It was of general application.
('9', 415, 1, 7, 952257) But in practice it was employed as an Indian Immigration Restriction measure.
('9', 415, 1, 8, 952335) An attempt was made to enforce strictly the provisions of Law 3 of 1885. When Lord Roberts was approached for relief, he said that the Indian position would be ameliorated after the establishment of complete civil administration.
('9', 415, 1, 9, 952565) 1 When the latter was initiated, Lord Milner was approached.
('9', 415, 1, 10, 952626) 2 Several attempts were made by the Local Government to improve the position, but sufficient firmness was lacking to carry them into effect.
('9', 415, 1, 11, 952767) The golden opportunity afforded by the new British occupation, of doing away withamong many other un British lawsthe equally un British anti Asiatic laws, was neglected or allowed to slip by.
('9', 415, 1, 12, 952959) Every later attempt at amelioration, being unsuccessful, resulted in making the position of British Indians worse and worse.
('9', 415, 1, 13, 953084) 17. Lord Milner (in 1904) changed the scope and intention of Law 3 of 1885 by using one of its clauses (with the consent of the British Indians) for the purpose of identifying every Asiatic in the Colony.
('9', 415, 1, 14, 953289) Under this arrangement and under a definite promise in writing that such identification was to be final, almost every British Indian resident of the Colony took out a certificate containing his full description and his thumb impression.
('9', 415, 1, 15, 953526) Nevertheless, just before the grant of responsible Government, the then Colonial Secretary, Mr. Duncan, (in 1906) brought up a Bill 3 which ignored Lord Milners promise, which nullified the certificates above referred to , and made it obligatory on every indian and on other Asiatics to take out another identification ticket.
('9', 415, 1, 16, 953853) The measure contained many other extremely objectionable clauses which need not be here described.
('9', 415, 1, 17, 953952) Indians were greatly agitated.
('9', 415, 1, 18, 953983) They bound themselves not to conform to the measure should it be sanctioned.
('9', 415, 1, 19, 954060) 18. A deputation came to England (in the latter part of 1906), waited upon Lord Elgin, and the Bill was disallowed.
('9', 415, 2, 20, 954176) 1 Vide The British Indian Association and Lord Milner, 11 6 1903. 2 ibid 3 Vide Johannesburg Letter, 4 8 1906.
('9', 416, 0, 1, 954287) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 417
('9', 416, 1, 2, 954328) 19. Responsible Government followed (in the beginning of 1907).
('9', 416, 1, 3, 954392) Almost the very first Act of the new Parliament was to restore the above measure, with one meaningless verbal alteration, not in any way affecting any of the objectionable clauses.
('9', 416, 1, 4, 954573) In spite of Indian protests, it was hurried through Parliament and received the Royal assent on the 2nd March, 1907. When this legislation was introduced by Mr. Duncan, it was stated that it was to be temporary and to be replaced by an immigration measure.
('9', 416, 1, 5, 954830) 20. When, however, an Immigration Bill was passed, as it was during the same session, it was found that it did not repeal the Asiatic Bill (now Act), but that, read together with the latter, the effect was to bring about, in a circuitous manner, the total prohibition of Indian immigration.
('9', 416, 1, 6, 955121) The two measures together, therefore, for the first time in the history of Colonial legislation, create a colour or racial bar in respect of immigration.
('9', 416, 1, 7, 955275) (As to how the total prohibition of Indian immigration has been brought about by the two Acts read together, see Note B.) 1
('9', 416, 2, 8, 955399) 21. During the January of 1908, active steps were taken to enforce the provisions of the Asiatic Act (Act 2 of 1907).
('9', 416, 2, 9, 955517) The Indians, in accordance with their solemn pledge, declined to submit to it, and the leaders were prosecuted and imprisoned.
('9', 416, 2, 10, 955644) 22. Through the intervention of Mr. Albert Cartwright, Editor of The Transvaal Leader, a compromise was effected.
('9', 416, 2, 11, 955758) It was partly written and partly oral.
('9', 416, 2, 12, 955797) Indians contend that General Smuts promised that, if they underwent identification voluntarily, the Asiatic Act should be repealed and their voluntary identification be legalised by means of another measure, preferably by amending the Immigration Bill which had now become law.
('9', 416, 2, 13, 956075) (For fuller details of the compromise, see Note C.) 2 Indians have, admittedly, fulfilled their part of the compromise, and have asked for repeal of the Act.
('9', 416, 2, 14, 956233) 23. General Smuts, on behalf of the Government, contends that he never made any promise of repeal, though he admits that the question of repeal was discussed between him and Mr. Gandhi and that there might have been a misunderstanding on Mr. Gandhis part.
('9', 416, 2, 15, 956489) 24. The facts proved and admitted are:
('9', 416, 3, 16, 956528) 1 Vide Statement of Transvaal Indian Case, 16 7 1909 This was inserted in accordance with Lord Ampthills suggestion; vide Appendix XIV.
('9', 416, 3, 17, 956664) 2 Vide Statement of Transvaal Indian Case, 16 7 1909 This was included as a result of Lord Ampthills suggestion; vide Appendix XIV
('9', 417, 0, 1, 956795) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 417, 1, 2, 956837) (a) That Mr. Gandhi sent him (22nd February, 1908) a draft Bill 1by his permission, one clause of which repealed the Act.
('9', 417, 1, 3, 956959) This was acknowledged, and the proposal to repeal was never repudiated.
('9', 417, 1, 4, 957031) (b) That two days after the completion of the compromise, General Smuts stated at a public meeting (6th February, 1908) that he had told them that the law would not be repealed so long as there was an Asiatic in the country who had not registered, and again that until every Indian in the country had registered, the law would not be repealed.
('9', 417, 1, 5, 957375) (c) That General Smuts actually drafted and circulated an amendment of the Immigration Act (13th June, 1908) repealing the Asiatic Act, but imported therein four new conditions, one of which was that British Indians, no matter what their status might be, should be treated as prohibited immigrants.
('9', 417, 1, 6, 957674) Acceptance of these new clauses by the Indian community he made a condition of carrying the amendment repealing the Asiatic Act.
('9', 417, 1, 7, 957803) Indians would not accept the new conditions.
('9', 417, 1, 8, 957848) 25. To resume.
('9', 417, 1, 9, 957863) The Indians not accepting the new conditions, the repeal fell through.
('9', 417, 1, 10, 957934) These new conditions were unacceptable to them because the first three took away the right of residence, in the Transvaal, of those British Indians who were at the time domiciled in the Colony, and the fourth condition, as stated above, constituted a national affront in that it prohibited the entry of British Indians, no matter how cultured they might be, on the ground of race.
('9', 417, 1, 11, 958315) Thus it is clear that the repeal fell through, through no fault of the Indians.
('9', 417, 1, 12, 958395) General Smuts went back even upon the written and manifest terms of the compromise.
('9', 417, 1, 13, 958479) For, although in accordance with the written compromise (see Note C.), Act 2 of 1907 was clearly not to be applied to those persons who had been voluntarily identified, and although their identification was to be legalised by a separate Act, a Bill was published (11th August, 1908 2) bringing such Indians under Act 2 of 1907 3. 26. In consequence of this double breach of the compromise on
('9', 417, 2, 14, 958871) 1 Vide Letter to General Smuts, (Enclosure) 22 2 1908.

('9', 418, 0, 1, 959130) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 419
('9', 418, 1, 2, 959171) the part of Mr. Smuts, Indians held a mass meeting (16th August, 1908), burned about 2,500 of the certificates they had voluntarily taken out, and so rendered themselves amenable to prosecution.
('9', 418, 1, 3, 959366) This induced a con ference (18th August 1908 1) between the Executive, the Progressive lea ders, and Messrs Gandhi and Quinn (the Chinese leader)Mr. Essop Mia, Chairman of the Association, not being available owing to short notice.
('9', 418, 1, 4, 959598) 27. As a result of the conference, a new Bill was brought in, placing voluntary registrants under a separate law.
('9', 418, 1, 5, 959712) The question of repeal was discussed, but the Government would not listen to the proposal, saying that the Act would be treated as a dead letter.
('9', 418, 1, 6, 959858) The question of the entry of highly educated Indians too was discussed, but no relief was promised under the Immigration Act, General Smuts only going so far as to say that temporary permits would be granted to such men.
('9', 418, 1, 7, 960079) 28. Another mass meeting (20th August, 1908) was, therefore, held to consider the result of the conference, and the meeting decided not to accept the new Bill, unless Act 2 of 1907 was repealed and highly edu cated Indians might enter as a matter of right after passing the educational and other tests, however severe, under the general immigration law 2. 29. The Government, however, carried their new Bill in spite of the Indian protests.
('9', 418, 1, 8, 960520) The new Billwhich is otherwise generally acceptablecontains certain defects which need not be set out here and which were recounted in a petition submitted to the Imperial Government.
('9', 418, 2, 9, 960704) THE OUTSTANDING QUESTIONS
('9', 418, 3, 10, 960730) 30. Apart from minor points arising out of the new Bill, the outstanding questions between the Transvaal Government and the Indian community are: (1) Repeal of Act 2 of 1907 and (2) The status of highly educated Indians.
('9', 418, 3, 11, 960951) 31. The Transvaal Government alleges that these two points are as good as granted, because
('9', 418, 4, 12, 961042) 1 The original has 1909, which is a misprint.
('9', 418, 4, 13, 961088) Vide Johannesburg Letter, 19 8 1908. 2 Vide Letter to E.F.C. Lane, 20 8 1908. 3 Vide Petition to Secretary of State for Colonies, 9 11 1908
('9', 419, 0, 1, 961228) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 419, 1, 2, 961270) (1) Act 2 of 1907 is to be treated as a dead letter, and (2) Highly educated Indians can receive temporary permits to be indefinitely prolonged under a clause of the new Asiatic Bill.
('9', 419, 1, 3, 961454) 32. The Indians contend that
('9', 419, 2, 4, 961483) (1) If Act 2 of 1907 is to be treated as a dead letter, it can serve no useful purpose to retain it on the Statute book of the Colony.
('9', 419, 2, 5, 961618) The Indians have (by reason of broken promi ses) grown suspicious and do not understand the meaning of a law being a dead letter and, yet, remaining part of the laws of the country.
('9', 419, 2, 6, 961800) If the Act is merely retained to satisfy the electors, they, being more intelligent, ought to understand that a law that is a dead letter need not encumber the Statute book of the Colony, and lastly, notwithstanding the fact that the Government had pronounced this Act to be a dead letter, it has been when it has suited the Governmentput into active operation against the Indians, and there is nothing to bar its being put into effect at any time in future.
('9', 419, 3, 7, 962259) (2) If the Transvaal Government are willing to admit highly educated Indians, they might as well admit them under the immigration law; unless the Government intend to insult the whole Indian people, it must be a matter of indifference to them whether educated Indians are admitted under the Asiatic Act or the Immigration Act; to the Indians it is a vital principle.
('9', 419, 3, 8, 962626) The manner of admission is everything to them.
('9', 419, 3, 9, 962673) They are more anxious that one educated Indian who enters the Colony should do so under the general immigration law and through the front door of right than that twenty or more Indians should enter the Colony through the back door of favouritism and as ticket of leave men, entitled to remain in the Transvaal only during the pleasure of the Government.
('9', 419, 4, 10, 963027) 33. This question of educated Indians is the crux.
('9', 419, 4, 11, 963078) There is no desire to flood the Transvaal with British Indians.
('9', 419, 4, 12, 963142) Indians recognize that the British and Boer population should remain predominant in South Africa.
('9', 419, 4, 13, 963240) But they contend that the Colony of the Transvaal should not be allowed to offer a national insult in carrying out that policy.
('9', 420, 0, 1, 963368) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 421
('9', 420, 1, 2, 963409) 34. Moreover, Indians who are resident in the Transvaal, if they are to rise in the social and moral scale, require the help of their highly educated brethren.
('9', 420, 1, 3, 963569) In order to prove their bona fides, they declare that they would not mind an administration of the Immigration Law so as to admit the fewest possible Indians (say six) in any one year.
('9', 420, 1, 4, 963754) While they object to legal inequality and legal discrimination, they are prepared to put up with administrative discrimination.
('9', 420, 1, 5, 963882) This very thing is now being done in Australia.
('9', 420, 1, 6, 963930) It was done in the Transvaal under the Peace Preservation Ordinance previously referred to.
('9', 420, 1, 7, 964022) They further submit that, if the present law does not confer sufficient administrative authority, the Act may be amended in the desired direction, but not so as to perpetuate a racial distinction.
('9', 420, 1, 8, 964219) UNDER THE NEW CONSTITUTION
('9', 420, 2, 9, 964246) 35. Under the new Constitution, the position of British Indians requires careful safeguarding, unless they are ultimately to be driven out of, or extinguished in, South Africa.
('9', 420, 2, 10, 964423) They are practically unrepresented.
('9', 420, 2, 11, 964459) What little representation they have enjoyed at the Cape and Natal is to be of no effect under the new Constitution.
('9', 420, 2, 12, 964576) The union of the Europeans in South Africa will, if the Imperial authority is not properly retained, spell disaster to vested Indian rights.
('9', 420, 2, 13, 964717) In the Orange River Colony, Indians, save as menials, are not admitted.
('9', 420, 2, 14, 964789) In the Transvaal, apart from the above mentioned legislation, they are debarred the right of buying land except in locations specially set apart for them, and even this right is withheld.
('9', 420, 2, 15, 964977) In Natal, Indian traders are being starved out under a one sided and oppressive administration of the licensing law of the Colony.
('9', 420, 2, 16, 965108) Minor grievances throughout South Africa are too numerous to set out in detail.
('9', 420, 2, 17, 965188) They affect the daily life of the Indian and make it well nigh intolerable, by continually reminding him that the wearing of a brown skin is a crime in the sub continent.
('9', 420, 2, 18, 965359) The unmistakable tendency of the legislation in South Africa is to impose restrictions on Indian liberty in the same proportion as the liberties of the European races are extended.
('9', 420, 2, 19, 965540) 36. It is, therefore, a matter of paramount importance, both from an Imperial and an Indian standpoint, that the Transvaal Indian question be satisfactorily settled.
('9', 420, 2, 20, 965706) It is an undoubted fact that the Transvaal is the predominant State in South Africa.
('9', 420, 2, 21, 965791) It leads; the other States follow.
('9', 420, 2, 22, 965826) If, therefore, the Transvaal Indian legislation is not first set on a firm and equitable basis, the Transvaal legislation is sure to be
('9', 421, 0, 1, 965962) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 421, 1, 2, 966004) copied under the Union, and then the Imperial Government will be powerless to afford relief.
('9', 421, 1, 3, 966097) THE INDIAN COVENANT
('9', 421, 2, 4, 966117) 37. Moreover, the Indians are bound by a solemn covenant to secure the above relief, even though they may have to suffer imprisonment and worse, for an indefinite length of time.
('9', 421, 2, 5, 966296) In virtue thereof, over 2,500 imprisonments, mostly with hard labour, have taken place during the two years and six months that the struggle has lasted.
('9', 421, 2, 6, 966449) The prison life has been anything but tolerable.
('9', 421, 2, 7, 966498) Indian prisoners are classed and accommodated with the South African Natives, and two thirds of their food is the same as that of the Natives.
('9', 421, 2, 8, 966641) There is no such thing as a political offence in the Transvaal.
('9', 421, 2, 9, 966705) Indian prisoners, whom General Smuts himself has called conscientious objectors, are imprisoned with the worst criminals.
('9', 421, 2, 10, 966827) The labour required of them is generally of a severe character.
('9', 421, 2, 11, 966891) Indians who have never lifted a heavy weight or done any spadde work have been put to wheeling heavily loaded barrows, digging holes repairing roads, etc., side by side with Kaffir convicts of the worst type.
('9', 421, 2, 12, 967100) 38. Many Indian families have been reduced to poverty.
('9', 421, 2, 13, 967155) Many homes have been broken up.
('9', 421, 2, 14, 967187) And several families whose wage earners are now in the Transvaal gaols are dependent for their daily bread on public charity.
('9', 421, 2, 15, 967313) 39. Latterly, the Government, by means of a secret arrangement with the Portuguese authorities, have taken to deporting to India those who do not comply with the provisions of the Asiatic Act and who can be dealt with under the deportation sections of that Act.
('9', 421, 2, 16, 967575) Under this procedure children have been torn from their parents; boys born in South Africa, and to whom India is a foreign land, have been sent penniless to India.
('9', 421, 2, 17, 967739) And, although Lord Crewe has denied that those who are domiciled in any of the South African Colonies outside the Transvaal are deported, at least one such case has undoubtedly happened of an Indian possessing educational attainments, and therefore capable of residing in Natal or the Cape, and possessing domicile in Delagoa Bay, being deported to India.
('9', 421, 2, 18, 968095) 40. These are the means that the Government are using to bend the Indian covenanters to their will, and while they have partly succeeded, a sufficiently large number remains who show no signs of weakening.
('9', 421, 2, 19, 968301) The most influential Mohammedan, and an undisputed leader of the Indians in South Africa, Mr. Dowd Mohmed, a resident
('9', 422, 0, 1, 968419) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 423
('9', 422, 1, 2, 968460) of many years standing in the Transvaal, and a man over 50 years of age; Mr. Parsee Rustomjee, a most prominent Parseeanother recognised leadera man who has spent hundreds of pounds in the cause of education (even of children belonging to a faith not his own)are both undergoing six months imprisonment with hard labour.
('9', 422, 1, 3, 968781) Two ex sergeants, who served during the late Zulu rebellion and who are holders of the rebellion medals, are also undergoing a like term of imprisonment.
('9', 422, 1, 4, 968935) At the present time there are nearly one hundred objectors undergoing imprisonment, and most of these have been through the gaols more than once in the course of the struggle.
('9', 422, 1, 5, 969111) THE EUROPEAN COMMITTEE
('9', 422, 2, 6, 969134) 41. Actuated by sympathy with the Indians in their sufferings, and believing in the justice of their cause, certain leading Europeans of Johannesburg have formed themselves into a committee to secure relief.
('9', 422, 2, 7, 969342) This committee is led by Mr. William Hosken, M.L.A., and has been working actively in the matter.
('9', 422, 2, 8, 969440) CONCLUSION
('9', 422, 3, 9, 969451) 42. Apart from any promise made by General Smuts, it is submitted that the two indian demands are intrinsically just, that it is not difficult for the Government to grant them, and that, in order to have them granted, the Transvaal Indians have gone through a long course of sustained suffering.
('9', 422, 3, 10, 969747) In the circumstances, they feel that their covenant should be respected, and that regard for the wishes of the self governing Colonies should not debar the Imperial Government from protecting British subjects in the same way as it would protect them in foreign countriesthe more so when such subjects are unrepresented, as in the present instance.

('9', 423, 1, 2, 970741) received a telegram which shows that an Indian youth named Nagappen, who was sentenced on the 21st June last to be imprisoned for ten days with hard labour, in connection with the struggle, was discharged on the 30th June in a dying condition, and died on the 6th July.

('9', 423, 2, 6, 971537) UNDER THE BOER Regime SINCE BRITISH ANNEXATION
('9', 423, 3, 7, 971584) Asiatics could freely enter the Republic and, subsequent to 1885, could reside and trade on payment of a 3 tax.
('9', 423, 4, 8, 971696) Only such Asiatics as could prove pre war residence have been re admitted.
('9', 423, 5, 9, 971771) Registration required by Law 3 of 1885 (amended in 1886) did not include identification particulars.
('9', 423, 5, 10, 971872) It consisted merely of the payment of the 3 fee and the holding of the receipt therefor.
('9', 423, 6, 11, 971961) Registration voluntarily assented to by Asiatics in 1903, under advice of Lord Milner, included very full indentification particulars.
('9', 423, 6, 12, 972096) Re registration under the Act of 1907 is compulsory and additionally humiliating in details.
('9', 423, 6, 13, 972189) It applies to all children from eight years of age upwords.
('9', 423, 6, 14, 972249) Failure to re register entails fine, im prisonment, and expulsion.
('9', 423, 6, 15, 972316) (Since modified by Act 36 of 1908).
('9', 423, 6, 16, 972352) Asiatics were denied burgher rights.
('9', 423, 6, 17, 972389) Asiatics, including British Indians, are excluded from both political and municipal privileges.
('9', 424, 0, 1, 972485) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 425
('9', 424, 1, 2, 972526) Asiatics might not own fixed property, save in Asiatic locations.
('9', 424, 2, 3, 972592) This is still the case.
('9', 424, 3, 4, 972616) Asiatics were liable to be relegated to streets, wards, and locations specially set apart for that purpose.
('9', 424, 4, 5, 972724) Asiatics, including British Indians, are still so liable, and are threatened with such segregation.
('9', 424, 5, 6, 972824) Whereas Law 3 imposing the above disabilities was virtually inoperative, British Indians [were] being protected by His Majestys Government.
('9', 424, 6, 7, 972964) Since the annexation, and more especially since the grant of responsible government, British Indians have failed to secure such Imperial protection.
('9', 424, 6, 8, 973113) Responsible English Mini sters claimed for British Indians the equal rights of civilized subjects of the Empire.
('9', 424, 6, 9, 973226) The British Government virtually pledged itself to the reinstatement in their just rights of Transvaal British Indians.
('9', 424, 7, 10, 973346) The British Government have apparently abandoned the self same Indians, who resided in the Colony prior to its annexa tion, to the tyranny of trade rivals, and of a Government largely composed of legislators who were responsible for the Boer Law 3 of 1885. British Indian protests agaist the Boer Law were supported by Imperial Govern ment, and the insistence by the Republic of its right to legislate indiscriminately against Asiatics within its borders figured promi nently in the causes that led up to the war.
('9', 424, 8, 11, 973860) Now, for want of effective Imperial protection, British Indians have been obliged to fall back on passive resistance, which has resulted in the imprisonment of 2,500 of their number, and other sufferings.
('9', 424, 9, 12, 974065) Generally, while theoreti cally British Indians were placed under the above disabilities, in practice the law was not strictly enforced.
('9', 424, 10, 13, 974202) The restrictions upon the freedom of British Indians have been enforced with the utmost rigour, and the absence of a penalty clause to Law 3 of 1885 has alone saved the Indians from its worst consequences.
('9', 425, 0, 1, 974408) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 425, 2, 2, 974450) The Asiatic Bill provides that every Asiatic in the Colony should take out an identification ticket, and it also defines an Asiatic eligible for receiving such ticket.
('9', 425, 2, 3, 974618) The definition states that only an Asiatic who is domiciled in the Transvaal from before the passing of this measure shall be eligible.
('9', 425, 2, 4, 974754) The Bill further provides that every Asiatic who is held to be ineligible is subject to a removal order from the Colony.
('9', 425, 3, 5, 974875) The Immigration Bill, among other provisions, makes a person who is subject to a removal order a prohibited immigrant.
('9', 425, 3, 6, 974994) Now, an educated Indian who has not been domiciled in the Colony before the passing of the Asiatic Bill is ineligible for holding an identification ticket, and is therefore subject to a removal order, and thus, under the Immigration Bill, is a prohibited immigrant.
('9', 425, 5, 7, 975260) The written compromise was that
('9', 425, 6, 8, 975292) 1. British Indians should voluntarily identify themselves.
('9', 425, 7, 9, 975351) 2. That Act 2 of 1907 should not be applied to such British Indians, and that the voluntary identification should be legalised by a separate measure.
('9', 425, 8, 10, 975501) These terms are embodied in a letter addressed by Messrs Gandhi, Quinn, and Naidoo to the Transvaal Colonial Secretary, and dated 28th January, 1908 1. Two days after the receipt of the letter, Mr. Gandhi, who was then a prisoner, was taken to Pretoria to discuss the compromise with the Colonial Secretary (Mr. Smuts), and a further discussion took place subsequent thereto.
('9', 425, 8, 11, 975877) At these interviews, according to Mr. Gandhis statement, Mr. Smuts promised to repeal the Asiatic Act (2 of 1907) on the completion by the Asiatics of their part of the bargain, i.e., voluntarily identifying themselves.

('9', 426, 8, 13, 976930) 245. LONDON
('9', 426, 9, 14, 976942) [After July 16, 1909] CURZON WYLLIES ASSASSINATION
('9', 426, 10, 15, 976993) Under the heading Deputation Notes, I have given all the information about the activities of the deputation that can be made public.
('9', 426, 10, 16, 977126) Under the above heading, I give other news worth reporting.
('9', 426, 10, 17, 977186) The assassination of Sir Curzon Wyllie and Dr. Lalkaka was a terrible thing.
('9', 426, 10, 18, 977263) Sir Curzon Wyllie served as an officer at several places in India.
('9', 426, 10, 19, 977330) Here he was Lord Morleys aide de camp.
('9', 426, 10, 20, 977369) Dr. Lalkaka was a Parsi physician and carried on business at Shanghai in China.
('9', 426, 10, 21, 977449) He was here on a short visit only.
('9', 426, 10, 22, 977484) On July 2, there was a tea meeting of the National Indian Association in the Jehangir Hall of the Imperial Institute.
('9', 426, 10, 23, 977602) Such meetings are arranged with the object of bringing Indian students into contact with Englishmen, who therefore attend as the guests of Indians.
('9', 426, 10, 24, 977750) Sir Curzon Wyllie was [thus] a guest of the assassin.
('9', 426, 10, 25, 977804) From this
('9', 427, 0, 1, 977814) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 427, 1, 2, 977856) point of view, Mr. Madanlal Dhingra murdered his guest in his own house, and also killed Dr. Lalkaka who tried to interpose himself between them.
('9', 427, 1, 3, 978002) It is being said in defence of Sir Curzon Wyllies assassination that it is the British who are responsible for Indias ruin, and that, just as the British would kill every German if Germany invaded Britain, so too it is the right of any Indian to kill any Englishman.
('9', 427, 1, 4, 978269) Every Indian should reflect thoughtfully on this murder.
('9', 427, 1, 5, 978326) It has done India much harm; the deputations efforts have also received a setback.
('9', 427, 1, 6, 978409) But that need not be taken into consideration.
('9', 427, 1, 7, 978456) It is the ultimate result that we must think of.
('9', 427, 1, 8, 978505) Mr. Dhingras defence is inadmissible.
('9', 427, 1, 9, 978543) In my view, he has acted like a coward.
('9', 427, 1, 10, 978583) All the same, one can only pity the man.
('9', 427, 1, 11, 978624) He was egged on to do this act by ill digested reading of worthless writings.
('9', 427, 1, 12, 978702) His defence of himself, too, appears to have been learnt by rote.
('9', 427, 1, 13, 978768) It is those who incited him to this that deserve to be punished.
('9', 427, 1, 14, 978833) In my view, Mr. Dhingra himself is innocent.
('9', 427, 1, 15, 978878) The murder was committed in a state of intoxication.
('9', 427, 1, 16, 978931) It is not merely wine or bhang that makes one drunk; a mad idea also can do so.
('9', 427, 1, 17, 979011) That was the case with Mr. Dhingra.
('9', 427, 1, 18, 979047) The analogy of Germans and Englishmen is fallacious.
('9', 427, 1, 19, 979100) If the Germans were to invade [Britain], the British would kill only the invaders.
('9', 427, 1, 20, 979183) They would not kill every German whom they met.
('9', 427, 1, 21, 979231) Moreover, they would not kill an unsuspecting German, or Germans who are guests.
('9', 427, 1, 22, 979312) If I kill someone in my own house without a warningsomeone who has done me no harmI cannot but be called a coward.
('9', 427, 1, 23, 979427) There is an ancient custom among the Arabs that they would not kill anyone in their own house, even if the person be their enemy.
('9', 427, 1, 24, 979557) They would kill him after he had left the house and after he had been given time to arm himself.
('9', 427, 1, 25, 979654) Those who believe in violence would be brave men if they observe these rules when killing anyone.
('9', 427, 1, 26, 979752) Otherwise, they must be looked upon as cowards.
('9', 427, 1, 27, 979800) It may be said that what Mr. Dhingra did, publicly and knowing full well that he himself would have to die, argues courage of no mean order on his part.
('9', 427, 1, 28, 979953) But as I have said above, men can do these things in a state of intoxication, and can also banish the fear of death.
('9', 427, 1, 29, 980070) Whatever courage there is in this is the result of intoxication, not a quality of the man himself.
('9', 427, 1, 30, 980169) A mans own courage consists in suffering deeply and over a long period.
('9', 427, 1, 31, 980241) That alone is a brave act which is preceded by careful reflection.
('9', 427, 1, 32, 980308) I must say that those who believe and argue that such murders may do good to India are ignorant men indeed.
('9', 427, 1, 33, 980416) No act of treachery can ever profit a nation.
('9', 427, 1, 34, 980462) Even should the British leave in consequence of such murderous acts, who will rule in their place?
('9', 427, 1, 35, 980561) The only answer
('9', 428, 0, 1, 980577) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 429
('9', 428, 1, 2, 980618) is: the murderers.
('9', 428, 1, 3, 980637) Who will then be happy?
('9', 428, 1, 4, 980661) Is the Englishman bad because he is an Englishmen?
('9', 428, 1, 5, 980712) Is it that everyone with an Indian skin is good?
('9', 428, 1, 6, 980761) If that is so, we can claim no rights in South Africa, nor should there be any angry protest against oppression by Indian princes.

('9', 428, 1, 12, 981243) We ought to abandon such fanciful ideas.

('9', 428, 3, 16, 981408) They are not deterred by any kind of suffering.

('9', 429, 0, 1, 982496) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('9', 429, 1, 3, 982645) My colleague and I have purposely refrained from seeking an interview with His Lordship, because we are endeavouring at the present moment to secure a settlement of the difficult question that has brought us here, without having to trouble the Imperial Government, but as the Conference regarding the South African Draft Act commences to day, we consider it desirable that we should draw His Lordships attention to the fact that the Transvaal Indian question has involved untold suffering to British Indians in that Colony,and that it still continues to cause grave anxiety to the British Indian leaders.
('9', 429, 1, 4, 983250) At the present stage we are desirous of avoiding a public discussion of the question, so as to facilitate a private settlement.
('9', 429, 1, 5, 983378) We shall, therefore, be deeply grateful to His Lordship if he will be pleased to grant us a private interview, so as to enable us to place the position to date before His Lordship.

('9', 431, 3, 4, 986339) SIR, In your leading article in the current number, you state that:
('9', 431, 4, 5, 986407) Mr. Gandhi, of Natal and Transvaal fame, admits that the campaign of himself and his friends will be dictated by sympathisers in England, whose names by the way are unfortunately associated with the dangerous movement in India, which has been brought into such startling prominence of late.
('9', 431, 4, 6, 986698) Will you kindly allow me to say in reply that what I said to Reuters Agent 1 was that our movements will be guided by the advice that may be given us by Lord Ampthill and his Committee.
('9', 431, 4, 7, 986884) I am not aware that Lord Ampthill or his colleagues are associated with what you call the dangerous movement in India.
('9', 431, 4, 8, 987003) Moreover, for passive resisters there can be no dictation save that of their consciences.
('9', 431, 4, 9, 987093) They are under solemn obligation to secure what they are justly entitled to, and, in their endeavour to do so, they are resolved to undergo personal suffering to any extent, not even excluding death.
('9', 431, 4, 10, 987293) The test of true passive resistance is sacrifice of self and not of others.

('9', 437, 1, 2, 997973) 253. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES
('9', 437, 2, 3, 998017) LONDON, July 24, 1909
('9', 437, 3, 4, 998039) TO THE UNDER SECRETARY OF STATE COLONIAL OFFICE WHITEHALL, S. W.
('9', 437, 4, 5, 998104) SIR, With reference to your letter of the 23rd instant No.
('9', 437, 4, 6, 998163) 24316/1909I have the honour to state that my colleague and I, if received, will, in view of the approaching unification of South Africa, place before His Lordship the position of the British Indians in the Transvaal as it arises from, and is affected by, the voluntary suffering that the British Indians in the Transvaal have undergone and are still undergoing.
('9', 437, 4, 7, 998525) It was the wish of the majority of those British Indians who, being too weak to put up with physical suffering or to risk pecuniary loss, have yielded obedience to the Asiatic Registration Act they nevertheless do not like, that we should proceed to London and, taking advantage of the presence in London of the chief members of the Transvaal Government, lay before His Lordship the Indian position in the hope of securing friendly intervention and thereby, if possible, ending a situation that has caused untold suffering to hundreds of innocent British Indians.
('9', 437, 4, 8, 999089) British Indians in the Transvaal have, for the past two years and six months, been moving the transvaal Government to repeal the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907, and so remove the humiliation it imposes upon them, and to respect the status of highly educated Indians desiring to enter the Transvaal in accordance with British traditions and in a manner similar to that obtaining in the Colony of the Cape of Good Hope and the other British Colonies.
('9', 437, 4, 9, 999540) I venture to hope that His Lordship will be pleased to give us an opportunity of laying the case before him personally, and so carry out the purpose for which we have been specially sent by the Indian community in the Transvaal.
('9', 437, 5, 10, 999769) I have, etc.,
('9', 437, 6, 11, 999783) M. K. GANDHI

('9', 438, 1, 2, 999937) 254. LETTER TO W. P. SCHREINER
('9', 438, 2, 3, 999968) July 24, 1909
('9', 438, 3, 4, 999982) DEAR SIR 1, Mr. Hajee Habib, President of the Pretoria Anjuman e Islam and I, as you may be aware, are in London as a deputation on behalf of the Transvaal British Indians in connection with the struggle that has now gone on in that Colony for the last two years and a half.
('9', 438, 3, 5, 1000257) We have heard a great deal about your noble and self sacrificing work in connection with the welfare of the coloured races of South Africa under the Draft South Africa Act.

('9', 443, 1, 2, 1010852) 257. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD MORLEY
('9', 443, 2, 3, 1010900) LONDON, July 26, 1909 THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO THE RIGHT HONBLE THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA WHITEHALL, S. W.
('9', 443, 3, 4, 1011014) SIR, I shall be obliged if you will place the following before Lord Morley: At the private interview 1 that His Lordship was graciously pleased to grant to Mr. Hajee Habib and myself, I was unable, owing to want of time, to say all I had intended to .
('9', 443, 3, 5, 1011266) I wish, therefore, on behalf of my colleague and myself to state that the two outstanding questions between the Transvaal Government and the Indian communitynamely, the repeal of the Asiatic Act and the guarding of the status of educated British Indians on a basis similar to that adopted in the other Colonies, are the questions which are of paramount importance, because of the solemn covenant undertaken by the community.
('9', 443, 3, 6, 1011691) This, however, does not mean that the British Indians do not feel aggrieved about the other disabilities in the Transvaal, such, for instance, as the prohibition to hold landed property, riding on the tramcars, etc.
('9', 443, 3, 7, 1011907) We, however,feel that these questions are not those for which the community has suffered imprisonment or suffered such personal hardships as it has for the removal of those two grievances.
('9', 443, 3, 8, 1012096) British Indians will, however, continue to adopt the means they have hitherto adoptedfor the removal of the other disabilities.
('9', 443, 3, 9, 1012224) But the two grievances above.
('9', 443, 3, 10, 1012254) named have been separated from the others by reason of the terrible suffering that they have involved and will continue to involve until a proper settlement is arrived at.
('9', 443, 3, 11, 1012426) My colleague and I trust that Lord Morley will be able to find time to give special attention to this matter and, by his friendly offices on behalf of those whose interests are in his keeping secure an honourable settlement.
('9', 443, 4, 12, 1012651) I have, etc.,

('9', 444, 4, 15, 1013563) I gather from his letter that something will be known next week.

('9', 444, 4, 17, 1013767) Should the outcome be satisfactory, it must not be attributed to any very strong pressure applied in England, but only to our gaol going.
('9', 444, 4, 18, 1013905) Anyone here can easily see this.
('9', 444, 4, 19, 1013938) Every white who hears of our gaol going is struck with admiration.
('9', 444, 4, 20, 1014005) Voluntary submission to suffering cannot but have a powerful effect.
('9', 444, 4, 21, 1014074) This has been my experience again and again.
('9', 444, 4, 22, 1014119) Mr. Hajee Habib, Mr. Abdul Caadir and I were invited to Miss Smiths.
('9', 444, 4, 23, 1014188) Everyone there was talking about the same thing, namely, gaol going The very mention of gaol going impressed people.
('9', 444, 4, 24, 1014305) I see the time drawing nearer every day when no one, whether black or white, will suc ceed in obtaining a hearing by merely making petitions.
('9', 444, 4, 25, 1014447) If I am rig ht,then, no force in the world can compare with soul force, that is to say, with satyagraha.
('9', 444, 4, 26, 1014552) I therefore wish that Indians should fill the gaols if, by the time this letter is published, there has been no decision or solution.
('9', 444, 4, 27, 1014686) On August 9, a number of Indian friends will have been released.
('9', 444, 4, 28, 1014751) It is my request to all of them to be fearless and go back to gaol.
('9', 444, 4, 29, 1014819) Let them not betray the pledge they have taken.

('9', 446, 3, 5, 1017092) Immediately on reading your letter 1, I telegraphed 2 saying that nothing would be done without consultation with Your Lordship and that I was writing this letter and sending the statement 3. ('9', 446, 3, 6, 1017474) My colleague and I are very pleased to find that you have been able to see the distinguished men whom you have mentioned in your letter.

('9', 447, 1, 4, 1019141) The whole position, I believe, I have clearly explained to Sir Richard Solomon and I believe, too, that he has understood it.
('9', 447, 1, 5, 1019267) There undoubtedly are other grievances in the Transvaal, as for instance, the prohibition to hold landed property, to ride in the tramcars etc., and we will have to trouble the local authorities as also Your Lord ship for assistance in the matter, but the distinction between the two grie vances which have brought the deputation to London and the others is, that the former have entailed passive resistance involving untold suffering by us, and must continue to do, so long as I can help it, until the grieva nces are redressed or every Indian perishes in the attempt to have them re dressed.
('9', 447, 1, 6, 1019861) The latter grievances are of long standing; there is no solemn covenant to impose upon ourselves personal suffering in order to remove them and we can wait for public opinion to mature and prejudice to die out, without reducing ourselves to penury and filling the Transvaal gaols.
('9', 447, 2, 7, 1020142) It is to me a test of Your Lordships very great interest [in our struggle] 1 as also, may I say, of your high mindedness.
('9', 447, 2, 8, 1020264) 2 passive resistance.
('9', 447, 2, 9, 1020286) Will you excuse me for saying that I know of no Indian, whether here, in South Africa or in India, who had so steadily, even defiantly, set his face against seditionas I understand it as I have.
('9', 447, 2, 10, 1020481) It is part of my faith not to have anything to do with it, even at the risk of my life.
('9', 447, 2, 11, 1020569) Most people, that is most Indians And Anglo Indians, express their detestation of bomb throwing and violence in words or in unreasonable action.
('9', 447, 2, 12, 1020714) The movement in the Transvaal, with which I have identified myself is an eloquent and standing protest in action against such methods.
('9', 447, 2, 13, 1020849) The test of passive resistance is self suffering and not infliction of suffering on others.
('9', 447, 2, 14, 1020941) We have, therefore, not only never received a single farthing from  the party of sedition in India or else where, but even if there was any offer, we should, if we were true to our principles, decline to receive it.
('9', 447, 2, 15, 1021157) We have hitherto made it a point not to approach the Indian public in India for financial assistance.
('9', 447, 2, 16, 1021259) The accounts of the British Indian Association are open to the world.

('9', 448, 1, 3, 1021540) 1 Mr. Doke, Mr. Phillips 2, and other notable men who are working in the Transvaal for us, know this fact most intimately.
('9', 448, 1, 4, 1021663) May I add, too, that the idea of passive resistance originated in South Africa was independent of any movement in India and that we have sometimes been bitterly assailed by some of our Indian friends for pinning our faith to passive resistance pure and simple?
('9', 448, 2, 5, 1021924) I hope Your Lordship will pardon me for introducing so much of the personal element, as also for the length of this letter, which was unavoidable.
('9', 448, 3, 6, 1022071) If any further elucidation or information be necessary, you can only add to the debt of gratitude to me by commanding [me to furnish the same.] 3
('9', 448, 4, 7, 1022217) Mr. Ritch points out that this explanation may not be quite clear to Your Lordship.
('9', 448, 4, 8, 1022301) He suggests my adding:
('9', 448, 5, 9, 1022324) The Immigration Law imposes an educational test on all immigrants white or black.
('9', 448, 5, 10, 1022406) The severity of the test is left to the discretion of the Immigration Officer.
('9', 448, 5, 11, 1022485) There will not be, there is not now, the same test for all.
('9', 448, 5, 12, 1022545) The officer, therefore, will set one test for Europeansand perhaps no test at all, as happens often in Nataland another for Indians.
('9', 448, 5, 13, 1022678) The Courts will not interfere with such exercise of discretion.General Smuts has said that the present Immigration Law does not give so wide a discretion as this to the Immigration Officer .
('9', 448, 5, 14, 1022869) If that be so, the law can easily be altered to extend the measure of discretion to the necessary degree.
('9', 448, 5, 15, 1022975) I have already submitted through Mr. Dallow an amendment which, in my opinion, would satisfactorily effect this.
('9', 448, 5, 16, 1023088) Mr. Smuts did not reject my amendment, but said that he did not consider it desirable to alter the law during that session (June last).
('9', 448, 5, 17, 1023224) Armed with the necessary powers, the Immigration Officer need admit only six Indians under the educational test.
('9', 448, 5, 18, 1023337) If a seventh applied, he can plough him by imposing a test impossible for him to pass, just as is done in Australia.

('9', 452, 3, 6, 1030329) SUFFRAGETTES
('9', 452, 4, 7, 1030342) Mr. Abdul Caadir, Mr. Hajee Habib and I attended a suffragette meeting.
('9', 452, 4, 8, 1030414) The St. James Hall was crowded to capacity by the women attending the meeting.
('9', 452, 4, 9, 1030493) According to Mr. Hajee Habibs estimate, there must have been about 1,500 persons, including men and women.
('9', 452, 4, 10, 1030600) Such meetings are held almost every week.
('9', 452, 4, 11, 1030642) A collection is made at every meeting, and at least 50 are received.
('9', 452, 4, 12, 1030711) At yesterdays meeting, it was 100. The meeting was held to honour some ladies who had been released from gaol.
('9', 452, 4, 13, 1030822) There were fourteen of them.
('9', 452, 4, 14, 1030851) They were presented silver medals.
('9', 452, 4, 15, 1030886) A dinner has also been arranged for them, for which tickets at one shilling each have been issued.
('9', 452, 4, 16, 1030985) The meeting was presided over by a lady named Mrs. Lawrence.
('9', 452, 4, 17, 1031046) All the speakers were women.
('9', 452, 4, 18, 1031075) All the arrangements were also made by them.
('9', 452, 4, 19, 1031120) Among those who had been to gaol, there were three or four who were mere girls of twenty or so.
('9', 452, 4, 20, 1031216) All of them had been arrested in the course of the campaign for the franchise.
('9', 452, 4, 21, 1031295) According to the practice here, the prisoners are placed in different classes.
('9', 452, 4, 22, 1031374) These women were awarded second class.
('9', 452, 4, 23, 1031413) It is their demand that they should be treated as firstclass prisoners.
('9', 452, 4, 24, 1031485) As the Government did not concede it, they resolved collecti vely to disobey the gaol regulations.
('9', 452, 4, 25, 1031584) They broke the windows of prison cells and refused to submit to any of the regulations.
('9', 452, 4, 26, 1031672) In consequence, they were confined in dark cells.
('9', 452, 4, 27, 1031722) There, too, they disregarded the gaolers orders.
('9', 452, 4, 28, 1031771) At last, all the women stopped taking food.
('9', 452, 4, 29, 1031815) One of them ate nothing for six days, some others for five days.
('9', 452, 4, 30, 1031880) In this way, everyone fasted.
('9', 452, 4, 31, 1031910) The Government felt helpless in the end and let them off.
('9', 452, 4, 32, 1031968) The women feel disappointed at this, and have declared that they will continue to go to gaol till all women like them are treated as first class prisoners.
('9', 452, 4, 33, 1032124) At this very meeting, the police served summonses on two of the women who had
('9', 453, 0, 1, 1032202) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 453, 1, 2, 1032244) been released, to answer a charge of having com mitted an assault while in gaol.
('9', 453, 1, 3, 1032325) The serving of the summonses was received with thunderous applause in the Hall.
('9', 453, 1, 4, 1032405) When we consider the suffering and the courage of these women, how can the Indian satyagrahis stand comparison with them?
('9', 453, 1, 5, 1032527) Their Association brings out a weekly of its own.
('9', 453, 1, 6, 1032577) It has a sale of 50,000, and a copy costs a penny.
('9', 453, 1, 7, 1032628) The contributors 1 are mostly women.
('9', 453, 1, 8, 1032665) Every week some women come forward as volunteers to go round selling copies.
('9', 453, 1, 9, 1032742) They receive no remuneration.
('9', 453, 1, 10, 1032772) Though all these ladies belong to good families, they are not ashamed of doing this work, but rather take pride in it.
('9', 453, 1, 11, 1032891) All of them turn out with ribbons on their shoulders bearing the words  Votes for Women printed on them.
('9', 453, 1, 12, 1032996) Besides bringing out this weekly, they have also published a number of other pamphlets.
('9', 453, 1, 13, 1033084) There are some women who, having offered their all in the service of this cause, now exert themselves physically.
('9', 453, 1, 14, 1033198) Some are highly educated women.
('9', 453, 1, 15, 1033230) They collect 3,000 in a year.
('9', 453, 1, 16, 1033260) They aim at collecting a total of 20,000. Their campaign has been going on for nearly five years.
('9', 453, 1, 17, 1033358) Its founda tions were laid a good many years ago, but it is during the last five years that they have been going to gaol in order to exert pressure.
('9', 453, 1, 18, 1033507) During this period, nearly 500 women have suffered imprisonment.
('9', 453, 1, 19, 1033572) Some of them have been to gaol more than once.
('9', 453, 1, 20, 1033619) All the [Associations] office bearers have been to gaol.
('9', 453, 1, 21, 1033676) They employ every means to get themselves imprisoned.
('9', 453, 1, 22, 1033730) So many years have passed, but they do not yield.
('9', 453, 1, 23, 1033780) They grow stronger every day.
('9', 453, 1, 24, 1033810) They think out new ways of harassing the Government, and some of the women have dedicated themselves entirely to this cause.
('9', 453, 1, 25, 1033935) Some are ready to die.
('9', 453, 1, 26, 1033958) They have taken a pledge that they must win.
('9', 453, 1, 27, 1034003) They would meet death rather than betray the pledge, so great is their spirit of determination.
('9', 453, 1, 28, 1034099) The systematic way in which they set about their work and their skill deserve the highest commendation.
('9', 453, 1, 29, 1034203) Their enthusiasm is unbounded.
('9', 453, 1, 30, 1034234) A great many men have been struck with admiration to see all this.
('9', 453, 1, 31, 1034301) Let Indians ask themselves whether it is anything to wonder at
('9', 453, 2, 32, 1034364) 1 The original has a word meaning those who assemble which appears to be a misprint for another word meaning those who write

('9', 454, 1, 2, 1034530) that we, in the Transvaal, have to wait a long time [for redress], have to suffer, fall ill in gaol or go hungry, even face death, when the British women have failed to get redress for such a long time and have to go through such suffering.

('9', 455, 3, 4, 1036597) SIR, Your correspondent South African has packed so much ignora nce into the letter published by you in your issue of the 21st ultimo, that he had need to conceal his identity,.
('9', 455, 3, 5, 1036775) May I correct a few of his misstatements?
('9', 455, 3, 6, 1036817) Mr. L. W. Ritch, though he calls me his friend and colleague, is notas your correspondent assumesan Indian.
('9', 455, 3, 7, 1036925) He is an English Jew and is at present practising as a barrister.
('9', 455, 3, 8, 1036991) The registration of Indians is a measure of identification, impugn ing the honesty of Indians as a class.
('9', 455, 3, 9, 1037097) The pass system with reference to the Kaffirs is somewhat of a taxing measure and in no way insulting in the same sense that the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907 is.
('9', 455, 3, 10, 1037263) There is as much difference between the Asiatic Registration Act and the Continental Passport system as there is between chalk and cheese.
('9', 455, 3, 11, 1037402) The Continental Passport is a protection to the holder and the non holding of it does not make him a criminal and liable to imprisonment with hard labour up to six months, whereas the non holding of registration certificates under the Asiatic Act by British Indians has sent already 2,500 Indians to gaol in the Transvaal.
('9', 455, 3, 12, 1037725) There are no Indian coolies in the Transvaal.
('9', 455, 3, 13, 1037771) The Indian trading community in Natalnotwithstanding your correspondents statement to the contraryhad no part in shaping the legislation in connection with the introduction of indentured Indian labour into that Colony.
('9', 455, 3, 14, 1037990) Your correspondents fiction is that every Indian in Natal lives at a cost of 10/ per month and a hut made of old tin linings of cases, whereas the fact, according to the borough valuation of Durban, is that the Indians hold substantial properties in that place, valued at nearly a million pounds, and that this very fact has been used against them by their European competitors in trade.

('9', 456, 2, 4, 1038750) described as perilously near to slavery.

('9', 457, 1, 13, 1042459) I believe, too, that the fullest expansion of national sentiment is quite consistent with the stability of British rule in India and I further believe that much of what we suffer in India is easy of remedy by effort from within.

('9', 458, 1, 2, 1043004) the British constitution, British subjects, no matter to what race they belong, have never got and never can get their rights until they have performed their corresponding duties and until they are willing to fight for them.
('9', 458, 1, 3, 1043229) The fight takes the form either of physical violence, as in the case of the extremists in India, or of personal suffering by the fighters, as in the case of our passive resisters in the Transvaal.
('9', 458, 1, 4, 1043426) In my opinion, the first form of seeking redress is largely barbarous and, in any case, inconsistent with the genius of the people of India, no because they are physically too weak to take that course, but because their training has adapted them to the latter mode, and I am free to confess that passive resistance in the Transvaal is a practical demonstration to the party of violence in India that they are entirely on the wrong track and that, so long as they pin their faith to violence for obtaining relief of any kind whatsoever, so long are they beating the air.
('9', 458, 2, 5, 1043996) I am quite aware that this exposition of my own view may not be of any use to Your Lordship and possibly is devoid of any interest whatsoever.
('9', 458, 2, 6, 1044139) The only reason why I mention it is to guard myself against being misunderstood.
('9', 458, 2, 7, 1044220) 1 I am most anxious not to withhold anything at all from Your Lordship and I am anxious also to retain, in any work that I undertake, the support of one who so loves the Empire and the country of my birth as yourself.
('9', 458, 3, 8, 1044438) With many thanks for the deep interest you are taking in our troubles and with apologies for the unavoidable length of this letter.

('9', 459, 3, 4, 1045374) GENERAL SMUTS SPEECH IN RICHMOND
('9', 459, 4, 5, 1045407) The following is a condensation of the speech.
('9', 459, 4, 6, 1045454) [February 5, 1908]
('9', 459, 5, 7, 1045473) In 1906, when the Government felt it right to put a stop to [the stream of immigrants,] .
('9', 459, 5, 8, 1045563) a law was introduced in the Legislative Council and passed.
('9', 459, 5, 9, 1045623) The object was to register in the most unmistakable way .
('9', 459, 5, 10, 1045681) every Asiatic who was legally entitled to be here.
('9', 459, 5, 11, 1045732) to give a definite status to the Indians who were here before the war and to see that the rest of Asia was kept out of the country .
('9', 459, 5, 12, 1045865) the Home Government would not .
('9', 459, 5, 13, 1045897) assent to the law.
('9', 459, 6, 14, 1045916) The first Parliament of the Transvaal met in March last and unanimously approved of [a similar bill and] it was assented to .
('9', 459, 7, 15, 1046042) The law 1 proposed that the Government should notify a period within which Asiatics [were to] register themselves....
('9', 459, 7, 16, 1046160) Of the 10,000 Indians in the country only 500 registered.
('9', 459, 8, 17, 1046218) Three alternatives remained .
('9', 459, 8, 18, 1046248) put them over the border; .
('9', 459, 8, 19, 1046276) they could have sent them all to prison; .
('9', 459, 8, 20, 1046319) or [go] to Parliament again .
('9', 459, 8, 21, 1046349) It was not easy putting men over the border.
('9', 459, 8, 22, 1046394) It was not a question for the Transvaal alone [Natal, Orange River Colony and Rhodesia having refused to admit coolies,] but an international question....
('9', 459, 8, 23, 1046549) The next alternative was to put the Indians in prison.
('9', 459, 8, 24, 1046604) He had sent every leader to prison, and hundreds more and it had had no impression.
('9', 459, 8, 25, 1046688) The policy of imprisonment was a very good policy as a threat, but .
('9', 459, 8, 26, 1046757) he defied any government to take 10,000 men by the collar and put them in prison here.
('9', 459, 9, 27, 1046844) [Imprisonment] was a course which was not only physically but morally impossible, .
('9', 459, 9, 28, 1046928) because it would injure the reputation and prestige of the white people of the Transvaal .
('9', 459, 9, 29, 1047019) The law of 1885 [too had] become a dead letter, and the result was that from 1885 to 1899 the Asiatics .
('9', 459, 9, 30, 1047124) paid no [fees for] licences and they did not bother about the laws .
('9', 459, 9, 31, 1047193) He wanted, by hook or by crook, to carry out the object of the law.
('9', 459, 9, 32, 1047261) He held out the olive branch.
('9', 459, 9, 33, 1047291) He told them that the law had expired, but that the Government would take their voluntary registration and lay it before Parliament .
('9', 459, 9, 34, 1047425) [The Indian leaders] accepted the suggestion .
('9', 459, 9, 35, 1047472) voluntary registration was the only course open.
('9', 459, 9, 36, 1047521) So he said All right, because there was nothing dishonourable to the Government in that .
('9', 459, 9, 37, 1047611) the position he took up from the start was that any means of identification for the Indian population of the Transvaal other than the 10 finger prints was insufficient .
('9', 459, 9, 38, 1047781) The Indians said they
('9', 459, 10, 39, 1047803) 1 Law 2 of 1907, also known as the Asiatic Registration Act
('9', 460, 0, 1, 1047863) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 461
('9', 460, 1, 2, 1047904) would never submit to that .
('9', 460, 1, 3, 1047933) they had now submitted, .
('9', 460, 1, 4, 1047959) they had learned more wisdom, and had seen that it was not criminal and not dishonourable .
('9', 460, 1, 5, 1048051) The Indians second contention was that they would never register until the law had been repealed, that the law was an indignity and disgrace.
('9', 460, 1, 6, 1048193) He had told them that the law would not be repealed so long as there was an Asiatic in the country who had not registered, and like wise men the leaders of the Indian community had waived the question of repeal .
('9', 460, 1, 7, 1048406) What could never be done by the Republican Government had now been done by a little give and take on both sides, and he thought the settlement was honourable to both sides .
('9', 460, 1, 8, 1048580) They had passed two laws .
('9', 460, 1, 9, 1048607) One was to register all the Indians who were here legally; the other was to close the door finally on the others .
('9', 460, 2, 10, 1048722) No Asiatic in future could come into this country unless he was a resident of the Transvaal before the war.
('9', 460, 2, 11, 1048830) The British Government had assented to this .
('9', 460, 2, 12, 1048876) it was the most drastic Asiatic Law that had ever been passed in the British Empire, .
('9', 460, 2, 13, 1048963) They knew that they belonged to a largely black Empire and that was a fact they must never forget .

('9', 460, 7, 19, 1049174) This Mass Meeting of British Indians hereby protests against the Asiatic Voluntary Registration Validation Bill now before the Parliament of the Transvaal, and endorses the Petition presented to the Honble the Legislative Assembly on behalf of the British Indian Association.
('9', 460, 7, 20, 1049450) Proposed by Mr. Dawad Mahomed (President, Natal Indian Congress)
('9', 460, 8, 21, 1049515) Seconded by Mr. Adam H. Gool Mahomed (President, British Indian League, Cape town), and Supported by Mr. Parsee Rustomjee (Vice President, Natal Indian Congress),

('9', 460, 10, 23, 1049734) Mr. V. A. Chettiar (Chairman, Tamil Benefit Society).
('9', 460, 11, 24, 1049788) RESOLUTION II
('9', 460, 12, 25, 1049802) This Mass Meeting of British Indians solemnly, sincerely, and prayerfully reaffirms the Resolution of the British Indian community not to submit to the Asiatic Act, which it considers to be contrary to religion and their conscience.
('9', 460, 12, 26, 1050035) proposed by Mr. Imam Abdool Kadir Bawazeer (Chairman, Hamidia Islamic Society),
('9', 461, 0, 1, 1050115) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 461, 1, 2, 1050157) Seconded by Mr. T. Naidoo and Maulvi Ahmed Mukhtar, and Supported by Messrs Ebrahim Aswat, Dildar Khan, E. M. Cachalia, R. K. Padiachy (Pretoria), V. Chetty, P. K. Naidoo, and M. P. Fancy
('9', 461, 2, 3, 1050345) RESOLUTION III
('9', 461, 3, 4, 1050360) This Mass Meeting of British Indians is of opinion that the Asiatic Voluntary Registration Validation Bill above referred to is a breach of the compromise entered into by the Government with the Asiatic communities, and hopes that the Colonists will demand an honourable fulfilment of the terms entered into by General Smuts on behalf of the Government of the Colony and in the name of the Colonists.
('9', 461, 3, 5, 1050761) Proposed fey Mr. Abdul Rahman (Potchefstroom)
('9', 461, 4, 6, 1050807) Seconded by Mr. E. M. Patel (Vereeniging), and

('9', 461, 6, 8, 1050928) A.E. Chhotabhai (Krugersdorp), and Amod Suliman Khota (Heidelberg)
('9', 461, 7, 9, 1050995) RESOLUTION IV
('9', 461, 8, 10, 1051009) This Mass Meeting of British Indians hereby authorizes the Chairman to forward copies of these Resolutions to the proper quarters.

('9', 461, 10, 13, 1051179) GENERAL SMUTS SPEECH IN LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY 1
('9', 461, 11, 14, 1051226) [PRETORIA, August 21, 1908]
('9', 461, 12, 15, 1051254) Members will remember that under the Crown Colony Government of 1906 a law was passed, which, however, failed to carry the assent of His Majesty the King and in March, 1907, the law .
('9', 461, 12, 16, 1051438) was passed without any alterations by the Legislature of the Transvaal.
('9', 461, 12, 17, 1051510) That law came into force last year.
('9', 461, 12, 18, 1051546) Different dates were proclaimed .
('9', 461, 12, 19, 1051580) under it for the registration of Asiatics in this country, but .
('9', 461, 12, 20, 1051645) the Asiatics organized a movement of passive resistance, and registration under that law proved .
('9', 461, 12, 21, 1051743) a failure.
('9', 461, 12, 22, 1051754) not more than 600 had registered by the time that the dates for registration expired, which was June 30 of last year.
('9', 461, 12, 23, 1051872) That was a very awkward and, in some senses, a very dangerous state of affairs.
('9', 461, 12, 24, 1051952) There is no more awkward position for a Government than a movement of passive resistance.
('9', 461, 12, 25, 1052042) It is a movement which is really tantamount to an act of war, and really amounts to a state of anarchy so far as the Government is concerned.
('9', 461, 12, 26, 1052184) In more primitive times one would have met it by simply issuing a declaration of war....
('9', 461, 12, 27, 1052273) I did my best ...
('9', 461, 12, 28, 1052291) to carry out the law ...
('9', 461, 12, 29, 1052316) and as a result early this year many Asiatics were languishing in prisons .
('9', 461, 12, 30, 1052392) finally I met some of the leaders of the Asiatic community and discussed the question with them, and the result was that, pending the meeting of this House, temporary

('9', 462, 1, 4, 1052905) up to date practically every Asiatic in the country ...
('9', 462, 1, 5, 1052961) has made application for registration....
('9', 462, 1, 6, 1053003) the applications numbered 9,158 .

('9', 462, 1, 8, 1053197) The small number of 171 applications have not yet been decided.

('9', 462, 1, 22, 1054020) They say: Our opposition has never been directed so much against the finger print requirements.
('9', 462, 1, 23, 1054116)  Then there is some reference to the relaxation of the finger prints.
('9', 462, 1, 24, 1054186) This offer was accepted by me, and from it two questions have arisen: the first whether the permission was given to repeal the Act.
('9', 462, 1, 25, 1054318) I do not think that any court of law could put such an interpretation on my promise.
('9', 462, 1, 26, 1054403) The consequence was that an Asiatic who registered voluntarily could do so under another Act, and not under Act 2 [of 1907].
('9', 462, 1, 27, 1054528) The Asiatics took the matter to the [Supreme] Court, and Sir William Solomon took the view that the interpretation of the agreement was entirely different from the construction which the Asiatics placed upon it.
('9', 462, 1, 28, 1054740) Well, Sir, it was then stated that, although this correspondence contained no compromise to repeal tile Act, yet in interviews which I had with Mr. Gandhi, I promised to repeal it.
('9', 462, 1, 29, 1054921) That is not so, and the impression may be the result of a misconception....
('9', 462, 1, 30, 1054997) The second difficulty arose in consequence of the provision that voluntary registration should also apply to those Asiatics who .
('9', 462, 1, 31, 1055127) were out of the Colony but who were entitled .
('9', 462, 1, 32, 1055174) to return .
('9', 462, 1, 33, 1055186) My answer .
('9', 462, 1, 34, 1055198) was that there was a compromise made for a specific periodthree monthspending the meeting of Parliament.

('9', 462, 1, 39, 1055718) provision should be made whereby Asiatics who could pass a slight education test under the Immigration Act should be allowed to .
('9', 462, 1, 40, 1055848) enter the country.

('9', 462, 1, 42, 1055932) hear!) .
('9', 462, 1, 43, 1055941) Large numbers of people who otherwise were undesirable would be free to enter the country, and that I would never allow.

('9', 464, 4, 5, 1060310) RESOLUTION I
('9', 464, 5, 6, 1060323) Mr. Dawad Mahomed, Chairman of the Natal Indian Congress, moved:
('9', 464, 6, 7, 1060388) This Mass Meeting of British Indians respectfully prays that the Government will be pleased to exercise the clemency of the Crown and allow Mr. Sorabjee Shapurjee, who was permitted to cross the border unchallenged under the Immigrants Restriction Act and who was brought under the operation of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, to return, and trusts that the disputes outstanding between the Government and the British Indians will be amicably settled, and that the Government will be pleased to recognize the status of British Indians as part of the Empire, and give the community the rest and peace to which, in the humble opinion of this Meeting, it is entitled.
