('9', 464, 15, 20, 1062130) He thought they might also congratulate the Indian natives in the Transvaal, because the courage, unity and consistency with which they had
('9', 465, 0, 1, 1062270) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 465, 1, 2, 1062312) pursued their end were not less admirable than the moderation and modesty with which they had put forward their demands...
('9', 465, 1, 3, 1062435) No one ...
('9', 465, 1, 4, 1062446) acquainted with the subject could doubt that the Indians were reasonable in their objections to these regulations ....
('9', 465, 1, 5, 1062565) but he blamed His Majestys Government for having allowed the situation to reach such an alarming pitch.
('9', 465, 1, 6, 1062669) Thus far the only explanation they had received from members of the Government was that it was impossible to interfere with a self governing colony.
('9', 465, 1, 7, 1062818) He protested against the misuse of the word interfere; for if by interference was meant the insistence by the Mother Country on the rights of individual citizens of the Empire, we were as much justified in interfering with a self governing colony as we were in interfering with foreign nations in such case, as we often did..
('9', 465, 1, 8, 1063144) why, then, was Indian slavery ignored?
('9', 465, 1, 9, 1063183) He used the term advisedly, for members of the Government and their supporters had defined as marks of slavery identification by finger prints, inability to hold fixed property, and relegation to Compounds...
('9', 465, 1, 10, 1063392) Nobody denied the right of the Colonists to manage their own affairs, but they must remember that they were partners in a great Empire and that their interests must not be pursued in such a manner as to injure the other partners.
('9', 465, 2, 11, 1063622) We had a right to insist that the Imperial point of view should be considered; and the Imperial point of view required that for the safety and honour of the Empire British citizens, whatever their colour, should be treated as such.
('9', 465, 2, 12, 1063854) British citizens ought not to be oppressed and degraded ...
('9', 465, 2, 13, 1063914) If the Colonies were inadvertently to get us into trouble with India, they would do us as much, or even more, harm than if they got us into trouble with foreign nations..
('9', 465, 2, 14, 1064085) Therefore, it was the business of Imperial statesmanship to explain these considerations to the Colonies.
('9', 465, 2, 15, 1064191) Why was this not done at the Imperial Conference last summer, when all the Colonial Premiers were here?
('9', 465, 2, 16, 1064295) As to the registration of finger prints, why did not His Majestys Government refer to the Indian Government and ask what system was adopted there?
('9', 465, 2, 17, 1064442) Instead of that, they allowed the Transvaal Government to tell them what they thought the practice was in India; and the Transvaal Government told them wrong ...
('9', 465, 2, 18, 1064604) In India the thumb and forefinger of the left hand only were registered; the ten finger system was confined in India to criminals alone ....
('9', 465, 2, 19, 1064745) The attitude of His Majestys Government was, first, timorous protest, and then reluctant assent to all that the Colonies did.
('9', 465, 3, 20, 1064871) EXTRACTS FROM LORD CURZONS SPEECH
('9', 465, 4, 21, 1064905) The question came before us in India in a twofold aspect in relation both to Natal and the Transvaal.
('9', 465, 4, 22, 1065007) The Government of Natal...sent a deputation....
('9', 465, 4, 23, 1065055) to ask us to agree to the repatriation of [indentured] labourers...
('9', 465, 4, 24, 1065123) We were willing.....
('9', 465, 4, 25, 1065144) provided we could.
('9', 465, 4, 26, 1065163) secure the relaxation of the hardships....
('9', 465, 4, 27, 1065206) under which the free.....
('9', 465, 4, 28, 1065232) Indian population of Natal then laboured....
('9', 465, 4, 29, 1065277) the Natal Government declined to accept our proposals....Your Lordships are all aware of the cruel and disabling restrictions...
('9', 465, 4, 30, 1065406) placed upon the Indian population in [the Transvaal].
('9', 465, 4, 31, 1065460) They were one of the..
('9', 465, 4, 32, 1065483) causes of the war.
('9', 465, 4, 33, 1065502) As soon as the war was over we felt it our duty....to address the then Secretary of State upon the subject ....
('9', 465, 4, 34, 1065614) A little later Lord Milner came to us with a request....
('9', 465, 4, 35, 1065671) for 10,000 and afterwards....
('9', 465, 4, 36, 1065701) 20,000 [Indians] to inaugurate railway labour in the new
('9', 466, 0, 1, 1065758) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 467
('9', 466, 1, 2, 1065799) possessions ....
('9', 466, 1, 3, 1065816) We agreed..
('9', 466, 1, 4, 1065828) and once again....
('9', 466, 1, 5, 1065847) used the position to endeavour to get better terms for the free Indians in the Transvaal.
('9', 466, 1, 6, 1065937) I am sorry to say that we failed.
('9', 466, 2, 7, 1065971) [the compromise] is one that seems....
('9', 466, 2, 8, 1066010) honourable to both parties....the Bluebook....
('9', 466, 2, 9, 1066057) leaves a rather disagreeable taste in the mouth....
('9', 466, 2, 10, 1066109) [The Transvaal Government] rushed through their anti Indian legislation with...almost indecent speed.
('9', 466, 2, 11, 1066211) Secondly, there was failure....on the part of General Botha to act up to the undertaking....to find some method of identification superior to that of finger impressions....
('9', 466, 2, 12, 1066384) Hear!) ....
('9', 466, 2, 13, 1066396) the system and method of finger impressions that were proposed in the Transvaal were undoubtedly humiliating ....
('9', 466, 2, 14, 1066510) Then....there was a failure on the part of the Transvaal Government to distinguish....between....
('9', 466, 2, 15, 1066608) Indians of good social status and refined education and the Indians of lower class....
('9', 466, 2, 16, 1066695) whose competition really had to be feared.
('9', 466, 2, 17, 1066738) That is the charge..
('9', 466, 2, 18, 1066759) which we are justified in bringing against the authorities in the Transvaal ....
('9', 466, 2, 19, 1066840) Well, we have now arrived at a settlement of the question; but I imagine that His Majestys Government will be the last to argue that that temporary settlement is a final settlement of the question.
('9', 466, 2, 20, 1067038) I am sure that your lordships realize that this question is in reality about the most momentous and the most far reaching which could possibly confront any body of statesmen.
('9', 466, 3, 21, 1067213) Let me....
('9', 466, 3, 22, 1067224) state to your lordships...
('9', 466, 3, 23, 1067251) the Indian point of view....
('9', 466, 3, 24, 1067280) the Indian coolie.
('9', 466, 3, 25, 1067299) .sees that [he is] invited and even encouraged by our Government to emigrate....
('9', 466, 3, 26, 1067380) to a colony which he enriches by his labour, and then society there appears to turn round upon him and treat him as if he were a pariah dog.
('9', 466, 3, 27, 1067521) He is penalized there, not for his vices, but for his virtues..
('9', 466, 3, 28, 1067585) And then the Indian remembers that...he has fought for the British Empire..
('9', 466, 3, 29, 1067661) and that it was largely owing to his efforts that Natal was saved ....
('9', 466, 3, 30, 1067732) Now...he claims the full rights of citizenship of the British Empire.
('9', 466, 3, 31, 1067802) I do not think it is for us to blame him for that .
('9', 466, 3, 32, 1067854) it is, after all, the only basis upon which you will expect the loyalty of an Asiatic population to an alien rule to be permanently developed or maintained.
('9', 466, 4, 33, 1068011) ....The colonial point of view is entirely different ....
('9', 466, 4, 34, 1068069) I realize that.....in a way, it is quite unanswerable....if [the Colonist] is selfish it is only in the pursuit of....self preservation ....
('9', 466, 4, 35, 1068210) He declines to acquiesce in any system which will mean...
('9', 466, 4, 36, 1068268) a permanent lowering of the standard of life, and he feels...the danger of being confronted with an enormous black problem...and...a great brown problem as well...it appears that you have two forces..
('9', 466, 4, 37, 1068469) .pulling in opposite directions within the framework of the same Empire ....
('9', 466, 5, 38, 1068546) In these circumstances what is the duty of the Government?...They can endeavour.
('9', 466, 5, 39, 1068627) to reconcile these opposing factors and principles.
('9', 466, 5, 40, 1068679) and anyhow .
('9', 466, 5, 41, 1068692) endeavour to work that there should be...
('9', 466, 5, 42, 1068734) no clash...
('9', 466, 5, 43, 1068746) between that ....
('9', 466, 5, 44, 1068764) In the first place they can so see.
('9', 466, 5, 45, 1068800) that fair terms are invariably secured for the labourer or the emigrant when he goes out...and, should his return be desired, for his return when it is to come about.
('9', 466, 5, 46, 1068967) It is for the Government to see that a good bargain is made for its own subjects.
('9', 466, 5, 47, 1069049) the bargain once made, to see that the terms are not hastily or rashly altered at a later date to the detriment of the man....Then...the Government
('9', 467, 0, 1, 1069197) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 467, 1, 2, 1069239) ought to see that the restrictions imposed upon Asiatics are made as little vexatious as possible....Then ..
('9', 467, 1, 3, 1069348) .they ought to see that nowhere shall occur the painful situation of Indian gentlemen ...of character, respectability, and education, being treated as if they were common coolies...and herded together...with men of very much lower status and occupation than themselves.
('9', 467, 1, 4, 1069618) ( Cheers.
('9', 467, 1, 5, 1069628) There is another suggestion which has been madenamely, that the Government should try to discover...some other field of emigration to which our Indian fellow subjects may go, free from the disabilities and restrictions to which I have alluded..
('9', 467, 1, 6, 1069873) .for my own part, it is one which I do not look upon with quite so much favour as some of the authorities who have taken it up.
('9', 467, 1, 7, 1070001) In any case I hope that the recent proceedings which have culminated in the victory...for our Indian fellow subjects .
('9', 467, 1, 8, 1070120) may read a lesson.
('9', 467, 1, 9, 1070139) both to the Government of the Colony and to the Government which sits on the bencha lesson to the Government of the Colony that it cannot afford to treat without the utmost consideration the rights of these immigrants.
('9', 467, 1, 10, 1070358) ; a lesson to His Majestys Government that they owe a duty just as great to the dusky millions of India as they owe to the white people of their own race in any colony of the British Crown.
('9', 467, 1, 11, 1070548) (Cheers.) Indian Opinion, 7 3 1908

('9', 468, 3, 4, 1071904) APPENDIX VII
('9', 468, 4, 5, 1071917) ASIATICS REGISTRATION AMENDMENT ACT (1908)
('9', 468, 5, 6, 1071960) FULL TEXT
('9', 468, 6, 7, 1071970) We print below the full text of the Act To validate the Voluntary Registration of certain Asiatics who failed to comply with the provisions of Act No.
('9', 468, 6, 8, 1072121) 2 of 1907 and to make further provision for the registration of Asiatics, recently passed by the Transvaal Parliament:
('9', 468, 7, 9, 1072240) Be it enacted by the Kings Most Excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly of the Transvaal as follows:
('9', 468, 8, 10, 1072406) 1. In this Act unless inconsistent with the context:
('9', 468, 9, 11, 1072459) adult shall mean of the age of sixteen years or over;
('9', 468, 10, 12, 1072513) application for registration shall mean an application to be placed on the register of Asiatics made in the manner and form prescribed by regulation and accompanied by the particulars and means of identification required by regulation; Asiatic shall mean any male person belonging to one of the native races of Asia and shall include a coolie, an Arab and a Malay but shall not include
('9', 468, 11, 13, 1072899) (a) a Malay born and resident in any British Colony or possession in South Africa; or
('9', 468, 12, 14, 1072985) (b) a person introduced into this Colony under the Labour Importation Ordinance 1904; or
('9', 468, 13, 15, 1073074) (c) an officer of any consular service;
('9', 468, 14, 16, 1073114) certificate of registration shall mean a certificate of registration under Act No.
('9', 468, 14, 17, 1073197) 2 of 1907, or a certificate under this Act in the form set forth in the Schedule to this Act or as prescribed by regulation;
('9', 468, 15, 18, 1073322) commencement of this Act shall mean the date on which Act came into operation;
('9', 468, 16, 19, 1073401) Governor shall mean the officer for the time being administering theGovernment of this Colony acting by and with the advice and consent of the Executive Council thereof;
('9', 468, 17, 20, 1073571) guardian shall mean the parent of a minor Asiatic or any other person under
('9', 469, 0, 1, 1073647) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 469, 1, 2, 1073689) whose care such minor is living for the time being, or failing any such person the employer of such minor;
('9', 469, 2, 3, 1073796) lawful holder as used in relation to any certificate of registration shall mean the person (other than a minor named therein) whose registration is thereby certified;
('9', 469, 3, 4, 1073963) minor shall mean under the age of sixteen years;
('9', 469, 4, 5, 1074012) register of Asiatics shall mean the register to be kept for purposes of this
('9', 469, 5, 6, 1074089) Act in manner prescribed by regulation;
('9', 469, 6, 7, 1074129) registrar shall mean the officer appointed by the Governor to keep the register of Asiatics and any person lawfully acting in such capacity; regulation shall mean any regulation made under Section seventeen of this Act;
('9', 469, 7, 8, 1074349) unregistered Asiatic shall mean an adult Asiatic who is not the holder of a certificate of registration.
('9', 469, 9, 9, 1074454) VALIDATION OF VOLUNTARY REGISTRATION
('9', 469, 10, 10, 1074491) 2. (1) Every person
('9', 469, 11, 11, 1074511) (a) who is an Asiatic as defined by Act No.
('9', 469, 11, 12, 1074555) 2 of 1907; and
('9', 469, 12, 13, 1074570) (b) by or in respect of whom an application for registration was on the tenth day of February 1908, or on any day subsequent thereto up till the tenth day of May 1908, made to the registrar or other duly authorised officer; and
('9', 469, 13, 14, 1074798) (c) to or in respect of whom a certificate in the form set forth in the Schedule to this Act was issued by the registrar;
('9', 469, 14, 15, 1074920) shall, when in possession of such certificate, be deemed to be lawful holder of a certificate entitling him to enter and reside in the Colony.
('9', 469, 15, 16, 1075063) (2) Every person who, having been the lawful holder of a certificate of registration under Act No.
('9', 469, 15, 17, 1075162) 2 of 1907, has been permitted to obtain a certificate in the form in the Schedule to this Act in substitution for such first mentioned certificate, shall also be deemed to be the lawful holder of a certificate entitling him to enter and reside in this Colony.
('9', 469, 16, 18, 1075422) (3) Every Asiatic who holds any certificate mentioned in this section shall be subject in all respects to the provisions of this Act and not to the provisions of Act No.
('9', 469, 16, 19, 1075592) 2 of 1907.
('9', 469, 17, 20, 1075603) PART II
('9', 469, 18, 21, 1075611) REGISTRATION OF ASIATICS AFTER THE COMMENCEMENT OF THIS ACT
('9', 469, 19, 22, 1075671) 3. An Asiatic shall be entitled to registration under this Act if
('9', 469, 20, 23, 1075737) (a) he satisfies the conditions described in sub sections (2) or (3) of Section four, whether he was or was not in this Colony at the
('9', 470, 0, 1, 1075871) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 471
('9', 470, 1, 2, 1075912) commencement of this Act; or
('9', 470, 2, 3, 1075941) (b) being the lawful holder of a certificate of registration issued under Act No.
('9', 470, 2, 4, 1076023) 2 of 1907, he desires to exchange such certificate for a certificate of registration under this Act; or
('9', 470, 3, 5, 1076127) (c) having been a minor resident in this Colony at the commencement of this Act, he first entered the Colony with an adult Asiatic who was his guardian and who was registered under Law No.
('9', 470, 3, 6, 1076316) 3 of 1885 or any amendment thereof or is registered or entitled to registration under this Act; or
('9', 470, 4, 7, 1076415) (d) he was born in any part of South Africa which was at the date of his birth within the boundaries of the Transvaal.
('9', 470, 5, 8, 1076534) 4. (1) Every unregistered adult Asiatic resident in this Colony at the commencement of this Act shall before such date or dates and at such place or places and to such person or persons as the Colonial Secretary may by notice in the Gazette prescribe for particular areas of this Colony, make application for registration, and the registrar shall, on being satisfied that such Asiatic is entitled to registration, issue to him a certificate of registration.
('9', 470, 6, 9, 1076992) (2) Every unregistered adult Asiatic resident outside the Colony at the commencement of this Act, shall,
('9', 470, 7, 10, 1077097) (a) if he was resident in the Transvaal for three years prior to the eleventh day of October 1899; and
('9', 470, 8, 11, 1077200) (b) upon application for registration from a place in South Africa but outside the Colony within one year after the commencement of this Act; and
('9', 470, 9, 12, 1077346) (c) upon satisfying the registrar of the facts mentioned in this sub section: be entitled to obtain a certificate of registration.
('9', 470, 10, 13, 1077477) (3) Every unregistered adult Asiatic resident outside this Colony at the commencment of this Act but who was
('9', 470, 11, 14, 1077586) (a) duly authorised to enter and reside in this Colony by a permit issued under the Indemnity and Peace Preservation Ordinance 1902 or any amendment thereof or issued between the first day of September 1900 and the date of the passing of the said Ordinance (unless such permit shall have been fraudulently obtained); or
('9', 470, 12, 15, 1077906) (b) was resident and actually in this Colony on the thirty first day of May 1902;
('9', 470, 13, 16, 1077988) shall be entitled, upon satisfying the registrar of the fact set forth in paragraph (a) or (b) of this sub section and upon application for registration from a place in South Africa but outside the Colony, to obtain a certificate of registration.
('9', 471, 0, 1, 1078235) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 471, 1, 2, 1078277) MINOR ASIATICS
('9', 471, 2, 3, 1078292) 5. In respect of every unregistered minor Asiatic born in this Colony, not being the child of a labourer introduced into this Colony under the Labour Importation Ordinance 1904, the following provisions shall apply:
('9', 471, 3, 4, 1078508) (1) If his guardian is an Asiatic, the minors name, his age, his residence and his relationship to his guardian shall be included in the certificate of registration of his guardian.
('9', 471, 4, 5, 1078690) (2) Within one month after such minor attains the age of sixteen years,he shall make application to the registrar for a certificate of registration; provided that, if he be absent from the Colony on attaining that age or one month thereafter, he may, from a place in South Africa but outside the Colony, make application to the registrar for registration and upon satisfying the registrar that he is entitled to registration, the registrar shall issue to him a certificate of registration, and his name shall thereupon be expunged from the register of Asiatics as a minor and shall be deemed to be no longer included in his guardians certificate of registration.
('9', 471, 5, 6, 1079353) 6. (1) Whenever the registrar is satisfied that any Asiatic claiming to be entitled to registration under Section three is not so entitled, he shall refuse to issue to him a certificate of registration, and notice of the refusal shall be sent by post to such Asiatic at the address given upon his form of application.
('9', 471, 6, 7, 1079671) (2) In every case of refusal by the registrar to issue a certificate of registration, an appeal may, within fourteen days of the date of the notice of refusal, he noted by letter addressed to the Colonial Secretary, and such appeal shall be heard by a magistrate specially assigned by the Governor to hear such appeals, and such magistrate shall be deemed, when hearing any such appeal, to be an inferior court within the meaning of Section nineteen of the Administration of Justice Proclamation 1902.
('9', 471, 7, 8, 1080173) (3) In the case of an Asiatic who is in South Africa but outside this Colony, the officer in charge of the Immigration Department shall, as soon as the date has been fixed for the hearing of such appeal, send by post to the appellant at the address given upon his application for registration a temporary permit entitling him to enter and remain in the Colony until the appeal has been determined.
('9', 471, 7, 9, 1080571) If the appeal be dismissed, the said magistrate shall make an order in writing directing the appellant to be removed from the Colony, and every such order shall be deemed to be an order made under Section six of the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 or any amendment thereof.
('9', 471, 8, 10, 1080845) (4) In the case of an adult Asiatic in the Colony who has not within a period prescribed by sub section (2) of this section noted an appeal or whose appeal having been noted has not been proceeded with or has been dismissed, the said magistrate shall make an order in writing directing such Asiatic to be
('9', 472, 0, 1, 1081150) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 473
('9', 472, 1, 2, 1081191) removed from the Colony, and every such order shall be deemed to be an order made under Section six of the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 or any amendment thereof.
('9', 472, 2, 3, 1081356) REMOVAL FROM THE COLONY
('9', 472, 3, 4, 1081380) 7. Any adult Asiatic who, after such date or dates as may be notified by the Colonial Secretary in the Gazette, is found within the Colony and fails, upon such demand as is mentioned in Section nine, to produce a certificate of registration of which he is the lawful holder, may be arrested without warrant and brought before a resident or assistant resident magistrate and if he fails to satisfy such magistrate that he is the lawful holder of a certificate of registration or that the time within which he is required to make application for such certificate has not expired the magistrate shall, save as in the next succeeding section is provided, make an order in writing directing him to be removed from this Colony and every order shall be deemed to be an order under Section six of the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 or any amendment thereof.
('9', 472, 4, 5, 1082231) 8. If an adult Asiatic who has failed to make application for registration in accordance with the provisions of sub sections (1) of Section four shall satisfy the magistrate before whom he is brought that such failureness due to some good and sufficient cause, the magistrate may, instead of making such order as aforesaid, direct such Asiatic forthwith to make application for registration within eight days, and if such Asiatic shall comply with such direction, his application shall be dealt with in all respects as if it had been made in accordance with the provisions of the said sub section and all the provisions of this Act which would have applied if the application had been so made shall apply accordingly, but, if he shall fail to comply with such directions, the magistrate shall make an order for removal as aforesaid in respect of such Asiatic and any such order shall be deemed to be an order made under Section six of the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 or any amendment thereof.
('9', 472, 5, 6, 1083228) Part III
('9', 472, 6, 7, 1083237) GENERAL AND MISCELLANEOUS
('9', 472, 7, 8, 1083263) 9. Every Asiatic who enters or is within this Colony shall, upon demand made upon him by any European member of a police force lawfully established therein or by any other European person authorised thereto by the Colonial Secretary, produce the certificate of registration of which he is the lawful holder, and shall also on like demand supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification as may be prescribed by regulation.
('9', 472, 7, 9, 1083702) Any Asiatic who fails upon lawful demand to produce such certificate shall, unless he is the lawful holder of a certificate of registration, be liable to be dealt with in manner mentioned in Section eight.
('9', 472, 8, 10, 1083908) 10. (1) If at any time any certificate of registration is lost or destroyed, the person to whom it was issued shall forthwith apply to the registrar to have the same renewed and the registrar shall, upon compliance by such person with
('9', 473, 0, 1, 1084143) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 473, 1, 2, 1084185) such procedure as is prescribed by regulation and upon payment of a fee of five shillings, renew the certificate.
('9', 473, 1, 3, 1084299) Such fee shall be denoted by means of revenue stamps to be affixed to the application for renewal and shall be defaced by the said registrar.
('9', 473, 2, 4, 1084441) (2) Any person into whose hands shall have come any such certificate shall, unless he is the person to whom it was issued, forthwith deliver or transmit the same as soon as may be to the Registrar of Asiatics, Pretoria.
('9', 473, 3, 5, 1084661) 11. Every certificate of registration shall be accepted as conclusive evidence in all places that the lawful holder thereof is entitled to enter and reside in this Colony; provided that this section shall not apply to persons who have, under Section five or six of the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 or any amendment thereof, been removed from the Colony.
('9', 473, 4, 6, 1085018) 12. Whenever, in any prosecution or other proceeding under this Act the age of any Asiatic is in question such Asiatic shall unless and until the contrary be proved be taken to be of the age which the registrar shall in any certificate issued under his hand certify to be in his opinion the apparent age of such Asiatic.
('9', 473, 5, 7, 1085339) 13. Any affidavit or sworn declaration which is required by regulation to be made by any person who makes an application for registration shall be exempt from stamp duty.
('9', 473, 6, 8, 1085510) TRADING LICENCES
('9', 473, 7, 9, 1085527) 14. (1) No Asiatic shall obtain any trading licence under the Revenue Licences Ordinance 1905 or any amendment thereof or under any bye law or regulation in force within the jurisdiction of a local authority, unless he produce to the person appointed to issue the licence a certificate of registra tion of which he is the lawful holder and either give his signature in English or supply such other or additional particulars or furnish such means of identification as the Colonial Secretary may either generally or in particular cases prescribe.
('9', 473, 8, 10, 1086072) (2) Any trading licences issued under such Ordinance or under any such bye law or regulation Between the tenth day of February 1908 and the commencement of this Act to an Asiatic who made such application as is prescribed in sub section (1) (b) of Section two of this Act shall, notwithstanding anything in Section thirteen of Act No.
('9', 473, 8, 11, 1086407) 2 of 1907 contained, be deemed to have been lawfully issued.
('9', 473, 8, 12, 1086468) (3) Section thirteen of Act No.
('9', 473, 8, 13, 1086500) 2 of 1907 shall be and is hereby repealed.
('9', 473, 9, 14, 1086543) THE PENALTIES
('9', 473, 10, 15, 1086557) 15. Any person who
('9', 473, 11, 16, 1086576) (a) for the purpose of or in connection with an application for registration or for the purpose of obtaining a certificate of registration, commits any
('9', 474, 0, 1, 1086728) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 475
('9', 474, 1, 2, 1086769) fraudulent act, or makes any false statement or false pretence;
('9', 474, 2, 3, 1086833) (b) forges or prior to the commencement of this Act has forged any document in the form set forth in the Schedule to this Act or forges any certificate of regist ration or utters any such document or certificate knowing the same to be forged; or
('9', 474, 3, 4, 1087079) (c) uses or attempts to use as a certificate of registration any such forged document or any such certificate of which he is not the lawful holder;
('9', 474, 4, 5, 1087227) shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding five hundred pounds or, in default of payment, to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding two years or to both such fine and imprisonment, and any person who incites to, or aids or abets any other person in, the commission of any such offence shall be liable to the like penalty.
('9', 474, 5, 6, 1087600) TEMPORARY PERMITS
('9', 474, 6, 7, 1087618) 16. Notwithstanding anything in the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 or this Act contained, the Governor may approve the issue of a permit, in the form prescribed by regulation, authorising an Asiatic to enter and remain in the Colony for any period named in such permit, and after the expiry of such period the person in respect of whom such permit was issued shall be deemed to be a person not duly authorised to be in this Colony, and if found may be arrested without warrant and the provisions of Section six of the Immigrants Restriction Act or any amendment thereof shall apply to such person as if he were a person mentioned in paragraph (c) thereof.
('9', 474, 6, 8, 1088275) THE GOVERNORS POWERS
('9', 474, 7, 9, 1088296) 17. The Governor may from time to time make, alter, or rescind regulations for any of the following purposes: (1) Prescribing the form of the register to be kept for the purposes of this Act.
('9', 474, 7, 10, 1088488) (2) Prescribing the manner and form in which application shall be made for registration, the particulars to be supplied and the means of identification to be furnished by any applicant for the purpose of or in connection with such application.
('9', 474, 7, 11, 1088732) (3) Prescribing the form of certificates of registration.
('9', 474, 7, 12, 1088790) (4) Prescribing the particulars to be supplied and the means of identification to be furnished (a) by any Asiatic upon such demand as is mentioned in Section nine;
('9', 474, 8, 13, 1088954) (b) by any Asiatic applying for the renewal of any certificate of registration which has been lost or destroyed.
('9', 474, 8, 14, 1089067) (5) Prescribing the procedure to be observed on or in connection with appeals to the magistrate mentioned in Section six.
('9', 474, 8, 15, 1089189) (6) Prescribing the form of permit to be issued under Section sixteen.
('9', 474, 9, 16, 1089260) (7) Generally for the better carrying out of the objects and purposes of this Act.
('9', 475, 0, 1, 1089343) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 475, 1, 2, 1089385) 18. Any Asiatic or the guardian of any Asiatic failing to comply with any requirement of this Act or of the regulations shall, except where otherwise specified, be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding one hundred pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('9', 475, 1, 3, 1089723) 19. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in sub section (b) of Law No.
('9', 475, 1, 4, 1089798) 3 of 1885 as amended by Volksraad Resolution Article 1419 of the twelfth day of August 1886 the portion of Erf No.
('9', 475, 1, 5, 1089913) 373 Church Street, Pretoria which was registered in the name of the late Aboobaker Amod and which at the commencement of this Act was registered in the name of Henry Salomon Leon Polak may be transferred into the name of the heirs of the said Aboobaker Amod.
('9', 475, 1, 6, 1090172) 20. This Act may be cited for all purposes as the Asiatics Registration Amendment Act 1908 and shall not come into operation unless and until the Governor shall have declared by proclamation in the Gazette that it is His Majestys pleasure not to disallow the Act and thereafter it shall come into operation on such date as the Governor shall by like proclamation declare.

('9', 476, 5, 9, 1091985) APPENDIX IX
('9', 476, 6, 10, 1091997) P. DUNCAN ON COLOUR QUESTION
('9', 476, 7, 11, 1092026) Mr. Patrick Duncan, C.M.G., spoke by invitation on the colour question at the annual meeting of the Rosebank branch of the League of Women.
('9', 476, 7, 12, 1092166) We take the following important extracts from the report of the speech given in The Star dated the 5th instant [September, 1908]:
('9', 476, 8, 13, 1092296) It was a very difficult matter in a country where there was supposed to be political freedom to have the largest section of the population entirely deprived of political rightsit was practically a condition of slavery.
('9', 476, 8, 14, 1092515) No people had ever been able to survive for long who lived on an inferior race in what was practically a state of slavery.
('9', 476, 8, 15, 1092638) It was bad for the superior race just as much as for the inferior.
('9', 476, 8, 16, 1092705) If they looked into the cases where a small superior population lived on the work of the larger inferior population, giving them no political rights, that state of things did not exist for long.
('9', 476, 8, 17, 1092900) It was hardly possible in the present state of societys civilisation for them to say that, however educated a man might be, however he may have advanced in civilisation in every way, he was to be excluded from political rights if his skin was not of the finest white.
('9', 476, 8, 18, 1093168) If they tried to make colour the test for political rights, they would find the greatest difficulty in drawing the line.
('9', 476, 8, 19, 1093289) They would find they were inflicting great hardship on many people, to all intents and purposes as civilised, educated, and as responsible citizens as themselves.
('9', 476, 8, 20, 1093452) It was difficult, then, to maintain the colour distinction as a bar to the franchise without inflicting very serious injustice and injury on many people.
('9', 476, 9, 21, 1093606) There was also the social side to this question.
('9', 476, 9, 22, 1093655) They ought to give to every man, whatever his colour might be, equal justice in the eyes of the law.
('9', 476, 9, 23, 1093756) They ought to give him a chance of improving his position.
('9', 476, 9, 24, 1093815) They ought not to look down on the ways in which he improved himself, however queer or awkward they may be.
('9', 476, 9, 25, 1093923) They could not benefit from his labour and refuse to give him every opportunity of raising
('9', 477, 0, 1, 1094014) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 477, 1, 2, 1094056) himself in the social scale.
('9', 477, 1, 3, 1094085) There was too much prejudice in this country against people on account of their colour.
('9', 477, 1, 4, 1094173) In applying the principle that the white man must be the predominant partner in this country, they must also allow the coloured man to live according to his rights, and make the best of what was in him, and not expect him to be a beast of burden and nothing else.
('9', 477, 2, 5, 1094437) They must give him every opportunity of living in a cleaner and better way.
('9', 477, 2, 6, 1094513) Many of the so called Locations found outside the towns in South Africa were a disgrace to civilisation.
('9', 477, 2, 7, 1094618) They could not expect the Native to be a decent citizen if they made him live in such hovels.
('9', 477, 2, 8, 1094712) When they complained that the he was a danger to society, they should remember, if they expected a man to live as a beast, he would be a beast, and, if they wanted him to be a man, they should treat him in a fitting way.
('9', 477, 2, 9, 1094933) They would not deter the Native from crime merely by savage punishment.
('9', 477, 2, 10, 1095005) Given the incentive to improve himself in social life in his own place, in that place they should respect him as a man.
('9', 477, 2, 11, 1095125) The question was a difficult one.
('9', 477, 2, 12, 1095159) Some people talked of segregation.
('9', 477, 2, 13, 1095194) That was impossible.
('9', 477, 2, 14, 1095215) Both people had to live side by side, and they had the white people in this country who were the trustees for the future of both races, and they had to think how they could live together for the common good of both.
('9', 477, 2, 15, 1095431) Indian Opinion, 19 9 1908
('9', 477, 3, 16, 1095457) APPENDIX X
('9', 477, 4, 17, 1095468) AFFIDAVITS REGARDING REPEAL OF REGISTRATION ACT
('9', 477, 5, 18, 1095516) (1) H. S. L. POLAKS AFFIDAVIT
('9', 477, 6, 19, 1095546) I, HENRY SALOMON LEON POLAK, of Johannesburg, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows:
('9', 477, 7, 20, 1095645) I am a British subject, born in England, and domiciled in the Transvaal, of which Colony I am registered Parliamentary Voter.
('9', 477, 7, 21, 1095771) I am an Attorney of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal.
('9', 477, 7, 22, 1095827) I am also Assistant Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal.
('9', 477, 7, 23, 1095918) In this latter capacity, I had occasion frequently, during the early part of the voluntary registration of the Asiatic communities that commenced on the 10th February last, immediately, after the compromise had been effected, to discuss the situation with Mr. Chamney, Registrar of Asiatics, who told me, within the Registration Office, that, of course, the Law would be repealed immediately parliament met, if the voluntary registration had been satisfactorily completed.
('9', 477, 7, 24, 1096391) I have a distinct recollection also, although I did not take special note at the time, of hearing Mr. Chamney make similar statements to several persons who were at the Registration Office at different times during this period.
('9', 477, 7, 25, 1096619) HENRY, S. L. POLAK
('9', 477, 8, 26, 1096638) Before me,
('9', 477, 9, 27, 1096649) Declared at Johannesburg, CHAS H. SMITH
('9', 477, 10, 28, 1096689) this 9th day of September, 1908 JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
('9', 478, 0, 1, 1096742) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 479
('9', 478, 1, 2, 1096783) (2) P. K. NAIDOOS AFFIDAVIT I, P. K. NAIDOO of Johannesburg, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows:
('9', 478, 2, 3, 1096897) On the day that Mr. Gandhi was assaulted in connection with the compromise, and a few hours after, I went over to the Registrars Office, in order to protest against Asiatic Law Amendment Act receipt forms being issued in connection with voluntary registration applications, and told him that Indians would not submit to the Act, and that they were undergoing voluntary registration because they were assured that, on their doing so, the Act itself would be repealed.
('9', 478, 2, 4, 1097364) Mr. Nadir Cama was present at the time, and Mr. Chamney emphatically assured us that, voluntary registration being gone through, the Act would certainly be repealed, and that the Asiatic Law Amendment Act forms had been issued only by mistake.
('9', 478, 2, 5, 1097608) In order further to impress us, the Registrar had other typewritten copies made, in which there was no mention of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('9', 478, 2, 6, 1097753) P. K. NAIDOO
('9', 478, 3, 7, 1097766) Before me,
('9', 478, 4, 8, 1097777) Declared at Johannesburg, J. RILL
('9', 478, 5, 9, 1097811) this 5th day of September, 1908 JUSTICE OF THE PEACE (3) N. CAMAS AFFIDAVIT I, NADIR CAMA, of Johannesburg, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows:
('9', 478, 6, 10, 1097972) I have read the affidavit of Mr. P. K. NAIDOO, of even date, and confirm the contents thereof.
('9', 478, 6, 11, 1098067) I was largely concerned with persuading the people to accept the compromise, and I had, besides the interview with Mr. Chamney in Mr. Naidoos presence, many other interviews with the Registrar of Asiatics, and the latter very often repeated the assurance that the Act would be repealed, in order to strengthen my hands and to pacify the people.
('9', 478, 6, 12, 1098412) NADIR CAMA
('9', 478, 7, 13, 1098423) Before me,
('9', 478, 8, 14, 1098434) Declared at Johannesburg, J. RILL
('9', 478, 9, 15, 1098468) this 5th day of September, 1908 JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
('9', 478, 10, 16, 1098521) (4) A. M. ANDREWS AFFIDAVIT
('9', 478, 11, 17, 1098549) I, A. M. ANDREWS of Johannesburg, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows:
('9', 478, 12, 18, 1098636) On the second or third day of the opening of the Von Brandis Square Office for voluntary registration, I entered the Office to make my application.
('9', 478, 12, 19, 1098784) Mr. Chamney asked me to give my thumb impression.
('9', 478, 12, 20, 1098834) This I declined to do, claiming exemption on the ground of educational qualifications, and also because I had some misgivings,
('9', 479, 0, 1, 1098961) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 479, 1, 2, 1099003) as, the previous day, I had seen receipts for voluntary registration applications issued on forms under the Asiatic Act.
('9', 479, 1, 3, 1099124) Mr. Chamney then pleaded with me, begging me to give the thumb print in order to enable the Government to have some means of identification.
('9', 479, 1, 4, 1099265) He informed me that the leaders had given their finger impressions, that this was merely an act of grace on the part of the Asiatics and had no connection whatsoever with the Act, that the issuing of the receipts under the Act was merely a clerical error, and that, on the completion of voluntary registration, that Act would be removed from the Statute book.
('9', 479, 1, 5, 1099625) Mr. Thambi Naidoo was also present at the time.
('9', 479, 1, 6, 1099673) A. M. ANDREWS
('9', 479, 2, 7, 1099687) Before me,
('9', 479, 3, 8, 1099698) Declared at Johannesburg, L. LIONEL GOLDSMID
('9', 479, 4, 9, 1099743) this 9th day of September, 1908 JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
('9', 479, 5, 10, 1099796) (5) THAMBI NAIDOOS AFFIDAVIT
('9', 479, 6, 11, 1099825) I, THAMBI NAIDOO, of Johannesburg, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows:
('9', 479, 7, 12, 1099913) I was one of the signatories to the letter addressed to the Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal in connection with the Asiatic Registration Act from the Johannesburg Gaol on the 29th January last.
('9', 479, 7, 13, 1100110) 1 When I sent the letter, I did so fully believing that, by Asiatics undergoing voluntary registration, the Act would be repealed.
('9', 479, 7, 14, 1100241) There was no definite mention made in the letter, in order to make the position of the Government as smooth as possible, but the intention, in stating that the Act be not applied to all those who volun tarily register and in making the clause applicable to those who might enter at any future time after the expiry of the period of three months fixed for the voluntary registration of those Asiatics who were resident in the Transvaal on the date of the compromise, was that, the Asiatics having honourably fulfilled their obligations, Act 2 of 1907 could be of no use to the Government and would, therefore, be naturally repealed.
('9', 479, 7, 15, 1100873) But the actual promise as to repeal of the Act was reserved for discussion at the interview between the Colonial Secretary and Mr. Gandhi, the first signatory to the said letter.
('9', 479, 7, 16, 1101052) Two days after the letter was sent to the Colonial Secretary, Mr. Gandhi was summoned to Pretoria.
('9', 479, 7, 17, 1101151) On his return from Pretoria, all the prisoners were dis charged, and a meeting of British Indians was addressed by him the same day in the afternoon, that is Friday, the 31st January.
('9', 479, 7, 18, 1101335) 2 At this meeting, Mr. Gandhi announced that General Smuts had promised to repeal the Act, if the Asiatics fulfilled their part of the compromise, namely, if the Asiatics made application for voluntary registration.
('9', 479, 8, 19, 1101551) Subsequently, when the compromise was in working order, and when Mr. Gandhi was assaulted, together with Mr. Essop Mia, I was also assaulted while
('9', 479, 9, 20, 1101698) 1 Vide Rhodesia and the Transvaal, 15 6 1907. 2 ibid
('9', 480, 0, 1, 1101751) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 481
('9', 480, 1, 2, 1101792) defending him from further injuries; and, in a bandaged condition, I attended the Registration Office and helped the authorities.
('9', 480, 1, 3, 1101922) The reason of the assault undoubtedly was suspicion, on the part of those who assualted, to the effect that Mr. Gandhi had not acted properly or that the Government would not carry out the promise of repeal, if such promise was given.
('9', 480, 1, 4, 1102157) Another reason for the assault was that the leaders had accepted the principle of registration by ten finger prints, which, among others, the Pathan section of the community resented most bitterly.
('9', 480, 1, 5, 1102355) The task of prevailing upon the people to take out voluntary registration, and of assuring the people that the compromise was fair, and that the Act would be repealed, fell upon the shoulders of myself and my co workers.
('9', 480, 2, 6, 1102576) In connection with this, I several times discussed the situation with Mr. Chamney, Registrar of Asiatics, and Mr. Chamney definitely stated to me that, on voluntary registration being undergone by the Asiatics, the Act would be repealed.
('9', 480, 2, 7, 1102814) Mr. Chamney, I am aware, even took to Mr. Gandhi a draft notice that was to be published in the Gazette in connection with the repeal.
('9', 480, 2, 8, 1102949) The assurance given to me was conveyed by me to my countrymen; and I am certain that, but for such an assurance, the community would never have accepted the compromise.
('9', 480, 2, 9, 1103118) C. K. THAMBI NAIDOO
('9', 480, 3, 10, 1103138) Before me,
('9', 480, 4, 11, 1103149) Declared at Johannesburg, A. S. C. BARTROP
('9', 480, 5, 12, 1103192) this 5th day of September, 1908 JUSTICE OF THE PEACE

('9', 483, 4, 7, 1108718) (4) EXTRACT FROM ROBERT SUTHERLANDS LETTER TO RAND DAILY MAIL.
('9', 483, 5, 8, 1108781) If President Kruger sent Mr. Gandhi and other high class educated British Indians in prison garb to break stones on the public roads of the late Republic for no better reason than they have been convicted; if he treated Indian women and children with the inhumanity which an eye witness states he saw done at one of our frontier towns, and forced Hindus and Mussulman political prisoners to eat fat or starve; if he put men born and bred on the plains of India in ice cold water on a winters morning in this, to them, rigorous climate, and made them go for a full hour in puris naturaubus, it would lead to an ultimatum from the British Government, which would put a stop to it in twenty four hours.
('9', 483, 5, 9, 1109481) Yet this British Colony of eighteen months old, which has scarcely shed its political swaddling clothes, does it with impunity .
('9', 483, 5, 10, 1109610) Mr. Gandhis crime which he is expiating by breaking stones on the streets of Volksrust in a dress ornamented with broad arrows is practically a protest against these odious laws.
('9', 483, 5, 11, 1109789) There are in India gentlemen who rank much higher than the Prime Minister of Nepal; who has lately been the honoured guest of England, and there are several who take precedence at the Court of St. James, of any in this country, yet to the highest the Transvaal laws offer the same insult.
('9', 483, 6, 12, 1110078) Mr. Gandhi, the convict of this countrys laws, comes of the same class as the Prime Minister of Nepal, and his father when he died held the same rank, being Prime Minister of one of the States of Western India.
('9', 483, 6, 13, 1110289) Mr. Gandhi himself is a man of high educational attainments, a barrister of the Inns of Court and a man of high moral character and exemplary life.
('9', 483, 6, 14, 1110437) He was born a Hindoo, but he has taken for his guidance what is best in all religions, including Christianity, the essence of which he has practised more strictly than the majority of nominal Christians.
('9', 483, 7, 15, 1110641) The Magistrate, when passing sentence, we are told, remarked that he was sorry to see a man who was an advocate of the Courts of this country in such a position, and, had he been in his private house instead of on the bench, he might, with equal appositeness, have added that he was ashamed of administering a law which compelled a highminded patriot to immolate himself in the interest and honour of his country and countrymen.
('9', 483, 7, 16, 1111070) Indian Opinion, 7 11 1908

('9', 484, 2, 3, 1111597) Indian Opinion, 21 11 1908 (6) R. M. SODHAS AFFIDAVIT 1
('9', 484, 3, 4, 1111653) I, Ratanshi Mulji Sodha, of Natal, presently of Johannesburg, do hereby solemnly and sincerely declare as follows:
('9', 484, 4, 5, 1111768) On the 14th day of October, Mr. Gandhi, a number of other Indians, and myself were sentenced to periods of imprisonment with hard labour at Volksrust.
('9', 484, 4, 6, 1111919) On the morning of the 15th Mr. Gandhi, I and 13 others, together with about 15 Natives,were taken out to work on the side of agricultural show ground close to the fence which divides the ground from the public road.
('9', 484, 4, 7, 1112135) Our work there was to dig and remove stones.
('9', 484, 4, 8, 1112180) We were quite close to the road, and anybody who passed could easily see us and here distinctly what was going on.
('9', 484, 4, 9, 1112295) A number of Europeans and Natives did pass by.
('9', 484, 4, 10, 1112342) The ground is within the Municipality of Volksrust, and the road is used by a number of people.
('9', 484, 4, 11, 1112438) The European warder who was in charge of the Indian prisoners kept on urging Mr. Gandhi to work harder and harder, though Mr. Gandhi was doing his best.
('9', 484, 4, 12, 1112591) All this might have been clearly heard by passers by.
('9', 484, 4, 13, 1112645) The exact words used were Come on, Gandhi; come on, Gandhi.
('9', 484, 4, 14, 1112705) Mr. Gandhi replied that he was doing his utmost, and was even trying to do more.
('9', 484, 4, 15, 1112786) The Warder kept urging Mr. Gandhi when he saw Mr. Gandhi stoop to pick up earth to rub on the palms of his hands, which were getting raw through blistering.
('9', 484, 4, 16, 1112943) When after nine hours almost continuous work, with a delay of one hour between 12 and 1, Mr. Gandhi returned to the gaol, he was so stiff with pain and fatigue that he could scarcely move.
('9', 484, 4, 17, 1113132) At 12 oclock on this day, one of the Indian prisoners who had fainted through over strain, heat and lack of water, which the Warder did not allow him to get, was taken in a sanitary cart to the gaol.
('9', 484, 4, 18, 1113332) Mr. Gandhi accompanied him in this cart.
('9', 484, 4, 19, 1113373) On the afternoon of that day, we were under the charge of a Native Warder, who also kept urging Mr. Gandhi to go on working, although he was doing his best.
('9', 484, 4, 20, 1113530) The words used were Come on, Gandhi; come on, Gandhi.
('9', 484, 4, 21, 1113584) Passers by could easily hear and see this.
('9', 484, 4, 22, 1113627) On the next day we were taken to a piece of ground near the road side, almost opposite Mr. Suliman Ahmed Cajees store.
('9', 484, 4, 23, 1113746) Mr. Cajee who was standing in front of the store, could easily see and hear whatever was going on.
('9', 484, 4, 24, 1113845) This, of course, would be from the opposite side of the road, but passers by could come quite close to us.
('9', 484, 4, 25, 1113952) We were digging holes for trees.
('9', 484, 4, 26, 1113985) and worked on this day as on the previous day, for nine hours.
('9', 484, 5, 27, 1114048) (Signed) R. M. SODHA

('9', 485, 1, 2, 1114350) (7) TRANSVAAL PRIME MINISTERS MINUTE [PRETORIA, January 30, 1909 ]
('9', 485, 2, 3, 1114417) Ministers have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of His Excellency the Gover nors Minute No.
('9', 485, 2, 4, 1114514) 15/1/08 of the 31st December last and His Excellency the Deputy Governors Minute No.
('9', 485, 2, 5, 1114599) 15/1/09 of the 14th instant covering respectively copies of despatches Nos.
('9', 485, 2, 6, 1114675) 424 and 451 from the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for the Colonies on the subject of the treatment of Mr. Gandhi while undergoing imprisonment.
('9', 485, 3, 7, 1114830) 2. Information is apparently required on two points, namely, Mr, Gandhis treatment in Volksrust and his journey from the Johannesburg railway station to the Gaol.
('9', 485, 4, 8, 1114993) 3. With regard to the first point, Ministers have the honour to confirm the telegram sent on the 3rd November last to the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for the Colonies in which it was stated that Mr. Gandhi, who always worked in the Indian gang of prisoners, was employed for two and half days in the Agricultural Show Ground at Volksrust digging holes for trees, and thereafter in the Municipal Plantation and Gaol Gardens.
('9', 485, 4, 9, 1115429) He never performed hard labour in public streets.
('9', 485, 4, 10, 1115479) Further enquiry also shows that Indian prisoners were treated with every consideration consistent with the Gaol Regulations.
('9', 485, 4, 11, 1115604) The work performed was of a very light nature and water was at no time refused when required.
('9', 485, 4, 12, 1115698) One of the prisoners fainted owing to the extreme heat and was conveyed back to the gaol in a scotch, or ordinary transport cart, and not in a, sanitary cart as is alleged.
('9', 485, 5, 13, 1115871) 4. As regards the second point, Ministers have the honour to state that Mr. Gandhi was returned from Volksrust to Johannesburg Prison in his Prison clothes as prescribed by the Regulations.
('9', 485, 5, 14, 1116061) During the journey from Volksrust, the Warder in charge offered Mr. Gandhi to procure a cab for him at Johannesburg station and repeated his offer on arrival at the station.
('9', 485, 5, 15, 1116235) Mr. Gandhi, however, elected to walk to the Prison and carried his kit in accordance with the Regulations.
('9', 485, 5, 16, 1116342) On arrival at the Prison, Mr. Gandhi was received by the Chief Warder and informed him that he had no complaint to make.
('9', 485, 5, 17, 1116463) He was seen the following day by the Governor of the Prison to whom he made the same statement.

('9', 485, 8, 20, 1116604) TREATMENT IN PRISON: (a) MARCHED IN CONVICTS GARB
('9', 485, 9, 21, 1116654) (1) EXTRACT FROM H. S. L. POLAKS LETTER TO THE PRESS ,OCTOBR 26, 1908
('9', 485, 10, 22, 1116724) Mr. Gandhi has been sentenced to two months hard labour for the offence of failing to give totally unnecessary finger prints for identification purposes.
('9', 485, 10, 23, 1116878) He has been set to work upon the public streets at Volksrust.
('9', 485, 10, 24, 1116940) Nobody complains about that.
('9', 486, 0, 1, 1116969) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 487
('9', 486, 1, 2, 1117010) It is part of the punishment to be borne by people whom General Smuts calls conscientious objectors.
('9', 486, 1, 3, 1117111) But is there any excuse for bringing Mr. Gandhi from Volksrust to Johannesburg in convict garb, as happened yesterday, and marching him from Park Station to the Fort publicly?
('9', 486, 1, 4, 1117287) Doubtless it was all part of the regulations.
('9', 486, 1, 5, 1117333) I believe that, when the Spanish Inquisition desired to degrade its victims, among whom were probably ancestors of mine, it clothed them in bag shaped yellow garb and marched them in this fashion through the streets prior to despatching them at the customary auto da fe.
('9', 486, 1, 6, 1117604) We, Transvaal Britishers, do not seem to have gone far beyond those mediaeval torturers in our desire to bring our victims to what, in our opinion, is a fitter frame of mind.
('9', 486, 1, 7, 1117779) Can you wonder that the Indian Community is getting more and more embittered and exasperated; and do you not marvel how, in spite of all these injuries and insults, they remain content to be passive resisters, suffering themselves rather than imposing suffering upon their European fellow colonists?
('9', 486, 1, 8, 1118079) Contrast the Christian example shown by these non Christian people with the Pagan cruelty of their Christian rulers.
('9', 486, 1, 9, 1118196) It makes one flush with shame to think of it all.
('9', 486, 2, 10, 1118246) Indin Opinion, 31 10 1908
('9', 486, 3, 11, 1118272) (2) A SHOCKING SIGHT 1
('9', 486, 4, 12, 1118295) On Sunday last, Mr. Gandhi was removed from Volksrust Gaol to the Fort, Johannesburg, he having been subpoenaed as a witness for the Crown in the case of Daya Lalla, who was charged with using a forged registration certificate, the case being now sent to the Criminal Sessions for trial.
('9', 486, 4, 13, 1118583) Mr. Gandhi was removed in convict dress, in charge of a warder, in whose company he travelled to Johannesburg.
('9', 486, 4, 14, 1118694) A few members of the Committee of the Association had got wind of the removal, and met the train upon its arrival at Park Station at six oclock in the evening.
('9', 486, 4, 15, 1118854) Mr. Gandhi, carrying his bundle of clothes in a large bag marked with the broad arrow, a basket of books, and, of course, wearing the convict suit, was then marched in custody from Park Station to the Fort.
('9', 486, 4, 16, 1119061) It was then broad daylight, and the streets were filled with onlookers, some of whom recognized Mr. Gandhi, even in the hideous disguise that he wore.
('9', 486, 4, 17, 1119212) Mr. Gandhi, of course, wore the convict garb of coloured prisoners, a particularly conspicuous one.
('9', 486, 4, 18, 1119312) Doubtless all this happened in terms of the regulations, but it is typical of the anti Asiatic policy of the Government that no instructions were issued that Mr. Gandhi should be transferred in civil dress, and taken to the Fort in a cab.
('9', 486, 4, 19, 1119551) So long as cultured Indian passive resisters and conscientious objectors are treated as though they were aboriginal native felons of the worst type, so long must this fight continue.

('9', 487, 3, 9, 1120371) He carried a large bundle and a basket of books.
('9', 487, 3, 10, 1120420) The train arrived at the scheduled time 6.0 p.m.
('9', 487, 3, 11, 1120469) It was then broad daylight.
('9', 487, 3, 12, 1120497) The sun did not set until a considerable time afterwards.
('9', 487, 3, 13, 1120555) Mr. Gandhi was marched through the public streets from the Station to the Johannes burg Gaol.
('9', 487, 3, 14, 1120649) This would take about twelve minutes.
('9', 487, 3, 15, 1120687) It would have been broad daylight all the time.
('9', 487, 3, 16, 1120735) I walked part of the way to the gaol at Mr. Gandhis side.
('9', 487, 3, 17, 1120793) I left Mr. Gandhi half way to the Gaol.
('9', 487, 3, 18, 1120833) I then walked back for about ten minutes to catch my tram, and thereafter went home.
('9', 487, 3, 19, 1120918) When I arrived home it was still daylight approaching dusk.

('9', 488, 1, 2, 1122061) months imprisonment with hard labour for failing to produce means of identification.

('9', 488, 3, 4, 1122247) Yesterday it was necessary that he should appear in some case in the Magistrates Court.

('9', 488, 4, 6, 1122431) Of course, there may be amongst us those who will be glad to hear that indignities are being heaped on this great Indian leader; but I venture to hope that the great majority of our colonies will feel ashamed and angry that a man of the character and position of Mr. Gandhi should be needlessly insulted in this way.

('9', 488, 8, 13, 1123613) It is that, policy of pin pricks applied to the Asiatics here, not by irresponsible persons, but by officials of the Government, which increases the irrita tion in India and renders a settlement of this difficult business well nigh impossible.

('9', 489, 3, 6, 1125074) While on the topic, we may express what we believe to be the general regret of the Natal public that certain Transvaal officials should have thought it necessary the other day to subject Mr. Gandhi to the indignity of handcuffing while being is the walked through the streets to give evidence in the Police Courts.

('9', 489, 4, 10, 1125910) Mr. OGrady asked the Under Secretary of State for the Colonies whether he was aware that Mr. Gandhi, the Transvaal Indian leader, who was undergoing three months hard labour under the Registration Laws, was, on March 10, marched from the Pretoria Gaol to the magistrates court, where his attendance was required as a witness, handcuffed; whether he would enquire if this indignity upon Mr. Gandhi was intentionally imposed by the authorities, or occurred by mistake; and whether representations would be made to the Transvaal Government to treat British Indians, who were going to goal for what they consider to be conscience sake, less severely than convicted criminals?

('9', 490, 5, 7, 1127356) MINUTE NO.
('9', 490, 6, 8, 1127367) Ministers have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of His Excellency the Deputy Governors Minute No.
('9', 490, 6, 9, 1127470) 15/1/09(2) of the 13th instant, covering copy of despatch No.
('9', 490, 6, 10, 1127532) 146 dated 24th April, from the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for the Colonies on the subject of the treatment of Mr. M. K. Gandhi while undergoing imprisonment.
('9', 490, 7, 11, 1127703) 2. In reply, Ministers have the honour to inform His Excellency that the statement that M. K. Gandhi was marched handcuffed from the Pretoria Gaol to the Pretoria Magistrates Court is correct.
('9', 490, 7, 12, 1127896) It is the universal rule to handcuff prisoners when so marchad and they are so marched when the prison van is not available, as happened in the case in point.
('9', 490, 7, 13, 1128055) The rule applies equally to European convicted prisoners and there was no reason therefore for exempting an Indian from its operation.
('9', 490, 7, 14, 1128190) Mr. Gandhi was however allowed to draw his sleeves over his handcuffs and to carry a book, which concealed the fact of his being handcuffed.
('9', 490, 7, 15, 1128331) LOUIS BOTHA

('9', 490, 9, 17, 1128376) APPENDIX XV
('9', 490, 10, 18, 1128388) COMMENTS BY RAND DAILY MAIL
('9', 490, 11, 19, 1128416) On the 21st instant, the Rand Daily Mail made the following editorial comments:
('9', 490, 12, 20, 1128496) Though the scheme of the Asiatics in the Transvaal for closing their stores is undoubtedly a clever one, it will hardly popularise their cause in this country.
('9', 490, 12, 21, 1128656) It simply means that the so called passive resistance has degenerated into coercion.
('9', 490, 12, 22, 1128741) There is no doubt that numbers of the Indians have been intimidated by their fellows, and are afraid to register or to take out trading licences; and now the scheme is to intimidate the European merchants and the Transvaal Government.
('9', 490, 12, 23, 1128976) We hope these methods commend themselves to Mr. Hosken and The Transvaal Leader and the other advocates of deliberate law breaking in this Colony.
('9', 490, 12, 24, 1129123) But in the case of the majority of the people we feel sure that these tactics will destroy the last shred of sympathy with the Asiatic cause.
('9', 490, 12, 25, 1129265) Anyway we are convinced the Transvaal
('9', 491, 0, 1, 1129303) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 491, 1, 2, 1129345) Government will not be bullied into making concessions by such methods, and we hope that the wholesale traders affected will not allow themselves to be made the tools of law breaking Indians.
('9', 491, 1, 3, 1129537) We do not think that many of the Asiatics will fall in with Mr. Gandhis little plan, and ruin themselves completely to further the cause of passive resistance when it assumes such a new and startling form.
('9', 491, 1, 4, 1129743) We believe that a firm attitude will quickly make the plot a failure.
('9', 491, 1, 5, 1129813) And in the meantime the Government should pay a little more attention to the picketing system which is intimidating so many of the law abiding Indians and preventing them fulfilling the letter of the law.

('9', 491, 5, 12, 1130430) J. J. DOKES LETTER DATED OCTOBER 7 TO RAND DAILY MAIL:
('9', 491, 6, 13, 1130485) In a sub leader on the above subject published in your issue of Tuesday, I notice that you hesitate to accept Mr. Polaks statement that a brutal assault had been made by a Kaffir on Mr. Gandhi, while the latter gentleman was imprisoned in Johannesburg Gaol.
('9', 491, 6, 14, 1130743) You say: It is not stated whether Mr. Gandhi complained to the prison authorities and had the Kaffir punished .
('9', 491, 6, 15, 1130855) and you add, in any case the attack does not seem to us to be one for which the Transvaal Government can be held responsible.
('9', 491, 7, 16, 1130981) It happens that I am able to supply part of the missing information.
('9', 491, 7, 17, 1131050) When I knew of the shameful assault, the details of which you naturally do not publish, I spoke of it personally to Mr. Roos, who expressed regret, and said that Mr. Gandhi had already told him of it.
('9', 491, 7, 18, 1131251) The Kaffir, I imagine, was not punished, as Mr. Gandhi would make it a point of conscience not to identify the man who had injured him.
('9', 491, 7, 19, 1131387) In similar circumstances, he refused to prosecute the Pathan by whom he had been assaulted.
('9', 491, 8, 20, 1131479) Regarding the responsibility of the Government, I fail to agree with you.
('9', 491, 8, 21, 1131553) It is perfectly true that the Government had nothing immediately to do with the assault, and that great regret was privately expressed, and I have no doubt was felt, that this had happened, but the Government is nevertheless responsible for the system under which it was possible.
('9', 491, 8, 22, 1131834) The fact is that passive resistance Indians have been classed as Natives and as criminals, and all attempts to get this altered, so far as I am aware, have failed.
('9', 491, 8, 23, 1131998) As a Native, Mr. Gandhi was locked up on one occasion in a cell with
('9', 492, 0, 1, 1132067) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 493
('9', 492, 1, 2, 1132108) Natives, and suffered a night of torture such as Mr. Polak describes.
('9', 492, 1, 3, 1132178) As a Native he was obliged to consort with Natives, and in that enforced contact the assault was committed.
('9', 492, 1, 4, 1132286) Efforts are made now and I believe successfully, to keep the Indians as much as possible to themselves.
('9', 492, 1, 5, 1132390) But so long as they are classed with Natives as criminals, and watched by Native warders, what happened to Mr. Gandhi in the Fort, to Nagappen at Yokeskei River Camp, and the others in different gaols may happen at any moment. Indian Opinion, 16 10 1909
('9', 492, 2, 6, 1132644) APPENDIX XVII
('9', 492, 3, 7, 1132658) EUROPEANS LETTER TO THE TIMES 1
('9', 492, 4, 8, 1132690) TO THE EDITOR THE TIMES LONDON
('9', 492, 6, 9, 1132721) The signatories of this letter are, most of them, South African Colonists of many years standing.
('9', 492, 6, 10, 1132819) One is a member of the Transvaal Legislative Assembly, others are clergymen of various Christian denominations, whilst others belong to one or other of the professions or are engaged in commercial pursuits.
('9', 492, 6, 11, 1133026) In addressing this letter to you, we are moved by feeling of concern regarding the present phases of what is known as the Transvaal Asiatic question.
('9', 492, 6, 12, 1133176) We frankly accept the position that the further immigration of Asiatics into this Colony shall be most stringently restricted.
('9', 492, 6, 13, 1133303) And the Asiatics themselves have publicly accepted that position.
('9', 492, 7, 14, 1133369) But recent events have shown us that the welfare of the Empire, which we have at heart, may be endangered unless a speedy termination of the present state of affairs can be effected.
('9', 492, 7, 15, 1133552) The Transvaal domiciled Indians to day in India are likely to be a grave source of danger to the Empire, since they will have left this Colony with a feeling of bitterness in their hearts at the remembrance of their harsh treatment by their European fellow subjects of the Crown, a feeling which they will not be slow to ventilate amidst the sympathetic surroundings of their native land.
('9', 492, 8, 16, 1133941) It has been, perhaps too easily, assumed that the public opinion of the white population of the Transvaal is unitedly opposed to the Asiatic claims.
('9', 492, 8, 17, 1134090) We believe, however, that, whilst the number of European sympathisers with the Asiatics who will openly express their views is not great, there is an important body of sympathisers in the European section of the community who are grieved and hurt at the treatment being meted out to the Asiatics for no apparent useful purpose.
('9', 492, 8, 18, 1134418) We have carefully examined the claims put forth by them, and we have had opportunities
('9', 492, 9, 19, 1134505) 1 This was dated Johannesburg, November, 1908 and reproduced in Indian Opinion, 6 2 1909.
('9', 493, 0, 1, 1134595) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 493, 1, 2, 1134637) of satisfying ourselves that they are legitimate and of such a degree of moderation as to be capable of being granted, without danger to the Colony.
('9', 493, 1, 3, 1134786) They are, in effect, two only.
('9', 493, 1, 4, 1134817) The first is that, at the next session of Parliament, the Government will introduce as a Government measure legislation repealing the obnoxious Asiatic Law Amendment Act, which the Colonial Secretary has declared to be unworkable.
('9', 493, 1, 5, 1135048) This law, which was passed unanimously by Parliament without consultation with the Asiatic leaders, and on the assumption that there was a considerable illicit influx of Asiatics into the Transvaal, has now been, for all practical purposes, replaced by the new Validation Act, which is generally acceptable to the Asiatics, and which removed the stigma under which they feel they labour so long as the old Act remains on the Statute book.
('9', 493, 1, 6, 1135487) In a speech delivered at Richmond, Johannesburg, on February 5 last, General Smuts is reported to have said:
('9', 493, 2, 7, 1135596) The character of that law was that it should come into force once, and should have its effect once, and once for all.
('9', 493, 2, 8, 1135714) It was a very risky law, because, if the Asiatics did not come forward during that period, registration became impossible, and the law became a dead letter.
('9', 493, 2, 9, 1135871) What happened?
('9', 493, 2, 10, 1135886) They were at a complete deadlock.
('9', 493, 2, 11, 1135920) That was the position into which they had drifted now.
('9', 493, 2, 12, 1135975) It was not by the fault of the Government, not by the fault of a party, because a law had been passed that required the co operation of the Indian population.
('9', 493, 2, 13, 1136134) They did not give the co operation; but they simply stood aside.
('9', 493, 3, 14, 1136199) Thus, besides being declared by the Colonial Secretary to be unworkable, the old Asiatic Act has also been superseded by more recent and generally unobjec tionable legislation, and is, consequently, no longer of any real value to anyone.
('9', 493, 3, 15, 1136437) The Asiatics have all along resented the imputations upon which the policy laid down in the old Act was based, and realise that so long as it remains their position is peri lous.
('9', 493, 3, 16, 1136616) Undoubtedly, in our opinion, they undertook voluntary registration in the belief that the Act would be repealed, and they feel that their straightforward action in carrying out their voluntary obligations has not been reciprocated.
('9', 493, 4, 17, 1136848) The second point is that the Asiatics request the recognition of the right of educated Indians to enter the Colony under the restrictions of the general Immigration Law of the Colony.
('9', 493, 4, 18, 1137032) It is admitted that the Immigration Act alone does not exclude educated Asiatics from entry into the Transvaal.
('9', 493, 4, 19, 1137144) On their side, the Asiatics are willing to allow the Government, by administrative methods, to restrict such immigration by raising the education test for Asiatic immigrants so as to make it impossible for others than professional men and university graduates to enter the Colony, and they have further publicly consented that the Government may administratively limit the number of these to six per annum.
('9', 493, 4, 20, 1137551) They urge, and we are at one with them in this, that the provision of temporary permits, renewable from time to time, is un British and unsuited to their needs, for those to whom these permits would be granted would be allowed to enter the Colony as an act of grace and not as a matter of right, that they would be prohibited immigrants with the penalties suspended, and they would, consequently, be unable efficiently to practise their professions.
('9', 493, 4, 21, 1138001) We feel that the unhampered admission of this small number of cultured
('9', 494, 0, 1, 1138072) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 495
('9', 494, 1, 2, 1138113) Asiatics is a necessity to the welfare of the Asiatics themselves, and even more important to the European population.
('9', 494, 1, 3, 1138232) Without the means of communal development, the Asiatics must, in course of time, become a source of danger to the white Colonists, for, in the absence of their natural leaders, they would sink to a depth of degradation which we cannot contemplate with equanimity.
('9', 494, 2, 4, 1138496) It is to secure these two pointsall else being a matter of detail onlyand easily capable of adjustmentthat the Asiatics are prosecuting a resolute policy of passive resistance.
('9', 494, 2, 5, 1138673) They are the greatest sufferers by their acts, and, as they are an unrepresented and otherwise voiceless minority, whose views have been on almost every occasion ignored by the Legislature, it is difficult to discover any other course open to them, to secure redress of their grievances than that which they have adopted.
('9', 494, 3, 6, 1138995) It has been suggested that the hardships of the present struggle, that the Asiatics have so vehemently protested against, are largely fictitious.
('9', 494, 3, 7, 1139141) We are unable to subscribe to that opinion.
('9', 494, 3, 8, 1139185) We consider that the Asiatics complaints are, on the whole, justified.
('9', 494, 3, 9, 1139256) There has been an enormous amount of hardship and suffering inflicted as the result of this unfortunate misunderstanding.
('9', 494, 3, 10, 1139378) Since the new phase of the struggle commenced, some four months ago, nearly 900 sentences of imprison ment with hard labour have been imposed upon men whom General Smuts himself has called conscientious objectors.
('9', 494, 3, 11, 1139592) They have been treated in gaol no better than aboriginal native felons, and the prison diet has been entirely unsuited to their national habits.
('9', 494, 3, 12, 1139737) Indeed, in some gaols, the food has been religiously unclean, and, as a result, many of the Asiatic prisoners have been half starved.
('9', 494, 3, 13, 1139871) There can be no doubt, too, of the immense financial loss that has befallen the Asiatic communities since the struggle first commenced, over two years ago, both by way of actual expenditure, and business loss due to restriction of trade.
('9', 494, 3, 14, 1140109) The mental anxiety of the Asiatic population, too, induced by the present unsettlement, has been intense, and this has reacted upon all sections of the population.
('9', 494, 4, 15, 1140273) For ourselves, we are satisfied, from personal observation, of the earnestness and determination of the Asiatics in the prosecution of their struggle for what they believe is justly due to them.
('9', 494, 4, 16, 1140468) They have shown a degree of courage and self sacrifice, and an honourable intention to abide by their obligations, that have evoked admiration.
('9', 494, 4, 17, 1140612) Many of their leaders, who are to day in gaol for the sake of their compatriots, are cultured men who would be an honour to any community.
('9', 494, 4, 18, 1140751) They include professional men, wealthy merchants, priests and well known traders.
('9', 494, 4, 19, 1140833) Those who are to day in gaol include representatives of all sections of the Asiatic commu nities, from the hawker to the wholesale merchant, from the clerk to the professional man.
('9', 494, 4, 20, 1141014) All faiths and castes are represented, and the Asiatics have shown a unanimity that is as praiseworthy as it was unexpected.
('9', 494, 4, 21, 1141139) We feel that the prolongation of this struggle must have a most unfavourable effect upon the trade and commerce of this country, adding unnecessarily to the many difficulties with which it is faced in its efforts to achieve nationhood.
('9', 494, 5, 22, 1141375) In these circumstances, we trust that a settlement on the lines above indicated will be sought by the Transvaal Government.
('9', 494, 5, 23, 1141499) In our opinion, there is nothing in the
('9', 495, 0, 1, 1141539) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 495, 1, 2, 1141581) Asiatic demands that cannot safely be conceded.
('9', 495, 1, 3, 1141629) These is a grave danger lest the British public be misled as to the real nature of the struggle now proceeding.
('9', 495, 1, 4, 1141741) It appears to us that it would be wise and prudent if, in future, legislation concerning the unrepresented sections of the people were not passed without previous consultation with their leaders.
('9', 495, 1, 5, 1141937) We wish it distinctly to be understood that we are in the fullest sympathy with all efforts of the Government to equalise conditions of European and Asiatic competition.
('9', 495, 1, 6, 1142107) To this end, it may be wise not only to apply existing municipal, sanitary, and other standards strictly, but even to raise such standards.
('9', 495, 1, 7, 1142247) But we respectfully submit that nothing could react more injuriously upon the European race than to deprive the Asiatics of all opportunity for development, and thus to diminish their wants instead of increasing them.
('9', 495, 1, 8, 1142465) We are, etc.,
