('9', 495, 7, 14, 1142572) LORD CURZONS LETTER TO GANDHIJI GROOTE SCHUUR, RONDEBOSCH, February 2, 1909
('9', 495, 8, 15, 1142648) DEAR SIR,
('9', 495, 9, 16, 1142658) I am extremely sorry that owing to an alteration in my plans caused by illness, I was in Johannesburg for so short a time as to be unable to meet your Committee in person and discuss with them the circumstances of the case.
('9', 495, 10, 17, 1142882) As it was, I endeavoured to make myself acquainted with both sides of it by personal enquiries and by a study of the papers with which I was provided by the courtesy of yourself and of others.
('9', 495, 11, 18, 1143075) Upon my arrival here, H. E. Lord Selborne had arranged to meet me with General Botha and Mr. Smuts; and we had a prolonged and friendly conversation about the matter, in which every aspect of it was passed under review.
('9', 495, 12, 19, 1143295) I had of course no authority to act upon your behalf.
('9', 495, 12, 20, 1143349) But my connection with India and the earlier history of the case, perhaps, gave me some title to express an opinion.
('9', 495, 13, 21, 1143466) My own impression, in entering upon the discussion, was that it should not be impossible to find some solution of the present difficulty which should be equally honourable to all parties; and I received repeated assurances from General Botha and Mr. Smuts of their anxiety ot treat the British Indians in the Transvaal in a spirit of
('9', 496, 0, 1, 1143800) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 497
('9', 496, 1, 2, 1143841) liberality as well as justice.
('9', 496, 2, 3, 1143872) How far it would have been possible, had I remained longer in the country, and been able to communicate personally with the principal parties concernedto effect any settlement, it would be useless now to conjecture.
('9', 496, 3, 4, 1144088) The main obstacle to such an arrangement at the moment appeared to be that, if the anticipations as to the formation of a single Government for South Africa are realisedas everyone hopes will be the casethe question will shortly be taken up again by a more powerful authority than the Government of any one State, and settled on wider grounds than those which affect the position of the Indians in the Transvaal alone.
('9', 496, 4, 5, 1144507) As soon as unification is carried [out] in this country, there must be communications between the joint Government of South Africa and the Home Govt.
('9', 496, 4, 6, 1144657) on this as on other matters; and I should hope personally that these communi cationswhich ought not now to be long delayedmay be made the occasion for a final and satisfactory settlement of this vexed problem.
('9', 496, 5, 7, 1144867) If either then or at any other time, I can be of service to the Indian community in S. Africa, I shall be very happy.
('9', 496, 6, 8, 1144985) Dear Sir,

('9', 497, 14, 22, 1147531) LORD AMPTHILLS LETTER TO GANDHIJI CONFIDENTIAL MILTON ERNEST HALL, BEDFORD, August 3, 1909
('9', 497, 15, 23, 1147622) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('9', 497, 16, 24, 1147639) I take the opportunity afforded by an interval in the House of Lords to write you a few lines.
('9', 497, 16, 25, 1147734) In the first place, let me thank you for your letter of the 29th July and for the copy of your Concise Statement, which you sent to me so promptly.
('9', 497, 16, 26, 1147882) I am also much obliged to you for the several telegrams in which you intimated that you would be guided by me for the present.
('9', 497, 16, 27, 1148009) I am afraid that it must seem to you that I am losing time but this is really not the case.
('9', 497, 16, 28, 1148101) The authorities are, of course, tremendously busy over the South Africa Bill and Imperial Defence, not to mention
('9', 498, 0, 1, 1148215) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 499
('9', 498, 1, 2, 1148256) convenience.
('9', 498, 1, 3, 1148269) Meanwhile, I am putting in a touch here and there by letter or by word of mouth wherever I see an opportunity.
('9', 498, 1, 4, 1148380) Now as regards your letter of the 29th: There is only one point on which I should be glad of a little further explanation, for the rest was quite clear and explicit.
('9', 498, 1, 5, 1148546) You tell me unequivocally that you receive no financial support from sedition mongers in India but you do not answer my question (I think I put it) whether they are co operating with you or advising you in any other way.
('9', 498, 1, 6, 1148767) I should like to be able to give a positive denial to that charge, which I do not myself believe, and to say that the continuance of your Passive Resistance is absolutely independent of anything that is being said or done in India.
('9', 498, 1, 7, 1148999) The contrary is alleged against you and I am naturally anxious to be able to repudiate the charge with proofs more effective than my own personal belief.
('9', 498, 1, 8, 1149153) You marked the Statment as an unrevised proof and so I am encouraged to make a few suggestions.
('9', 498, 1, 9, 1149249) PARA 15: With reference to the first two sentences, I suggest that you should add as an appendix Mr. Ritchs comparative statement of the position now and before the War.
('9', 498, 1, 10, 1149419) There ought to be some brief explanation of the effect of Law 3 of 1885. PARA 17: Before the last sentence but one I would suggest a little amplification.
('9', 498, 1, 11, 1149574) It would be appropriate to explain that the five finger method of identification, which in India is confined to criminals, was deliberately adopted although Sir E. Henrys report stated that thumb impressions only were sufficient.
('9', 498, 1, 12, 1149804) PARA 20: It seems to me advisable to explain exactly how the total prohibition was brought about by reading the Asiatic Law and Immigration Law together.
('9', 498, 1, 13, 1149958) PARA 21: Surely Act 2 of 1907 should be substituted for Act 1908.
('9', 498, 1, 14, 1150024) PARA 22: The terms of the compromise should be set forth.
('9', 498, 1, 15, 1150082) After this paragraph a little connecting narrative seems to be wanting.
('9', 498, 1, 16, 1150154) You want to tell how the Indians found that the compromise was not what they honestly believed it would be.
('9', 498, 1, 17, 1150262) PARA 25: This might be re drafted so as to show that it was not the fault of the Indians that repeal fell through.
('9', 498, 1, 18, 1150377) It would also be desirable to explain in what respect General Smuts went back even upon the written and manifest terms of the compromise.
('9', 498, 1, 19, 1150515) PARA 26: does not explain sufficiently clearly why the Indians burned their certificates.
('9', 498, 1, 20, 1150605) It should be remembered that this Statement, if it is used at all, will be for the instruction of persons who know nothing at all about this question.
('9', 498, 1, 21, 1150756) PARA 29: I suggest that the petition referred to should be printed as an appendix.
('9', 498, 1, 22, 1150839) PARA 30: (1) Is not 1908 again a misprint for 1907?
('9', 498, 1, 23, 1150891) For the rest I think that you have wonderfully compressed the long story and brought out all the essential points.
('9', 498, 1, 24, 1151006) I hope that you will not mind my offering these few suggestions, for it seems to me that I am necessarily in a better position to appreciate what information is required by people in this country than you to whom the whole circumstances are so familiar.

('9', 499, 1, 2, 1151391) APPENDIX XXI
('9', 499, 2, 3, 1151404) TRANSVAAL INDIANS PETITIONS
('9', 499, 3, 4, 1151432) (1) PETITION TO THE QUEEN 1
('9', 499, 4, 5, 1151460) THE QUEENS MOST EXCELLENT MAJESTY
('9', 499, 6, 6, 1151494) THE PETITION OF THE WIVES, THE MOTHERS, OR THE DAUGHTERS OF BRITISH
('9', 499, 7, 7, 1151562) INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL WHO HAVE PASSED THROUGH THE TRANSVAAL
('9', 499, 8, 8, 1151625) GAOLS DURING THE PAST TWO YEARS FOR CONSCIENCES SAKE
('9', 499, 9, 9, 1151678) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT:
('9', 499, 10, 10, 1151699) Your Petitioners are the wives, mothers or daughters of British Indians who have suffered or still are suffering imprisonment in the Transvaal in connection with the Asiatic struggle that has been unfortunately going on in the Transvaal.
('9', 499, 11, 11, 1151937) Your Petitioners believe the struggle on the part of the British Indians to be righteous and for the honour of their race.
('9', 499, 12, 12, 1152060) Your Petitioners are further aware that those Indians who have been continually courting imprisonment are bound by a solemn oath not to submit to the Asiatic Act of the Transvaal Parliament until the grievances which have dictated the oath are redressed.
('9', 499, 13, 13, 1152315) Your Petitioners have felt bound to encourge their sons, husbands or fathers, as the case may be, in observing their obligation.
('9', 499, 14, 14, 1152444) Owing to the above, Your Petitioners have in many cases been obliged to suffer not only the pangs of separation but [also] privation.
('9', 499, 14, 15, 1152578) Many Indian families have been reduced to poverty during the struggle.
('9', 499, 15, 16, 1152649) Your Petitioners are aware that, under the British Constitution, Your Majesty cannot directly intervene on behalf of the sufferers.
('9', 499, 15, 17, 1152781) But Your Petitioners respectfully lay their case before Your Gracious Majesty in the hope that it may be possible for Your Majesty to use your influence unofficially, as mother or wife feeling for mothers or wives, and help to end a situation that has become most acute.
('9', 499, 16, 18, 1153052) The points required by the sufferers are the repeal of a law which is no longer required by the Government and the removal of a racial bar in the immigration law of the Colony, so that it may be possible for the most highly educated Indians to enter the Colony on the same terms as any other immigrants.
('9', 499, 17, 19, 1153356) Your Petitioners respectfully hope that their humble prayer will be taken into
('9', 499, 18, 20, 1153435) 1 There is no evidence that this and the following two petitions were drafted by Gandhiji, but it is not unlikely that he had initiated the move to present them.
('9', 499, 18, 21, 1153597) They were ready for circulation, to secure signatures, before he left for England, and were published in Indian opinion with the remark that they were being extensively signed in the Transvaal.

('9', 500, 1, 2, 1153832) consideration by Your Gracious Majesty.
('9', 500, 2, 3, 1153872) And for this act of justice and mercy, Your Petitioners shall for ever pray, etc.
('9', 500, 2, 4, 1153954) Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909
('9', 500, 3, 5, 1153979) (2) PETITION TO DADABHAI NAOROJI
('9', 500, 5, 6, 1154012) THE HONBLE DADABHAI NAOROJI
('9', 500, 7, 7, 1154040) We, the undersigned, British Indians residing in the Transvaal hereby approach you as the father of the Indian nation that is to be, with reference to the gigantic struggle in which we are engaged in this Colony.
('9', 500, 7, 8, 1154253) Through you we appeal to the whole of India.
('9', 500, 8, 9, 1154298) We will not go into the history of the struggle, but will state the question as it stand today.
('9', 500, 9, 10, 1154394) The Indian inhabitants of the Transvaal have asked for repeal of the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907, so that Indians possessing educational attainments, be they ever so few, even six per year, may enter the Transvaal on the same terms as the other immigrants.
('9', 500, 9, 11, 1154656) To day, by reason of the Registration Act read together with the Immigration Act of the Colony, no British Indian can immigrate into the Colony unless he has been previously domiciled.
('9', 500, 9, 12, 1154841) The laws of the Colony, therefore constitute a colour bar.
('9', 500, 9, 13, 1154900) No other British Colony possesses such legislation.
('9', 500, 9, 14, 1154952) Indians have, therefore, publicly entered into a solemn covenant not to submit to the Registration Acts of the Colony but to suffer imprisonment and other hardships until the national insult is removed.
('9', 500, 10, 15, 1155155) Under the covenant, during the past two years and six months, over 2,500 Indians have suffered imprisonment mostly with hard labour.
('9', 500, 10, 16, 1155288) Many homes have been broken up, many families have been ruined, in the struggle.
('9', 500, 10, 17, 1155369) Fathers and sons have gone to goal at the same time, leaving behind them weeping wives and mothers.
('9', 500, 10, 18, 1155469) Many families are being supported from charitable funds raised by us.
('9', 500, 10, 19, 1155539) At the present moment, nearly two hundred Indians are suffering imprisonment for conscience sake.
('9', 500, 11, 20, 1155637) The hardship felt has been so great that many have succumbed owing to sheer exhaustion.
('9', 500, 11, 21, 1155725) Others have left the Colony and are probably today starving.
('9', 500, 11, 22, 1155786) A resolute band of over 300 continues an active struggle.
('9', 500, 11, 23, 1155844) Some have passed through the Transvaal goals five times.
('9', 500, 12, 24, 1155901) The covenanters are derived from all classes and strata of Indian society.
('9', 500, 12, 25, 1155976) Hindus, Mahomedans, Parsees, Sikhs and Christians are all fighting Indias battle.
('9', 500, 12, 26, 1156058) Merchants who have never undergone physical exertion and have been brought up in the lap of luxury are breaking stones, or doing scavengers work, or wheeling barrows of earth and living on coarse mealie meal and boiled potatoes or rice and ghee.
('9', 500, 13, 27, 1156304) We ask India to come to the rescue and demand from the Indian Government a removal of the bar sinister.
('9', 500, 13, 28, 1156408) Until the racial taint from the Transvaal legislation is
('9', 501, 0, 1, 1156465) 502 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 501, 1, 2, 1156507) removed, the little band of Indians referred to above will suffer unto death.
('9', 501, 1, 3, 1156585) We pray for relief.
('9', 501, 1, 4, 1156605) Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909 (3) PETITION TO BENGAL CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
('9', 501, 2, 5, 1156673) TO THE PRESIDENT OF THE BENGAL CHAMBER OF COMMERCE CALCUTTA
('9', 501, 4, 6, 1156733) We, the undersigned, British Indians residing in the Transvaal, beg to approach you as the leader of Anglo India.
('9', 501, 4, 7, 1156847) We approach you regarding the Asiatic struggle that has now been going on in this Colony for the past two years and a half.
('9', 501, 5, 8, 1156971) We do not desire to trouble you with the history of the question.
('9', 501, 5, 9, 1157037) The point of dispute between the local Government and the British Indians is whether, as regard immigration, the laws of the Colony are to contain a racial disqualification.
('9', 501, 5, 10, 1157211) The local Parliament has passed two laws one called the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907, and the other the Immigration Act of the same yearwhereby a British Indian, no matter what his educational attainments may be, becomes upon entering the Colony, unless previously domiciled, a prohibited immigrant by reason of his Indian birth or extraction.
('9', 501, 5, 11, 1157559) This legislation is without parallel in British Colonies.
('9', 501, 5, 12, 1157617) We have, therefore, after other efforts had become vain, publicly entered into a solemn covenant not to submit to the Registration Law above named and another passed in the year 1908, whilst the struggle was yet going on, until the Registration Act of 1907 is repealed so as to remove the racial taint.
('9', 501, 6, 13, 1157920) By reason of the covenant, over 2,500 Indians, respresenting all races, classes, and religions, have undergone imprisonment.
('9', 501, 6, 14, 1158045) Many Indians domiciled in the Transvaal or in some other South African Colony have been, by arrangement with the Portuguese administration at the Province of Mozambique, deported direct to India, at a moments notice, in some cases leaving families and businesses behind uncared for and unattended.
('9', 501, 6, 15, 1158343) Many homes have been ruined.
('9', 501, 6, 16, 1158372) Many merchants have been reduced to poverty.
('9', 501, 6, 17, 1158417) Many families are being supported out of charitable funds collected by the Indian community.
('9', 501, 7, 18, 1158510) We do not desire unrestricted Indian immigration into the Colony.
('9', 501, 7, 19, 1158576) We accept the principle of white predominance in this sub continent.
('9', 501, 7, 20, 1158645) All we claim is that the Transvaal cannot, unlike the other Colonies, impose a racial test and thus, in the words of Mr. Chamberlain, wound the susceptibilities of Indias millions.
('9', 501, 8, 21, 1158826) We have appealed to all partiesall British subjects.
('9', 501, 8, 22, 1158879) And we have received support from all of them.
('9', 501, 8, 23, 1158926) Even in the Transvaal, a small European Committee, composed of prominent members of the community, under the Chairmanship of Mr. Wm.
('9', 501, 8, 24, 1159059) Hosken, M.L.A., has been supporting us.
('9', 501, 9, 25, 1159099) The honour of India, we doubt not, is as dear to Anglo Indians as it must be to Indians.
('9', 501, 9, 26, 1159188) Through you, therefore, we ask the whole of Anglo India to help us, in any
('9', 502, 0, 1, 1159263) VOL. 9: 23 JULY, 1908 4 AUGUST, 1909 503
('9', 502, 1, 2, 1159304) manner you may consider best, to end the unfortunate situation.
('9', 502, 2, 3, 1159368) Owing to the almost unbearable severity of the struggle, many have succumbed.
('9', 502, 2, 4, 1159446) But the heroic band still continues to court imprisonment again and again.
('9', 502, 2, 5, 1159521) They are determined to fight unto death.
('9', 502, 2, 6, 1159562) The Transvaal gaols contain, at the time of addressing this appeal, nearly 200 Indian conscientious objectors.
('9', 502, 2, 7, 1159673) The Government have, for the purpose evidently of gagging us, arrested five such objectors, who were chosen as delegates to proceed to India and England.
('9', 502, 2, 8, 1159827) We pray for relief.
('9', 502, 2, 9, 1159847) Indian Opinion, 3 7 1909
('9', 502, 3, 10, 1159872) APPENDIX XXII
('9', 502, 4, 11, 1159886) LORD AMPTHILLS LETTER TO GANDHIJI CONFIDENTIAL July 29, 1909
('9', 502, 5, 12, 1159947) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('9', 502, 6, 13, 1159964) I have just returned home to find your letter of yesterday.
('9', 502, 6, 14, 1160024) I write hastily to reply in the midst of a local tamasha.
('9', 502, 7, 15, 1160082) Nothing would be more unfortunate than that Sir Mancherjee and I should be at cross purposes and that must be avoided at all costs.
('9', 502, 8, 16, 1160214) I cannot insist, as you tell me that Sir Mancherjee does; I can only advise.
('9', 502, 8, 17, 1160291) It is for you to choose between his advice and mine.
('9', 502, 9, 18, 1160344) Your choice lies between the diplomatic and the political method.
('9', 502, 10, 19, 1160410) If you choose the former, then you must leave the conduct of the business entirely to me just as the Cabinet leave their diplomacy entirely to Sir Edward Seely.
('9', 502, 10, 20, 1160571) Diplomacy is only possible through individual agency and by private action.
('9', 502, 10, 21, 1160647) If, however, you choose the political method, then I will stand aside altogether so as to leave Sir Mancherjee a free hand.
('9', 502, 10, 22, 1160771) I could not take part in a course of action which seems to me inappropriate and erroneous at the present juncture.
('9', 502, 10, 23, 1160886) As the result of the past ten dayss work, I am in touch with Lord Crewe, Lord Morley, Lord Lansdowne and Lord Curzon on the one side and with Lord Selborne, General Smuts and Sir George Farrar on the other.
('9', 502, 10, 24, 1161093) I am to have a discussion with General Smuts next week, probably on Wednesday.
('9', 502, 10, 25, 1161172) All those I have named are open to a settlement.
('9', 502, 10, 26, 1161221) My advice to you is that you should leave matters to me for the present seeing how far I have already gone, and that, if my negotiations should fail, you should then try Sir Mancherjees suggested course of action.
('9', 502, 10, 27, 1161435) Please let me know as soon as possible what you decide.
('9', 502, 11, 28, 1161491) Yours very faithfully,
('9', 502, 12, 29, 1161514) AMPTHILL
('9', 502, 13, 30, 1161523) From a photostat of the handwritten original: S. N. 4967
('9', 503, 0, 1, 1161580) 504 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('9', 503, 1, 2, 1161622) APPENDIX XXIII
('9', 503, 2, 3, 1161637) LORD AMPTHILLS LETTER TO GANDHIJI
('9', 503, 3, 4, 1161671) CONFIDENTIAL
('9', 503, 4, 5, 1161684) July 28, 1909
('9', 503, 5, 6, 1161698) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('9', 503, 6, 7, 1161715) I am away from home and have only just received your letter of the 26th inst.
('9', 503, 6, 8, 1161793) I must reply hastily as it is past midnight and I am at the end of a long and tiring day, but as I am off again early tomorrow morning I shall lose much time if I do not write to you now.
('9', 503, 6, 9, 1161981) I have not been idle since I last wrote to you.
('9', 503, 6, 10, 1162029) I have had long talks with Lord Selborne, Lord Crewe, Sir George Farrar and I have also approached Lord Morley, General Smuts and others.
('9', 503, 6, 11, 1162167) Lord Curzon is working with me.
('9', 503, 7, 12, 1162199) There is no fixed disinclination for a settlement on the part of any of the above mentioned, but there is nothing to be gained by unduly pressing them or by any loud public action.
('9', 503, 7, 13, 1162380) Private negotiation is the only possible means.
('9', 503, 8, 14, 1162428) In reply to your question, please let me see your statement and then I shall be better able to suggest what you should do with it.
('9', 503, 8, 15, 1162559) But I beg you not to publish or circulate anything without first consulting me.
('9', 503, 8, 16, 1162639) It would be fatal if any of the responsible statesmen were offended or put out at the present juncture.
('9', 503, 8, 17, 1162743) I may be too sanguine, but I really hope that they will agree upon a settlement if they are allowed to do so of their own accord.
('9', 503, 8, 18, 1162873) Now, I want an answer from you to this question:
('9', 503, 9, 19, 1162922) If the Act of 1907 is repealed and if a promise is given that six Indians will be admitted to the Transvaal annually in the way you have proposed, will you be contented?
('9', 503, 9, 20, 1163092) Will that finally remove the sense of injustice and indignity under which the Indian community in the Transvaal is suffering?
('9', 503, 10, 21, 1163218) Please let me know explicitly what I can say on this point, for the objection which I have to meet is the assertion that the Indians will never be contented, and that any concession will lead to fresh demands.
('9', 503, 11, 22, 1163428) There is also much prejudice in high quarters on account of a belief that Passive Resistance in the Transvaal is being fomented and financed by the party of sedition in India who do not desire that the question should be settled.
('9', 503, 11, 23, 1163658) Please tell me how I am to meet this charge.
('9', 503, 12, 24, 1163703) You may of course show this letter to your colleague and I should be obliged if you would show it to Mr. Ritch, as I have not time to write it all to him, but please do not show it to anyone else.
('9', 503, 12, 25, 1163900) Yours very faithfully,
('9', 503, 13, 26, 1163923) AMPTHILL
('9', 503, 14, 27, 1163932) From a photostat of the handwritten original: S. N. 4965
